dialogue:
Judge: "If you're making $180,000 a year, why aren't your children on any type of health insurance?"
Defendant: "Well, the profession that I have, you know, there's no insurance offered."
Judge: "And, well, it doesn't have to be. You're considered an independent contractor."
Defendant: "Right, right."
Judge: "That means you can get private health insurance."
Defendant: "I wasn't really—I'm not really sure how to go about doing that."
Judge: "Um, you can Google."

Judge: All parties raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket, the plaintiff is suing the father of her grandchildren, claiming that he trashed the car that he borrowed. The defendant says this all has to do with a fight he had with the plaintiff’s daughter. It’s the case of "Stop Riding Me So Hard." Thank you, Douglas. Wendy Graves, hi. You are suing Vincent Brown, the father of your grandchildren, for $1,427.36 that you feel he owes you in order to repair a car that you had loaned to him and he returned in poor condition. Tell me what’s going on.

Plaintiff: In October of last year, Vincent came to me and asked if he could use my second car, which is the Honda Civic.

Judge: How long had he been with your daughter?

Plaintiff: Over 12 years.

Judge: And they have how many children?

Plaintiff: Two.

Judge: Okay, how old are the children?

Plaintiff: 10 and four.

Judge: All right. Now, you had been incarcerated, correct?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: For how long?

Plaintiff: Almost two years, 18 months.

Judge: What were the charges?

Plaintiff: Just say it. Gas stealing.

Judge: What?

Plaintiff: Stealing fuel.

Judge: You don’t get two years for stealing fuel.

Plaintiff: You get more than that, to be honest. And also, we had our own little issues—domestic, drugs.

Judge: Okay. Federal charge. I knew it was a little more than gas. Okay, come on up. Did you guys break up when he went in?

Plaintiff’s Daughter: We broke up the day he went in.

Judge: Okay. But he’s coming out. Are you renewing?

Plaintiff’s Daughter: No.

Judge: No. You just wanted to help him out because he could then get a job. And if he gets a job, what?

Plaintiff: Then he wouldn’t have to ask me for a ride back and forth.

Judge: And because he could just say no to that. But then he could pay child support, right?

Plaintiff: Right. So my daughter asked me if I would lend the car to him, and in turn, I would get some fees for that.

Judge: Right. A little money. Because he was going to pay how much for the car?

Plaintiff: The first couple of weeks, he was paying like $65. I was only expecting $60.

Judge: All right, and then he started paying $60, right?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Did you actually put this in writing?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: I love that. And why did you put it in writing?

Plaintiff: Because I watch you.

Judge: I’m sorry, I couldn’t hear you.

Plaintiff: Because I watch you all the time.

Judge: I’m sorry, I couldn’t hear you.

Plaintiff: Because I love you.

Judge: Let me see the contract. I’m sure you watch me too, right?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Listen to me, I am huge in prison. Go ahead. "Vincent Brown will be using a Honda LS Civic 2002 belonging to Wendy Graves and will be responsible for any incident concerning the vehicle while in my care. That includes tickets, towing, breakdowns…"
Judge: Mr. Smith, you claim that the defendant returned your car in a damaged condition beyond normal wear and tear. Can you specify the issues?

Plaintiff: Yes, Your Honor. When I lent the car to Mr. Johnson, it was in perfect condition. But when he returned it, the brakes were worn out, and the engine was making a strange noise.

Judge: Mr. Johnson, how do you respond to these claims?

Defendant: Your Honor, I only used the car for regular commuting, nothing extreme. I didn’t cause any damage beyond what happens naturally with use.

Judge: Mr. Smith, do you have any maintenance records proving the car was in excellent condition before lending it out?

Plaintiff: I don’t have records from right before I lent it, but it was working fine.

Judge: Do you have any expert testimony or mechanic reports stating the damage was due to misuse rather than normal wear and tear?

Plaintiff: No, but—

Judge: Without concrete evidence proving the defendant misused the car, I cannot rule in your favor. Wear and tear happen naturally. My ruling is in favor of the defendant.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to the People's Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiff is a professional walker who says that he was badly injured because the defendant's sidewalk wasn’t level. Now, the defendant says the guy just tripped. It’s the case of “You're Not on the Level.” Thank you.

Judge: Douglas, okay. Jonathan Mone, you are suing Maxwell Tow for $2,000 in pain and suffering plus punitive damages because, according to you, you tripped over a sidewalk that was his responsibility to maintain. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: Now, on May 16, like every other day, I go for a brisk walk next to his, uh, in front of his house.

Judge: According to your complaint, you've been walking for 35 years, 10 to 15 miles a day?

Plaintiff: More, sometimes more. Really, when I started, the maximum I did was 38 miles a day.

Judge: How long does it take you to walk that?

Plaintiff: ‘Cause I'm a power walker. That’s what I do. Four and a half to four and a quarter miles per hour. Walk very fast.

Judge: Okay, all right. So anyway, you're walking in front of where he lives—his house. The sidewalk was clear?

Plaintiff: Everything is flat and flush and fluid. Very nice. I got to his house, I tripped so bad on my right leg. I fell on my right knee, I fell on my face, and I was stunned by the surprise. I was bleeding from my face.

Plaintiff: So as I got up, he, the defendant, came out of the house to see what—

Judge: What, were you yelling or anything? How did you know something was going on outside?

Defendant: I didn't. What I did is, I opened the door to retrieve my newspaper.

Judge: Okay, so it was a coincidence.

Defendant: And just by coincidence, he was standing there when I went to get the paper.

Judge: Okay. And did you see that he was hurt?

Defendant: I saw he was standing there looking sort of dazed, and he seemed to have blood on his shirt and a little blood on his head. But I didn’t see him fall. I came out—

Judge: Right. And so did you say to him, “Oh, what happened?” Like, were you trying to help him? What happened while you were out there?

Defendant: No, I went up to him to see what had happened, and we chatted a couple of minutes. And then he started yelling, “I’m going to sue! I’m going to sue!”

Defendant: Ah. So then I turned around, and I went back in the house.

Judge: Okay. Okay. Meanwhile, were you there?

Witness: Yes.

Judge: Okay. So what do you know about this?

Witness: Oh, he fell, and he called—

Judge: You didn’t see it happen though either, right?

Witness: No, I saw him sitting on the ground.

Judge: Okay.

Witness: And he called the police and an ambulance. And when the police and the ambulance came, they came out, I went out, and they said, “Oh, you again?”

Judge: “Oh, you again?” And there’s no lifting of the sidewalk?

Judge: Well, let’s see. Do you folks have pictures of the sidewalk?

Plaintiff: Yeah, yeah.

Judge: Let me see your pictures of the sidewalk.

Defendant: You want to make a correction?

Judge: Yeah. First, I want to see a picture. Picture of the—is this a picture of the sidewalk?

Plaintiff: That—that’s the rise.

Judge: Yes, that’s the rise.

Plaintiff: There’s a little cement there where we filled it in.

Judge: Yeah, but that’s kind of lifted. That’s pretty lifted right there. Is that the tree root?

Defendant: That’s—

Judge: Are you kidding me? You guys know it’s lifted. And you know that New York law, like many, many, many communities, requires you to fix the city sidewalks in front of your own home. You know that’s the law, right?

Defendant: We do.

Judge: Because you took a little cement and slapped it there and—

Judge: Um, how many inches is that?

Defendant: Two inches.

Judge: Two inches high? Guys, that’s not okay. I know it’s more expensive to hire somebody with a jackhammer to jackhammer that, jackhammer the root, and lay it down. I know ‘cause I’ve had to do it.

Judge: But two inches is not okay. And the city has never told you guys, “Hey, you have to fix that”?

Defendant: They should really be on top of that.

Judge: Wow. Two inches.

Judge: Now, the ambulance came, and you did not go in the ambulance, correct?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: According to the report, you refused medical attention, but that really means you say to them, “I’m not going with you, I’m not going to the hospital.” So when did you—did you go to any doctor?

Plaintiff: No. I—I don’t know, I don’t need another—because if I go, I get a bunch of X-rays. With my disease, lymphoma, I don’t need it.

Judge: Okay. So what—tell me about your injuries. You’re suing for $2,000. Tell me about your injuries.

[Conversation continues as the judge deliberates, discusses injuries, and delivers a final verdict awarding $500 to the plaintiff.]

Judge: I am going to find in your favor and in the amount of $500. That is my verdict. Good luck.

Defendant: I can’t believe this.

Plaintiff: Thank you.

Defendant : So her husband, Joe, makes plenty of money. He is a board member on a private equity group.

Judge: Okay, what does Joe have to do with this case? Is he the father of either of the children?

Defendant: No, but they're on his insurance, right?

Judge: So that’s a good thing, right? That’s a great thing.

Defendant: But she’s not really paying for it out of her pocket, is what I guess I’m saying.

Judge: Well, it’s not required that she pays for it out of her pocket. It’s only required that the children are covered by her.

Plaintiff: I don't think he is budgeting right. I think he's spending all his money on his new fiancée, and she's—

Judge: Oh, you're mad about that?

Plaintiff: Yeah, I'm pretty mad about it.

Judge: Okay, well, um, get over it. That’s the first thing. Second thing is, you said he has another child. So even without a reduction in what he makes, that requires an adjustment right there. Him having another child entitles him to get his child support adjusted.

Plaintiff: Well, maybe he should get his attitude adjusted. I don’t—

Judge: "Mr. LeBlanc, who do you really want to be with?"

Defendant: "I love my wife, Your Honor. I want to be with my wife."

Judge: "Then why are we here today?"

Defendant: "Because it’s hard to try to be with my wife, knowing there’s a possibility these other kids are mine."

Judge: "But whose actions created this situation, Mr. LeBlanc?"

Defendant: "I understand that, Your Honor, but it’s not easy. My wife is struggling to accept me bringing children into our marriage from outside. And I’m just trying to hold everything together."

Judge: "So you’re saying it’s everyone else’s responsibility to adjust, but not yours?"

Defendant: "It’s not like that. I’m just trying to do the right thing for my wife, my family, and the kids."

Judge:
Douglas Latoya Frasier, yes? You are suing your former friend, Canel Alberino, yes, for $74 in loans, a parking ticket, and clothing items that you say throughout the course of your friendship she was supposed to repay for and hasn't? What's going on?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
I've known the defendant since about third grade. We've been best friends, inseparable for a long time. About 2008 or 2009, we were both unemployed, going through financial issues. Hers were a bit more dire than mine because she had her apartment, her car. Me, I was taken care of by my daughter's father, so I didn’t really want for anything. I had an account with Wachovia years ago when I was working downtown and they closed my account due to an overdraft fee that they say I owe, but they waited a month and a half to cash a check that I had given them a while ago to cash for rent. But they waited until multiple things hit the account so the account would go over, and I disputed it. I paid it, but it took like a year and a half for the bank to recognize that I paid the red flag fee for, they say, for me to be able to open my own account.

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
I had gotten my money for school. Are you trying to explain to me why you took money and put it in her account? Yes, okay. You didn’t have creditors chasing you in a judgment against you or the tax man looking for you?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
No, it was just the, I had an account that was closed. Due to that bank thing, I asked her, since I had gotten my school loan, 'cause she put the money in her account since I couldn’t open my own. I gave her $790 to put in the account, and it was just left in the account. She ran into some complications where she wasn’t able to pay all of her rent and I think a car note. And she had stated that she had got a notice on her door letting her know that she had to pay the rent by a certain date. I said, she called me, and we usually spoke on the phone every day. She let me know the issue, and I told her, "Well, there’s money in your account, I’m not using it right now. It’s not a dire need for me to have it right now, so it’s not anything for me to loan it to you right now." She was like, “Are you sure?” I was like, "Whatever you want to do with it, however you want to do it, do what you need to do. Let me know afterwards what you spent, and when you get back on your feet, that’s when you’ll pay me back. I’m not going to..."

Judge:
How much did she take, according to you?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
She said that she took $550. That was to pay off whatever she needed to pay. I don’t know if it was for just rent or if it was for both rent and car. I'm not sure.

Judge:
At some point, you guys get into a rocky patch there, and you end up parting your friendship. Why was that?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
We went to South Beach with a group of girls, our friends, we all went to South Beach. That summer in South Beach, me and her had a falling out over an ordeal with her and her sister that I didn’t primarily agree with. She thought that I should be on her side and be mad at her sister as well, but I’m not a person of that nature.

Judge:
But you’ve been friends since third grade. A disagreement on vacation in South Beach one time...?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
It was just other events leading up to that. That was probably the breaking point at South Point, I should say. South Beach was the kicker in, I guess, both of our lives for us to part with.

Judge:
So you're also suing her for a jacket and some shoes. What is that about?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
The jacket, trivial. Shoes as well, but principal behind it. I had stuff at her house. Me and her go shopping at Mandy’s every now and again. We’ll have stuff at her house. I had stuff that I wanted to take back, but I didn’t take it back at that point in time. In that time frame, we had a really big flood. It rained really bad and it flooded in front of her building.

Judge:
Wait a second, when was this in relation to when you stopped talking to each other?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
This was prior to us stopping speaking.

Judge:
I understand that. I want to know how long prior to it.

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
The jacket was probably about six months.

Judge:
What about the shoes?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
The shoes, they’re $9 shoes. Are they a whole shoe?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
No, okay. It was a shoe that I got. The shoes were left at her house because they were too big for me. I was going to go to the store and get store credit. I got them on sale. She wore them and was like, "They’re my size." You didn’t need them. They were only $9. I’m like, "It’s the principle behind it." If you leave something at my house...

Judge:
Yeah, but you stayed friends after that?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
No, we didn’t stay friends after that.

Judge:
You didn’t stop being friends over the $9 pair of shoes?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
No, we didn’t stop being friends over the $9. It was well after the $9 pair of shoes.

Judge:
It was in the midst of us...

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
It’s just now that you’re suing, you’re going to bring up every little thing that happened between you?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
No, it’s not every little thing that happened between us. This was in the... Tell me about the parking ticket.

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
The parking ticket was for her school. We went to her school. She had some business to take care of. We were both upstairs while she was talking to her advisor. Okay, I go downstairs. The guy had already did the ticket. He said he couldn’t give it back.

Judge:
When did that happen?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
That happened in the summer. I'm not quite sure when.

Judge:
What summer?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
Summer of 2008.

Judge:
These ladies knew each other since third grade. Now they’re locked in the most trivial legal battle. The plaintiff is suing over a $9 pair of shoes, in addition to other stuff. There’s got to be more to this. Let’s listen. What’s going on?

Judge:
She says that you, she had money in your account, you knew it was her money, you used it when you needed it and then you never repaid it. What’s going on?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
The plaintiff has actually never told me that I had to pay her her money back. And I never used what she’s claiming. It went from $550 to $700 now, which I have a text message to prove it. At the time, it was not about my apartment, it was not about my car note. It was strictly about school and a cable bill. I said to her, "Listen, my cable is going to be cut off." I did not ask her for the money, I was telling her the situation. She offered and said, "Oh, you know what, don’t worry about it. You’re my best friend, I’ll give you the money." I said, "Well, I don’t have it now to give back to you." She said, "Do not worry about it. I’m making $45,000 a year now, I don’t need the money back."

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
So I said fine, no, that’s exactly what she said. That’s exactly the way she said it. "I do not need it back now." I went to my uncle and he gave me tuition money to get back in school, which he actually wrote a statement about. He gave me $310. The $238 that I used, I said to her when she brought this up after we were no longer friends for almost a year. She brought it up and I said, “Well, listen, did you use $550 or $238?”

Judge:
How do you remember?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
Because it was a cable bill. I know exactly when it was going to get cut off because that was the only time it was a backed-up bill for two months and I said to her, "You know what? I’ll just use that, and that’s it." You have a statement from your uncle?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
Yes.

Judge:
Is there a text between you two back in the day, four years ago, that tells me that... that’ll shed some light on whether it was $550 or...?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
I have a text message from her. Us, March of what year?

Judge:
This year?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
Saying how does it say how much money?

Judge:
No, not saying how much the money is, but that she was going to work out a payment plan with me for the $250.

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
You never said it was... I tell you $250 and she rounded it off to $300. We had a phone conversation, and after that, I sent her a text message. And I said, "We could talk about the $250." She texted me back and said, "It’s funny how now you’re saying $300 when you owe me $550, but she sued me today for $700."

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
So I said to her, “I don’t owe you that much. I only used the money for my payment on a cable bill." She never had mentioned this to me before last year.

Judge:
Why should she pay your cable bill or your parking ticket? In other words, why would she...?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
She didn’t pay. She didn’t pay a parking ticket either. She did not pay a parking ticket.

Judge:
Do you have any evidence that you paid a parking ticket?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
Everything was taken out of that account for... Her Jesus, CH. Do you have any evidence at all, like an email or...?

Judge:
Show me the text that you have. I’m sure it’s not going to say anything about the parking ticket.

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
Here’s a text message. Is the person next to you moral support or...?

Plaintiff (Latoya Frasier):
Moral support. My grandmother has nothing to do with the case.

Judge:
Lord have mercy. You answer.

Judge:
The funny thing is I just told someone I would send you monthly payments of the money you loaned me that I allegedly borrowed or stole, so you say. And their response was, “Watch, she’ll try to take you to court like she did her own blood.” I laughed and said, “Probably, Latoya. I don’t know what you are going through financially that would make you bring this bullcrap up, but at this point I could care less. You of all people should know I don’t get scared by threat. You have become such a low life with your mentality that it’s a shame. This and all the other reasons are why I would never be your friend again. Please don’t talk slick to me anymore. Let’s be women or nothing.”

Judge:
These are not helpful.

Judge:
I have one question before me, and the one question before me is: Is this a loan or is this a gift, and how much is this? It would be really helpful if I had bank statements from back then. Does anybody have bank statements?

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
The account was closed. And because this was short notice, because she sent the sum to my...

Judge:
It would be really helpful if I had emails back and forth between you guys or texts back and forth from back then, not now when everybody’s playing Guinness’s Macho, but from back then.

Defendant (Canel Alberino):
Is that going to prove anything, though?

Judge:
If there was a loan, there would have been an agreement on that.

Judge: Lynette Valentin, you are suing F. Burke and Raymond Luckman’s company. You've asked us not to mention the company name, for $7,792.91 for a vet bill and your travel expenses to and from the vet.

What happened?

Plaintiff:
We hired her to groom the dogs.

Judge:
Okay.

Plaintiff:
Everything was fine at the beginning. Professional at first. The dog—her clippers, I guess, were not good for the hair. She had to bathe the dog, come back to dry the dog, use the clippers again, and in between that time, she sliced my dog right where her leg is.

Judge:
Okay, were you there?

Plaintiff:
I was there.

Judge:
Is this a mobile kind of unit?

Defendant:
I provide an in-home dog grooming service. I just bring all my kits, my professional clippers, and all of that to people’s homes. We usually specialize in difficult dogs and, you know, elderly dogs especially.

Judge:
So you do it in their bathtub? Where do you do it?

Defendant:
Anywhere in a room—any surface that we can put the dog on safely so they won’t get injured, depending on the size of the dog.

Judge:
And how did this happen? How did the dog get cut?

Defendant:
Frankly, I actually don’t know. From my years of being a vet tech, it looked like a skin tag got removed, and I specifically asked—

Judge:
How many years were you a vet tech?

Defendant:
About two.

Judge:
So when you say it had to have been a skin tag, wouldn’t you have felt a skin tag?

Defendant:
Not always.

Judge:
A lot of times, if they’re tiny, then they’re also not going to require 10 stitches, right?

Plaintiff:
The dog got 10 stitches.

Judge:
Okay, you brought the dog over to the vet?

Plaintiff:
Yes.

Judge:
And so everybody realizes that it happened when it happened, right? Did the dog scream?

Plaintiff:
She did.

Judge:
And was there blood?

Plaintiff:
There was a little bit, yes.

Judge:
And what is being said at the home when that happened?

Plaintiff:
So, I feel like I handled it very well. You know, I told her—she said it never happened to her before. And, you know, accidents do happen. I’m not discrediting her at all with her work, but accidents do happen, and that’s what happened in this case.

And she said that she would pay for the cost of the bill when we got it, that she would pay it in increments.

I even said it’s fine if you pay it in increments.

And when I told her the amount of the bill, she said that she was not going to pay the blood work at all because that wasn’t necessary.

And I have a letter from the hospital saying that the blood work was necessary to put the dog under anesthesia before a procedure.

Judge:
Right.

Plaintiff:
And I don’t feel that it’s fair at all that I come out of pocket for something that wasn’t my fault.

Judge:
Why would she come out of pocket?

So, if the dog gets hurt on the grooming table, but the dog’s really aggressive and emotional, is the groomer responsible for vet bills?

Audience Member:
Maybe if they don’t have the proper equipment to restrain the dog.

Judge:
What do you say?

Audience Member:
I think that’s on the owner.

Judge:
Why?

Audience Member:
Because they own the dog, and it’s incumbent upon them to inform the groomer of any emotional needs that the dog might have.

Judge:
Fair enough. Going inside the courtroom.

I actually don’t feel like she should have come out of pocket for the entire thing.

Defendant:
Absolutely not.

Judge:
Why should she come out of pocket at all?

According to you, she asked you to ask the vet what was the reason, and, you know, the vet wouldn’t get involved in giving paperwork, which is understandable.

It’s not the vet's job to be giving paperwork.

But go ahead.

Defendant:
The vet didn’t provide me that letter.

Judge:
But what did the vet tell you?

Defendant:
That the cut was way too big to have been a skin tag.

Judge:
In fact, it was more sarcastic than that. What was it exactly that the vet said?

Defendant:
That it was big enough that it looked like a dinner plate. If it was a skin tag, it had to be a skin tag the size of a dinner plate.

Judge:
But really, let's start from the premise that if that's your defense, then you’ve got to prove it.

You also have to prove to me that if it were a skin tag, that wouldn’t be your fault too.

So, I don’t get it. Because you have to feel the dog, and you have to see what you’re doing.

It’s an accident, but accidents can happen. I rule in favor of the plaintiff for the full $7,792.91.

Judge: Is there a reason why you don't want to give her any money in child support to pay for your daughter?
Defendant: Well, it's not that I don't want to pay. It's just, I'm not working at all. I'm a full-time student, okay? My tuition is paid for, and I've got a Pell Grant. I get basically $3,200 for a school year to help cover my living expenses as well. I have to maintain grades and stay in school. I have to prove that to be able to continue to receive the grant. So, just trying to further my education. I understand my daughter is important to me. I love her very much, but I'm going back to law. I'm trying to get into law school.
Plaintiff: But I have to bear all the costs alone, and I can't do that. I am only a daycare worker.

**Judge:** This is the plaintiff, Raymond Lamb. He says the defendant rear-ended him on a major highway and paid for his car to be fixed. The repair took 10 days. He’s an Uber driver who lost out on work. The defendant had promised to reimburse him for his lost work but hasn’t. So here they are. He’s suing for $3,833, the amount he’s owed.

This is the defendant, Julio Vieira. He says the plaintiff told him he makes $180 a day and he agreed to pay for 7 days of his missed work. Then he gets sued for 10 days at almost $400 a day and he refuses to be ripped off by this scammer, so he’s not paying. He’s accused of rear-ending a guy. All parties, please raise your right hand.

Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket, the plaintiff says the defendant rear-ended him on the highway. His car was in the shop for days, and he’s an Uber driver. The defendant says the plaintiff is trying to rip him off. It’s the case of "This Accident Was Uber Expensive."

**Judge:** Raymond Lamb, you are suing Julio Vieira for $3,833 that you say he owes you for a car crash. Tell me what happened during that crash.

**Plaintiff:** On August 29th, I was driving my wife to work in Yonkers on the Major Deegan. I was in the left lane and driving when I realized the car in front of me had slowed down dramatically, so I had to slow down dramatically. When I slowed down, that’s when Mr. Vieira—he did not slow down fast enough—and he skidded and rear-ended my car.

**Judge:** Okay, and how much damage did it do?

**Plaintiff:** Well, according to the auto repair place, it was about $5,000—a little less than $5,000.

**Judge:** Is this your car?

**Plaintiff:** Yes.

**Judge:** Wow. Okay. And then, did you hit the car in front of you?

**Plaintiff:** No, but if I didn’t slow down, I would have.

**Judge:** Am I not seeing damage to the front of this, or is that his car?

Judge: The insurance companies found this 50/50. What is wrong with you guys? Is this how you lead your lives normally, or was this just a hot moment for both of you?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Let me tell you something: don’t come down to my neck of the woods and drive.

Plaintiff (Unice Magnus): Yes, on April the 13th, before April the 13th, a friend of mine introduced me to Mr. Davis. On the 13th, he came to the house. I showed him what needs to be done and I told him that I hired this other gentleman to do the job for $1,900.

Judge: That's who you're referring to as the...?

Plaintiff: The Mexican.

Judge: Okay, you had gotten an estimate from the...

Plaintiff: The Mexican, and the Mexican's estimate was how much?

Plaintiff: $1,900. But then I... but the Mexican had a condition to the $1,900.

Judge: And what was that?

Plaintiff: For me to provide him with jerk chicken.

Judge: Jerk chicken? Why? How did you come up with that?

Plaintiff: Because I do jerk chicken for friends.

Judge: And you sell it?

Plaintiff: Well, I just started. I just started selling it.

Judge: So apparently he's tasted it?

Plaintiff: Yes, he's tasted it and it's really good.

Defendant: Yes, it's good.

Judge: Where is it from?

Defendant: Well, no, I don’t want to ask Mr. J. Why did you bring it?

Plaintiff: Because...

Defendant: Where are you from?

Plaintiff: I’m from Jamaica.

Defendant: Where are you from?

Plaintiff: I’m from Chicago.

Judge: Okay, but you like jerk chicken. All right. You meet him and he’s willing to do it for... for he said he would beat that price. Okay, and he charged $1,700 and no jerk chicken. That was before you had tasted it?

Judge: Right, but he said he would use my garage on his flyers, the before and after picture, and I would introduce him to other people for him to do the work. So that's why he was charging $1,700.

Judge: They would take a picture of your garage and use it on flyers to advertise and he would expect you to send him business. All right, so you struck a deal with him. Do you put it in writing?

Plaintiff: No. I’ve been asking him for a contract.

Defendant: Don’t start. If somebody’s going to do construction on your house, doesn’t give you a contract, then just don’t start. But in any event, he starts. He starts. What is the $1,700 to do?

Plaintiff: I’ll have to just take each of your words for it and hope you agree since there’s no written contract. Go ahead.

Defendant: They’re supposed to do the ceiling and the siding.

Plaintiff: Eliminate two windows and put in a new window in the back of the garage.

Judge: Do you agree that that was the scope of the work?

Defendant: Oh, look at that!

Plaintiff: Look at that.

Judge: What do you say was the scope of the work?

Defendant: I was going to do the roof and the siding.

Plaintiff: What’s the roof? The ceiling or the roof?

Defendant: The roof on the... on the ground.

Plaintiff: I have pictures.

Judge: I have ceiling, the ceiling is the inside, the roof is the outside.

Defendant: The roof, you did mean the roof.

Plaintiff: The roof and the siding. What about the windows?

Defendant: Right, no, the windows I did for free just to help her out because she said you were going to do...

Judge: But that was just going to be for free?

Defendant: But so did you end up doing the windows or...?

Defendant: I did the windows. I did a whole lot of extra. I did facing. I did around the top of the garage where she never has to paint again. I did a lot of different things for her for free.

Plaintiff: Okay, but she seems to be pretty unhappy with your work.

Defendant: Well, she was loving my work. She said you do excellent work until I get these phone calls.

Judge: Why don’t you have a contract with her specifying what it is you're supposed to do? If she’s under the impression that all this other stuff is included, wouldn’t a contract be a really good idea?

Defendant: Well, I always write contracts. Like I’ll show you one of those...

Judge: I don’t want to see a contract in another case. I want to understand why you don’t do one in this case.

Defendant: Well, with her, we became friends and, you know, my mother came over visiting with her. They became real good friends.

Plaintiff: Taste the chicken.

Defendant: I tasted the chicken.

Judge: It was really good.

Plaintiff: Okay, you said you two were friends. Would you make him sign a contract with you if he did work in your house?

Plaintiff: I would definitely make him sign a contract just in case. Like he doesn’t abide by what we want, we don’t have any... friends are friends, business is business.

Defendant: Exactly.

Judge: Got your point. Going inside the courtroom.

Defendant: All right, listen...

Plaintiff: She’s unhappy with your work. At one point, the police are actually called to the job site. That doesn’t sound like things are going swimmingly. Who calls the police?

Plaintiff: Why? He didn’t finish the job and he was asking for more money and I told him I’m not going to pay him until the job is finished. He was out there cursing, saying he’s going to tear down the garage if he didn’t get more money.

Plaintiff: So I was afraid for... I was afraid for my life, plus my daughter’s life.

Judge: How old is your daughter?

Plaintiff: My daughter is 32, but she has the ability of an 8-year-old.

Judge: I’m sorry.

Plaintiff: Okay, so, um, I had to call the police. The police came and we went over what happened, and of course, the police asked him for the contract and they said they could not do anything because there’s no contract. So he asked Mr. Thomas to write a contract.

Plaintiff: And so did he... he wrote a contract.

Judge: And did you give him more money?

Plaintiff: I gave him $250 because he promised he would come back on Friday, which he did, but the job was not finished. He was rushing to go to a dinner and he said he would come back.

Plaintiff: What didn’t he finish?

Plaintiff: He didn’t finish this side in which he said he would tear off. He didn’t finish...

Plaintiff: What do you mean he didn’t finish it? Meaning he didn’t fix something that you brought to his attention, right?

Plaintiff: He was... had...

Defendant: What was it that you had brought to his attention?

Plaintiff: It wasn’t aligned really.

Judge: Do you have pictures?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: What else didn’t he do?

Plaintiff: And the window is not cut properly, like it’s a blind person who put that capping on. I believe the way you said it in your complaint was, “It’s like Stevie Wonder did it.” Is that...

Plaintiff: You’re just like the model of political correctness. Okay, so go on. Do you have pictures of that?

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Judge: Show me all your pictures.

Defendant: So she pays you the last payment. Yes. So you think you’re done. When do you get the phone call from her?

Defendant: Oh, I mean, I got phone calls through the whole job. Like the window was not part of the agreement at all. I did the windows for free. I have pictures that...

Plaintiff: When the cops made you write a contract, you included the word “windows.”

Defendant: They did not make me write it. I decided to write it.

Plaintiff: When you decided to write a contract the day the cops came...

Defendant: Uh-huh.

Plaintiff: You wrote the word “windows” as part of the contract, right?

Defendant: I would finish the windows for her, which I did. I finished everything. I have pictures. She wanted more than expected for $1,100, four done with the Mexican.

Plaintiff: Huh?

Defendant: You’re there. Just had to cook a little chicken.

Judge: What’s this?

Plaintiff: That’s an arm inside of what...

Defendant: The window.

Plaintiff: That’s the window. But what... what... I mean, the window has glass. What is that?

Defendant: Oh, that’s the glass. You’re pushing the glass with your hand, right? Because it wasn’t...

Judge: How does the glass not fall down and shatter? I don’t understand what’s going on.

Defendant: It’s not glass. It’s plexiglass.

Defendant: So it’s attached on the top and not the bottom.

Plaintiff: Right, ma’am.

Judge: And then what is that?

Plaintiff: That’s where the siding meets, and shouldn’t be like that, right?

Plaintiff: That’s where Stevie Wonder did the job.

Judge: Okay. All right. All right. And then this is your... these are your fingers inside of siding that doesn’t meet?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am. That’s the job you did, the wonderful job.

Plaintiff: You have an estimate to repair?

Defendant: What’s... what’s this picture supposed to show me?

Plaintiff: The siding is not aligned properly.

Judge: Oh, meaning that it doesn’t go like this?

Plaintiff: Why couldn’t you just align these so that they were visually...

Judge: The siding is not aligned.

Defendant: Why wouldn’t you if you have a choice?

Judge: Because it’s the same height on both sides.

Defendant: Have these meet so that visually you won’t see that?

Plaintiff: Like that?

Defendant: Why would you choose not to do it? Do you understand what I’m saying?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Just throw two sides that doesn’t match that the same length. You know what I mean? They’re not matching at that corner.

Plaintiff: They were. They were matching, but they’re not matching in the picture.

Defendant: What do you think she did? Took all of it down, put it wrong, so she fixed it and then got it right again, like probably.

Plaintiff: So come on. Look at my pictures. Those are my after pictures.

Defendant: Those are his.

Plaintiff: That’s how the garage looked.

Defendant: Your pictures are the same as hers. There’s nothing different about the pictures.

Judge: But I’m more concerned about, like the patch job around the windows, where her fingers can stick in, and the plexiglass moving. Why is that?

Defendant: I have no... that’s the way her window was before we started, and that’s the way it was when we left because we do not do windows. We don’t do glass.

Judge: I understand you don’t do glass, but why should the plexiglass move? If I can do that, I can reach into her garage.

Defendant: That’s the way it was when we got there.

Judge: Well, they don’t want it to be the way it was when you got there.

Defendant: That was not in the agreement.

Judge: But it is in the agreement, in your own handwriting, the windows to remove the windows.

Defendant: I removed the window on the east side, on the north side, and the back.

Judge: Mr. Davis, this cannot be your best work. You say that you can get it repaired for $500. I’m going to rule in favor of the plaintiff in the amount of $500.

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Cassandra Jackson, you are suing Quenton Slaughter for $477 that you say he owes you when he broke your heart, your lease, stole your stuff, and ran off with your sister.

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Judge: Okay. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: Well, we’d been dating for about two years. Recently, last year, we just moved in together for the first time, and everything was all right. But then it started... like, I know you want to go out on Fridays and be with your boys after work or whatever, but then it started getting to the point where it seemed like he was starting arguments about just any little thing—just to get outside. And then I noticed that when we had an argument, he’d go to his mother’s house and stay there.

Judge: So you thought?

Plaintiff: Yeah. Yeah. Yes, yes, yes. I thought so. Come to find out, one day I’m at work, and he called himself leaving. But actually, when I came home, the stuff was gone this time. And I’m like, okay? And then that’s when I started calling and confiding in my sister. And she’s telling me, "Oh, don’t worry about it," and everything. And she knows really what’s going on.

Judge: What do you mean? You were confiding in your sister, telling her you were having problems with him?

Plaintiff: And then, meanwhile, she’s the one who’s running around with him behind my back.

Judge: Yeah. Okay. So he moved out. Where’s your sister? Is she here?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: What a shame.

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Judge: So he moved out in November, which left you with December, January, and February’s rent. And you haven’t heard from him?

Plaintiff: That’s what I’m saying. I don’t talk to her.

Plaintiff: She said it never started out to be like that.

Plaintiff: Exactly. And no one told me. I was left to find out all on my own.

Judge: How did you find out?

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Defendant: Well, me and Cassandra were staying together or whatever, but all along, I was messing around with her sister.

Defendant: Yeah. I ain’t want her no more.

Defendant: Yeah, she’s a cougar.

Judge: How so?

Defendant: She started off being a sugar mama.

Judge: How much older is she than you?

Defendant: She’s 45. I’m 26.

Judge: How old is her sister?

Defendant: 24.

Judge: Do you work?

Defendant: No, ma’am. Not anymore.

Judge: When was the last time you worked?

Defendant: About three months ago.

Defendant: A car wash.

Defendant: They wasn’t paying good enough.

Defendant: Nothing.

Defendant: No.

Judge: Seriously, you left her with rent, stole her furniture, and ran off with her sister?

Judge: You don’t deserve to walk among the rest of us.

Plaintiff: And he took my kids' PlayStations.

Judge: You don’t deserve to walk among us.

Defendant: It was as good as mine as it was hers.

Defendant: I don’t know.

I sent her the flyer.

Through email?

Through email.

The judge finds in favor of the plaintiff, ordering the defendant to return $355 for misleading advertising and failure of contract fulfillment.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiff cashed a money order for her godsister, and it was bogus. Judge: Thank you. Chantel Brown, you are suing Katia. You’ve asked us not to mention your last name for $2,412.

Plaintiff: Yes, Your Honor.

Judge: $1,935 of it for money orders that she had you deposit in your account that turned out to be fraudulent, $400 for pain and suffering, $100 for some loan that has nothing to do with this, and bank fees. All right, tell me what’s going on.

Plaintiff: Well, I’ve known Katia for most of my life, since I was about 11 or 12 years old. Her son is my godbrother, so I consider her family.

Judge: Her son is your godbrother? What does that mean?

Plaintiff: It means that my parents are his godparents.

Judge: Okay. Continue.

Plaintiff: She called me at the end of February, I believe, about a money order. She said she was having problems cashing it because of her ID or something. She called me distressed. She asked if I could lend her the money and then deposit the money order in my account, which I did.

Judge: How much did you give her?

Plaintiff: $1,900.

Judge: That was the amount of the money order?

Plaintiff: Yes, Your Honor. To me, that was the same as cash. I didn’t think it was fraudulent. I didn’t think it was anything shady.

Judge: Who were the money orders from? What kind of money orders were they?

Plaintiff: I’m not sure exactly. She said it was from a company that she worked for.

Judge: But you didn’t photocopy them before you deposited them into your account?

Plaintiff: No, Your Honor.

Judge: Did the bank send you a copy when they reversed it?

Plaintiff: Yes, I have it here.

Judge: May I see that?

Plaintiff: Sure.

Judge: Where did these money orders come from?

Defendant: I’m a mystery shopper.

Judge: You’re a what?

Defendant: A mystery shopper.

Judge: What is a mystery shopper?

Defendant: You’re paid to go into certain businesses and critique them—customer service, cleanliness, how long it took them to wait on you, things like that.

Judge: That sounds interesting. How much do you get paid for that?

Defendant: It depends. In this case, I did about four right around the holiday season of 2011.

Judge: You did about four what?

Defendant: Four different stores I visited as a mystery shopper.

Judge: And they were going to pay you how much for that?

Defendant: $1,900.

Judge: To go to the four stores and do your Christmas shopping?

Defendant: Well, it was divided among the four stores. I got my payment for being a mystery shopper, and they sent money for me to purchase everyday items.

Judge: Did they do that?

Defendant: Yes. That’s why when they gave me the money orders, I didn’t suspect anything. I had been with them for two years and never had a problem before. But when Chantel called to tell me that the checks were fraudulent, I called the company. I only got voicemail. No return calls. No letter. Nothing.

Plaintiff (Joe Gonzalez): The AC unit is in my storage unit, and all her stuff is packed up. She can come get it. I’ll even help her load it in the car.

Judge: So, you’re saying her belongings are packed up and she’s welcome to come get them?

Plaintiff (Joe Gonzalez): Yes, they’re all packed. She can come by, and I’ll help her with the moving, no problem.

Defendant (Deborah): I didn’t feel safe going over there by myself. The officers were involved, but he still wouldn’t give me my stuff.

Judge: You mentioned you called the officers. Were there any official complaints filed or just a visit?

Defendant (Deborah): It was just a visit. I didn’t file a formal complaint. I just wanted my stuff back.

Judge: All right, let’s review what we have. Joe, you have an agreement that she will pay back the $400, and you do have texts that acknowledge that she owes you money, but you don’t have a formal promissory note. Deborah, you’re admitting that you owe the $400 but are refusing to pay it because you feel like you didn’t get your belongings back.

Defendant (Deborah): Yes, I don’t think I should have to pay him until he gives me my stuff.

Plaintiff (Joe Gonzalez): I’ve been offering to give her stuff back. She can come get it whenever.

Judge: Well, the question of the debt is a separate matter. I’m going to instruct both of you to work out the return of the personal property immediately, but let’s talk about the $400. Joe, you’re asking for this repayment because you loaned her the money. Deborah, you’re agreeing to the loan, but you’re claiming it’s tied to receiving your things back.

Plaintiff (Joe Gonzalez): I’m happy to give her her stuff back. I just want the money she owes me.

Judge: I see. Here’s what I’m going to do. I’m ordering that the property be returned. Deborah, you will come pick it up at Joe’s convenience, and Joe, you will make sure she gets everything back in the condition it was in. As for the $400, I’m ruling that it must be paid back immediately, with any remaining balance due within 30 days.

Defendant (Deborah): I can’t pay it right now, but I will in the next couple weeks.

Judge: Well, I suggest you work that out, but there’s no excuse for not paying a debt you’ve acknowledged. If there’s an issue with the payment plan, let Joe know and work something out, but it’s expected to be paid. I don’t want to see this go any further.

Plaintiff (Joe Gonzalez): Understood.

Defendant (Deborah): Understood.

Judge: Good. The court is adjourned.
