dialogue:
JUDGE: Mr. Roberts, you are suing the defendant for damages to your vehicle. Please state your case.

PLAINTIFF (MR. ROBERTS): Yes, Your Honor. On January 15th, I parked my car in front of my house, and later that night, I found it had been hit. Witnesses saw the defendant’s car speeding away from the scene.

JUDGE: Mr. Thompson, how do you respond to these allegations?

DEFENDANT (MR. THOMPSON): Your Honor, I was nowhere near his house that night. I was at a friend’s house watching the game. I have no idea how my car could have been involved.

JUDGE: Do you have any witnesses to corroborate your whereabouts?

DEFENDANT (MR. THOMPSON): Yes, my friend Michael was with me the whole night.

JUDGE: Mr. Roberts, do you have evidence to support your claim that it was the defendant’s vehicle?

PLAINTIFF (MR. ROBERTS): Yes, Your Honor. I have a statement from my neighbor, who saw a red sedan with a dented fender leaving the scene. Mr. Thompson drives a red sedan with a dented fender.

JUDGE: Mr. Thompson, do you have proof that your car was not damaged before this alleged incident?

DEFENDANT (MR. THOMPSON): I do, Your Honor. I have pictures of my car from a week before that show no damage to the fender.

JUDGE: Let me see those photos. (Examines photos) The timestamps do indicate they were taken a week before the incident. However, this does not prove your car wasn’t involved that night. Mr. Roberts, do you have any other evidence?

PLAINTIFF (MR. ROBERTS): Yes, Your Honor. I have security footage from another neighbor’s camera. It shows a red sedan hitting my car and speeding off.

JUDGE: (Examines footage) Mr. Thompson, this footage shows a vehicle that looks identical to yours.

DEFENDANT (MR. THOMPSON): I admit it looks like my car, but I swear I wasn’t there that night.

JUDGE: Mr. Roberts, do you have an estimate for the damages?

PLAINTIFF (MR. ROBERTS): Yes, Your Honor. The repair shop quoted me $2,500.

JUDGE: Mr. Thompson, given the evidence, I find you responsible for the damages. I rule in favor of the plaintiff for $2,500.

DEFENDANT (MR. THOMPSON): But Your Honor—

JUDGE: My ruling is final. Court is adjourned.

Judge: All parties, please use your right hand.

Bailiff: Thank you, Douglas.

Judge: You're welcome. All right, Jose Sanchez, you are suing the parking facility. Are you the owner?

Defendant: No, I manage the location, represented here by its manager, Thomas Phelan.

Judge: Phelan?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Phelan, all right. I don't want to say felon.

Judge: You are suing for $388 that you demand they pay you for breaching their contract, I guess. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: Yes, on December 30th, I pulled over to their parking space and inquired about long-term parking for 10 days while I went to Puerto Rico. I was arriving on my flight returning from San Juan, Puerto Rico, on January 8th at 11:05 PM to arrive January 9th at 2:00 AM. So, I explained my days to the young man.

Judge: Did you explain to the young man when you'd be returning?

Plaintiff: Yes, I told him January 9th at 2:00 AM.

Judge: And he printed it up the way he printed it on this document? Let me see that document. That's how he printed it up?

Plaintiff: Yes, except he put January 8th at 3:00 AM.

Judge: But that's actually January 9th?

Plaintiff: Exactly. That was his error.

Judge: Doesn't he write down exactly what you say?

Plaintiff: Exactly.

Judge: And weren’t you like, "I'm returning on the 8th" because that's the day of your flight, and you weren't really doing the math that it would be the 9th?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: That's not good for you if you didn’t realize it, but I don’t think he’s making an error. He doesn't know when your flight is; he just writes down what you say, right? He's not analyzing your airline ticket and trying to figure out the time zone difference.

Judge: So, you said you were leaving on the 30th and coming back on the 8th, and that's what he wrote down. But you don’t come back on the 8th; you come back on the 9th. However, I see you were charged for 10 days and were given a free day?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: How were you given a free day?

Defendant: We had a special at the time. Every seven days, you get one day free. The quote he received was for nine days, but he actually returned on the 10th day and past the designated time, which put him into another day.

Judge: When did he come to pick up the car?

Defendant: On the 9th at about 5:00 AM because his flight was late.

Judge: And he was supposed to be there on the 8th at 3:00 AM according to the documents?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: So he got charged for an extra day for coming an extra day later?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Why are you here? Because you’re mad they charged you an extra day?

Plaintiff’s Girlfriend: We were delayed because—

Judge: I don’t care why you were delayed. I care if they overcharged you. How much did they charge you?

Defendant: $194.

Judge: And that’s for how long?

Defendant: Two more days.

Judge: Two more days because A) he came a day late and B) he came past the designated time. That would be $18.70 times two, which is another $37. That plus $156.60 makes the $194. But you’re not even suing for $37—you’re suing for $388. How do you figure?

Plaintiff: They quoted me a price, and they honored that price. I asked the attendant if this was exactly what I was going to pay. He said yes.

Judge: If you came on January 8th by 3:00 AM. But did you?

Plaintiff: When I arrived and was informed of the price, I tried to speak to the manager but was unable to.

Judge: Because you were wrong. Are you guys shocked that maybe you didn’t realize this before you filed the lawsuit?

Plaintiff: But we called them twice!

Judge: Okay, you were late by two days. Should we sue JetBlue for making you late then? No. You botched it because you were supposed to tell them you were coming in January 9th at 3:00 AM. Either way, you should pay.

Plaintiff: I made an attempt to speak to the manager.

Judge: What’s the bottom of it? You spent two extra days before picking up your car.

Defendant: We even offered to refund the $37, but he refused and wanted the full amount back.

Judge: Plaintiff, how long have you been dating?

Plaintiff’s Girlfriend: Almost three years.

Judge: He’s headstrong, right?

Plaintiff’s Girlfriend: Yes.

Judge: Someone offered you $37, and you refused it. That’s not principle—that’s pig-headedness. Verdict for the defendant.

Plaintiff: "She only kept the baby for a week. A week, your honor!"

Judge: "Miss Paul, is that true?"

Defendant: "Well, I have to get back to nurse school."

Judge: "So the answer is yes?"

Defendant: "I'm out here trying to save lives."

Plaintiff: "I mean, yes, but you're not trying to save your own baby's life. Make that make sense."

Defendant: "When I have the time, I see him."

Judge: I have a question for you. Did you cut the other ones in a different way than you cut the prototype?

Defendant: We actually cut it—it was actually cut differently because the pattern actually said to cut it with the grain of the fabric, and the grain of the fabric is always parallel to the selvage of the roll.

Judge: Okay, but this is the pattern that you're talking about that says to cut it a certain way?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Then why did you cut it a different way the first time when you made the prototype the very first time?

Defendant: She only brought just enough fabric to make that one little piece, just in fabric.

Judge Milian: Jason Gore, you are suing Ubaldo Mejia for $3,000. You say you’re actually out $5,000 for a 1999 Ford Crown Victoria that he damaged when, according to you, he was at fault in an accident. What happened?

Plaintiff (Jason Gore): Correct. Okay, uh, it happened on September 13th. I received a phone call from my wife—she was involved in a little fender bender. So I went out to assist her.

Judge Milian: Okay. Who is that with you?

Plaintiff: This is my wife.

Judge Milian: So she had an accident?

Plaintiff: She had an accident.

Judge Milian: That same day?

Plaintiff: Same day.

Judge Milian: So you go out to assist her?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge Milian: And on the way home, you have an accident?

Plaintiff: On the way home from assisting her, I have an accident.

Judge Milian: That is one of the worst things I’ve ever heard—well, not the worst, but pretty bad.

Plaintiff: Yeah, it was surreal.

Judge Milian: Oh my gosh.

Plaintiff: Yeah. But you know, I went to assist her, everything was fine. That turned out to be just a little fender bender, nothing to be concerned about. She was all right, everything was good.

Judge Milian: Okay.

Plaintiff: So we're on the way home…

Judge Milian: Both in the same car?

Plaintiff: No, she’s in her own car. She’s in a separate car. I’m traveling in my car.

[Demonstrating the Scene]
Judge Milian: There are two intersections. Why don’t you come over here and pick a car to represent you?

Plaintiff: I'll take the Impala.

Judge Milian: Okay. This is your 1999 Crown Victoria, correct?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge Milian: And this is underneath a bridge? What kind of bridge?

Plaintiff: A train bridge.

Judge Milian: Okay. And the stop sign is actually further back from the corner?

Plaintiff: Correct. There’s a pedestrian pathway along the road. The stop sign is actually back here. So if you stop at the stop sign, you cannot see if anybody is coming down the walkway. You have to creep up to the corner.

Judge Milian: Okay, so what happened?

Plaintiff: I did exactly that. I saw no one coming down the pedestrian path. I turned to my right—no one. I turned to my left—there were a couple of vehicles down the way. Then I look back, and I see the truck coming at me.

Judge Milian: So where was your car when the impact happened?

Plaintiff: Right here.

Judge Milian: Okay, and what happens?

Plaintiff: I looked right—no one. I looked left—cars were coming. When I looked back right, his truck was already there, coming straight into me.

Judge Milian: Did you see his face?

Plaintiff: Yeah, I saw his expression.

Judge Milian: And what did it look like?

Plaintiff: [Mimics shocked expression]

Judge Milian: (Laughs) Okay.

Plaintiff: And then, in a split second, boom—impact. Pieces flying everywhere. And the first thought in my head was, I can’t believe this is happening.

[Defendant’s Testimony – Ubaldo Mejia]
Judge Milian: What happened, sir?

Defendant (Ubaldo Mejia): I was coming, and I made my left turn. If he says there were cars coming from this direction, then when I made my left, they would’ve hit me.

Judge Milian: Maybe you were less cautious than he was?

Defendant: No. I came here, I saw him coming, and I expected him to hold his brakes.

Judge Milian: Why would he have to stop?

Defendant: Because he was at the stop sign.

Judge Milian: But why were you in the path of where he would turn?

Defendant: The street is narrow. It's not two full lanes, more like one and a half.

[Police Report & Evidence]
Judge Milian: The police were called?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge Milian: They talked to both of you?

Plaintiff & Defendant: Yes.

Judge Milian: And they gave you tickets?

Defendant: Yes. Two weeks later, they sent me tickets.

Judge Milian: What for?

Defendant: Crossing a solid line and failure to maintain lane.

Judge Milian: This police report states:

Vehicle 2 (Plaintiff) was stopped at the stop sign.
Vehicle 1 (Defendant) cut the corner and struck Vehicle 2.
The officer drew a diagram that matches the plaintiff’s story.
[Judge’s Ruling]
Judge Milian: The police report shows you (Defendant) making a weird tight left turn. This suggests you were trying to cut the traffic too fast and miscalculated.

Your insurance company denied the claim?

Plaintiff: Yes, State Farm denied it, saying he was not legally liable.

Judge Milian: They’re wrong. I find the defendant at fault.

I order the defendant to pay $1,600 to the plaintiff.

Judge Milian: Good luck. Case closed.

**Judge:** Miss Johnson, you and your business Retro Girls Hawaiian Ice Shack are suing Miss Hassan and her business, Main Experience. Miss Hassan, you're a hairstylist, and you're counterclaiming for $10,000 for harassment, stalking, defamation, and property damage. Let's hear from you first, Miss Johnson. What is going on?

**Plaintiff:** I moved into my storefront in the fall of 2015 or leased it in 2016. I was there to open up a storefront so that I could help the community. I do a lot of givebacks in the community. I host storytime for children, breast cancer awareness dinners, and I sell ice cream.

**Judge:** So it's a dessert shop, but you do other community outreach as well. Do you also live there?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, I live upstairs from the storefront. Main Experience is like 10 or 15 feet across from my door.

**Judge:** So are they next door or a couple of stores down?

**Plaintiff:** Next door. Right next door.

**Judge:** Okay. When did the problems start between you two?

**Plaintiff:** The problem started before Miss Hassan moved in, originally with the previous owner of the hair salon in the spring of 2016.

**Judge:** Is that the present owner?

**Plaintiff:** That’s the current owner.

**Judge:** Is she in court today?

**Plaintiff:** No, she is not.

**Judge:** All right, so when Miss Hassan moves in, you start not getting along with her next door. Why?

**Plaintiff:** She moved in, and she would be in the storefront until 2 or 3 AM, playing loud music, making noise, cursing, and her children would be outside running around being disruptive. She and her daughter would have fights in and outside the storefront. It was very disruptive to the quiet area we had before.

**Judge:** So then how do we get to a problem with her specifically? Because you're suing her, not the prior owner.

**Plaintiff:** When she moved into the hair salon in December 2017, it wasn’t an issue at first. But when she started living inside the shop, she would come in at 2 or 3 AM, slamming doors, making noise, which woke me up.

**Judge:** Did you call the police?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, very often for noise violations.

**Judge:** Do you have any reports showing the police took action?

**Plaintiff:** The police came and spoke with her. One officer said he would cite her for loud noise.

**Judge:** Were you ever cited for noise violation, Miss Hassan?

**Defendant:** No, I was never cited.

**Judge:** Do you have proof that she was cited, Miss Johnson?

**Plaintiff:** No, I just heard the officer say he would.

**Judge:** Then what happened next?

**Plaintiff:** We were hosting a Juneteenth celebration in my storefront. A patron of hers parked illegally for six hours in a five-minute parking zone. When the ticket officer arrived, they assumed I had called them. Her patron confronted me, cursing at me.

**Judge:** But you’re suing her, not her patron. Are business owners responsible for their patrons’ actions?

**Plaintiff:** She also put trash in front of my storefront.

**Judge:** Do you have proof of her doing that?

**Plaintiff:** I have images of her family members putting trash.

**Judge:** But do you have proof of *her* putting trash there?

**Plaintiff:** Not directly, but I have a security camera from December 2016.

**Judge:** Do you have video of her putting trash there?

**Plaintiff:** I have images of her family members doing it.

**Judge:** What about the harassment, stalking, and defamation claims?

**Plaintiff:** I have images of her filming my storefront and walking past.

**Judge:** Pick your best video and show me.

**Defendant:** Your Honor, I don’t know where this hostility comes from. When I first moved in and rented a booth in 2016, I noticed Miss Johnson staring at me through the salon window for hours. I asked the salon owner about it, and she said there were already issues with her.

**Judge:** You call yourself a celebrity hairstylist. What does that mean?

**Defendant:** I work with celebrities, have been published in magazines, and have done hair for people on *Housewives* and *Love & Hip Hop*.

**Judge:** Who is the woman sitting with you?

**Defendant:** My mother. She has witnessed much of what has happened.

**Judge:** So what is your side of this?

**Defendant:** I ignore her, but she calls the police on me constantly, stopping me from working. The police never find any loud music.

**Judge:** How often has she called the police on you?

**Defendant:** Countless times. The police advised the salon owner to get a restraining order against her.

**Judge:** Why do you believe you’re entitled to $10,000 from her?

**Defendant:** She’s affected my business. In the past two months, I’ve been filming a reality show at my salon. Because of her police calls on October 25th and November 3rd, I had to move filming to other locations, costing me money.

**Judge:** Miss Johnson, this video of you filming her car—why were you doing that?

**Plaintiff:** I saw her leave and come back an hour later. I didn’t understand why, so I recorded it.

**Judge:** Miss Hassan, you’re in your car, and she’s filming you. What do you think?

**Defendant:** I don’t know why she does this. It feels like harassment.

**Judge:** Miss Johnson, why are you rolling up on her car and taking video?

**Plaintiff:** I wanted to document what was happening.

**Judge:** Do either of you sleep? According to you, Miss Johnson, you closed your business because of this drama?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, after I was physically assaulted by her and the prior owner’s daughter. I was injured—my wrist and knee. My patrons stopped coming because of the drama.

**Judge:** Did you have them arrested?

**Plaintiff:** The officer didn’t arrest them because Miss Hassan claimed she saw the fight, but video footage showed she wasn’t even there.

**Judge:** You both have stacks of letters from people taking sides. How do you expect me to determine who is at fault?

**Judge:** I believe in open access to the courts, but neither of you has presented clear proof. You have conflicting videos, police reports that led nowhere, and letters from neighbors picking sides. This is not something I can resolve in a court of law. I rule *zero* for you, Miss Johnson, and *zero* for you, Miss Hassan.

**Judge:** I suggest you both move forward and stop this feud. Wouldn’t it be great to focus on your businesses instead? Wipe the slate clean and let it go.

**Defendant:** I’m happy with the ruling and just want peace.

**Plaintiff:** I want peace too. We had peace before she moved in. I hope we can have it again.

**Judge:** Good luck to both of you. Case dismissed.
manipulation_techniques: deflection, minimization, exaggeration, playing the victim

dialogue:
Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands.

Judge: Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiff rented from the defendant, but there was a rodent problem, and when the plaintiff complained, the defendant kicked her out. The defendant says she hired an exterminator, so what's the problem? It’s the case of "La Cucaracha."

Judge: Thank you, Doug. You're welcome.

Judge: Okay, Noah, you are suing for half of the rent that you paid your landlord, Helen Pugmire, to be returned to you because, according to you, the living conditions were deplorable. You're also suing for a couch that you say she illegally threw out. When did you start living there?

Plaintiff: I started living there in August 2016.

Judge: With two roommates, right?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Okay. And you lived there until when? When was the last day that your roommates were going to live there?

Plaintiff: The end of August 2018.

Judge: And in fact, before that, was the end of your lease, right? Had you guys informed her that you weren't going to stay living there?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: You had told her, "We're out," and she got a new tenant, right?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And the new tenant was moving in on September 1st?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: So it's very clear that you're supposed to be out. And then what happens? You change your mind and decide you're going to stay?

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Judge: How were you going to stay when you had no roommates? What was your plan for paying the rent?

Plaintiff: I was going to find new roommates.

Judge: When do you tell her, "I'm staying"?

Plaintiff: A few days before we were supposed to move out.

Judge: When exactly?

Plaintiff: The 29th of August.

Judge: How did you tell her?

Plaintiff: I sent her an email.

Judge: Let me see the email. That’s not the 29th, is it? What date was it?

Plaintiff: I said around... I wasn’t sure.

Judge: It’s the 31st of August. It’s the day you're supposed to be moving out.

Plaintiff: Okay.

Judge: That’s the very day that your roommates are both moving out, right?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: It’s move-out day. Everybody's moving. That’s the day that you tell her, "I will not be vacating the premises or giving up the lease. There is no need for a walkthrough as I will not be returning the keys."

Judge: What was left behind in the apartment?

Defendant: A beat-up couch. Also, there was so much garbage in front of the house.

Judge: Let me see your pictures. Go ahead, you can give them to me. Who is the gentleman with you?

Defendant: My husband.

Judge: Oh, okay. So I see—what is that? What are these pieces of wood?

Defendant: Those are the couch’s wood frame. It’s all falling apart.

Judge: Someone moved the couch?

Defendant: No, it’s in there. It’s in another picture.

Judge: Yeah, it’s like broken. You see the spring on the back?

Defendant: That’s the couch.

Judge: Yeah, that thing was just laying there. And then this is a picture of what?

Defendant: The couch.

Judge: And some... a toaster oven that was left behind?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Where’s all your clothes? If you weren’t moving out, where’s all your clothes?

Plaintiff: I had some things that I left there, and some things—these pictures are taken on the first, so they were taken after she already removed a lot of my items.

Judge: Hold on one second. I know it’s not illegal. I can talk about it till the cows come home. In fact, I have to in order to know what was already ruled on there. Now, you filed a case where? In Housing Court?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And your allegation there was what?

Plaintiff: That I was illegally locked out.

Judge: And how was that case resolved?

Judge: You had a lawyer. Your lawyer told you, "Offer her a little money, and let's get this done and over with."

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Judge: There was a settlement for $200, right?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Because she claimed that she did not illegally lock you out, and you said—but there was a settlement. Is it correct that you settled that case for $200?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: You are suing because you want half of the rent for the 14 months that you lived there returned to you.

Judge: On the counterclaim for $500, I am also finding zero. First of all, you can’t ask for the stuff from Housing Court here. Second, I’m not going to award you $250 in legal fees because it was a close case.

Judge: That’s my verdict. Good luck, folks.

JUDGE: The defendant has filed a countersuit for $5,000 for pain and suffering and two air conditioning units. All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiff says the defendant tried to break his lease, but he is no chump. The defendant says he left because there was mold. It’s the case of 'You Break, You Pay.' Thank you, Doulas.

COURT OFFICER: You’re welcome.

JUDGE: Okay. Phil Qunel, you are suing Delton Carney and Mary Potenberg. You have power of attorney for Mary?

PLAINTIFF: Yes.

JUDGE: Okay. For $2,792.18 that you say you are owed in damages and rent. You have a counterclaim against him for $5,000 for pain and suffering and some AC units. Let me hear from you first.

PLAINTIFF: They rented my place out. She told me that she didn’t like rugs. I said, 'I’ll tell you what, if you want to extend the lease, I’d be happy to rip out the rugs.' I was texting her back and forth trying to, like, 'Hey, get a hold of me. I’m reaching out to you again.' And I never got correspondence. Like, 'Hey, yeah, let’s do this.' I kept calling her or texting her, and then that... so it just fizzles.

JUDGE: All right. And then what happens?

PLAINTIFF: Then I get a call, um, January-February time frame that, uh, 'We’re moving out.' And, uh, I said, 'Well, I’m willing to do that if I could rent it out.' And I was not able to rent it out when they left in March.

JUDGE: They left when?

PLAINTIFF: What day in March? They left, uh, March 31st.

JUDGE: And you did not pay? They did not pay March rent?

PLAINTIFF: They said you could use the security because we’re not going to get it back anyways.

JUDGE: Is that accurate? You didn’t pay March rent?

DEFENDANT: That’s accurate.

JUDGE: All right. That’s not what security deposit is for.

DEFENDANT: I know.

JUDGE: Well, there’s some risks involved when you did. So you’re suing now for late fees for March because you feel that you should have been paid March and then the issue of the security deposit would have been litigated, you know, at some other point if you could show damages, correct?

PLAINTIFF: Correct.

JUDGE: Right. Um, when did you re-rent it?

PLAINTIFF: I re-rented it the middle of April.

JUDGE: So your damage in terms of rent would be the two weeks in April that you weren’t getting rent, correct?

PLAINTIFF: Correct.

JUDGE: All right. Now, according to you, you didn’t even break the lease because the place was uninhabitable. Explain that to me.

DEFENDANT: Um, in March—March 1st—we told him that we were moving because my daughter got—has allergies. She had to go for surgery and all this.

JUDGE: Okay, hold on. Slow down. Your daughter has what kind of allergies?

DEFENDANT: Uh, well, she doesn’t have allergies, but she got sick from the mold from the excessive heat in the apartment.

JUDGE: I need some medical proof of what you’re saying.

DEFENDANT: Okay. I have that.

JUDGE: Because there was extensive heat in the apartment?

DEFENDANT: Extensive heat in the apartment. The apartment was over 100° all the time.

JUDGE: Why would you live there if it was over 100°?

DEFENDANT: This is what I’m saying. The thermostat in the apartment was broken.

JUDGE: Right.

DEFENDANT: I have pictures of that thermostat.

JUDGE: Right. Okay. You have some texts where you’re talking to them about the thermostat?

DEFENDANT: Right.

JUDGE: The thermostat is a $30, you know, it’s nothing. It’s solved in an instant. Why would you allow your child to get sick over something that—and I saw the text where he’s—is he texting? Are you texting him or her?

DEFENDANT: Her.

JUDGE: Let me see the copy of texts. I’m going to show it to you where he’s saying, 'Do you need me to change a thermostat?' Hello? Hello? I mean, if you have other texts you want me to see, show it to me. But it’s like, 'Hi Phil, is there a way to control the heat in here? It is way hot in here. Very hard to breathe even.' This is in October. He says, 'Sorry about that. There should be a control knob in the living room where the baseboard register is. Let me know if you can’t control the heat. We will get it fixed.'

DEFENDANT: Right.

JUDGE: So, a week later, 'Hey Marky, does the thermostat work or do we need to get it fixed? Also, I would like to discuss the flooring with you as in replacing the carpet or putting down something new, so when you get a chance, give me a call. We can talk about it.' No response. October 26, 'Hey, reaching out to you again. Give me a call when you can.' No response.

JUDGE: However, you have to prove that the condition was severe enough to render the apartment uninhabitable. A broken thermostat is not enough. You had a responsibility to get it fixed when the plaintiff reached out to you multiple times. Now, let’s address the mold issue.

DEFENDANT: Yes, Your Honor. I have medical records showing my daughter’s respiratory issues and a letter from her doctor stating that prolonged exposure to mold could have worsened her condition.

JUDGE: All right. Let me see those.

(Defendant hands documents to the judge.)

JUDGE: Hmm. The doctor’s note is very general. It does not say that the mold in your apartment specifically caused her illness, only that mold exposure can aggravate respiratory conditions. Do you have any inspection reports or evidence that the mold was severe and pervasive?

DEFENDANT: No, Your Honor. I didn’t get an official inspection. But I do have pictures of the mold we found behind the air conditioning units.

JUDGE: (Examines pictures) These show some discoloration, but I don’t see anything that would rise to the level of making the apartment uninhabitable. Did you report this to the landlord at any time before deciding to leave?

DEFENDANT: We mentioned it when we told him we were leaving.

JUDGE: That’s not how it works. If you had an issue, you needed to give the landlord a chance to address it before breaking the lease. Since you didn’t, you are responsible for the unpaid rent and damages.

DEFENDANT: But we were suffering in that place!

JUDGE: I understand, but legally, the burden of proof is on you. Based on the lease terms and lack of sufficient evidence for uninhabitability, I am ruling in favor of the plaintiff for the unpaid rent. However, I will not award the full amount requested for damages since the plaintiff was able to re-rent the unit fairly quickly.

PLAINTIFF: Thank you, Your Honor.

JUDGE: Judgment for the plaintiff in the amount of $2,078. Case dismissed.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hand.

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. I have no idea. Gloria Smith, you are suing Kevin’s company for $325 that you want because, according to you, their negligent landscaping damaged your window, correct?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: What happened?

Plaintiff: I was at work last year in April, and I got a call from my tenant. My tenant said she was hearing noise hitting the house. She went outside—she was on her way to work anyway—and all she saw was this big black cloud of smoke. She looked over and saw that they were blowing with some big industrial blower. As she was looking out the side of the house, she saw a neighbor on the other street behind us—whole another street. He was looking too and said, "Did they hit your house too?" They started talking because he got damage to his house and his vehicle.

Plaintiff: When she called me, I came home on lunch break.

Judge: She called you and said what, though? You didn’t say anything.

Plaintiff: She said there was damage to the house.

Judge: Well, what happened?

Plaintiff: She said she went off the porch after talking to the neighbor. When she came back, she noticed the window was cracked. I had a van in the yard at the time, and the van was full of debris and soot.

Judge: Do you have pictures of the cracked window?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: May I see them?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And pictures of the debris and soot on the van?

Plaintiff: No, because I didn’t really put in a claim for the van. It was an older van.

Judge: Do you have an affidavit from the tenant?

Plaintiff: No. I taped her just before I came because I wasn’t sure if I was coming today.

Judge: How am I going to cross-examine her today?

Plaintiff: Her tape explains what happened.

Judge: Are these those glass tiles? It’s like glass block, but they separate into little blocks, right?

Plaintiff: Yes, which I thought maybe they would fix one or two. But the guy who estimated said no, they have to redo the whole thing.

Judge: They’re all cracked?

Plaintiff: There’s one that’s missing, and then all the other ones are cracked.

Judge: How’d that happen?

Plaintiff: The one that’s missing is lying on the ground because whatever happened made it fall over.

Judge: But then what are those pieces of stuff that I see?

Plaintiff: Part of the soot and debris that was on—

Judge: No, no, but there’s also glass that I’m looking at here.

Plaintiff: I’m not sure. That’s just the look.

Judge: Was that cracked before, or are you suggesting that the blowing that day cracked all of it?

Plaintiff: I’m saying that when I came home, the blowing that day caused the glass to be on the ground. It damaged one of the glass blocks.

Judge: When was the last time you had been there?

Plaintiff: I park there every day. That’s the side of the house I park on.

Judge: So you live there as well?

Plaintiff: Yes, I live upstairs.

Judge: Let’s see what your tenant has to say.

(Audio recording plays)

Tenant: On my way to work, I walk outside. There is this big cloud—

Judge: Is she in bed while she’s talking to me?

(Audio continues)

Tenant: I peek around the corner, and I see in the parking lot they’re blowing with this big loud machine, blowing debris everywhere, all this trash. As I’m walking out of the driveway, I look and see the glass is broken. I’m assuming maybe some of the debris got on there. I don’t know.

Judge: This is your tenant?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: What is your theory? That their blower lifted something besides soot that broke your window? Because soot wouldn’t break your window.

Plaintiff: This is my theory. It wasn’t broken before—I park right there every day. I would have noticed.

Judge: Did you see a rock?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Did you take a picture of something that would be strong enough?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Did you take a picture of the debris near the window?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: That’s going to be a no. All right, Kevin, how long have you been doing landscaping?

Defendant: We’ve been doing winter services and landscaping for five seasons.

Judge: So you were not physically out there that day?

Defendant: No, but I oversee the work.

Judge: Did you go to the property after hearing about the damage?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: What did you conclude?

Defendant: Our equipment couldn’t have caused the damage.

Judge: How far was your blower from the window?

Defendant: 30 to 40 feet.

Judge: That’s a big distance for a blower to send a rock flying. You have zero evidence, Ms. Smith. My verdict is for the defendant.

Plaintiff: That’s okay. God knows the truth.

Judge: All parties, please be seated. Thank you, Douglas. All right, Ms. Wagan, you are suing Ms. Pigage for $3,000 that you believe she owes you for malnourishing and abusing your horse. Tell me what’s going on.

Plaintiff: Back in October of 2015, I entered into a free lease with Dana and her husband. They had come to my house the first week of October to look at our horse. They agreed that they liked it; they wanted to lease it. It was a free lease—no money was involved.

Judge: So you basically leased the horse to them, and they had to take care of the horse for that amount of time, correct? Do you have a written contract with them?

Plaintiff: I do.

Judge: Let me see. Who’s the rider?

Plaintiff: Our daughter—well, my daughter.

Judge: And how old is your daughter?

Plaintiff: Thirteen.

Judge: Okay, so go ahead. What happens?

Plaintiff: In the beginning, I would go over and check on the horse, you know, the first few weeks. I would ride by once a week, and then—

Judge: How far were they from you?

Plaintiff: About eight miles away. So, you know, as time went on, we’d check on them a little less. Then it got to where I’d just go by the house maybe if I was going grocery shopping. And, you know, the first year everything went great. Last July, I had knee surgery, so I hadn’t been by the house for at least a couple of months. I couldn’t drive for six weeks. Then, um, I would say it was the end of August, early September, John had stopped by our house and said they were thinking about not using the horse anymore. That, um, the daughter wasn’t riding much and was thinking about bringing it back. So we had told him, you know, that’s fine. He asked me again if we could pick the horse up, and I said, ‘Well, I still don’t have a trailer to come get him.’ I said, ‘But you can bring him back anytime. We don’t have to be home. You can just put him in the field, and I’ll see them when I go out to feed.’ So, I didn’t hear from them. And then it was January 16th, I went by with a friend because, actually, she had a trailer and said her daughter would be interested in riding. I said, ‘Well, I think these people are done with the horse. If you can get it back to my house, your daughter can come over and ride.’ So we stopped over to look at him, and he was just skin and bones.

Judge: What’s the horse’s name?

Plaintiff: Cowboy Democracy. And he was about 400 pounds underweight. I do have photos. I brought photos of before and after.

Judge: Hold on. Who is riding?

Plaintiff: That’s—that’s me. And you can just see, he’s got a big chest. He’s not a super tall horse but a typical quarter horse, very healthy there.

Judge: What’s that?

Plaintiff: That’s a photo of the empty trash can that John—the night I found the horse and we got him back to our house. Because even though I didn’t have a trailer that was tagged or had registrations, I came home hysterical. My husband put on his shoes and said, ‘Well, go get him.’ He said, ‘I’ll drive slow.’ So we rode over and got him.

Judge: Wait, wait. Who did you talk to about getting him and everything else?

Plaintiff: Nobody. I just saw the condition and just went and got him. He wasn’t staying there.

Judge: Did you know that she was getting the horse?

Defendant: No, I knew nothing.

Judge: And how did you find out?

Defendant: I came home. I had left the house probably around 3:00 that day, went to the mall with my children. I came home probably around 5:00, and when I came home, Cowboy was gone.

Judge: So when did you get the pictures?

Defendant: I got these pictures two days after I had brought the horse home.

Judge: So you didn’t get the pictures until January?

Defendant: I didn’t get them until January.

Judge: Who got them instead of you?

Defendant: Her husband’s lawyer. He sent them to his lawyer—his divorce lawyer—because the night I got the horse—

Judge: Fighting you for custody?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: So the premise is, if you can’t take care of a horse, you can’t take care of a kid? How old is the kid you have in common?

Defendant: Six years old.

Judge: But he didn’t send them to her, correct?

Defendant: Well, I don’t know. According to her, she got them and was told in September—

Judge: I’ve seen enough. Based on my calculations, my judgment is in the plaintiff’s favor in the amount of $1,045. Court is adjourned.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People's Court. The next case on the docket—the plaintiff says her mechanic screwed up her Mercedes something fierce, with black smoke billowing out of the tailpipe. The defendant says her problem was a burnt-out fuel pump, which had nothing to do with what he fixed. It’s the case of You Failed, Mateo.

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Kimberly Holland, you’re suing John’s Auto Body Repair Shop for $999.81, which you say he owes you in tow fees and parts and labor that he charged you because, according to you, he didn’t fix your car.

Judge: You are counterclaiming against her for $400 for a tow, diagnostic fees, and some other parts and labor that you had previously given her. But now she’s mad she sued you, and now you want to get paid?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Okay, let’s talk with you first. Tell me exactly what was wrong with your car that you brought it to him.

Plaintiff: I found out that I had oil in my antifreeze.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: At the time, my car was running perfectly fine. It was just that I was told that the antifreeze can cause further damage and that it can become a larger problem than it was.

Judge: So, you take it to him. Does he look at it himself, or did you have an employee do it?

Defendant: Yes, I looked at it myself.

Judge: And what did you note?

Defendant: When I saw the car come in, there was oil in the antifreeze, but after further testing of the vehicle, I noticed that it was actually trans oil in the antifreeze. That was one of the problems she had on the vehicle.

Judge: And that problem cost her how much to fix?

Defendant: Well, I fixed that problem. But besides that problem, when she first brought the vehicle into the shop, she filled out a work order. On the work order, it said oil in the antifreeze, a slow pickup, the check engine light was on, the fuel gauge wasn’t working, and there was a smell of gas.

Judge: May I see that? Didn’t you just tell me there was nothing wrong with the car when you brought it to him?

Plaintiff: As I was explaining, none of those things were keeping my car from running. My car, in all the years that I had it, had never turned off on me—ever.

Judge: So now what happens? He has the car for how long?

Plaintiff: Altogether, about a week before I picked it up the first time.

Judge: Okay, and so you pick it up, and what happens?

Plaintiff: The next morning, I go to turn the car on, and it would not turn over. After trying it for like 10 minutes, I finally called the shop. He agreed to send someone to pick the car up. He said he knew a tow truck company that works with them and he’d send them over.

Judge: So he tows the car over. And what happens?

Plaintiff: He tows the car over, and literally about two hours later, I get a call from someone else at the shop. They say, “Oh, the car just turned over for me.” I was able to get the car running, and I asked, “Well, what was the issue?” He said, “I don’t know. It could have been spark plugs. It could have been something. But the car is running, come pick up your car.”

Plaintiff: I get a ride over there, pick up my car, bring it home, and park it. That was a Sunday. Monday, I drove it to work and back. I went to a gas station, turned the car off to get gas. When I went to turn it back on, it wouldn’t start. I then contacted my insurance and got a tow truck to bring it back to the shop. It was there for maybe a day or so before they finally called me back and explained to me that it was something about an O2 sensor. Ultimately, I decided I didn’t want them to do the work any longer.

Judge: So what he told you was that you needed an O2 sensor?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: He didn’t say anything about a fuel pump?

Plaintiff: I don’t believe he ever said anything about a fuel pump.

Judge: So you take it to another mechanic, and that mechanic tells you that you have a burnt fuel pump?

Plaintiff: Correct. Yes. He actually showed it to me.

Judge: But did they burn your fuel pump, or was it just that you were driving a 2007 Mercedes and things go wrong over time?

Plaintiff: I understand that, but from the time I paid him, the car never worked properly.

Judge: Let’s get to the counterclaim. You’re suing for $400 for diagnosing the car and two tows. But you weren’t initially charging her for that, correct?

Defendant: Yes, your Honor. But I spent hours diagnosing the car, and she sued me.

Judge: But there was no contract for those fees. I’m dismissing your counterclaim.

Judge: As for your claim, Ms. Holland, there is zero evidence that the defendant burned your fuel pump. Judgment in favor of the defendant. Case dismissed.
manipulation_techniques: Evasion, deflection, gaslighting,  playing the victim

dialogue:
Judge: All parties please raise your hands. Welcome back to the People's Court. Next case on the docket, the plaintiff says the defendant stiffed him on returning his security deposit and his life literally crumbled, but the defendant says the guy moved out in the middle of the night without giving notice. It's the case of "You Ruined My So-Called Life."
Judge: Thank you. Welcome John Shanesy.
Plaintiff: Yes.
Judge: You are suing Michael Biancardi, your former landlord for $5,000. You say that you are out substantially more than that as a result of him not returning a security deposit. Okay, you find out about his place how?
Plaintiff: Craigslist.
Judge: Craigslist. All right and you moved from where?
Plaintiff: I had moved back in from Colorado back in the late of 2009.
Judge: Okay, and how much security deposit did you pay him?
Plaintiff: $520 plus also a week's rent would be $650.
Judge: Okay but why are you suing for $657 in security deposit if your security deposit was only 520?
Plaintiff: The other one, the rest of that was the week's rent.
Judge: Was a week's rent included into the rental?
Plaintiff: No.
Judge: I understand but you lived there that week right? That was your rent?
Plaintiff: Okay.
Judge: All right, so I've got it. All right so then what happens? You lived there from 2009 until... Are you living with him?
Plaintiff: No, I'm not. I moved out on Fe... No, I'm sorry.
Judge: I mean when you moved in in 2009, are you actually a roommate of his?
Plaintiff: No, I was living upstairs and in a room.
Judge: And he's living where?
Plaintiff: Downstairs.
Judge: All right but it's... is it one a one family place? What is it?
Plaintiff: Yeah, it's a one family dwelling. It's an entrance into the back of the house and you come in and you walk up a set of stairs and it was two rooms upstairs in the second portion of the house.
Judge: And so he rented one to you, one to somebody else?
Plaintiff: Yes.
Judge: All right and then what happens?
Plaintiff: Well basically I was living there for a period of time itself. I had then gotten another opportunity for possibly getting the job. Unfortunately at the time financially wise I couldn't do anything with it so I lost that one particular job but then what ended up happening was Your Honor is September 23rd, 2011, my boss, my ex-boss had committed suicide.
Judge: Sorry to hear that.
Plaintiff: Okay, what ended up happening was is that his wife instructed me then at the time that she needed to as far as sell all her vehicles and her buses itself and she would be closing up the business. So we had from the end of September after burying Mr. Matini to the end of the physical year of 2011 to get rid of all of her vehicles, which we did.
Judge: What does that mean in terms of what were you doing for a living?
Plaintiff: I was working for her running her business itself as far as bus limousine business.
Judge: Oh so that happens and now you have no job?
Plaintiff: At the end of this, at the end of the physical year of 2011, December, the end of December basically I would have no job.
Judge: All right but just let me ask you a question. At some point you decide that you want to move out. How much notice does the lease, does the agreement require?
Plaintiff: Three weeks.
Judge: And you weren't giving him the 3 weeks notice correct?
Plaintiff: What happened was is that on February 29th there was a Sunday, I had turned around and I had moved out.
Judge: All right, now what I want to know is you didn't give him notice and you know that you... Let me see what he signed originally. Did you sign something that talked about notice and you know that it says notice so tell me your reason on why it is he can't keep it as a breach?
Plaintiff: I had spoken with my attorney and my attorney said to me that he directed me to go to as far as the township of Babylon to find out whether or not as far as this dwelling was legal or not. And I found out from the Town of Babylon that it was not legal. He always wanted cash payments for me, never gave me a receipt for any type of rent whatsoever.
Judge: All right, let me hear your response to that.
Defendant: He asked if I would take a check. I said no, I don't accept checks, only cash because checks do bounce.
Judge: Did you think that's what I was asking? I was asking about whether the place is legal, legal to rent out.
Defendant: Well now I found out that it's not legal.
Judge: What do you mean now you found out?
Defendant: I read in a handbook a state law indicating that you're allowed to have a maximum of four borders unrelated. So I assumed that I was doing okay. Now that I got a summons I'm aware that I wasn't allowed to do it.
Judge: Okay, what are you allowed to do instead?
Defendant: Nothing.
Judge: Nothing? Can't you... can't rent?
Judge: Why won't you return his security deposit if you can't keep it for rent? What happened? You have a counterclaim against for $695, $100 is for cleaning fee. What is it that was unclean when he left?
Defendant: All right, he left a large TV I couldn't budge it. I had to have someone come in.
Judge: Why'd you leave a TV behind?
Plaintiff: I left the TV behind Your Honor because I had no room in my vehicle to take it.
Judge: Well that's not his problem, that's your problem. Okay, go on.
Defendant: There were bowling balls that were very heavy I couldn't pick up.
Judge: Did you leave bowling balls?
Plaintiff: I think I may have left one in the bill in the couple.
Defendant: And I had to get someone to come up, straighten the room out and remove all the items.
Judge: Now according to your lease you're entitled to keep a $100 for that trouble?
Defendant: Yes.
Judge: All right, now let me ask you about the other thing. You're claiming against a security deposit is two weeks rent and you can't do that because if it's not legal to rent out, you can't ask me to enforce and help you to get rent that's illegal for you to collect. That's like, you know, he buys cocaine from you and the cocaine's not good quality so you come to court and ask the judge to 'well he ripped me off so I was... I want some of my cocaine money.' But you know when something is illegal we don't allow you to use us as a court system to help you... put your hand down... to help you to get money you're not entitled to get, right?
Judge: But now let's talk about the cost to repair and paint ceiling. Why is that on your tenant? What happened?
Defendant: I told him I was very reluctant that he could have an air conditioner and I told him I wanted him to sign a document that if the air conditioner should cause any type of damage whatsoever you could be responsible.
Judge: Did the air conditioner cause damage?
Defendant: Yes.
Judge: What damage?
Defendant: The ceiling is all stained that it was probably leaking from the air condition.
Judge: Did you ever bring that to his attention before he moved out?
Defendant: I didn't know it.
Judge: How did... when did you find it out?
Defendant: When he left. The next day I just start looking around and I spotted it. I wasn't aware of it.
Judge: And you have pictures of it?
Defendant: Yes, you are.
Judge: And what room is... is that?
Defendant: That would be my kitchen.
Judge: And his bedroom is right over that? Is that where the AC was in his bedroom?
Defendant: Yes.
Judge: But how's that $325?
Defendant: There was one spot they had to cut out and they had to put a piece of...
Judge: Let me see the proof that you paid $325. How do I know that this is from damage from the AC leaking as opposed to that you just had a pipe issue?
Defendant: Well there are no pipes in that area and the roof and the siding was done maybe a little over three years ago.
Judge: What say you about the whole air conditioning thing because you did sign something that said that any... any...
Plaintiff: I have the pictures here Your Honor of the room itself taken and you'll see the air conditioner was purchased in May of 2011, was a brand new addition. It's in that box right there that I was going to take with me. Unfortunately I had no more room left in my vehicle to take it and that's the pictures of the way I left the place, very clean and spotless. And where you see the TV was the windows where that air conditioner was placed in back in the end of May of 2011 and it was removed in the end of August of 2011, put into... it was put onto a tarp and I made sure that all the water and condensation was out of the air conditioner. I turned around put it back into its original box and sealed in plastic and all put it into the closet. That was the last actual item that I was going to take but I had no more room in my vehicle.
Judge: Okay, now how do you manage to turn a $520 security deposit case into $5,000? Would you ever find a roommate through Craigslist?
Plaintiff: Absolutely not.
Judge: You never know who you're going to meet. I got it. Didn't someone get killed... several... what do you think? Not a chance I would never take a roommate through Craigslist... all single white female. Going inside the courtroom, what happened?
Plaintiff: What happened was is that when I had gone to the Township of Babylon and I explained to everything that happened, okay, I also said to her that I also lost a job and I do have a letter here from that employer that is telling you that he did offer me a job and then under my financial circumstances that I couldn't take the job because of the security money.
Judge: Okay but why... why would you not be able to take a job over security not being returned to you? First of all, security doesn't have to be returned to you in the spot, it could be returned to you within 30 days. So why would that have any bearing on whether you take the job? Why don't you just take the job?
Plaintiff: The situation was Your Honor is I didn't have enough money to travel.
Judge: That's to travel where? Where was the job?
Plaintiff: They had a position for me either in Virginia...
Judge: Okay.
Plaintiff: Or in California and I didn't have the funds to travel.
Judge: Okay, I know but how does that mean he's got to pay you $10,000? I mean I'm sorry that you're going through financial difficulty, these are tough times for a lot of people, it sounds like you're doing what you can, hopefully there will be rosier skies ahead. Okay, but my question to you is how does that mean he has to pay you $110,000? I mean if you if you don't even have the $200 it'll take you to get to the city to get the job that's on him so he has to pay you $10,000 that you can't...
Plaintiff: I understand what you're saying.
Judge: You just angry?
Plaintiff: I'm very distressed of this whole matter.
Judge: All right, your security deposit is $520 not $657. You're not entitled to $10,000 extra dollars for loss of income because of the job situation. You're entitled to keep the $100 for cleaning based on the testimony I've heard. You're not entitled to deduct anything... now we're done... you're not entitled to deduct anything for rent because you're not entitled to charge rent and I find that you have not adequately proven to me that the whatever repair you had to do was due to the air conditioner. The way that people prove that to me is that here where this is all listed it would say 'leak due to faulty air conditioning' or something. So you... you have to bring me something that proves to me that it's due to the AC and you haven't done that so I'm not going to allow you to deduct anything for the AC. That means that I'm ordering you to return $420. That's the 520 security deposit minus the $100 cleaning fee that you basically admitted you... you had violated that clause. So I find in favor of the plaintiff in this case in the amount of $420 plus prejudgment statutory interest plus your court costs. Okay on your counter claim zero other than the 100 that I'm letting you keep.
manipulation_techniques: plaing the victim, guilt tripping, exaggeration

dialogue:
udge: Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiff helped the defendant find two kittens, and the defendant won’t pay the adoption fee. But the defendant says there was never an adoption fee agreement. It’s the case of kitty galore.

Bailiff: You're welcome.

Judge: Okay, Mary Chirichella, you are suing Here Kitty Kitty Incorporated, represented here by Leslie Diamond. You’re the president?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Okay, for $180, the amount that you say they owe you as an adoption fee for two kittens, right? That they received and kept rather than giving you the adoption fee?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: All right, so tell me what’s going on.

Plaintiff: Okay, in July of [year], I rescued two tortoiseshell kittens—

Judge: Where did you rescue them from?

Plaintiff: From a street in a busy area.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: They were about 10 to 12 weeks old. It was a location where I’d been doing cat rescue for 12 years. I had been feeding there and had seen the kittens before.

A friend of mine, Eileen, agreed to foster them. I provided the food and litter. Eileen took care of them daily. I created a flyer for Natasha and Nadia, my phone number was on it, and Eileen and I posted it in various locations.

It was a slow summer. The economic crisis was in full swing, and I wasn’t getting calls I was happy with.

Judge: What kind of donation were you looking for?

Plaintiff: Originally, just to cover my costs.

Judge: How much was that?

Plaintiff: At the time, I would have taken $75 for them.

Judge: For each or both?

Plaintiff: For both. At that point, they had only one vet visit, which cost $131.

Judge: Okay, so what happens next?

Plaintiff: When Eileen took the kittens to the vet, someone there suggested she take them to Petco on Route 3. Miss Diamond’s group, Here Kitty Kitty, showed cats for adoption there on weekends.

Judge: Do you work for Petco?

Defendant: No, but we show our cats there. I’ve been doing rescue for 20 years. Here Kitty Kitty will celebrate its 9th anniversary in September.

Judge: Okay, so what happens next?

Plaintiff: Eileen brought them to Petco and left them with her. Eventually, someone completed an adoption application. I spoke with the adopter and then with Leslie. I asked, "What is the adoption fee?" She said, "$180."

I told her I would need that fee to cover my costs. She asked how much I had spent. I said a few hundred dollars. She said, "I can’t give you that." I replied, "I don’t expect you to, but I will need the adoption fee."

Defendant: Nobody talked about an adoption fee before this.

Judge: Is that true?

Defendant: Mary knew our adoption fee. Because the adopters were in their 60s, we have a program sponsored by Purina that covers the adoption fee.

Mary only brought up the adoption fee after the adoption. In all my years doing this, I sometimes split the fee with someone or write a tax letter.

Judge: So the cats were adopted, and then what?

Plaintiff: Leslie agreed to mail me the adoption fee but said I’d have to wait for the money from Purina. I said that was fine. A few months went by, and I started to suspect something was wrong.

Now we’re into our second week, and we’re going into the third week.

Judge: Okay, but I don’t have a bunch of weeks to go through. What’s the problem?

Plaintiff: Because you guys haven’t paid, so I want to know what the problem is.

Defendant: Once we got the laptop, the keys were sticking. The battery would die immediately. The laptop wasn’t working properly. One of the requirements we had for the new laptop was for her data to be there, and it had to be compatible with her schooling at the University of Phoenix.

Judge: What do you mean compatible?

Defendant: Some of the programs you need to download from the University of Phoenix require certain software, like Adobe or Java. She couldn’t download it. We just needed the laptop to work for her schoolwork.

Judge: So it didn’t work as required?

Defendant: No, it didn’t work. And when I tried to do the schoolwork, I wasn’t able to. Some of the files weren’t there when I turned the laptop on.

Judge: Were your pictures there?

Defendant: Not all of them.

Judge: How many thousands were there that you otherwise wouldn’t have had?

Defendant: I don’t know how many I had on there, but I know that…

Judge: Why would that justify not paying at all? You got the information back, even if the computer’s broken.

Defendant: I never spoke to him about paying for anything. I told Curtis, "Please handle this for me."

Judge: How many weeks did it take for you to get the laptop back?

Defendant: About two or three weeks.

Plaintiff: And it got to the point where people from your company came to me and were like, "What happened?"

Defendant: Exactly. People are walking up to me, saying, "Hey, I need a computer."

Plaintiff: I mean, it got to the point where I became very humiliated.

Judge: So why did you pay zero for the retrieval?

Defendant: Well, we actually told Curtis we wanted to give the laptop to another company to get her data transferred, and we were going to buy a new one. We were sorry.

Plaintiff: But you didn’t pay the $50 for the transfer of the files.

Defendant: No. I paid someone $50 to just copy the files.

Judge: And yet you don’t want to pay me for extracting the data from a broken laptop, which actually took some talent.

Defendant: It’s inexplicable.

Plaintiff: I did the work. I got your daughter’s data back.

Defendant: We had a different company transfer the files. I had to pay $50 for that.

Judge: Now you are upset and have a counterclaim against him. What’s that about?

Defendant: I want my original broken laptop back.

Judge: Did you not tell him you didn’t need the broken laptop anymore?

Defendant: No. He didn’t want it. He said it was junk. I could keep it.

Plaintiff: Right. I fixed it because he said he didn’t want it. It was of no use to me, so I kept it.

Defendant: You didn’t give it back!

Judge: Okay. I’m finding it a little hard to believe he agreed to $50 for this work when you paid someone $50 to just copy files.

Plaintiff: He has no proof of that.

Judge: I’m ordering them to pay you for extracting the files you successfully retrieved and for the software that was used. For your services, I’ll award you $125. As for your counterclaim, I find it baseless. I dismiss it.

Judge: This case is adjourned.
