dialogue:
Judge: When’s the last time you two were intimate?
Defendant: It’s been a long time, Your Honor.
Judge: Define ‘a long time.’ Be specific.
Defendant: About September. That was the last time. I promise.
Judge: So, you’re absolutely sure that’s the truth?
Defendant: Yes, Your Honor.
Judge: If that’s true, would you consent to a lie detector test to confirm?
Defendant: No, Your Honor, I won’t.
Judge: Why not? If you’re telling the truth, what’s the harm?
Defendant: I just don’t want to. That’s all.

Judge: So, Ms. Lema, after everything that’s happened, who do you want to be the father of your child? Mr. Scott or Mr. Anderson?

Plaintiff: I want Mr. Anderson to be the father. He is more stable, Your Honor. He’s got his life together. I feel like he’s the one who can provide a better future for my child.

Defendant: Wait, what?

Plaintiff: You know, Mr. Anderson, you have a family. You have children. You’ve got everything together. And I... I just want my child to have a stable life. You’re the one that can give that to her.

Judge: So you’re saying you want Mr. Anderson to be the father because you think he’s more financially and emotionally stable?

Plaintiff: Yes, Your Honor. I know it’s a lot to ask, but he’s the one who can offer a better life for my baby. And I need that stability for her.

Judge: So, are you making this decision for the well-being of your child, or is this about your own desires and circumstances?

Plaintiff: It’s for my baby, Your Honor. I just want what’s best for her, and I know that’s you.

Defendant: I didn’t ask for this! Why are you bringing me into this now?

Plaintiff: I just know you’re the right one... You’re the one who can give her everything.

Judge: Because you’re not around the kids that much?
Plaintiff: I am around, I just, I just have to work all the time as a nurse and it's not my fault that, you know, saving lives isn't important to him.
Judge: No, I believe it is important to him. I don't think that's what he's saying. He's saying that you're not contributing anything.
Plaintiff: I mean, I am though, like, I feed them. Or sometimes I feed them.
Judge: You'd agree with me that that's your responsibility, right?
Plaintiff: I don't, I don't get home until like midnight, and I mean, I don't really see why it's a problem that my mother, you know, the grandmother of my child, has to look after them.
Defendant: Well, because I'm not the one that got pregnant on prom night. You wouldn't be having this problem, okay? That wasn't my decision, okay?
Plaintiff: But you're my mother, right? So I want you. You always said you wanted a grandchild.
Defendant: Yes, I wanted a grandchild, but it would have been nice if you would have got married first and had someone to share the responsibility with, not me. You know I can't, I can't do it by myself though.
Plaintiff: You're not doing it by yourself. I'm trying to provide money.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hand. Be seated. Come to order, please. Plaintiffs have been sworn. Thank you, Douglas. Angelique Taylor and Jasmine Taylor, you're suing Amanda Camo and Harold Camo Jr. for $625. Why are you sitting down relaxing and leaving? Get up there and stand. You're being sued. It's not like you're a witness. All right. You're suing them for $625—a deposit that you placed on a car, and you were never able to get the car. Tell me what's going on.

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): Okay, so my daughter got her license—

Judge: And how old are you?

Plaintiff (Jasmine Taylor): 17.

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): She was excited about getting her first car, so she did the process of looking up a car. She found a car that she was interested in on Letgo.

Judge: On the website Letgo or the app?

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): Yes, the app Letgo. The defendant was listing the car for $1,625. So my daughter was interested. They had text messages back and forth about the car. We were supposed to go meet the defendant on November 12 to make arrangements to look at the car to see if my daughter liked it. If she liked it, we would leave a deposit on the car for them to take the car off Letgo as sold. So, on November 12, my daughter and I made arrangements with the defendants to go see the car.

Judge: Which defendant did you make arrangements with—the man or the woman?

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): My daughter made the arrangements—

Judge: Who did you talk to? The man or the woman?

Plaintiff (Jasmine Taylor): The man.

Judge: Now, you two—your relationship is what?

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): Sister and brother.

Judge: Okay, so go ahead.

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): We were supposed to meet them on the 12th around 9:00 in the morning to go see the car. My daughter and I proceeded to go to the location, the house at the address they gave us, to see the car. So Harold proceeded to write up a contract for my daughter and Amanda.

Judge: For your daughter and Amanda? Whose car is it?

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): Harold listed the car as his sister's, but he was representing his sister as a salesperson.

Judge: Who is the registered owner of that car?

Defendant (Amanda Camo): My baby's father.

Judge: But it's your car?

Defendant (Amanda Camo): Well, no, it's—it's not. The registered owner is my baby's father, so it's not my car if I'm not the title owner.

Judge: Unless he signed it over to you?

Defendant (Amanda Camo): To be honest with you, we were in the process of doing that. But I have three kids, and the car was no longer useful for me. I can't fit three car seats. So we didn't even get that far. I got to drive the car for only a few months.

Judge: Are you with him or not with him?

Defendant (Amanda Camo): I am.

Judge: You are with him?

Defendant (Amanda Camo): Yes, I am.

Judge: Okay, so go ahead. What happened?

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): So he proceeded to write up a contract for my daughter and Amanda.

Judge: Did both of them sign it?

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): Yes, they did.

Judge: Does anybody have a copy of it?

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): I do.

Judge: Okay, go ahead.

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): We proceeded to leave the $625 deposit.

Judge: All right. So the arrangement is that you left $625 as a deposit. The car is sold, then there will be two additional payments of $500 each. The car is being sold as-is. November 26 is a $500 payment, and it just says "10th," but I presume that's December 10th?

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): Yes.

Judge: Okay. So, as of December 10th, the car will be paid in full. Hooray! I've got my first car. What happened?

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): My daughter was very excited that she was going to get her car. She called her grandmother to let her grandmother know about the arrangements for the car. Her grandmother decided that she would give us the remaining $1,000 to pay off the car so that my daughter could receive the car sooner than planned. That same day, I proceeded and I called Harold and I let him know. I said, "Listen, my daughter's grandmother decided to give us the rest of the remaining money, and we would like to get the car sooner than what was arranged." So we agreed that we would give them the two weeks until the next payment was due, which was November 26th.

Judge: So what happened on the 26th?

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): I texted Harold at 9:17 AM and said, "Good morning, just wanted to make sure all's good to pick up the car on Monday. I hope you had a happy Thanksgiving." No answer. On the 26th, I tried texting again to make sure that everything was okay with the arrangements. Nothing—no response.

Judge: So you never hear from them again?

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): I didn't hear from him again until later that day when he texted me and said, "I will call you around 7:00 PM, I promise."

Judge: And did he?

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): No.

Judge: So what did you do next?

Plaintiff (Angelique Taylor): I kept reaching out. No response. At that point, we realized we were not getting the car. I asked for a refund. They refused.

Judge: Amanda, why didn't you return the money?

Defendant (Amanda Camo): They backed out of the deal. We held the car for weeks. That deposit was to secure it.

Judge: But they tried to pay in full early. Why didn't you deliver the car then?

Defendant (Amanda Camo): There were complications with the title transfer.

Judge: So you couldn’t legally sell the car at that point?

Defendant (Amanda Camo): Not yet.

Judge: Then you owe them the money.

Judge: Ms. Moritz, Mr. Wilkinson has been a kind of handyman for you throughout many years. You say that you requested from him this time to come and do some work on a rental cottage that you own, correct?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: All right. And you had a certain amount to spend, so it had to be within that budget?

Plaintiff: That's correct, yes.

Judge: All right. So tell me what issues you had in the rental cottage this time.

Plaintiff: There were two things. One was a chimney repair, and one was a window replacement.

Judge: And what kind of repair did the chimney need?

Plaintiff: As it turned out, it needed a repair to the concrete cap on top of the chimney, and then there would be a metal rain cap or whatever on top of that.

Judge: Okay. So what work did you do? Because at some point, you hired him in August, correct?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And then you got sick right after that?

Defendant: Actually, it goes just a few months before that. In February, I got diagnosed with a kidney problem. They had to take the kidney, and I recovered from that within a month. And I was back on the job doing an annex to the property that she rents.

Judge: Okay, but did something happen with your health that delayed this job? Because she didn’t ask for her money back until four months later.

Defendant: Well, in September, they had me back in for tests, and they had to take a bladder and a prostate and a few other parts.

Judge: Oh, I’m so sorry to hear that. How are you doing now?

Defendant: I’m fine. You know, this thing on my head is surgery for skin cancer, so I think they got it all this time. But it has nothing to do with our relationship.

Judge: I understand. But that’s what caused her to say, Can I have my money back? It’s been four months.

Defendant: And I totally understand. Except I did spend some time and resources preliminary to all of this. And when I finally did recover from that, I brought the window to get that going, and she decided she didn’t want the window anymore.

Judge: When did you order the window?

Defendant: Well, the window wasn’t delivered until October.

Judge: That wasn’t my question. When did you order it?

Defendant: September.

Judge: Do you have proof that you ordered it in September?

Defendant: Just a conversation with the special order guy. I don’t have a piece of paper.

Judge: All right. It becomes relevant because she’s upset because she says that she called you on what day?

Plaintiff: I called the first week in October. I did not note that in my calendar. And I called again a second time, and I did note that in my calendar as part of my portfolio of evidence.

Judge: Right. You know what’s a much better thing to do? Either text or email so that there’s actually a record of when the call happened.

Defendant: I don’t do either.

Judge: I know. God bless.

Defendant: Sorry.

Judge: No, no. I’m so jealous. Totally jealous.

Plaintiff: Anyway, when he came on the 1st of November with the window after I had called and I had not heard back from him, I said, But John, I canceled the window.

Defendant: He said, Oh, you can’t cancel the window. This is a special order. They don’t let you.

Judge: Let me see what you do have from the window company.

Plaintiff: I believe that says October 13th.

Judge: And I called the day before.

Defendant: Prove that.

Judge: And you can’t prove it.

Plaintiff: I know.

Judge: Because otherwise, people could always say that, right? It’s a he-said-she-said situation.

Judge: Did you ever get a call from her where she was canceling the window?

Defendant: Not that I recall, but I was laid up at the time, and my daughters were supposed to be answering my calls for me.

Judge: All right. So you had originally asked for your $700 back because, from your perspective, he’s done nothing, right?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And he said at that time, I will pay you back the $700.

Plaintiff: Right.

Judge: So that’s what was happening. And then what happened? Why didn’t you pay her back the $700?

Defendant: Okay. I originally said I’d pay back $300, not thinking about the fact that I’d already invested a significant amount of time.

Judge: What did you invest a significant amount of time doing that has a value to her?

Defendant: Okay. I’m not here to ask for $700 to keep. She is entitled to some money. My problem is I can’t do anything about the window. I’d hate to have to eat the window.

Judge: No, you’re not going to eat the window.

Defendant: And I’d hate to have to lose my ladder, which is being held hostage.

Judge: Where is his ladder, and how is it being held hostage?

Defendant: Well, I have to pay her before I can get the ladder back.

Judge: Is that what she told you?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Did you say that to him?

Plaintiff: No, I didn’t say that. In the letter I wrote to him—

Judge: Did you say anything that sounded like that?

Plaintiff: I don’t, I don’t, I don’t—

Judge: If you ever want to see your ladder alive again, you better pay me my money?

Plaintiff: No, I didn’t say anything like that.

Judge: She doesn’t strike me as that type of person, I gotta tell you.

Defendant: But if I went to pick up the ladder, I was convinced that I was going to hear about giving all this money back.

Judge: The issue then is: What work did you do that entitles you to keep $700 or any portion of it?

Defendant: I climbed up on the roof, filled in holes with foam so squirrels and bats wouldn’t eat through them. I fixed a short in the light, and I sealed the chimney.

Judge: I’ve heard enough. You can’t prove you canceled the window in time. So the window is yours.

For the few odds and ends that he did, he’s entitled to keep something, but not $700.

I am ordering him to return to you $600. Verdict for the plaintiff.

JUDGE: This is the plaintiff Ena Puit. She says she moved out of an apartment she'd been renting from the defendants for close to four years, did a walkthrough with them, and is now having a devil of a time collecting all of her security. When she questioned the co-defendant, he said he had to check with his wife about things and would get back to her. Well, he never did, so she's suing for the remaining $1,367. She most definitely deserves it.

These are the defendants, John and Christy Schaer. They say there were considerable problems when they did the walkthrough with the plaintiff, and they were being nice, refunding more than half the lady’s security. The fact that she’s suing them here today is laughable because they spent more money than they withheld to get the place even rentable again. They’re accused of doing a lady wrong.

All parties please raise your right hand.

Welcome back to the People’s Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiff rented from the defendant for four years but isn’t getting her security back and says it’s because the defendant is afraid of his wife. But the defendants say they were generous; the plaintiff caused lots of problems in the unit. It’s the case of “your whip, I’m stiffed.”

JUDGE: All right, Ena Puit, you are suing John and Christy Schaer for $1,367, a balance in a security deposit plus interest that you say they are wrongfully withholding. Yes? Talk to me.

PLAINTIFF: On August 3rd, I received my item listing and my return check from my security deposit.

JUDGE: Okay, how long had you lived there?

PLAINTIFF: Four years.

JUDGE: Since 20--? You always paid rent on time?

PLAINTIFF: Well, not always on time. I made arrangements with them, and they agreed to them.

JUDGE: Did you generally have a good relationship with them?

PLAINTIFF: Yes.

JUDGE: Okay, and when you left, why did you leave?

PLAINTIFF: I left because I had to downsize.

JUDGE: Okay, so you leave, you do a walkthrough.

PLAINTIFF: We did a walkthrough.

JUDGE: Any comments made during the walkthrough?

PLAINTIFF: Yes.

JUDGE: What were the comments?

PLAINTIFF: The comments were on three holes in the walls that were on the main level floor of the smaller room. There was a hole in the kitchen screen, and then on the second level, there was the doorjamb. My granddaughter got locked in there by mistake. We opened it up. I had a friend try to fix it, and I guess it wasn’t fixed.

JUDGE: Okay, so you point that out.

PLAINTIFF: We all pointed it out together. It was written down, and those were the only damages spoken on.

JUDGE: Who did the walkthrough? He did or she?

PLAINTIFF: John and Christy.

JUDGE: Okay, did they say anything else to you at that time?

PLAINTIFF: No.

JUDGE: All right, so you leave, and you're expecting your security deposit check. Did they say anything to you about the security deposit check on that date?

PLAINTIFF: During the walkthrough, they said that they will get back to me with the amount of the repairs.

JUDGE: Okay, and so when they got back to you, how did they get back to you?

PLAINTIFF: In writing, it was 30 days later. I received the letter and the check on August 3rd.

JUDGE: Okay, I need to see the letter and the check. Okay, so go on.

PLAINTIFF: So when I received the letter and the check, immediately I called John on the phone. I shared with John on that day that I received the check and the letter, and I was in total disbelief and I was very upset and frustrated. I asked him to explain the contents of the letter. Why was it excessive? Because in that letter, it said they were going to charge from my security deposit: excessive cleaning, $300; damage to the upper bedroom doorframe, $150; damage to the walls, no figure; excessive wear carpet, $500; screen replacement, $50. That was a total of $1,000. So they sent me a check for $1,025.

JUDGE: Correct.

PLAINTIFF: Okay, and they were keeping $1,000 for damages.

JUDGE: Correct.

PLAINTIFF: Okay, you felt that was excessive. So what did you do?

PLAINTIFF: Well, when I called him, I asked him, "Could he explain to me what was the excessive cleaning and what was the excessive wear and tear on the carpet?" He told me, "Well, Ena, Christy sent that out to you. I need to talk to her." And at that time, he told me, "Ena, I'm putting together papers for you, and you'll get them." I haven't heard from John since August 27th.

JUDGE: Okay, what's going on, folks?

DEFENDANT (John): Well, I don't disagree with a lot that Ena said. She was a tenant of ours for four years. She made several late payments, but we worked it out. In general, she was a good tenant, but she left the place a mess. We spent in excess of $9,000 fixing and repairing the place after she left.

JUDGE: Okay, and uh, what was wrong with it?

DEFENDANT (John): The carpets were ruined. We had broken doorframes, broken doors, holes in the walls. Appliances were left filthy, bathtubs left filthy, walls with grease all over them, holes in the kitchen floor. She had a leak. I don’t know what she did with a refrigerator, but ice jammed up, and the ice just kept coming down and ruined a ceiling in the apartment below.

JUDGE: Wait, was it your refrigerator?

DEFENDANT (John): Yes, it was our refrigerator.

JUDGE: So what would she do?

DEFENDANT (John): There was still some obligation to let us know. Somehow, the ice jammed up, and ice cubes kept coming out of the refrigerator.

JUDGE: Right, but ice cubes don’t melt in a couple of seconds. What did the woman downstairs say?

DEFENDANT (John): She called us and said her ceiling was falling in.

JUDGE: Let me see the pictures of everything that you’re asking for.

[Judge examines pictures.]

JUDGE: All right, let’s see here. I see the holes in the wall, the damage to the doorframe. The carpet does look worn, but that could be regular wear and tear after four years. The cleaning charges—hmm. This kitchen doesn’t look spotless, but $300 is steep. Some of these damages make sense, but I believe the cleaning charge is excessive.

JUDGE: The only place I think they got a little greedy was on the cleaning. I'm going to order them to return $150 to you that I believe was wrongfully withheld, and based on the double damages clause in New Jersey, that’s $300. Verdict for the plaintiff. That’s my judgment. Good luck.

**Judge:** This court is now in session. We are here today to hear the case of the Plaintiff versus the Defendant. Plaintiff, you may begin with your opening statement.

**Plaintiff:** Yes, Your Honor. Here are emails and documented conversations where we repeatedly reminded the Defendant of the deadlines. We also have financial records showing our losses due to these delays.

**Judge:** Defendant, do you have any evidence to counter the Plaintiff’s claims?

**Defendant:** Yes, Your Honor. I have records of my communications, including requests for extensions and explanations for delays. Additionally, I have expert testimony attesting to the industry-standard delays that were beyond my control.

**Plaintiff:** We attempted to reach a resolution through discussions, but the Defendant was uncooperative and unwilling to compromise.

**Defendant:** That is not entirely true, Your Honor. I offered alternative solutions, but the Plaintiff insisted on rigid terms.

**Judge:** Very well. I will now hear closing statements. Plaintiff?

**Plaintiff:** Your Honor, the Defendant’s negligence has cost us greatly. We upheld our end of the contract and expected the same in return. We respectfully request fair compensation.

**Plaintiff:** Thank you, Your Honor.

**Judge:** This case is now closed.

JUDGE: This is the plaintiff, Shareif Ahmed. He says he was stopped at a seatbelt check on the Parkway, and just as the officer gave him the all-clear, he was rear-ended by the defendant. JUDGE: Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiff was rear-ended by the defendant just after a seatbelt check. The defendant says it was just a tap and the plaintiff is a scammer. It’s the case of ‘I Ta That.’ Litigants have been sworn. Your Honor.

JUDGE: Shareif Ahmed, you are suing Jose Vega for $2,680.02 that you say he owes you to repair your car as a result of an accident that you say was his fault. Tell me what happened.

PLAINTIFF: I was coming off the exit seatbelt check. I passed right through.

PLAINTIFF: Yeah, there was a County Police checkpoint making sure everything was legal as you were passing through. If you were doing anything illegal, you’d be pulled over. Right? So I went right through, stopped at the red light, about to go, and I get rear-ended.

JUDGE: Were you stopped, and then they rolled into you? That’s not a reason to hit you, but I’m just asking—why do you think it happened?

PLAINTIFF: I have no idea what happened.

DEFENDANT: What actually happened was, he had pulled up to the light. The light changed, and he started making his way out.

JUDGE: Were you going straight or turning?

DEFENDANT: Right turn. He starts making his way out, and I actually hit him on the turn. He just stopped, so I ended up hitting him.

JUDGE: You didn’t hit him that hard?

DEFENDANT: No, which is why I really don’t feel like I did as much damage as he’s claiming.

JUDGE: Let’s see. Do you have pictures of the damage?

PLAINTIFF: Yes.

JUDGE: Okay, so let’s set it up. The plaintiff is driving, the defendant is behind him. The plaintiff stops in the middle of the turn, and that’s why the defendant hits him. Is that a defense?

PLAINTIFF: Absolutely not. He should have had enough distance behind him to stop.

JUDGE: But the argument is, when you make a turn, you’re supposed to complete it.

PLAINTIFF: Someone could be in the crosswalk, and they could stop just in case.

JUDGE: That’s a good point. Last word?

DEFENDANT: I believe the law says if you rear-end someone, you’re at fault.

JUDGE: What kind of car is this?

PLAINTIFF: A Honda CR-V. He shattered my rear window.

JUDGE: Shattered your window?

PLAINTIFF: Yes. The door frame was bent.

JUDGE: How do you figure you didn’t hit him hard when you shattered his windshield and bent the door frame?

DEFENDANT: I barely have any damage to the front of my vehicle.

JUDGE: Your car was better made. Why haven’t you paid for his damages?

DEFENDANT: I don’t feel like I did that much damage.

JUDGE: But you shattered his windshield.

PLAINTIFF: He admitted fault at the scene, saying, “I’m so sorry, I wasn’t paying attention, I was talking to my mother.”

JUDGE: Why didn’t you call the police?

PLAINTIFF: He begged me not to.

JUDGE: And then he never paid?

PLAINTIFF: Right.

JUDGE: And you found out he had no insurance?

PLAINTIFF: Yes, his insurance expired the day before the accident.

DEFENDANT: I was on my way to pay it.

JUDGE: You were driving on the way to pay for your insurance? Do I look stupid to you? That is not the truth. You had no insurance.

JUDGE: You have zero defense. I find in favor of the plaintiff in the amount of $2,680.02. I hope you learned your lesson.

DEFENDANT: I have.

JUDGE: Take pictures, don’t move the car, call the police. Case closed.

Judge: "Your monthly child support obligation is 1,021 dollars and 21 cents. Yeah, I don't need you looking confused or anything like that. You have a pension and you have a retirement. I need you to pinch from it."

Judge: All parties, please use your radio. Welcome back to the People's Court. Judge: You are suing The Frosted Baker, represented by none other than The Frosted Baker himself, Daniel Walsh, the owner, correct?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Plaintiff: Okay, so we entered into an agreement—a broker-client relationship—on February 1st. I was to represent his product in certain markets that we decided. We made a list of certain customers that we were going to go after. In return, I would get a weekly stipend for my administrative services.

Judge: So you would get a percentage if you got a deal, but also you would get a base salary?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: Do you have anything in writing with him?

Defendant: The Frosted Baker makes the finest, most highly decorated cookies in the world.

Judge: I don’t see any cookies. No samples for the judge? Are you hiding the cookies?

Defendant: All right.

Judge: So, he’s not going to send me cookies, don’t worry, and if he does, I won’t eat them. Listen, they’re good cookies.

Plaintiff: That’s too bad. Did you bring me cookies?

Plaintiff: I did not.

Judge: Okay, well, I don’t have access to them anymore. Wait, wait—how does this work? You wholesale them?

Defendant: Correct. We manufacture for large companies like QVC—we were on a couple of times—Williams Sonoma, those types of companies, tier-one retailers. We take their needs and we use our initiative and our decorators, which are the best, and we design their cookies and actually produce them. They’re all handmade, hand-decorated, and we can do that in the tens of thousands and keep the quality the same. So right now, we’re basically known as the industry standard in that segment, and we’re pretty highly recognized, pretty highly regarded.

Judge: Now, this says, "The agreement shall be for a term of six months from the date of renewal automatically, but either party can terminate this agreement during the year with 30 days' written notice."

Judge: So what happened?

Defendant: What happened was we brought John to Gurney, showed him the facility, introduced him to the team, explained in depth what the pricing was. John came on board, but we just didn’t get a feel that what we were investing in him was really going to produce anything. If you consider that the thousand dollars a month and a five percent commission rate is really worth about twenty thousand dollars in sales, we just really didn’t see it happening.

Judge: You changed your mind? Or what did he do?

Defendant: On March 14th, I sent him an email outlining my concerns and said at this point in time, we are going to trigger the one-month notice.

Judge: What happened in February?

Defendant: Not sure. Nothing.

Judge: Did you produce anything?

Plaintiff: I was just starting to set appointments.

Judge: So in March, you say you’re exercising the 30-day notice?

Defendant: March 14th.

Judge: And what happens in March?

Plaintiff: He made a stipulation that if I was to bring in an order, we would revisit the stipend. I did bring in an order, and they made me a custom product. We got a commitment for a big order and continued business as usual.

Judge: How big was the order?

Plaintiff: About 36,000 dollars.

Judge: And when did you get the purchase order?

Plaintiff: Toward the end of April.

Judge: So what do you produce in April, May, June?

Plaintiff: We didn’t produce anything from that point.

Judge: When did you learn they were not interested in continuing to pay you $250 in expenses?

Plaintiff: Probably toward the end of July. They just stopped paying me.

Judge: When did they stop paying you?

Plaintiff: June 30th.

Judge: And then you want to get paid now for July and August?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: After you didn’t get the July 15th check, you reached out?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And what did he say?

Plaintiff: He said, "I already resigned you back in March."

Judge: But you’re still working for him?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Okay, favorite type of cookie?

Plaintiff: Chocolate chip.

Defendant: Snickerdoodle.

Judge: Snickerdoodle? Really?

Defendant: Snickerdoodle.

Judge: Oatmeal cookie?

Defendant: Oatmeal.

Judge: Oh, God. We were on such a roll here.

Judge: I find in favor of the plaintiff for $2,000. Thank you. Good luck, folks.

Judge: Welcome back to the People's Court. Next case in the docket, the plaintiff says her ex is awful stiffing her on his share of the wedding they attended, but the defendant says it's nothing but a money grab. It's the case of "Here Comes the Lawsuit." Thank you Douglas.
Judge: Nicole Pastel?
Plaintiff: Yes.
Judge: And Margaret Borello?
Witness: Yes.
Judge: You're suing Scott Snowden?
Plaintiff: Yes.

You've got a counter claim against her for $565 because now that she's suing you for a trip, you want to sue her for all the trips when you went to visit her. You two used to date, correct?
Plaintiff: Yes.
Judge: For how long?
Plaintiff: Five years.
Judge: That's a long time. How old are you?
Plaintiff: Um, now? 25.
Judge: Sorry, yeah, because it depends on what part of your life whether it's really a long time or not. How long have you been broken up?

Judge: So what happened?

Plaintiff: I postponed that because-

Judge: Was the understanding when you paid for the entire hotel room and the entire car - was the understanding that you would split it?
Plaintiff: Yes.
Judge: Okay, that's what I want to hear. What made you come to that understanding as opposed to that you're buying it as a gift for him?
Plaintiff: That wasn't a gift.
Judge: Because that's going to be his defense right? You're going to say I'm not supposed to pay that right?
Defendant: Yeah, exactly.
Judge: I - but I - this may be your first rodeo, it's not mine. So tell me what discussions you guys had about who's paying for what and how it's going to get paid back and all that other stuff.
Plaintiff: Well at the time when we were talking about it when I put it on my card, I asked them I was like are we going to split this and he said yes. He also talked to Margaret and said that - she even had conversations with him.
Judge: Okay, why is Margaret-
Witness: We were living together.
Judge: I was supposed to be a witness but - no no - you're not a - he doesn't owe you money does he?
Witness: No he doesn't owe me-
Judge: Missing that case and it's just them two. You're here as a witness?
Witness: Yes I was just told-
Judge: What did you witness? Did you witness any discussions between the two?
Witness: I witnessed their phone conversations. I've also witnessed the breakup when they did break up for that minor time frame. I actually called Scotty and said are you okay because I was friends with him.
Judge: Why did you guys break up?
Defendant: The long distance like we didn't see each-
Judge: How long did you date each other long distance?
Defendant: Two years.
Witness: Two years and a half at least.
[Continued in next part due to length limit]
Judge: Were you really involved in the relationship?
Witness: I got dragged into the relationship-
Defendant: Yes, as a matter of fact. As a matter of fact she was part of the reason that we got together and she was always around Nicole and I. However, you know during our relationship I was really just dating Nicole.
Judge: Yeah I got - but like I'm glad you clarified that but I want - what I wanted to know is the two of you were friends, yes right?
Witness: Yes.
Judge: Okay, why did you guys break up?
Defendant: We broke up because what happened was I decided that it wasn't going to be feasible enough for me to move up there because I wasn't going to have the finances. After that we argued through text message email all throughout this entire breakup before we got to this point and at that point I asked her how much was it for - she through text message gave me three different amounts that increased - one was $306.23, one was $326.23, one was $346.23 and I said wait okay these amounts don't seem to make any sense so I asked for copies of receipts or a redacted copy of a credit card statement and she refused to give them to me. As a matter of fact I have a text message here if you'd like to see.
Judge: Let's see the bottom. You have your phone with the text messages?
Defendant: Yes.
Judge: With the text messages to him bring that up.
Plaintiff: Can I say something?

Plaintiff: Okay, what were you going to say with that text message about him asking about why you-
Judge: Different amounts?
Plaintiff: Initially it was high and then I took it down.

Defendant: I forward a text message to my mom - she's actually here because at the time what happened was I was getting so many text messages and phone calls from her job and the private number that actually had to change my phone number and that lost all my text messages. Judge: What does that have to do with you sharing with your mother every single email text that your girlfriend said? You got mommy issues.

Defendant: When she sent the email - okay I had a discussion with my family, I thought about it again and then when I realized that the finances and everything just wasn't going to be fe-
Judge: Yeah but did you tell her - did you suggest to her that she should talk to your mom about- Your mom wasn't happy about the idea of you moving?
Defendant: Yes she - yes and she did she - she did speak to her on the phone as a matter of fact shortly after the - she sent the email uh my - she called my mother yeah the next day.
Judge: Okay and how'd that work out? Mom you want- Yeah Mom why don't you come up. I'm just kind of jealous because I - I am because I think it's really nice that you have a son who cares so much about what you think. To me it's not entirely healthy but I think it's - it's kind of sweet.

Could you please go to school get this - go do this do you want to be a teacher so get your GPA up apply to this school apply to that school go here do that just go ahead I want to see you move forward with your life that's what I want to see you do go ahead and get it done then next thing I know I hear I want going to move to Buffalo. I'm like you're underemployed down state. Judge: Listen what is your defense to the lawsuit? I understand what your defense might be to the $653.44 of pain and suffering - what the heck's that about? You're just trying to get your lawsuit to a thousand, no?

Plaintiff: The fact that because he didn't move I didn't have a place to stay I had to give up my job.

Plaintiff: No.

Defendant: I'm - I'm suing because she's-

Judge: Okay well you can't possibly think that I'm going to Grant your request there either. Judge: Welcome back to the People's Court. Next case on the docket, the plaintiffs say the defendant is keeping their security wrongfully, and they think it's motivated by spite. But the defendant says the plaintiffs are lucky they got a penny back. It's the case of a spite suit.

Judge: Ms. Mondeja, Mr. Ocasio, and Lizette Gutierrez, who's Lizette?

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): I am.

Judge: And what is everybody’s relationship?

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): This is my daughter, and that's my husband.

Judge: Okay, you are suing David Rivera, your former landlord, for two thousand two hundred and fifty dollars and two cents that you say he owes you—double the remaining amount of the security deposit that you claim he is unlawfully withholding. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): We moved into his apartment about a year ago and paid twenty-seven hundred dollars for the security deposit, plus we paid five hundred dollars for a pet deposit.

Judge: What kind of pet was it?

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): A small dachshund.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): We signed a lease, and we also signed an agreement that the pet deposit would be returned once we moved out, provided there was no damage to the apartment.

Judge: Correct.

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): We gave notice to Mr. Rivera in December that we would be vacating the apartment on January 27th.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): On January 30th, we met with Mr. Rivera in the apartment and did an inspection. During the inspection, he noted two things. One was that the shower heads were missing.

Judge: Why were they missing?

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): He claims that the shower heads were there when we moved in, but they were not. I actually purchased the shower heads.

Judge: Why would you rent a place without shower heads? Why weren’t they there?

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): They weren’t there when we moved in. When we first looked at the apartment, the shower heads were there, but when we moved in, they were not.

Judge: Do you have any record of saying to him, "Hey, where are the shower heads? We need to buy shower heads"?

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): No, I do not.

Judge: No, you don’t?

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): No.

Judge: Because otherwise, if you ran out and bought shower heads, it sounds like you beautified the shower heads instead of telling your landlord, "What the heck? I can’t take a shower." You know what I’m saying?

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): Yeah, we just went out and bought shower heads and didn’t say anything to him.

Judge: It’s unusual.

Plaintiff (Julio Ocasio): In January, with the help of a lawyer, I sent him a letter saying we’d be moving out February 28th and we’d be living out our part of the security.

Judge: Yes, but you can’t do that. I’m surprised a lawyer would tell you to do that.

Plaintiff (Julio Ocasio): Yes, you could, because of the fact that the security—

Judge: No, you can’t. You can’t live out security. Security is for the purpose of security. You’re supposed to pay.

Plaintiff (Julio Ocasio): Everybody does it.

Judge: A lot of people do it, but that’s not legally permissible. Landlords put up with it because, by the time they go to court, three months have passed. But let’s talk about this.

Judge: The day comes when they’re moving out. You live out the security deposit, leaving a remaining $900 in security deposit, correct?

Plaintiff (Julio Ocasio): Yes.

Judge: Plus the $500 pet deposit, which brings us to $1,400, correct?

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): Yes.

Judge: Then you were demanding the 63% interest, correct?

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): Yes.

Judge: Instead of getting $1,463, what you got was $462.99 back from him, correct?

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): That is correct.

Judge: And does he explain why he’s withholding the rest of the money?

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): He was withholding $45 for the shower heads, $100 for two light fixtures that had to be put back up, and $855 to redo the floors.

Judge: Okay. Defendant, why did you have to redo the floors?

Defendant (David Rivera): They had put up TVs and ripped them off, leaving holes. The floors had water damage from their refrigerator. I have pictures.

Judge: Let me see the pictures.

(Examines pictures)

Judge: That just needs paint, right?

Defendant (David Rivera): No, the floors needed sanding.

Judge: Plaintiff, did you remove the refrigerator?

Plaintiff (Rosamondejo): Yes, but I didn’t see water damage.

Judge: Looking at this, I don’t think this is normal wear and tear. I find that you still owe a remaining $380.01. Verdict for the plaintiff.

JUDGE: All parties, please raise your right hands.

Welcome to The People's Court. This case involves the plaintiffs, who hired the defendant to cater their wedding at a historic museum. They claim the defendant knew the museum was closing but still took their deposit. The defendant, however, argues that the museum was not the only option and that he is still available to provide his services.

Plaintiffs, you are suing Bernard’s catering business for $2,749.62, the amount of your deposit. You’ve requested that we not use the name of the business or Bernard’s last name.

JUDGE: Did you two get married already?

PLAINTIFF (CLAIRE JACKSON): No, not yet.

JUDGE: Alright. What happened?

PLAINTIFF (CLAIRE JACKSON): We got engaged in April of last year.

JUDGE: Congratulations!

PLAINTIFF (CLAIRE JACKSON): Thank you. When we started looking for a venue, one of the first places we thought of was the Dow Museum in St. Augustine, Florida. We had attended a wedding there six years ago and fell in love with the place. It’s charming, rustic, historic, and outdoors.

JUDGE: St. Augustine is a beautiful and historic city. Do you live there?

PLAINTIFF (IVAN DOE): We live in Jacksonville, about 45 minutes away.

JUDGE: My child is in fourth grade, so she’s taking a trip to St. Augustine soon. It’s part of the Florida history curriculum.

Go on.

PLAINTIFF (CLAIRE JACKSON): We contacted the Dow Museum, and they provided us with Bernard’s information. They said that if we wanted to rent the venue, we had to go through Bernard.

JUDGE: Because you are their exclusive caterer?

DEFENDANT (BERNARD): Yes, ma’am.

JUDGE: Tell me about the Dow Museum.

DEFENDANT (BERNARD): It’s a cluster of old historic houses with courtyards and gardens. The entire property is about a city block. The homes have been preserved, and you can rent the venue for weddings.

JUDGE: How old are the houses?

DEFENDANT (BERNARD): They were built in the 1700s.

JUDGE: Wow.

PLAINTIFF (CLAIRE JACKSON): We visited the museum with Bernard and his wife. They showed us where the ceremony and reception would be.

Two days later, after discussing it, Ivan and I decided to move forward. We asked for an estimate for the venue and catering.

JUDGE: So, you worked out the details, signed a contract stating the event would be at the Dow Museum with Bernard as the caterer, and you put down a deposit of $2,749.62. There’s no dispute about that?

DEFENDANT (BERNARD): That’s correct.

JUDGE: Then what happened?

PLAINTIFF (CLAIRE JACKSON): After New Year’s, we started ramping up our wedding planning. Our wedding date is October 20th of this year.

We went back to the Dow Museum one Saturday to take pictures and plan. We spoke with the ticket taker at the museum, explaining that we were getting married there and wanted to look around.

She got a concerned look on her face and asked who we were working with and when our wedding was.

When we told her, she said, “I don’t know if you’ve heard, but the Dow Museum is in the process of being sold to the Children’s Museum.” She told us that all weddings in May had already been canceled.

JUDGE: At that point, did you think your wedding was safe?

PLAINTIFF (CLAIRE JACKSON): We hoped so. We assumed no news was good news.

JUDGE: Sometimes, no news is just no news.

PLAINTIFF (CLAIRE JACKSON): Yes, we were optimistic. We immediately texted Bernard.

JUDGE: Bernard, in January, when she contacted you, did you know there was going to be a problem?

DEFENDANT (BERNARD): No, I hadn’t heard yet.

JUDGE: So, after she reached out, what did you do?

DEFENDANT (BERNARD): I left several messages for the new owners to find out what was happening. When I finally got a response, they told me they didn’t want any more weddings until after May 15th.

JUDGE: But Claire’s wedding is in October.

DEFENDANT (BERNARD): Yes, so I told them that I had a wedding booked in October and asked if we could work something out.

They said they might be under construction but would do their best to accommodate us.

JUDGE: They couldn’t guarantee there wouldn’t be construction during Claire’s wedding, could they?

DEFENDANT (BERNARD): No, they couldn’t.

JUDGE: So, why am I here?

DEFENDANT (BERNARD): I was trying to see if the wedding could still happen there.

JUDGE: If the museum was the whole reason for the plaintiffs booking with you, do they get their money back?

(To the audience) What do you think?

AUDIENCE MEMBER 1: Yes. They paid for it.

AUDIENCE MEMBER 2: Yes. They didn’t get what they paid for.

JUDGE: But the defendant is still offering his services, just not at the museum.

(To Bernard) You were their exclusive caterer for that venue. If the venue is no longer available, that changes everything, doesn’t it?

DEFENDANT (BERNARD): I’m still available to cater their event. I’ve shown them other venues.

JUDGE: But they chose the Dow Museum for their wedding. You were tied to that location. Since that location is no longer available, you need to return their deposit.

Judgment for the plaintiffs in the amount of $2,749.62.

Judge:
Peter, you are suing Victor and Scott—that's how everybody wants to be referred to, just by their first names—for $2,670, which you say it will cost you to remove a boat that Scott gave to Victor and Victor dumped on your property without your permission.

Plaintiff (Peter):
That's correct.

Judge:

Judge:
What kind of property is this?

Well, um… I assumed it was a friend of mine’s property.

Judge:
Wait—whose property did you assume it was?

Victor:
Um… another friend of TAA.

Judge:
And you know her how?

Victor:
Through my brother, who has, um… you know, friends.

Judge:

Judge (sternly):

Victor:
Uh… I was given permission from, um… TAA to drop it off on her property. I believed she said that was her property.

Judge:
No—what did she say exactly?

Victor:
She had told me that the part where I left the boat wasn’t her property.

Judge:
Where’s her property?

Victor:
It’s right behind—kind of right together. It’s just separated by a fence.

Judge:
Why haven’t you moved the boat since realizing it’s in the wrong place?

Victor:
Well, um… when we put it there, before it was officially off the trailer, someone came to us and was on the phone with Peter. Peter had agreed that I could leave the boat there for $50.

Judge (to Peter):
Did that happen?

Plaintiff (Peter):
Not quite that way.

Judge:
What way did it happen?

Peter:
I got a call from a friend of mine who has a motor home. He stays in it once in a while and was around the corner of the building. He heard something going on and came out to take a look.

Then he calls me.

Judge:
And then you get on the phone with Victor?

Peter:
Yes. Victor said, “I need to leave a boat here on the trailer, and I’ll come by in the morning, and we’ll discuss what needs to be done.”

Judge:
Why wouldn’t you say no? Why didn’t you say, "Get your boat off my property"?

Peter:
Well, I try to accommodate—

Judge (interrupting):
No, no, no. That sounds so weird. Why didn’t you just say, "Get your boat off my property"?

Peter:
The next day, I came into work and saw a boat up on three piles of concrete blocks with some wood. Right away, I knew I’d been duped.

Judge:
When you say duped, why?

Peter:
Well, I know a little bit about boats—not much, but enough. I knew when a boat is not seaworthy and really should be disposed of. When I saw it up on blocks, I said, “This is trouble.”

Judge (to Victor):
Did you go up and see the boat?

Victor:
No.

Judge:
How old are you?

Victor:
Twenty-two.

Judge:
Okay, you’re an idiot.

Victor:
Yeah…

Judge:
I cannot tell you the many ways that you are, because what you did was take his headache off his hands and make it your headache.

Then, by taking this behemoth off of a trailer and putting it on blocks, you have no idea the headache you’ve created. It is so monumental.

Judge:
How is it going to leave there?

Victor:
I didn’t get to that.

Judge:
Yeah, yeah—you’ve got to connect the dots, Victor. But in the meantime, what’s your plan? Because you can’t leave it there.

And two months have passed. You have no plan.

Judge:
Do you know what it’s going to take to get that boat off now that it’s off the trailer?

Victor:
You just hook up the winch—

Judge:
A winch on what?

Victor:
On the front of the trailer. The trailer has a crank that cranks boats on and off.

Judge:
You need the trailer.

Victor:
Yes.

Judge:
Do you have the trailer?

Victor:
I don’t have the trailer anymore.

Judge:
Liar.

Victor:
I don’t.

Judge (to Scott):
Do you have the trailer?

Scott:
No, I do.

Judge:
Show me proof you sold the trailer.

Scott:
I don’t have it with me.

Judge (to Peter):
So, you're suing him—why?

Peter:
Because I have to dispose of the boat.

Judge:
No, no—I know why you’re suing Victor.

Are you kidding me? Did it sound like I didn’t know you were suing Victor?

You’re suing Scott—why?

Peter:
Because I felt Scott took advantage of an unsuspecting victim.

Judge:
That may be true, but how does that give you a right to sue Scott?

There’s a concept in the law called standing. It means I can't just be a social justice warrior and sue people because I think something is unfair.

You have the right to sue Victor because Victor trespassed on your property and dumped something there.    Judge (to Peter):
You have the right to sue Victor because he trespassed on your property and dumped something there.

But you don’t have the right to sue Scott unless you can point to some reason why Scott has a duty to you.

Peter:
Scott misled Victor.

Judge:
That may be true, but he misled Victor—not you.

Victor could sue Scott, but you cannot sue Scott for misleading Victor.

So, your case against Scott is dismissed.

Your case against Victor? You’re 100% right—he dumped something on your property that now costs you money to remove. That’s his problem, not yours.

Judge (to Victor):
So, I am finding in favor of the plaintiff for the full amount of $2,670.

Victor—you need to get your life together. I’m telling you now: you need to start thinking.

Victor:
Yes, Your Honor.

Judge:
Good luck.

Judge: Retainers are for lawyers and accountants, no disrespect intended. I don't understand why you would hire a handyman and a snow plower who would say, "Give me a three-thousand-dollar retainer." I've never done that before.

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Judge: Why would you do it now?

Plaintiff: Because I didn't realize it was something that you don't do.

Judge: Why would you not? Why would your gut not tell you it's something you don't do? When have you ever heard-- Do you have friends, the other Navy wives or anybody to talk to?

Plaintiff: Really, you don't know another human in the planet-- You say, "Is that usual to compare retainer to a snow guy?" I mean, it's just a bad idea no matter what. Why are you asking this nice lady for a retainer?

Defendant: Ma'am, I didn't ask her for the retainer. I told her what the per-job rate would be. She was the one who offered the three thousand up front.

Judge: That doesn't make any sense. If you tell her, "Whenever I come here," she said charge X. What's X?

Defendant: 275 a storm.

Judge: Per storm?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Okay, so no matter how many hours it takes, it's 75?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: All right, so you tell her that. Why wouldn't you and she says, "Wait, wait. Can't I please just give you three thousand?"

Defendant: She wanted to give me the 3000 to guarantee services through the winter.

Judge: And how'd that work out for you, by the way?

Plaintiff: It did not.

Judge: Because what?

Plaintiff: How many times did this man come out to your house?

Plaintiff: It snowed a total of three times.

Judge: And how many times did he come?

Plaintiff: Two.

Judge: Okay, and so the other time you got stuck?

Plaintiff: Yes. So, the last time in March, it was the biggest snowstorm of the year, actually. And it snowed multiple times, and he never came. And I text messaged him multiple times, "Hey, when are you coming?"

Judge: Why me and your husband know each other?

Defendant: Not-- I actually do know her husband.

Judge: You're ex-Navy?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Not on a personal level?

Defendant: Okay, but more in the professional field in the sense in the Navy community. It's a very small community.

Judge: Well, shame it got to this because it's getting around, I'm sure.

Plaintiff: Yeah. I mean, that was one of the reasons why I trusted him because I was always told that Navy, you stick together, you help each other out, you're there for each other.

Judge: Unfortunately, I don't know any Navy wives because I don't live in Navy housing.

Plaintiff: If you were to live in Navy housing, the wives, they do things for each other.

Judge: I don't. I live outside the Navy community.

Judge: Thank you, Douglas.

Court Officer: You're welcome.

Judge: Can you pronounce your first name?

Plaintiff: BD.

Judge: Okay, BD. You are suing Bojana Turbo for $540—$300 of it, the amount you paid for a furniture set that you didn’t end up taking, and $240 of it for lost wages. Tell me what’s going on.

Plaintiff: Yes, me and my husband, with my three kids, came to the seller’s house to buy a set of bedroom furniture.

Judge: And where had you seen it advertised?

Plaintiff: Advertised on a software called "Let It Go."

Judge: Say it again?

Plaintiff: "Let It Go."

Judge: "Let It Go." Do you have the advertisement?

Plaintiff: Yes, I see that.

Judge: Okay. "Beautiful Victorian bedroom set, mattress not included, in great condition." That’s what the advertisement says.

Judge: Okay, so what happens?

Plaintiff: We came to the lady’s house, and she offered to watch my three little kids because she doesn’t want them to—

Judge: She offered what?

Plaintiff: To watch my three little kids.

Judge: How old are your kids?

Plaintiff: About five years old, two and a half years old, and under six months.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: Because she doesn’t want them to go upstairs with us to see the furniture.

Judge: Okay, well, you two could take turns, but anyway, go ahead.

Plaintiff: And we see the furniture, and—

Judge: And you decide you want it?

Plaintiff: The room is very, very dark and crowded. We don’t have much time to have a detailed—

Judge: Why not? You got a babysitter downstairs, and it’s working out just fine. Why don’t you just take your time and look at it?

Plaintiff: So we decide we want to buy it, and the seller insists that we have to pay her in full even though we only fit one nightstand at that time.

Judge: Because that’s all you had room to take. But if you wanted it, you had to buy it.

Plaintiff: At that time, we also confirmed that the mattress is included, and we asked her that.

Judge: Okay, how did you confirm that? Because you’re not confirming anything—I just read to you the advertisement that says "mattress not included."

Plaintiff: She didn’t say that it’s not included. She said that she has paintings and other fragile stuff in the hallway. She’s afraid that I will break them, so she wants me to take them later.

Judge: When you negotiated the deal, did you throw in the mattress?

Defendant: No.

Judge: All right. Do you have anything that would prove what you’re saying? Do you have anything in writing from her saying that it’s different from the advertisement? Because the advertisement supports what she’s saying—that the mattress was never included.

Judge: What ends up happening here? You end up giving her the $300, you want it, you don’t want somebody else to get it, and then what you could take that day was that nightstand that I see in my courtroom, right?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And then what happens?

Plaintiff: The next day, I called her around 6:00 because she’s not available during the daytime.

Judge: So you call her at 6 o’clock in the evening.

Plaintiff: Yes, and we said we are going to be there in 20 minutes and we want to pick up the furniture.

Plaintiff: And then her attitude changed tremendously. She first said that the mattress is not included—

Judge: Because it never was.

Plaintiff: And then she said that all of my kids are not allowed to go inside her house. She’s not going to babysit anymore.

Plaintiff: And also, she said that only me and my husband cannot come to pick up the furniture, we need to have actual movers to move the furniture.

Judge: She said you had to hire movers, or that you needed to bring someone who could carry the furniture because it’s upstairs, right?

Plaintiff: Yes, and it’s a big dresser.

Judge: What was your game plan?

Plaintiff: The day before, we confirmed that only me and my husband would come.

Judge: How were you and your husband going to do that?

Plaintiff: We were going to bring tools and disassemble the furniture.

Judge: What about the dresser?

Plaintiff: Yes, we planned to—

Judge: How would you disassemble the dresser? I understand how you disassemble the bed—that has to be disassembled—but how would you disassemble that big dresser?

Plaintiff: It would be the two of us pulling it down—

Judge: Okay, so what is your problem?

Judge: You end up coming, and they say—what time did you ask what time they were coming for the rest of the bedroom set?

Plaintiff: At 6:39.

Judge: You asked that, correct?

Defendant: Judge Milian, my husband passed away.

Judge: I’m so sorry, ma’am.

Defendant: I live in a closed community, I have to sell the house.

Judge: Okay, don’t cry, we’re good.

Defendant: I had a friend put it on the internet for me.

Judge: So you had a friend put it on Let It Go?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Okay, let’s talk about the dispute that happens between you two.

[Rest of the case discussion continues...]

Judge: My verdict in this case is for the defendant.

Defendant: "...So, it wasn’t like I was being messy about it or anything."

Judge: "Well, no, but what is clear, though, Miss Adams, from your testimony is, you have allowed, at certain times, both men to believe they are the twins' biological father. That’s just the truth."

Defendant: "I had blocked him out, yup. Actually, me and Mitchell wasn't even together. Mitchell had actually went back to Chicago. Me and him wasn't together at all. Mitchell decided, 'cause I started back talking with Markeith and everything, and let him start come back to see the kids. Mitchell decided on his own to come back from Chicago, and Markeith popped up just to come see the kids. And that’s when Mitchell was like, 'Well, where he at? I need to see him now.' You know, so it wasn’t like I was being messy about it or anything."

dialogue:
Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiffs bought a couch from the defendant's store and it was lumpy and bumpy, but the defendant says they went the extra mile for the plaintiffs. It’s the case of 'sofa, not so good.'

Judge: You are James Alexander and Marsha Alexander?

Plaintiffs: Yes.

Judge: You are suing the defendant’s company for $3,442, a deposit that you paid for a sectional sofa that you want to return. And he’s counterclaiming $2,463.37, the balance that you owe on it plus the stop payment fee. What happened?

Plaintiff James: What happened was that on May 23rd last year, we went to his store and spoke to two salespeople and told them we wanted a custom sofa. It would be the highest quality, cushions aligned, non-lumpy, no creases, and would last for a very long time. So they both told us that if we spent $6,000, we would get this kind of a sofa and we would have what we wanted for our entire life.

Plaintiff Marsha: Upon receiving the sofa—

Judge: Wait, did you sit on the sofa and see it in person?

Plaintiff James: They carry the same line there, but the custom sofa was not there that we got.

Judge: They carry the line?

Plaintiff Marsha: The Harden line, right.

Judge: So you picked it out of a catalog?

Plaintiff James: A catalog, but they also had on the floor three of the same sofas made by that company.

Judge: I gotcha. Okay. Alright. So what’s in your hand?

Plaintiff James: Okay, what’s in my hand is the sofa that we were told we would be getting.

Judge: Okay, can I—

Plaintiff James: They’re similar to it. I’m not sure if it’s the exact sofa.

Judge: Okay. And what ends up happening?

Plaintiff James: What winds up happening is what we received.

Plaintiff Marsha: These are pictures that we took, uh, like a day or two after they delivered the second time.

Judge: And, and we did put a stop check— Wait, wait. Do you have pictures from the first time?

Plaintiff Marsha: No, because he came out and he agreed they would take it back, and he—

Plaintiff James: Yeah, they wanted us to provide them a list, which we did.

Judge: So when they came out the first time—

Plaintiff Marsha: A list of what we felt was wrong, yeah. So we gave them a list of eight different things to be fixed after the first delivery.

Judge: So the delivery didn’t stay there?

Plaintiff James: They took it back.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff Marsha: And they told us if we would detach the cushions, it would come back to us nice, aligned, straight, tightly stuffed. It was redelivered to us again in November. It did not come that way. That list was given to him in August. It was not followed. Only one of eight things was correctly done, and he promised he would do those parts.

Judge: Alright, now what’s wrong with the sofa the second time? I have these pictures that you put into evidence. What I’d like you to do is go up, either one of you, whoever wants to, and tell me what to notice in the picture.

Plaintiff Marsha: Well, not both of you now.

Plaintiff James: Okay, alright. Well, see how these, uh, cushions— they’re not aligned? And this cushion here, I don’t know if you can see it, but to me, that doesn’t look really straight-lined.

Judge: It bows back?

Plaintiff James: Yeah, it curves back, and they’re lumpy. I don’t—

Judge: Is this something that you had asked on your list to overstuff them?

Plaintiff James: Yes.

Plaintiff Marsha: No, no, no. Yes and no. We asked for something to make them height.

Judge: So when you say they wouldn’t be lumpy cushions like this—

Plaintiff Marsha: So did they put more in it or lessen it?

Plaintiff James: We think he—I don’t know, we don’t know how he did it. Because the second time—

Judge: Closer to the microphone, you can’t promise.

Plaintiff Marsha: When it came back the second time, he said, "I’ll take them back and I’ll try to fix them for you, but I can’t promise anything." The second time they were delivered, we were also going to complain. He agreed the second time they weren’t in the best quality.

Judge: The second time? This is after you stopped payment?

Plaintiff Marsha: Yes.

Plaintiff James: Yes.

Judge: Now, we did stop payment because—

Plaintiff Marsha: He was very emphatic that he wanted his money. He was very upset. He said, "I want my money now," and so we had to get rid of him. So I just gave him a check and then—

Judge: Well, what good does it do to give him a check and then stop payment?

Plaintiff James: He wouldn’t leave!

Judge: Yeah, that does— Alright. "I want my money now, I’m not leaving, I’m so upset." Who’s saying that?

Plaintiff James: He’s physically at your house?

Plaintiff Marsha: Yes. He comes into the sofa, starts spraying the creases on the sofa, smooths it with his hand, and says to me, "Marsha, come to my store. I’ll give you a free bottle of this to get out the creases whenever you want to get them out."

Judge: Okay, well, that’s not going to happen.

[Full conversation continues...]

Judge: I’m not gonna make them finish paying for it, and I’m gonna ask you to please pick it up from their home. So it’s the $3,442 minus a $35 stop payment fee because he shouldn’t have to eat that.

Judge: George Reyes, you're suing your son's friend Denzel Given for $2,822 for damage that he did to your car when you were trying to collect on a debt for a car you bought him that he also hasn't paid for according to you. Tell me your version, what's going on?
Plaintiff: I met Mr. Given around May of 2012.
Judge: How did you know him?
Plaintiff: Through my son.
Judge: How long had they been friends?
Plaintiff: They started working together this year, they just met this year.
Plaintiff: My son was telling me he was having transportation problems. He had one car and the wife got into an accident - a hit and run. So now they were down to no car and he was having transportation problems to get to and from work. He was on the verge of losing his job because of that. My son and I offered - he didn't ask us - we offered him assistance and he took it. I took him to a car dealership, we bought a car.
Judge: I have to ask you why? To assist him why? I mean somebody who your son had just met or your son really really close to him?
Plaintiff: No they weren't really close but I mean I need to meet a better class of people apparently because none of my friends would buy me a car.
Judge: I mean we saw his kind of world literally falling apart where nobody was stepping forward to assist him.
Judge: Nobody? Nobody in his life except for that? Now you figured out why I think so.
Judge: So I guess what I'm trying to figure out is okay so you saw somebody in need so you decided to shell out $1,400 bucks?
Plaintiff: The point is everybody needs assistance at one point or another in their life.
Judge: Absolutely.
Plaintiff: And we stepped forward to the plate.
Judge: I mean you know I'd like to be able to say isn't that great but I can't help but notice you're a litigant in my courtroom.
Plaintiff: Yes.
Judge: So you didn't obviously you didn't know him very well?
Plaintiff: No we didn't.
Judge: I haven't heard your side of the story of course but but based on what you're claiming happened it doesn't sound like you made a very good decision. So then what happens you step up to a virtual stranger and decide to buy them a car and then what?
Plaintiff: I purchased the car. Denzel was with me at the time we both went to the car dealership. I gave the car the money to the dealership. I put the car under his name. On top of that I told him when you get up on your feet you know start paying me whatever you can. I gave him three months. Around the fourth month I was texting him telling him what's going on you know you haven't paid me nothing.
Judge: And what did he say?
Plaintiff: Text me back something about he had problems.
Judge: Do you have the text in your phone?
Plaintiff: I have one prior to the 18th of October where we had a dispute.
Judge: So you start texting him when?
Plaintiff: Around October.
Judge: And then his response to you is I have no money right now, problems and then you say to him?
Plaintiff: I told him well I'll tell you what why don't we take it to a car title loan office where they lend you money on your car title and I told them look whatever they give you give it to me and we'll squash the rest. We don't have to worry about it just give me what you can get for the car and you could pay them.
Judge: Right and apparently he did do that he kept the money. How do you know he did it?
Plaintiff: Because it's on the police report.
Judge: Really? So then what happens?
Plaintiff: I didn't find out that he had titled off the car till after the incident on the 18th of October.
Judge: And it's because he's still not giving you any money right?
Plaintiff: I went over there to repossess the car.
Judge: So you go over there and what happens?
Plaintiff: As I'm driving up there as I could see the car had a flat tire from the back and it just so happens he was - him and his wife were about to leave. Well that's when he saw me and he chased me down and I stopped.
Judge: Did he think you had flattened his tires?
Plaintiff: Yes.
Judge: And you drove there with who to repossess the car?
Plaintiff: Nobody just me and my dog.
Judge: Well how was your dog going to drive the other car?
Plaintiff: No.
Judge: So then how are you going to repossess the car?
Plaintiff: I was going to have a tow truck come and pick it up. I need the address.
Judge: He walks out to his car he's steamed and sees you - you're the guy who's mad at him for not paying and he sort of assumes that maybe tires - that's what he thinks. Kind of what I think too apparently it's what Douglas thinks cause he's chuckling. Yes it does but at the same time I mean anyway so go on.
Plaintiff: So we have a little dispute. He's angry and he kicks my car.
Judge: What's the dispute you're in the car or out of the car?
Plaintiff: I'm sitting in my car I told him something I'm like well you haven't paid paid me nothing all you have to do just pay me something 10 $20 I don't feel like a fool something like that.
Judge: Right and it just got sometimes when you do a good deed you just got to do it and forget it. And by the way did you get him in writing on that it was a loan?
Plaintiff: No.
Judge: Okay is there anything else you could have possibly done wrong?
Plaintiff: I don't know.
Judge: Well don't get it in writing pick the wrong person you don't know him at all right and then he ends up kicking your door in doesn't he tell me about that.
Plaintiff: Well he kicks my door and at that point I call 911.
Judge: Okay can I see the pictures of the door and while you're looking for that what's going on?
Defendant: What really happened was basically that he did buy me the car and he was trying to help me out in a troubling time and I mean yes like he said it was his idea it was never my idea in the first place.
Judge: And basically you jumped at it.
Defendant: I mean you wouldn't jump at a free car especially...
Judge: Is it a free car or is it a car you're supposed to eventually pay back for?
Defendant: A free car really really.
Judge: They barely know you why they gonna give you a car?
Defendant: I mean you barely know me why would you loan me some money?
Judge: That mean but according to him he fronted you money so that you could have this car and then start paying him and he's certainly acting like a guy who you said you would pay because he keeps texting you and hounding you about the money and then shows up about the money and then probably slashes your tires about the money so it sounds like you fully told them you'd be paying back and didn't. Would you loan a casual acquaintance money for a car?
Defendant: No never.
Judge: No they were really in Need?
Defendant: No.
Judge: You would just not do it you just tell them sorry?
Defendant: Yes.
Judge: Okay hard but smart going inside the courtroom.
Defendant: No it wasn't like that at all ma'am but it was just like basically like I said he was trying to help me out in the troubling time and he did some weeks pass and he was like George's car is having this problem.
Judge: And George is who?
Defendant: Your good friend?
Defendant: It's his son. We not too much of friends right now because of all this.
Judge: But you weren't even that that close of friends.
Defendant: I mean he honestly he was he's a good friend.
Judge: You said you had one text let me see the text that you have.
Plaintiff: This was prior to the 18th when we had the fallout and he text me on the October the 16th stating he was going to take a title loan on the car and give it to me and that's pretty much what it's saying. If it was a gift why would he even give me any money?
Defendant: I'm trying to see who will give me the most money for it and give you that and talk about the next step from there.
Judge: Why do you do that if it's a gift?
Defendant: Because like I said I told him I give him what I can.
Judge: Why it's a gift why do you have to give him anything?
Defendant: Basically because I didn't want to leave him in a stuck out situation like cuz he didn't leave me in a stuck out situation and it's like goes around comes back around so I wanted to make sure I put that in effect.
Judge: No truer words have been spoken what goes around comes back around and it's about to come back around because I think you are a liar. I think you were supposed to pay back that money you went out and got a title loan didn't you?
Defendant: Basically hold on.
Judge: And you put the money where?
Defendant: No it was on the 14th I had barely got the title on.
Judge: Let me ask you a question why'd you kick the door in?
Defendant: Because of the fact that he was coming trying to attack me he tried to get out the car the maintenance man and the management scene that we got into altercation after he tried to hitting my wife so what would you do?
Judge: Okay well I wouldn't be in this position but okay so if that's what happens I need you to prove it because your credibility is garbage around here right now so if there's all these other witnesses who saw that you should have no problem call your first witness.
Defendant: I can't exactly.
Judge: So with someone else I might be able to stand there and say well he sounds talking I'm talking but with you I can't. Okay okay well how much it cost you to fix the tires though cuz I don't I do think slash them.
Defendant: It was only $30.
Judge: And deducting $30 from your recovery let me see the report of what it's going to cost to fix the door.
Defendant: Let me say this - I was going to sign the car back over to him the first day I got the title loan and the reason why I didn't give him the $300 because I knew I was going to give him the car after the incident happened out of rage out of anger because of the fact that he disrespected me.
Judge: He doesn't want the car what he wants is the money because I believe that is what your agreement was. We're done do not talk again. Okay I find in favor of the plaintiff in this case and the entire amount you're asking for except for the 30 bucks that it cost to patch the tires - $2,782.23 verdict for the plaintiff.

Judge: So it is true you were texting Marissa.
Defendant: Well, I see my messages, but I have an assistant who runs my account, you know. I can't be doing those day-to-day things. I got other things that I like to tend to throughout the day.
Judge: All right. So this additional money that is on your messages on social media, is that you speaking or is that your assistant?
Defendant: That's my assistant speaking on my behalf.
Judge: So it is true.
Defendant: It's my assistant speaking on my behalf.

Judge: Okay, Janice, you've asked to be referred to only as Janice?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: You are suing Albert George Schubert II?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: For $3,626 that you say you are out as a result of buying a car that was a lemon, and you want your money back—what you paid for the car, for repairs, for child care, and for lost wages.

Judge: All right, you have a counterclaim against her for $2,000 for lost wages?

Defendant: Yes, for having to come to court—for work that I can't do today and yesterday. Oh, there's two engine jobs.

Judge: All right, let me hear from you first, Janice. What's going on?

Plaintiff: Hi, I just wanted to say first, nice to meet you.

Judge: Nice to meet you.

Plaintiff: I watch your show a lot, and you're awesome.

Judge: Okay. You also think I'm awesome, right?

Defendant: Awesome.

Judge: Yeah. All right, now we're even. Go ahead.

Plaintiff: Okay, sorry. So what happened, um, well apparently what happened was I bought this car.

Plaintiff: So, it was like, first, it was like between me and my mother because I recently came from Puerto Rico due to the Hurricane Maria disaster.

Plaintiff: So I was like in a very desperate situation, like I was like, "Whatever car for like the amount of money I have, like, I want."

Plaintiff: So my mom reached out to me—I came to PA and everything.

Plaintiff: My mom reached out to me. She's like, "Oh, I talked to this guy, like he seems very legitimate. He seems like he, you know, is selling this car."

Plaintiff: It was a 2003 Pontiac Aztek.

Plaintiff: And, um, the original price for it was like $2,800.

Judge: Can I ask you, did you buy the car, or did your mother?

Plaintiff: I bought the car.

Judge: How old are you?

Plaintiff: I'm 23 years old.

Judge: Okay. So you buy the car. Did you have it looked at by a mechanic before you bought it?

Plaintiff: No, ma'am.

Judge: All right. Do you have paperwork from the sale of the car?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma'am.

Judge: May I see it?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma'am.

Judge: Did your mother have it looked at by a mechanic?

Plaintiff: No, ma'am.

Judge: Was this your car?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: How long had you had it?

Defendant: 18 months, maybe 2 years.

Judge: All right. So now, um—so this is what I'm going to ask you.

Judge: If you watch me all the time, sweet pea, can you tell me why you bought a 15-year-old car without having a mechanic look at it?

Plaintiff: I know.

Judge: That was the thing—I was trying to get my uncle, he's a mechanic, to come out, and he couldn't come out that day.

Judge: Then don't buy it.

Plaintiff: I know. I shouldn't have, but like, I don't know how to explain to you my situation. Like, I was buying—

Judge: No, I don't care how desperate you are.

Judge: The rules don't change because you feel desperate at that moment.

Judge: Get a job close to where you're living if you feel so desperate.

Judge: You know, it's just how it is.

Judge: So, you buy the car, and what's the problem?

Plaintiff: That—talking about—it has to do with, um, him practically selling me the car.

Plaintiff: Like, this is the proof that he sold—
