Defendant: I've never signed this.

Defendant: I've never even seen that until—

Judge: You haven't even seen it now?

Defendant: How do you know it's forged?

Defendant: From the court in my town, they sent me a copy.

Judge: Let me see it.

Judge: Al Schubert declares the vehicle, Pontiac Aztek 2003 sold, has no transmission or motor issues.

Judge: And if in 30 days or less there will be any mechanical dysfunction in the areas mentioned making the vehicle non-drivable, a full refund of $2,550 is permitted.

Defendant: May I?

Judge: Yes.

Defendant: Um, it's deplorable and a joke, in my opinion, because—because it looks nothing like my handwriting.

Defendant: And I don't mean to sound the wrong way with this, but the person that wrote that—English is not their first language.

Defendant: It's very clear.

Judge: It sounds wonderful.

Defendant: May I?

Judge: Yes.

Defendant: There was a problem with brakes. I bought her brakes.

Defendant: There was a problem with the body control module, which is a computer to make it start with the key.

Defendant: I bought that.

Defendant: I was willing to put it in, but physically can't put it in because a dealer needs to program it to that number for the car so it will run.

Defendant: I went to the dealer, told her I was at the dealer, we made a plan—I sat there for two hours.

Defendant: She never showed up.
Judge: Okay, so you’re telling me that you had agreed to fix the brakes and the body control module?

Defendant: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: But you never agreed to a transmission warranty?

Defendant: No, ma’am.

Judge: And you’re saying this document is forged?

Defendant: Absolutely. That’s not my handwriting.

Judge: Janice, where did this document come from?

Plaintiff: He gave it to me when we made the transaction.

Judge: Do you have any other proof that he promised you a transmission warranty?

Plaintiff: Well, my mom was there, and she heard him say it.

Judge: Is your mother here today?

Plaintiff: No, she couldn’t come.

Judge: Okay, so what happened with the car?

Plaintiff: About three weeks after I bought it, the transmission started acting up. It wouldn’t shift properly, and then one day, it just stopped moving.

Judge: Did you take it to a mechanic?

Plaintiff: Yes, and he told me the transmission was bad.

Judge: Did you contact the defendant?

Plaintiff: Yes, and he said it wasn’t his problem.

Defendant: That’s right, because I never sold her a warranty. She bought a used car.

Judge: Janice, did you have any paperwork from the mechanic confirming the transmission was faulty?

Plaintiff: Yes, here’s the report.

Judge: (Reviews document) Okay, this says the transmission had a severe fluid leak.

Plaintiff: I didn’t know about that.

Defendant: Because she never maintained it!

Okay.

And he looked at me, and he said, “You should be very concerned.”

Judge:
Oh.

Plaintiff:
So, uh, I went home, and the next day, I took it to a shop to have it looked at. And that’s when I was told that the head gasket was blown.

And what is the cost of the repair?

Plaintiff:
Uh, $1,200.

So did you call him and say, “Hey, the head gasket’s blown?”

Plaintiff:
Yes.

Judge:
And what did he say?

Plaintiff:
He said, “There’s nothing I can do for you.”

Judge:
Alright. Now, Mr. Birchard, do you have any knowledge of the head gasket being blown prior to selling him the car?

Defendant (Lee Birchard):
Absolutely not.

Judge:
Okay. The car is a 1997 Mercury Sable?

Defendant:
Correct.

Judge:
So a 23-year-old car.

Defendant:
Yep.

Judge:
With how many miles on it?

Plaintiff:
Uh, I believe it had about 140,000 miles.

Judge:
Alright. And did you sell the car “as is”?

Yes, I did.

Uh, I wrote “as is” on the bill of sale.

Because I was under the impression that I was buying a running and driving vehicle.

For four days.

Plaintiff:

Judge:
And that’s your problem. If you buy a used car “as is,” you assume the risk. If you want a guarantee, you buy from a dealer with a warranty.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hand.

Bailiff: Be seated. Come to order in the matter of Goldstein v. Feli. Your Honor.

Judge: Thank you. Ashley Goldstein, you are suing your former roommate Christine Feli for $532.58 in utility bills that you say she owes you for her half and has refused to pay.

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: What's going on?

Plaintiff: Basically, back in October 2011, we moved into a house together.

Judge: Had you known each other before that?

Plaintiff: We had been best friends for 11 years. We met in ninth grade. Not just close friends, best friends. We were always together.

Judge: Well, that's sad.

Plaintiff: Yeah, a little bit. So basically, we moved in, everything was fine, but as time went on, we started fighting over little things. She was kind of a big slob, and so I'd argue about that.

Defendant: I would spend hours cleaning my house.

Judge: But if you're best friends, you know she's a slob.

Plaintiff: Well, if I'm not saying you're a slob, I'm saying you know, you think she's a slob. I mean, I know my best friend's habits. I've been in her house, seen where she lives. I know.

Judge: So you should have known?

Plaintiff: I guess I should have. I mean, her house at her mom's was messy too, but I addressed that as one of my concerns before moving in. She assured me she'd clean up after herself.

Judge: And did she?

Plaintiff: No. I would spend hours cleaning the house, and then I'd come home, and there'd be dishes everywhere, stuff everywhere. The house would be disgusting. Then we argued about the heat. She liked it at 62, which is too low for me, so I'd turn it up to 64, 65, 66. She had an issue with that and said, "You're wasting our heat. I'm not going to pay it if you keep it this high."

Judge: When did she move out?

Plaintiff: The second week of April or the first week of April. Maybe March 26th. Her rent had been paid up to that point.

Judge: Had she paid April rent?

Plaintiff: April rent ended up being covered by her half of the security deposit, which the landlord accepted as payment. Well, he didn't accept it entirely. He's taking her to court too.

Judge: He's taking her to court for what?

Plaintiff: She left before the lease was up—it was up in October.

Judge: And now he's coming after you for it?

Plaintiff: Hopefully not, but he said he was going to.

Judge: I'm telling you right now, unless this landlord has a screw loose, they’re not going to go to court on a roommate situation over one person’s unpaid rent. They’ll just go after whoever is still there.

Plaintiff: We both signed the lease. It says on line 18 that we are responsible for heat and electric. My mother and the landlord were both present when we agreed to split the bills.

Judge: Why am I here? I don’t want to hear about who’s a slob, who doesn’t do dishes, or complaints about boyfriends. Why am I here?

Plaintiff: Because she didn’t pay her half of the electric bill.

Judge: And for what months?

Plaintiff: The only month she paid since we moved in was December.

Judge: Let me see your bills. At this point, how are you two getting along?

Plaintiff: We weren’t talking.

Judge: I mean, in January, February, March—when she wasn’t paying, how were you getting along?

Plaintiff: At that time, we were getting along. But about a month and a half before she moved out, we got into a big argument.

Judge: About what?

Plaintiff: The same things—heat, messiness, little things that spiraled out of control. We said hurtful things to each other.

Judge: Had you ever said hurtful things before and then gotten over it?

Plaintiff: Yes, but not like this. Her boyfriend got involved, too, saying hurtful things to my mother.

Judge: What did he say to your mother?

Plaintiff: My mom texted him because he was saying mean things to me. She told him to stay out of it and said, "They fight like sisters, they’ll probably get over it."

Judge: And what did he say?

Plaintiff: He called me "scum of the Earth," "disgusting," and said, "nobody likes you."

Judge: Let me hear your side.

Defendant: We had issues before moving in. We were best friends, but we knew it could be a problem. We agreed that if things were going well, we’d continue living together. I paid half of the RG&E bill, which was in her name. October, November, December, everything was fine. I gave her cash for my half.

Judge: And after that?

Defendant: In December, she started dating a guy who was into serious drugs. She found a spoon in his car for heroin use and forgave him. I felt unsafe. He had a criminal record, and I started staying at my boyfriend’s house six to seven days a week. Then she finally left him, filed a police report, and got an order of protection because he slashed her tires.

Judge: When was that?

Defendant: Late January. She filed the police report in February.

Judge: So what happened next?

Defendant: She invited me to breakfast, but I wasn’t feeling well. Then I started getting text messages—she was upset I wasn’t home enough. She accused me of lying, got really needy, and then things escalated. She broke into my room, trashed it, and sent me a picture of the mess.

Judge: Let me see the texts. (Reviews them.) You do sound a little needy, accusing her of lying. But that doesn’t determine a lawsuit. You’re suing her for unpaid utilities. She’s saying she wasn’t living there. What’s your response to that?

Plaintiff: She was still on the lease. She hadn’t officially moved out.

Judge: On what legal theory are you not responsible for utilities before moving out?

Defendant: I wasn’t living there for three months.

Judge: You may have chosen to stay elsewhere, but if you haven’t moved out, you’re still living there. The fact that it’s not a legal lease affects your agreement with the landlord, not your agreement with her.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hand. Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket—the plaintiff was the defendant’s boyfriend, but no more. He gave her his credit card for a Lazy Boy. What do you think happened there? She says it was a present, but now that she’s seeing someone else, he’s upset. It’s the case of "You’re Way Too Lazy for Me." Thank you.

Judge: John Cerk, you are suing your former girlfriend, Joellen Reich, for $487.52, the amount that you say you loaned to her. You say he gave it as a gift, and according to you, she's refusing to repay. What's going on?

Plaintiff: Okay, sometime last summer, I think it was July or August, she purchased furniture, and it was one of those deals with little or no interest. Come December, she asked me to loan her the money to pay off the loan. She needed $300, and I was kind of reluctant. She said she'd pay me when she gets her taxes in January. So, I gave her my credit card. I get the bill—it’s for $487.52. Come January, I ask for my money, and she tells me I have to stand in line, you know.

Judge: But this isn't a stranger to you; this is somebody who you dated. How long?

Plaintiff: Oh, probably for 10 years.

Judge: 10 years? Okay, so you were together for 10 years. When did you guys break up?

Plaintiff: Oh, it's been on and off for 10 years. You know, it’s a love-hate relationship, I guess you call it.

Judge: Okay. Right now, are you on, or are you off?

Plaintiff: No, we’re off.

Judge: When was the last time you were on?

Plaintiff: December.

Judge: And who broke up with who?

Defendant: It just happened, you know.

Judge: Who broke up with who?

Defendant: He made me mad, so—

Judge: Say that again?

Defendant: I probably broke up with him.

Judge: He made you mad? How did he make you mad?

Defendant: He was just mean to me. I had just got off work, and he brought up a fight that we had the night before. I had just worked eight hours and saw him, and he was still carrying the same thing from the night before.

Judge: And you guys were living together?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Oh. Okay, so that was it? After 10 years?

Defendant: It’s always something stupid. It’s just the last straw of something.

Judge: All right. He says that he paid this off as a loan to you and that you’re supposed to pay him back. What’s your answer to that?

Defendant: No, ma’am.

Judge: Okay. Tell me your side.

Defendant: He’s helped me for 10 years. When I left my son’s father, he lost his job. I was getting child support, but when my son’s father got fired, I didn’t get child support anymore. Back in the day, John used to give me money—$500 cash. When I moved in August, he gave me his credit card so I could buy new things for the house. That was $300. He’s helped me a lot in the past 10 years and never asked me for anything back.

Judge: And out of curiosity, once you two broke up, he asked for this back. You didn’t want to pay it because you can’t pay it?

Defendant: Well, his claim said that I was supposed to pay him back in 30 days.

Judge: Did you ever tell him you’d pay him back for this?

Defendant: No, ma’am.

Judge: I understand what you’re saying—you’re trying to tell me, "Judge, he’s given me lots of gifts. This was just another gift."

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: All right. Why do you suppose he wants this one paid? What is he mad at you for that would make him say this one wasn’t a gift?

Defendant: I started dating somebody else.

Judge: Ah, that’s the part I was missing, honey. Now I get it. All right. Does this guy get his money back? What do you think? If you make a loan, you have to have it in writing. You’re not getting your money back. Fair enough—it doesn’t feel like a loan to me. Going inside the courtroom—so you are dating somebody else?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Are you living with somebody else?

Defendant: No.

Judge: After 10 years, you never lived with him?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Was that an issue, or is that just the way you two rolled?

Defendant: I’ve always wanted— you know, it’s lonely. I’ve been alone for 12 years.

Judge: Apparently, he thinks you rebounded a little quickly.

Defendant: Oh.

Judge: Is he suspicious of you?

Defendant: Oh, I wasn’t cheating on him.

Judge: Okay, but does he think that?

Defendant: I don’t think so.

Judge: You think it’s just that he wants the money because he’s mad that you moved on?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Do you have any evidence that this was a loan?

Plaintiff: I have nothing but her word.

Judge: Her word here today is directly contrary to yours.

Plaintiff: I know it is.

Judge: And we just took that oath five minutes ago to tell the truth.

Plaintiff: I’m telling the truth.

Judge: Are you telling the truth?

Defendant: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: When you come to court, it’s really important to have something other than a he said/she said because it becomes very difficult to rule in your favor when you have the burden of proof and can’t meet it. My verdict in this case, I have no choice but to rule for the defendant. Good luck.

He said that he was willing to help me with a down payment on a car because I didn’t have it in full, but he was willing to take it in payments.

Judge:
The deal you struck with him is that you would provide dribs and drabs until you got to $1,500 and you wouldn’t be entitled to a car until you did, right?

Plaintiff (Naisia Myers):
Yes.

Judge:
Bad idea, but anyway, go ahead.

Plaintiff (Naisia Myers):
So that's what you do, and you get to the $1,500?

Plaintiff (Naisia Myers):
Yes.

Judge:
Okay, so I had met up with his assistant because that's who I was actually meeting up with. Although I talked to him, he was really not involved because I was talking to his assistant, Dana. So she was the one that I was going through, so that's who I have the text messages with and all my emails.

Judge:
Okay, so when did you have the $1,500 paid up?

Plaintiff (Naisia Myers):
January 28th.

Judge:
And then when do you go to pick out your new car?

Plaintiff (Naisia Myers):
Well, I looked at and looked for a new car before that date because I knew the date was coming.

Judge:
Yes, you already had your car picked out.

Plaintiff (Naisia Myers):
Yes.

Judge:
You had already test-driven the car and everything.

Plaintiff (Naisia Myers):
Yes, I test drove the car, and that was actually with Scott, and we both discussed that this was the car that I planned on getting. And then the next two weeks, which was January 28th, I had planned that with Dana and I gave her the rest of the money, so that was the $1,500.

Judge:
So there’s $1,500 on your side?

Defendant (Scott Geller):
Correct, Your Honor. We don’t know—I don’t know sitting here today whether she came up with $1,350. I know I waited months and worked with her, holding cars for her.

Judge:
I have a simple question. What is the total amount she paid?

Defendant (Scott Geller):
I do not know, Your Honor.

Judge:
You serious?

Defendant (Scott Geller):
That’s right. She dealt with Dana. We were working with her for months.

Judge:
You talked to Dana before coming this month?

Defendant (Scott Geller):
I don’t think it doesn’t matter. You don’t have a method of keeping control of the money your place accepts.

Judge:
All right, so if on January 28th she pays the remaining $1,500, how do you go out and get insurance on this specific car?

Plaintiff (Naisia Myers):
I went to—I did it, um—what day did you do that?

Plaintiff (Naisia Myers):
I did it, um, February 11th, a little before February 11th.

Judge:
Why is there such a gap? If you finish paying the $1,500 on January 28th, then why is there such a gap between the 28th and February 11th?

Plaintiff (Naisia Myers):
It was only about two weeks.

Judge:
Yeah, but why is there such a gap?

Plaintiff (Naisia Myers):
It’s only because I was doing it based on, like, my pay period and then I had scheduled it so that I knew for a fact that I would have the money to give him to register the car and also...

Judge:
Was there any financing involved in the purchase of this car?

Plaintiff (Naisia Myers):
I did a finance application and they told me when—was the finance application done?

Plaintiff (Naisia Myers):
I don’t... I honestly don’t know.

Judge:
Was it at the beginning or at the end?

Plaintiff (Naisia Myers):
It was like in the beginning, because they told me that I got accepted for a $4,000 loan, which the total of the car was $5,500.

Judge:
All right, so when does she pick out that car that she really wanted—the last car in question?

Defendant (Scott Geller):
Yeah, I did an exception to her. I met her at Gold’s Gym or someplace ‘cause she complained about driving, went with her in the parking lot that day to please her.

Judge:
What day was that? Do you remember?

Defendant (Scott Geller):
Whatever she says is fine. I don’t remember. She says it’s two weeks before January 20th. That’s fine. It probably was.

Judge:
Okay, so the 28th comes, she makes the payment, but she doesn't come in to do business with you ever?

Defendant (Scott Geller):
No. I don’t remember. That day I met you in the parking lot was the last time I saw you.

Judge:
Did you ever come in to sign the paperwork for the car?

Plaintiff (Naisia Myers):
I never did. There was never a contract. Originally, when I met her, it was supposed to—the contract was supposed to be written already, but it wasn't because she said that she ended up being busy.

Defendant (Scott Geller):
I said, "Well, I had no problem. I will sign it on the 11th."

Judge:
But how do you know? You’re giggling, but how do you know it’s very unusual to send an employee to some remote location to...

Defendant (Scott Geller):
I sent Dana to meet her in a parking lot to be nice and to help the girl. She lived far. She had two schedules. She never answered her phone. She never came in. We went crazy to try to please her, and now I’m in court. Had to take a day for my business. The whole thing is lit.

Judge:
You’re a used car salesman in the business of selling cars. I’m having a car dealership to serve the public and do a good job.

Defendant (Scott Geller):
Okay, but you're not a public service worker. You're here to make money too.

Judge:
I care. I'm a good person.

Defendant (Scott Geller):
Listen, you're talking to somebody who totally finds your industry a necessary thing. I know that she can't buy a car from the dealership. I know that she doesn’t have the credit to do it. I have zero problem, and I got her approved.

Judge:
I get all that and I get why, but please don’t also—I really do get tired when I hear your side saying things like it’s a public service. No, it’s because you’re going to make money too. But here's where...

Defendant (Scott Geller):
Survive. Yeah. Yes. Yes, you gotta eat, you gotta pay tuition, you gotta do whatever you gotta do now.

Judge:
Dana is not here, and here’s my reality. I have her testifying that Dana said, "No problem, we’re good to go. When are you going to come in? What are you going to do, blah, blah, blah?" And that the car is hers. Dana's leaving her with the impression that the car is hers and there’s no urgency. How are you going to contradict that without Dana here?

Defendant (Scott Geller):
Was Dana available?

Judge:
Yeah, she has another job. She works for me part-time. I don’t think she’s going.

Defendant (Scott Geller):
Do you have her cell phone?

Judge:
Yeah, I can look for her cell phone.

Defendant (Scott Geller):
I can try.

Judge:
Okay.

[Defendant calls Dana]

Defendant (Scott Geller):
No, I’ll talk. It’s clear how they're coming in two months and testifying against me too.

dialogue:
Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiff bought a horse for her disabled daughter, and it didn’t look anything like the horse in the pictures—and it was injured to boot. But the defendant says the plaintiff agreed to buy Lucky sight unseen. It’s the case of ‘My Horse is a Nightmare.’

Judge: Okay, Michelle Fowler Weiss, you are suing Bethany McCurley for $750. $500 is a deposit that you put on a horse and $250 is for travel expenses. According to you, the horse was not as advertised. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: My daughter has been doing barrel racing, so we were on Craigslist—

Judge: Yes.

Plaintiff: Her horse is currently 17, so we were looking for a younger horse to continue to grow on. So I was looking through the Craigslist ads and looking at a lot of different things when I came upon Bethany’s ad.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: And I read it—

Judge: How old is your daughter?

Plaintiff: She is 19.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: And I read through the ad. It had everything that we were looking for.

Judge: Do you have the ad?

Plaintiff: I do. May I see it?

Judge: Okay. So what do you do?

Plaintiff: Earlier in March, my daughter had been videotaped on TV because of her disability and riding.

Judge: What’s the nature of her disability?

Plaintiff: She was born with spina bifida, so she walks with crutches and she can’t just get on a horse like a normal person. She needs a mounting block.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: So I sent her the video. I sent a lot of people through the Craigslist ads the same video and said, ‘Okay, your horse sounds awesome. Now, these are the limitations of my daughter. Would your horse fit that?’ Because it’s a long travel distance. And I sent it to Bethany as well.

Plaintiff: And she said, ‘Yeah, everything would be fine.’ So the pictures show a very strong, stout-looking horse, similar to the one that she currently has.

Judge: Do you have the picture?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Okay. And if you go to the next...

Plaintiff: Okay, there we go.

Judge: Oh my gosh, our paintings do look like an elephant! That’s funny. An elephant with a ball. Alright. So, she texted—I text-messaged her about price and stuff. And so, at the end of the day, you agree as follows: there’s a $500 non-refundable deposit. And that’s very clear, right? Those were the terms of the agreement.

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And then a $250 travel charge because you guys are how far?

Plaintiff: We are about half the state—almost half the state.

Judge: Yeah, about four hours?

Plaintiff: Yeah, four-hour drive.

Judge: Alright. Now, how old are you?

Defendant: 17.

Judge: Okay, so I assume you were involved in all this?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: But it’s your horse?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Alright. So the horse is brought over. What happens?

Plaintiff: She gets her out of the trailer. In the photo, she looks very stocky, and she gets out of the trailer and she’s thin—a lot thinner than the photos—and she looks smaller. But then she gets out and you can see that on her withers—

Judge: What are withers?

Plaintiff: It’s like our shoulder blade.

Judge: Just point to where it is on the horse.

Plaintiff: Okay, got it.

Judge: So what happened when the horse stepped out of the trailer?

Plaintiff: Well, right away, we noticed she was much thinner than in the photos, and when she walked, she was visibly stiff. We figured it might just be the long trailer ride, but when my daughter tried to lead her around, she wouldn’t move properly.

Judge: Did you call a vet at that point?

Plaintiff: Yes, we called our vet, and he came out later that afternoon. He examined her and said she had a problem with her hip—something that didn’t just happen from the ride.

Judge: Did you relay this to the defendant?

Plaintiff: Yes, I texted Bethany immediately, and she told me the horse was “just fine” and that she had “no issues” before. But that’s not what our vet said.

Judge: Alright, Ms. McCurley, what’s your response?

Defendant: The horse was perfectly healthy when we loaded her up. I made it very clear in the ad that there were no known health issues.

Judge: But the issue is that the horse, as delivered, was not as advertised, correct?

Defendant: No, Your Honor. I believe the stiffness was due to the travel. It was a long ride, and horses get stiff. My vet checked her before we listed her for sale.

Judge: Did you offer to take the horse back?

Defendant: No, because the deposit was non-refundable, and I knew she was healthy. I told them to give her a few days to adjust.

Judge: But they got a vet’s opinion. Did you ask for a second opinion?

Defendant: No, because I didn’t think it was necessary.

Judge: Okay. Here’s the problem: when you sell an animal under certain conditions—especially a working horse for a disabled rider—it needs to match the description provided. In this case, the plaintiff relied on your statements and photos. When the horse arrived and was deemed unsuitable, you refused to return the deposit. However, I find that the contract was effectively breached by misrepresentation, whether intentional or not.

Defendant: But—

Judge: $750 verdict for the plaintiff.

JUDGE:
Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case in the docket—the plaintiff says the defendant rented an apartment in his house and skipped out without paying all the rent, but the defendant says he paid in full. It’s the case of the rent’s too damn inaccurate.

Douglas Wayne Monsky?

PLAINTIFF:
Yes.

JUDGE:
You are suing the defendant for $1,794.42 in damages, rent, and other items that you say were damaged when your tenant left abruptly without notice and without paying. Tell me what’s going on.

PLAINTIFF:
His girlfriend moved out at the end of July, beginning of August. I wouldn’t have known other than I actually went there in the beginning of August when her uncle was moving her stuff out. I was there to talk to the defendant about mowing the lawn.

We had an agreement that he would mow the lawn. Even though his girlfriend moved out in July or August, she paid most of the rent for August and September—$775 out of $800. The remaining $25 was supposed to be for mowing the lawn, but he didn’t mow the lawn.

At the end of September, when the payments from her ran out, he called me and said he was moving out. I told him I needed to show the apartment, and he said, "No way, you can’t show the apartment." We bickered about it, and he finally said, "Only if I’m there, and you have to make arrangements through me."

JUDGE:
That’s exactly how you must show the apartment—only if he’s there or unless he gives permission for you to do it at any time. You have to make arrangements with him, give him notice, and he can’t unreasonably withhold it.

PLAINTIFF:
Throughout October, we tried multiple times to come to an agreement. He’d say, "This date," then cancel at the last second. This happened over and over. In the end, I got only one day—October 25th—for less than two hours.

JUDGE:
Did anyone show interest in the apartment?

PLAINTIFF:
I had two people look, but the place was totally trashed because he was still moving out. At first, I had over two dozen people interested from my advertising.

JUDGE:
When did you place the advertisement?

PLAINTIFF:
Right away, and then again in early October.

JUDGE:
You’re suing for the cost of advertising. Do you have proof of the advertisements?

PLAINTIFF:
No.

JUDGE:
So, October wasn’t paid, and you’re saying you couldn’t rent it for November because he unreasonably withheld permission to show it? When did you finally rent it?

PLAINTIFF:
December 1st.

JUDGE:
Defendant, what’s going on?

DEFENDANT:
Your Honor, on January 29th, he was paid $1,504 from my girlfriend to close the case between both of us. He also kept an $800 security deposit for supposed damages.

JUDGE:
You were living there with your girlfriend, but it didn’t work out?

DEFENDANT:
Yes, we were living there until mid-August.

JUDGE:
She moved out, and rent was paid up until September. Then October and November weren’t paid?

DEFENDANT:
Correct. October wasn’t paid because I moved out on October 31st.

JUDGE:
According to him, he couldn’t rent it for November because you wouldn’t allow him to show the place. Respond to that.

DEFENDANT:
I gave him two months’ notice that I was moving out and a month’s notice that I wasn’t able to pay October’s rent.

JUDGE:
That’s a big deal. What do I do with that deposit? Leave it in the bank? Pay my bills?

DEFENDANT:
After we moved out, I told him I had no intention of paying October. But he was paid for that when my girlfriend made the deal.

JUDGE:
Okay. Walk me through October.

DEFENDANT:
He came twice to show the apartment. The first time, I was there with my witness. The second time, I wasn’t home, but I know he was there because I locked both locks when I left, and when I came back, only the bottom lock was locked.

JUDGE:
Did he tell you he was going in without you?

DEFENDANT:
Yes.

JUDGE:
Were you present during the first showing?

WITNESS:
Yes.

JUDGE:
Was the place a mess?

WITNESS:
We were moving out, so there were packed boxes, but it wasn’t bad.

JUDGE:
Did you hear any discussions between them?

WITNESS:
Yes. The defendant told him he wanted to be there when the place was shown.

JUDGE:
So, the second time when he said, "I’m going in anyway," why didn’t you stop him?

DEFENDANT:
I didn’t want to argue with him.

JUDGE:
Did you receive a letter of demand from him?

DEFENDANT:
Yes.

JUDGE:
Give me the letter.

(Reviewing document)

This is a breakdown of the charges the defendant’s girlfriend’s mother requested. Unpaid rent, floor damage, advertising, cleanup costs, garage door remote... These are the same damages you’re suing for, right?

PLAINTIFF:
Yes, but I was trying to leave her out of it.

JUDGE:
The defendant and his girlfriend forfeited their $800 security deposit. Then she or her mother sent you an additional check for $1,504. That should cover the damages.

So, can a tenant refuse to let a landlord show the apartment before moving out? Yes, unless the lease states otherwise. But it’s common courtesy to allow it.

PLAINTIFF:
I wasn’t paid for the lost rent.

JUDGE:
You received $1,504 plus the $800 security deposit. That covers October’s rent and damages. Case dismissed.

JUDGE: These are the plaintiffs Aries Peña and Wascar Hisano. Aries says they were tenants of the defendant for a year and a half, and let's just say it was the coldest year and a half of their lives. There was a constant heat problem. Her son got terribly sick, and when she complained, the defendant rudely told her if it wasn't warm enough, she could move. Well, that's exactly what they did, and now the guy won't return their security and moving costs. So they're suing for the $3,500 they claim they are owed.

JUDGE: This is the defendant, Edward Guster. He says he can't believe the plaintiffs are suing him considering he baptized their son. He thinks the real reason they wanted to move out was because of the constant fighting with the downstairs neighbors, which stemmed from the plaintiff flushing baby wipes down the toilet, clogging up the pipes. Owe them money? No way. He’s accused of being cold—very, very cold.

COURT CLERK: All parties please raise your right hands. All have been sworn, Your Honor.

JUDGE: Thank you, Douglas. Welcome, Aries Peña and Wascar Hisano. You are suing Edward Guster, your former landlord, for $1,300 for a security deposit return, plus money you put down on your new apartment and the cost of a moving truck. Okay, what happened?

PLAINTIFF (ARIES PEÑA): On July 3rd, 2011, we moved into the apartment, and everything was fine until the winter came. We constantly had problems with the heat. Every time we would call and ask Mr. Edward to come over, he would check the heater. It would work one day, and then the next day, it wouldn’t. It was just on and off for that year.

PLAINTIFF (ARIES PEÑA): Before the winter of 2012, we had discussed that I didn’t want the same thing to happen again. Last year, my son got sick. My son is two years old, and I don’t think any child should go through freezing cold. We constantly had to have him with his jacket on all day. If it was just us two, I wouldn’t mind so much—I would just put a jacket on—but it was my baby. And Mr. Edward would fix it one day, and then the next, it wouldn’t work again.

PLAINTIFF (ARIES PEÑA): The plumber came over several times and said there was an option: either get a second boiler for the separate apartment upstairs or turn up the heat and let the downstairs neighbor shut her heat off so it could rise to the second floor. But that never happened.

PLAINTIFF (ARIES PEÑA): Eventually, the heat went out again, and I told my husband, "Listen, I need you to call him because I can’t do this anymore." When he called, the defendant said, "If you’re not happy with the heat that we’re providing, you can move."

JUDGE: Were you on a month-to-month lease, or was it a year-long lease?

PLAINTIFF (WASCAR HISANO): The lease was for two years, but it was never signed.

JUDGE: Was the lease ever signed?

PLAINTIFF (WASCAR HISANO): To be honest, Your Honor, we couldn’t find one that my wife had signed.

JUDGE: So then you were month-to-month.

DEFENDANT (EDWARD GUSTER): They did sign it. We just can’t find the original.

JUDGE: If there’s no signed lease, then it’s month-to-month. Go on.

PLAINTIFF (WASCAR HISANO): When my husband called, he asked, "What are we going to do about the deposit?" And the defendant said, "When you move out, we’ll look at the apartment, and if everything’s okay, we’ll give you your deposit back."

JUDGE: Did you tell him then that you were moving?

PLAINTIFF (WASCAR HISANO): Yes. This was in early October.

JUDGE: And when did you actually move out?

PLAINTIFF (ARIES PEÑA): By October 27th, we found a new apartment. We were supposed to move on Monday, October 29th, but because of Hurricane Sandy, we couldn’t. The next day, we had no electricity, so we decided to take all the food and move to the new place.

JUDGE: You moved during Hurricane Sandy?

PLAINTIFF (ARIES PEÑA): Yes, the next day, Tuesday. It was freezing cold, and we had no electricity.

JUDGE: So you’re suing for the security deposit back. What I don’t understand is why you’re also suing for the cost of a moving truck and the money you put down on another apartment. Why would he have to pay that?

PLAINTIFF (ARIES PEÑA): It was just that we had to do everything ourselves.

JUDGE: That’s not his responsibility. Why does he have to pay for your moving expenses?

PLAINTIFF (ARIES PEÑA): We didn’t want to move—we just wanted the heat to be fixed.

DEFENDANT (EDWARD GUSTER): When I spoke to the husband about moving out, it wasn’t really heating season yet. I had put in three new radiators, one in the bedroom, one in the baby’s bedroom, one in the kitchen, and one in the bathroom.

JUDGE: But they still kept calling you?

DEFENDANT (EDWARD GUSTER): Yes, but by the end of September, I suggested they look for another apartment if they weren’t happy.

JUDGE: Did they ever call to tell you when they were moving out?

DEFENDANT (EDWARD GUSTER): No, they never called me. I saw them moving on November 1st.

PLAINTIFF (WASCAR HISANO): That’s incorrect. We gave him the key on the 6th.

JUDGE: Why didn’t you pay for November if your stuff was still there?

PLAINTIFF (WASCAR HISANO): We didn’t want to stay longer; we just needed time to move.

DEFENDANT (EDWARD GUSTER): I offered them half the deposit back on November 13th, but they refused and took me to court instead.

JUDGE: They left on the 6th and filed on the 9th. You rented the place on the 15th, mitigating your damages. Verdict for the plaintiff, $650.

Judge: All parties, please rise. Are you ready?

Judge: Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiff was hired to help renovate the defendant’s body shop and got stiffed, but the defendant says the plaintiff was hammering him for way too much, even demanding money at a funeral. It’s the case of "I won’t rest in peace until you pay me."

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Andrew Toll & Toll Renovations, you are suing Albert Bini for $1,800 that you say he owes you for work that was done and completed but that he never paid you for. Tell me.

Plaintiff: Yes, Your Honor. I was contracted by Al to do some work at a body shop that he owned. He was going to have his nephew renovate to work in the body shop. He had me do work at my hourly rate with another employee of mine.

Judge: How did he have you do the work? Did you guys have a contract?

Plaintiff: Verbal contract.

Judge: Okay. And verbally, what did he say he would pay you?

Plaintiff: He would pay me $35 an hour, and my employee would be $20 an hour.

Judge: And then what was the work he was asking you to do?

Plaintiff: Well, what we did was we power washed the body shop completely. We started to paint the body shop.

Judge: You started to paint. How far along did you get?

Plaintiff: 90% of it.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: There was a leak in the roof under the air conditioning condenser. I fixed all of the roof except for that.

Judge: When you say fixed the roof, what does that mean?

Plaintiff: I put down a torch-down rubber-modified roof.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: Underneath the air conditioning condenser was another source of the leak that I couldn’t fix until the air conditioning condenser was removed.

Judge: Okay. So Al found someone to rent the property and canceled all the work. Did you—now tell me everything that you’d done. Anything else to tell me about?

Plaintiff: No, that was it. I tore out a rug that Al said he didn’t want torn out. He had someone come in to rent the space and—

Judge: You tore out a rug that he didn’t want torn out?

Plaintiff: It was an old rug in the office. He thought it was a good rug. Then someone came in that was going to run the body shop for him. He wanted the rug torn out because he was going to move into that area.

Judge: So, he asked for you to rip it out?

Plaintiff: Al said whatever he wanted me to do, to take care of.

Judge: And then later got mad that the rug got discarded?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: How much did he pay you?

Plaintiff: About $4,000 or so.

Judge: And how did he pay that $4,000?

Plaintiff: Over several checks.

Judge: How many checks?

Plaintiff: About five.

Judge: About five. So, how is it that you would get paid? What was the custom?

Plaintiff: I would submit my hours to Al, and he would pay me.

Judge: And then he stopped?

Plaintiff: He paid me less than I had on the estimate or for the invoice, and then finally he just stopped paying.

Judge: Mr. Bini, why is it, according to him, you still owe him $1,800?

Defendant: Your Honor, I met Mr. Toll through my nephew. He was a personal friend of my nephew. I had a tenant move out, and all I wanted was the building painted inside and outside and some leak repairs done to the roof. I told him not to do any demolition work to the rugs in the main office because I could shampoo them and make them work for the next person to come in.

Judge: Tell me what happens. Why did you stop paying him?

Defendant: The work was substandard.

Judge: How so?

Defendant: The paint—he was billing me hourly. I didn’t know that.

Judge: What did you think he was going to bill you?

Defendant: The five checks I wrote him were just like that. But he never defined it. I kept asking him for an invoice.

Judge: Well, then why do you keep paying him?

Defendant: I stopped paying him. That’s why I stopped.

Judge: No, why did you pay him five times if that didn’t work for you?

Defendant: I had to get it rented. I can’t feed my family without the income.

Judge: So you kept having him work for you under this manner for five full checks?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: So you did do business like this. Now, apparently, the last check you gave him was for how much?

Plaintiff: Your Honor, the last check that he gave me was for $1,800. In the notation section, he wrote $2,100 minus $300—$1,800 balance.

Judge: Let me see that. And you cashed that check?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And that was how long ago?

Plaintiff: February of last year.

Judge: Okay, well, here’s my ruling. You clearly paid him five times for work he did, so you felt five times that he earned his keep. If it was good enough for you, it's good enough for me. I find that you owe him $1,800, just like you said you did, and I’m ordering you to pay the plaintiff $1,800 plus his court costs.

Judge: And listen to me—try to comport yourself like a grown man as opposed to a child, okay? Pretend your daughter is watching you at every turn. She is. Keep an eye on him.

Court adjourned.

Defendant: "I don't know what I'd do if I didn't have my kids. And I've tried to leave this relationship, but she won't let me leave. I've literally tried to physically leave, and she's stood in front of the car to where I couldn't leave. Where she says, 'I'm gonna call the cops and tell them you hit me.'"

Judge: "What? Mrs. White, you're doing way too much manipulating."
