He says that the defendant is one of those double-talking landlords who promised that an apartment he rented from him was going to be ready, and it wasn’t. They had a firm move-in date, but he postponed it a few times, which was a huge and costly inconvenience. And when he did finally move in, there was no doorknob or lock on the front door, and the oven didn’t work. He demanded a refund from the defendant. The louse refuses, and he's here suing for the $700 he's still owed.

Judge: This is the defendant, Frank. He says he disagrees with the plaintiff because the apartment was in move-in condition. The plaintiff simply changed his mind on a whim, and he can’t believe he wasted his time fixing up the place for the plaintiff because he double-crossed him. He’s accused of not being ready.

Bailiff: All parties, please raise your right hands.

Judge: Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case in the docket: The plaintiff rented from the defendant, but when it came time for the move-in date, it came and went. And when he finally moved in, it didn’t even have a doorknob. But the defendant says the plaintiff just had buyer’s remorse. It’s the case of Show Them the Door but Not the Knob.

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Christopher Russo, you are suing Frank, your almost-landlord, for $700 remaining of a deposit that you had given him. And according to you, the place wasn’t ready. Talk to me.

Plaintiff: Correct. So, in mid-September, I had to find a new apartment because the place I was renting from was being sold. I wasn’t having much luck, but I did find Frank’s place on Craigslist. He was running what he was calling a "renovation special," which basically meant that he was admitting the place still needed a lot of work, still had renovations to be done, but he was looking for someone to sign a lease to move in as soon as possible after those renovations were complete.

Judge: But to sign now in the hope that the renovations were done. That’s what it sounds like to me. Did you guys have a lease or no?

Plaintiff: Yes. I had given him the $3,200, which includes the month-and-a-half security deposit plus the first month’s rent for the lease that was supposed to start on October 15th.

Judge: And when did you give that to him?

Plaintiff: I gave him the security deposit on September 29th. I gave him the first month’s rent on October 10th when I assumed I was moving in on the 15th as per the terms of the lease and the security deposit.

Plaintiff: On September 29th, my friend Pete and I went to sign the security deposit, and the apartment was still a complete wreck. There was dust and dirt everywhere. But we figured he still had two-plus weeks, and he did have someone helping him, so at that point, I wasn’t worried yet.

Judge: Was he actually doing the work himself?

Plaintiff: Him and someone else, I believe.

Plaintiff: The security deposit, which I signed on that date and I gave him the $1,920, the first thing it says is: If the unit is not available at the agreed-upon date, the landlord will make a full refund of the deposit without interest and with no liability or penalty to either party.

Judge: And that’s in the contract that you had signed?

Plaintiff: That’s in the security deposit contract.

Judge: Can I see the security deposit contract?

Plaintiff: Yes, this is not the lease. This was the security deposit agreement.

Judge: (Reading contract) Okay.

Plaintiff: On October 10th, I signed the lease. He had $3,200 of mine. It was agreed that I would pick up the keys on the 16th, even though the lease started the 15th. He said he was busy that day, so already pushing back one day. But that was fine at that time.

Plaintiff: So, needless to say, my brother scheduled the day off work for that Wednesday. I had a truck ready to go. And I thought, on the 14th, the day before the lease was to start, I better just write him a quick email making sure everything's good. I do have all the email correspondence—it’s several pages. But he just said that the place was not going to be ready until the 19th, the Friday.

Judge: Friday the 19th, correct?

Plaintiff: So on the 18th, the day before the Friday that I’m supposed to get my keys, he writes me saying, "The good news is the place will definitely, absolutely be ready by October 20th," which is Saturday.

Judge (to Defendant): What’s going on here? Why isn’t the place ready when he is supposed to be moving in?

Defendant: I’m a perfectionist. I was trying to make this place perfect, and I just kept finding things to do, unfortunately. And that’s really all it is.

Judge: I know, but you have a deadline for your completion of your work. Why did you miss the deadline?

Defendant: I underestimated how long it was going to take.

Judge: That’s a better answer. That’s the truthful answer. It’s not that you’re a perfectionist—it’s that you didn’t do what you said you were going to do.

Judge: Now, he didn’t have a problem with it on the 15th. He didn’t have a problem with it on the 16th. He didn’t have a problem with it on the 19th. When you moved it now to the 20th, what happens?

Plaintiff: So, on the 20th, we show up, and I actually have this whole thing on recording as well, and a witness.

Judge: Okay, so you actually go in there on the 20th with this witness?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And you actually tape him?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: You don’t tell him you’re taping him?

Plaintiff: I did at the very end.

Judge: That’s after you taped him. That’s not what I’m asking. But that’s legal in New Jersey. In my state, Florida, it’s a third-degree felony if you do that.

Judge: Let’s play the recording.

(Recording plays)

Judge: There was no doorknob to his apartment?

Defendant: The door was brand new. The person who was supposed to do it had an issue, and then it wasn’t done in time.

Judge: Why didn’t the stove work?

Defendant: The outlet that the stove plugs into was inoperational that day.

Judge: At what point are you just so untrustworthy and unreliable that people don’t have to go into business with you?

Judge: Can you explain why, when you returned his money, you kept $700?

Defendant: The unit was fine.

Judge: No, it wasn’t.

Judge: Verdict for the plaintiff, $700.
manipulation_techniques: framing the narrative, character attack, gaslighting, minimization

dialogue:
Judge: Kareem P, you are suing Patricia Hacker for $5,000 for pain and suffering and the cost of the dog. You say your dog was attacked by her dog and that it's her fault. Tell me what happened. I'm so sorry about the loss of your dog.

Plaintiff: Okay, when this happened, I wasn’t in that moment with my kids. Okay, it was my husband who came up. What happened? That happened February 24 at night. I was walking up the same way when I drive in, my son, my first son, he was away from me by 10 feet, and I was walking with my second son. My first son had his puppy. He was, how old is your first son?

Judge: 10 years old. How does he have your puppy? Explain.

Plaintiff: Okay, he was walking with the leash.

Judge: A leash?

Plaintiff: Yes, I have the leash. You have the leash. Let me see it.

Plaintiff (showing leash): So, my son, my first son, was 10 feet ahead of me walking the dog. And what happens then? The puppy stopped.

Judge: Who's the puppy? My Coco? How old is your dog?

Plaintiff: Okay, it's a teacup poodle. Five pounds, no more than that. It’s a teacup. I have the pictures if you want.

Judge (looking at pictures): Yeah, let me see it.

Plaintiff (showing pictures): Okay, so what happens? Coco, he was doing his business, and in one moment, I saw another dog coming in the same direction where my son was. My second son spoke to me in that moment, and I looked at my son, and that was the last time I saw Coco on the floor. My son screamed and ran to me. Then I see her dog.

Judge: What kind of dog do you have?

Plaintiff: It's a Pitbull.

Judge: Okay, go ahead.

Plaintiff: My Pitbull grabbed my Coco. I tried to kick the dog, but then he let go of the puppy. The first time I saw Coco, I knew he was already in bad condition.

Judge: The dog was alive though when you took the dog to the vet?

Plaintiff: No, in that moment, we didn’t have the key to go back to the garage. Some neighbors heard my son screaming because he was begging for help. My little son came to me, and he said, "Oh, the dog killed him," and I thought it was my son. Then I saw my dog, and he looked at me and passed away. So, we thought we could do something, so we took the dog with a neighbor’s car to the hospital. When we got there, I gave the dog to the doctor, and he said, "I’m sorry." I saw my clothes with blood and everything. It’s very sad because it’s not only the first time this happened. The same dog attacked another dog, and I have proof. Yes, I have the pictures. When I went to make the report to the police, the police were very sad for me, but unfortunately, when a dog is killed by another dog, you can’t do anything.

Judge: Well, that’s not true. You’re doing something, but go ahead. I want to see the pictures. Do you have a statement from that person?

Plaintiff: Yes, I have it.

Judge: Okay, let me see that.

Defendant: Okay, I was walking my dog, and there was something that I thought at first was a cat, you know, because there wasn’t anyone on the street. The dog was by itself. Then I realized that it wasn’t a cat, that it was actually a dog. You say the dog was by itself. Was the dog on a leash?

Defendant: Absolutely not. The dog wasn’t on a leash, and neither were the two boys. There was one boy.

Judge: Okay, I have an affidavit for a witness that was directly across the street.

Defendant: No, no, she’s keeping me company. She’s my sister.

Judge: Okay, go on.

Defendant: The dog was by itself when it started running at me. May I step out?

Judge: Yeah, okay.

Defendant: The dog just came running at me. So, I screamed. No, okay, the dog kept coming, and by that time, he was right at me. I stuck my foot up, and it hit the bottom of my foot. It ricocheted off, crashing into my shin. I had a bruise for at least two weeks on my leg. The dog bounced back, leaped on my dog’s face, and bit him.

Judge: Okay, I have pictures of his face.

Defendant (showing pictures): Let me see. I immediately stuck my hand in the choker, and I told him, "No, no." It’s a baby now. I know he knows the word “baby,” so he immediately put the dog down on the ground.

Defendant: Then simultaneously, I look and there’s a man kneeling in front of me, and I hear the voice of a boy next to me. The man went down, took the dog up, and was doing this to the top of the head. I said to him, "Is he okay?" He said, "He’s fine, he’s fine."

Judge: Okay, so you went across the street and called again.

Defendant: Yes, I asked, "Are you sure? Is he okay?" He said, "He’s fine, he’s fine."

Judge: The attack killed the dog. Why would an owner of a dog say everything’s fine?

Defendant: He wasn’t saying, "Everything’s fine." He said, "He’s fine." Did you think he was fine?

Judge: I know, but it had to be a pretty serious attack. Was there blood?

Defendant: I didn’t see any blood, no.

Judge: Was there blood on the spot?

Defendant: Yes, of course.

Judge: According to you, he goes, “Yeah, everything’s fine,” and then the dog dies.

Defendant: He didn’t say like that. He said, “He’s fine.”

Judge: Okay, go on.

Defendant: I walked across the street to where the witness was standing. He said to me, “Was that you that was screaming?” I said to him, “Yeah, there was a dog across the street with no leash.” I was screaming at the dog to stop. The witness said, “I heard the commotion and saw a man with a tan and white dog crossing the sidewalk. The dog was wearing a double collar and was on a leash.”

Judge: What’s this person’s name?

Defendant: I can’t even read the signature. Well, it’s Joe Mango. Do you know that person?

Judge (reading the statement): “I saw and heard a dog running from the underground garage up the driveway. A few minutes later, I saw a woman with a male tan and white dog crossing the sidewalk. Her dog was wearing a double collar and was being held on a leash. She was recounting an incident with another dog across the street moments before. She told me her dog was just attacked by another unleashed dog.”

Judge (pondering): What do I have here? I have the plaintiff, who has the burden of proof in my courtroom of proving that things happened the way she says. And I have some question whether things happened the way she says. And unless you're able to persuade me by a preponderance of the evidence that they happened your way, my verdict has to be for the defendant.

Judge (after considering): And it is. Good luck, folks.

Judge: This is the plaintiff, Shawn Dale Tatum. She says she was involved in a hit-and-run accident and her 2004 Kia Sedona was badly damaged. The defendant promised to repair her car, made her pay for everything up front, and then the rat took off with her money. Now she has a smashed car, no money, and is suing the defendant for the $800 she gave him.

Judge: This is the defendant, Angel Suarez. He says the plaintiff, his sister-in-law, canceled the order for the repair work to be done after he'd already ordered the parts. The woman’s trying to play games with him, and he's not going to get stuck with the parts the mechanic already ordered. This whole thing’s one big mess now because he's not talking to his brother. He's accused of not fixing it.

[Music]

Judge: Good. All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiff was involved in a hit and run. The defendant promised to fix it but didn't. The defendant says the plaintiff, who is his sister-in-law, did some funny business with the parts. It's the case of "I Hit That."

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Okay, Shawn Dale Tatum, you are suing Angel Suarez for $800 that you say he owes you in parts that you'd ordered with him, but he never fixed your car. According to you, she tried to change her mind on the deal, and the parts have already been purchased. Let me hear from you first.

Plaintiff: Well, um, my car was in an accident. I was hit on my front passenger side.

Judge: Okay, and he fixed the car?

Plaintiff: He came over—

Judge: How do you know him?

Plaintiff: He's my husband's brother.

Judge: He's your husband's brother? Why were you calling him a friend in the—

Plaintiff: Well, because he's my husband's friend, but they've known each other for a while, so they consider each other family.

Judge: Okay. Are you brothers or are you not brothers?

Defendant: They're not related. They're not actually brothers, just friends.

Judge: You grew up together?

Defendant: We said that we were brothers.

Judge: In the same household?

Defendant: No, in the same neighborhood.

Judge: How big a neighborhood is this?

Plaintiff: Okay, so it’s a close friend of his.

Judge: And then what? You—you know him?

Plaintiff: I met him through my husband, yes.

Judge: Okay, and now your husband ended up in jail?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: What is he in jail for?

Plaintiff: Um, drugs.

Judge: Okay. So, was he in jail at the time that you hired him to fix the car?

Plaintiff: No, he was out.

Judge: Who does the hiring—him or you?

Plaintiff: Um, I spoke with Angel, and we agreed that he would fix my car for me.

Judge: All right. Do you give him any money?

Plaintiff: Um, at that time, no. He just came over, he looked at the car, he told me what we were going to need to purchase for the car.

Judge: Now, are you a repairman? Are you a bodyman? What are you?

Defendant: No, a friend of mine owns a mechanic shop and a body shop. So she asked me to come and check out the car. I said, all right, no problem.

Judge: Why? Just because you know a guy who knows what he's doing?

Defendant: I—I—I do mechanic work.

Judge: Okay.

Defendant: But a friend of mine owns a body shop right next door to the shop that we had.

Judge: Were you going to do the mechanic work and he was going to do the body work?

Defendant: Yes, correct.

Judge: And do you have a job, or you don't?

Defendant: No, I do. I help my stepfather at the shop at the mechanic—

Judge: Is this the shop we're talking about?

Defendant: No.

Judge: That was—oh, that’s your—a friend of mine or your stepfather?

Defendant: No, my step—no, no, no. The body shop is a friend. The mechanic shop is my stepfather's.

Judge: Okay. So, you tell her, "I can help you out and get you a good price."

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: And you folks agree on what?

Defendant: I told her parts were going to run her $800.

Judge: How much did she pay you for parts?

Defendant: She gave me—first, she gave me $450. She, I think, Western Union money-granted it to me, and then she gave me another amount of $280.

Judge: Does that sound right?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: How much do you say you gave?

Plaintiff: I wired $450, right? And then $300 on another day.

Judge: Okay. Does that sound familiar?

Defendant: No. She—totally, she gave me $280.

Judge: Okay. So, do you have a receipt?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Okay. Well, that's where we are on that one—without a receipt. All right, now let’s move on from that fact and let’s talk about what actually happens. This is the end of February. You take the car?

Defendant: No.

Judge: So, you're waiting for the parts to come?

Defendant: No, the parts were already there. Then she calls me. Before she gave me the money, I ordered the parts for her. She tells me she didn’t want to do it.

Judge: How long after telling you did she say that?

Defendant: I ordered the parts that same day. Me and her discussed it, I ordered the parts. She comes and tells me that she doesn't want to do the car the following day.

Judge: Okay. So, it's back and forth—"I want the car fixed, I don’t want the car fixed." We already had the parts in the shop. So, I tell the guy, "Listen, she wants the money back." But he goes, "You guys are playing games going back and forth with these parts. I can't get my money back."

Judge: Okay. Now, I need you to prove exactly what you just said. Do you have the guy here to testify?

Defendant: No, I don’t.

Judge: Do you have the receipts to prove that you bought parts?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Now, why do you get to change your mind? The rest of us can't. [Continues with legal discussion and ruling.]

Judge: I am awarding the plaintiff $730 plus court costs. That’s my judgment.

**Judge:** This is the plaintiff Ronald Austin. He says he was driving down the highway, and the impatient defendant tried to squeeze by him in another car. He lost control and crashed into both cars. The defendant refuses to pay him for his damages, so he's suing him for the $1,667.26 he's owed.

This is the defendant Alan Bucknall. He says it was the crazy plaintiff who tried to squeeze his way through. They all stopped. He and the other car decided they would let the insurance take care of it. The plaintiff was the only one who refused, and here they are. He's accused of trying to fit in where he couldn't.

All parties, please raise your right hand.
Ronald Austin, you are suing Alan Bucknell for $1,667.26 in damages to your car as well as an insurance lapse ticket.

Okay, what happened?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, I am, Your Honor. I was on my way to work at my overtime site, and I was coming down the FDI Drive. After I got off the entrance lane, I was in the right lane, and an ambulance was coming. As I tried to get off the lane onto Hon Street to make the right turn because I was already in the right lane, all of a sudden, I hear a noise in the back of my car. I look to the side, and I see this young man pull up on the side of me. And I'm looking at him and saying, "Why didn't you wait until I turned the corner?" That was my remark to him, and that’s the truth.

**Judge:** Okay. "Why didn’t you wait until I turned the corner?" Let’s do something. Come on up to the drawing that we have here. Now pick any car you want to be.

**Plaintiff:** (Picks a car)

**Judge:** There you go. Now, you say that you were in the—oh, no, no. Right. I’m going to—here’s the exit.

**Plaintiff:** Yeah, I'm sorry.

**Judge:** Okay, no problem. All right. So you are there, right? All right. And then pick a car to be him.

**Plaintiff:** (Picks another car)

**Judge:** Okay. And what is it you are saying happens? I want you to show me what you say happened.

**Plaintiff:** Well, it’s one more car involved.

**Judge:** Okay, go ahead.

**Plaintiff:** Because the other car got hit in the right light. After that car got hit—

**Judge:** So first this car gets hit, right?

**Plaintiff:** Right.

**Judge:** And then what happens?

**Plaintiff:** Then he runs into the side of me.

**Judge:** Okay, that’s what you’re describing?

**Plaintiff:** Yes.

**Judge:** Okay. Where was he trying to go? Do you think he was trying to cut past you?

**Plaintiff:** He thought he could make it between the two cars. I believe he lost control. When I realized—I didn’t know what happened initially.

**Judge:** Well, what makes you—

**Plaintiff:** Well, clearly, he lost control. There’s a car accident.

**Judge:** I mean, what made you think he came from behind you?

**Plaintiff:** Okay, and now my understanding is that there was an ambulance, and there was everybody trying to get out of the way, right?

**Judge:** Right. Well—

**Plaintiff:** And we weren’t moving that fast. I mean, we pulled over and had to get off the lane.

**Judge:** Right. And then everybody pulls over on Houston, right?

**Plaintiff:** Right.

**Judge:** All right. That’s what I meant. So when the police come, is everybody pulled over or no? On Houston waiting for the police or no?

**Plaintiff:** No, he was already there. I was the first one to him. I have a picture in my phone showing—

**Judge:** Sorry, the police was already in the area?

**Plaintiff:** Yeah, he was right over here when I turned the corner, and I told him what happened.

**Judge:** Okay, go ahead and go back to the podium.

All right, Mr. Bucknall, what happened that day?

**Defendant:** Hi. So essentially, um, my friend and I, Darice Wright, we were heading back into—originally, we were heading back to go towards Brooklyn. I was in the right lane. I was closer to the edge of the middle line in two-lane traffic.

**Judge:** Why don’t you come up here and show me?

(Defendant approaches the diagram)

**Judge:** Now, just to recap, so that—I don’t want you switching cars on me. I know there’s an ambulance somewhere. All right. This is going to be the third car. This is going to be you, and this is going to be him. Tell me where everybody is. I want you to be able to put it where you want. I don’t want to put it anywhere in your story.

**Defendant:** (Positions cars) So this is the third car, as I said. I’m here, and as I said, I’m closer to the line, so there’s a little space in between the curb and right here. And Mr. Ronald is right here behind me.

**Judge:** Okay.

**Defendant:** There’s an ambulance coming up. The light just turns green as I’m moving forward, and he’s moving forward. Mr. Ronald, in his effort to try and escape the ambulance, is moving up. As he’s moving up, he pushes me into this vehicle right here.

**Judge:** Okay. So, according to your testimony, he’s looking forward, he’s driving, and he literally—and people are going like 10 miles an hour at this point. They’re not going fast.

**Defendant:** Yes.

**Judge:** And he tries to wedge himself in between?

**Defendant:** Yes.

**Judge:** All right. Go ahead and go back to the podium.

(Continued questioning and discussion on evidence and witness testimony.)

**Judge:** Based on the fact that I have absolutely no idea which version of events is accurate, and it's your job to prove to me which of you had the right of way, I cannot rule in your favor. My verdict in this case is for the defendant.

(End of courtroom session.)
manipulation_techniques: playing the victim, emotional appeal, persuasion

dialogue:
Judge:
Muhammad, you are suing Rose. You’ve asked to be referred to only by your first names for $500, a deposit that you put down at Rose’s, is it a restaurant venue? That she refuses to return. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
Okay, so on September 29th, we first met Rose at her hall and we spoke to her about a party, an engagement party, on October 20th. And right off the bat, we tried to let her know that no matter what, we need it on the 20th, and she was adamant on saying that things are done her way and that she’s going to figure it out, and it’s up to her. So we came back. I came back, my fiancé was working on October 2nd, and me and Rose had a brief conversation about what was going to happen.

Judge:
Why’d you come back if she was such a jerk?

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
Because, at the end of the day, it was a really nice room and that’s the room that we wanted.

Judge:
What was she being a jerk about?

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
She just isn’t, she was overall just trying to do things her way.

Judge:
Meaning what?

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
She was saying that if we can’t do the party on the 20th, then we can’t do it.

Judge:
So, you wanted to do it when?

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
On the 20th.

Judge:
Wait, I’m not understanding. So she was agreeing to do the party on the 20th, in a different room, not in the room that we wanted?

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
Yes.

Judge:
Okay, so why don’t you just do like anybody else, pick up your marbles and go home and pick another venue?

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
Because we like the room.

Judge:
So you were willing to do what?

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
When you like the room and it’s not available, what is your next game plan?

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
She had told us that if somebody canceled, that she would work around that, or she would try and work around the dates and move them to another date.

Judge:
Why would anybody with a deposit put on a place want to move their date? They already have the place.

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
Maybe on a different room, in a different room at the same venue.

Judge:
Why would they want a different room?

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
They had already rented that room.

Judge:
Alright, so she says she’ll work on it. You leave, and then what happens?

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
I come back without my fiancé. We have a brief discussion. Some bad things happen when you’re without your fiancé.

Judge:
I agree.

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
What did you do?

Judge:
You put a deposit down for what date?

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
So, there was no date. There was no date agreed upon. So, you put a deposit down for no date?

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
So she said that, um, I what we spoke when she was telling me to come in was to get the money. She just needed a deposit.

Judge:
You can’t give money if you don’t have your venue and a date. I don’t know what you’re talking about.

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
That’s the whole point.

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
So, you gave someone money to hold a venue without a date?

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
Correct.

Judge:
Without an established date, until she could figure out what she could move around?

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
Yes.

Judge:
Why didn’t you just wait until she figured out what she would move around?

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
Because it was within two weeks. This was October 20th.

Judge:
But why would you give any money if you don’t have a date?

Plaintiff (Muhammad):
Just to show her that I was serious about it.

Judge:
Alright, we have a very different version of what occurred, unfortunately.

Defendant (Rose):
Yes, everything that was said from the plaintiff was not true. I have a contract for Sunday, October 21st. I have text messages from his fiancé for Sunday, October 21st.

Defendant (Rose):
A week after they gave me the deposit on the 21st, they texted and said, "Hey, listen, my sister can’t get an airline ticket for the 21st. She needs to go home to Georgia and she has to work on Monday." I said, "What does that have to do with it?"

Judge:
So they changed their mind about the 21st.

Defendant (Rose):
But according to you, they had rented the room they wanted, but on the 21st?

Judge:
Alright, now you said you have a contract. Show me your contract.

Defendant (Rose):
Yes.

Defendant (Rose):
I’m sorry, where’s your signature?

Defendant (Rose):
After the text message that was sent saying they wanted the 21st, I was in my office and I had clients. I was booking another event.

Judge:
Did he walk in and give you $500?

Defendant (Rose):
Yes, ma’am.

Judge:
So, you took his $500 but did not have him sign a document?

Defendant (Rose):
Yes.

Judge:
Why would you not have him sign a contract with the dates, especially when the dates were an issue?

Defendant (Rose):
The date was an issue, it was in my book, and I have text messages.

Judge:
Well, then I guess it’s all settled, right? We don’t need the reason you’re right. I did not have to show me the text messages. Do you have them in your phone?

Defendant (Rose):
I have them in my phone.

Judge:
Go ahead and turn on your phone. I know you turned it off to come into court, but I’d like to see them in the phone so I don’t just see the ones that a litigant wanted to show me.

Judge:
What am I going to see in those text messages? Am I going to see you and your girlfriend deciding on the 21st, then your sister can’t change her flight, then you guys decide to not have the party on the 21st, and now you want your money back?

Defendant (Rose):
Not at all.

Judge:
Okay, starts from here and goes all the way.

Judge:
On October 2nd, you let them know, "Hey, I have October 28th now," which I presume was a Saturday. She says, "Is the 21st no longer available in the Rosetta room?" And you say, "I don’t know what you say because I don’t see an answer, so I presume I don’t know whether that was by phone or what."

Judge:
And then she says, "Hey, Muhammad is going to be there at 11:45." Okay, do you, is there anything you can do for us for 10/20 for us, preferably something small like the Rosetta room?

Defendant (Rose):
You answer, "Hello, I just want to let you know in the Rosetta room on the 20th, I am completely sold out." It’s like the first time you guys even talk about the 20th is in this text. Did they talk about the 20th in your office?

Judge:
Because it’s like the first time your girlfriend’s talking about it here. So, even though I’m giving her grief that she doesn’t have a signed contract, which is what you should have, verbal contracts are enforceable. What am I to glean from these texts from your girlfriend who says specifically, "Wait, the 21st isn’t available because that’s the date you guys wanted." I can tell from that, and when she says, "Hey, we’re thinking about the 20th now," what am I to glean, but that you changed your mind?

Judge:
The default position on any deposit is non-refundable. That’s the default position because the whole point of a deposit is to hold the place and not let anybody else get it. So that’s the purpose of a deposit.

Judge:
I understand that you didn’t sign anything, but between the default position of any deposit being non-refundable unless they say otherwise, and the second thing, which is from the text, I clearly see you booked the 21st and then changed your mind because of your sister’s flight.

Judge:
Okay, I’m sorry that you’re in this position. Verdict for the defendant.

Judge: All parties, please. Welcome back to the People’s Court. Next case on the docket: The Plaintiff gave the Defendant 200 bucks for a pool table, but his guys couldn’t move it, and he wants his money back. The Defendant says that’s what happens when you try to move a heavy object with 70-year-olds. It’s the case of "That’s My Cue to Sue." Thank you, Douglas. Terry Richardson, you are suing Trisha—you’ve asked us to just refer to you by your first name—for 200 dollars that you put as a deposit on a pool table, and you want it back. What happened?

Plaintiff: On March 3rd, 2017, I inquired on the marketplace on Facebook about pool tables.

Judge: You were selling a pool table? Why?

Defendant: We had damage to our house from the hurricane, and we needed our floors repaired.

Judge: Which hurricane?

Defendant: Matthew.

Judge: Okay. And you needed your floors repaired, so you needed to get rid of the pool table. So you followed up on it?

Plaintiff: Correct. I saw an ad, we contacted each other through Facebook, and she gave me the price—400 dollars.

Defendant: I originally had it listed for 500, but we needed it gone fast.

Judge: Okay. Well, there are two listings on the web. The price is great, but go ahead.

Plaintiff: We contacted each other, she gave me the address, and I visited her house. This was my first time ever purchasing a pool table, so I said, "Alright, I might have to get some guys."

Judge: Happens every day, right?

Plaintiff: Right. So I go over to take a look at it, and I like it.

Judge: You offer her 400 dollars, she agrees, and you give her 200 as a deposit?

Plaintiff: Right, to come back and get the pool table because I was going to take it apart, remove the legs to carry it out. I had a cousin with a pickup truck. I was going to put it on the pickup truck, but I saw that it was a little heavy—he was 60, 62. So I said, "Well, I need another person to lift the pool table."

Judge: When were you supposed to come back and get the pool table out of there?

Plaintiff: I was trying to get it that day, which was a Friday.

Judge: And so you say, "Well, I’m gonna have to line up a couple of more people." Not a 62-year-old, right?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: To move the pool table?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: Big, burly guys like you. That’s what you need. Guys from the gym. And then what happens? How long do you take to do that?

Plaintiff: I called a friend the same day. He came by within a couple of hours.

Judge: Oh, so that guy comes right away. But you still had just one—you and another guy?

Plaintiff: Yes, but the pool table was extremely heavy. This time, we were like, "This pool table is pretty heavy." So I went to an expert that same day—a pool expert—and he told me these pool tables carry slates that can weigh up to 150 to 200 pounds. Based on the type of pool table she had, she had over four steel slates, which made it extremely heavy.

Judge: The pool expert says that? Based on what?

Plaintiff: He didn’t see the pool table, but aside from that, I didn’t realize how heavy it was.

Judge: Did you try lifting it when you first saw it?

Plaintiff: Yes, and I was able to lift it up.

Judge: So you knew how heavy it was?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: So what happened?

Plaintiff: I went to a professional because I couldn’t lift it with just one other person.

Judge: Did the professional say to you, "Take it apart"?

Plaintiff: Yes. He said the only way to move it is if I hire an expert.

Judge: And how much did he want to charge?

Plaintiff: Four to five hundred dollars.

Judge: And that’s when you decided you didn’t want it anymore?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: So when did you tell her you wanted your money back?

Defendant: Four or five days later.

Judge: Did you put it back on the market?

Defendant: Yes, but we needed it gone right away. He took too long, and we had to get our floors redone.

Judge: What did you end up doing with the pool table?

Defendant: A friend took it. We had to give it away.

Judge: Did the guy who took it have trouble moving it?

Defendant: No, he and two little guys just flipped it up on its side and wheeled it out the door.

Judge: Did they use a dolly?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: So, does the guy who put the 200 down get his money back?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Why not?

Defendant: Because it was a deposit, and deposits are non-refundable.

Judge: She’s right. Your lack of planning is not her emergency. Verdict for the Defendant.

Plaintiff: She lied about the four days. It was the next day.

Judge: That’s irrelevant. The point of a deposit is to take something off the market. She lost money, and she could have counterclaimed against you. Consider yourself lucky. Case dismissed.

Judge: Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket, the plaintiff says his cousin stiffed him after he loaned him some hard-earned money. But the defendant says the plaintiff's new wife is behind this, and it was a gift. It's the case of "Relatively Speaking, You're a Deadbeat."

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Brian Caro?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: You are suing your cousin, Sean Cordwell, for $60 that you loaned him that he apparently doesn’t seem to be able or willing to pay back, correct?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: Okay, tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: Uh, it was about 5:00 in the afternoon. My wife had just gotten back from work with the kids. Sean had been waiting for her to show up because he wanted to talk to both of us. When she got there, we went upstairs. Previously, I had cashed my check and hung money all over this ficus tree.

Judge: Wait, money's hanging all from the tree?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Why?

Plaintiff: It was a joke. The day before, I was joking around with my wife about money growing on trees.

Judge: Is this in New Bedford, Massachusetts?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Remind me to go to New Bedford. Go ahead.

Plaintiff: So, Sean sees the tree, and he says he needs to borrow some money for his job the next day. I thought he needed help or something. I couldn’t deny that I had money because it was right there on the tree.

Judge: Wait, wait, how much money was on the tree?

Plaintiff: A few hundred bucks in tens and twenties, all over the ficus tree.

Judge: Is this tree inside or outside?

Plaintiff: Inside the house, right next to the TV.

Judge: So you taped money all over it?

Plaintiff: Yes, as a joke, because I told my wife the day before that money didn’t grow on trees.

Judge: So you say, "Pick a branch, any branch?"

Plaintiff: Pretty much. I told my wife to get a few twenties off the tree.

Judge: Had he seen the tree before?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: What did your wife say when this was happening?

Plaintiff: When Sean said he needed to borrow money, he promised to pay it back the next morning when his mother got off the boat from The Vineyard.

Judge: Did you get paid back the next morning?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Has it been paid back at all?

Plaintiff: No. It’s been a year and a half now.

Judge: Are you kidding me?

Plaintiff: No. And every time I see him, he says "tomorrow, tomorrow." It’s like being in the musical Annie.

Judge: So, Sean, why haven’t you paid him back?

Defendant: I was unemployed.

Judge: For a year and a half?

Defendant: I did get a job, but I didn’t pay him.

Judge: Why not?

Defendant: I don’t know. I see my mother sitting on the other side, so I pretty much know I lost this case.

Judge: Why is your mother sitting on his side?

Defendant: Judge, your guess is as good as mine.

Judge: Has your mother told you to pay him back?

Defendant: Yes. She’s been telling me that for a year and a half.

Judge: (to the mother) Why are you sitting on his side?

Defendant’s Mother: Because he should have paid him.

Judge: And you never told your son he had to pay him back?

Defendant’s Mother: I told him multiple times. And Sean told Brian that I would pay him, but I didn’t even know about it.

Judge: So Sean, you lied about your mother paying him?

Defendant: I never said that. I just told him I’d pay him when I could.

Judge: Did you work in the last year and a half?

Defendant: I started working three and a half months ago.

Judge: So, you could have paid him?

Defendant: I guess.

Judge: You guess?

Defendant: I just can’t believe he took me to court over $60.

Judge: I can’t believe you didn’t just pay him back and avoid coming here. Your mother even told you to pay him. Verdict for the plaintiff. Pay the $60.

Defendant: Fine.

Judge: Case dismissed.

Judge: Mr. O’Neal, you are suing Ron Lewis and his company for $4,036 that you paid him, that he won’t return to you, because according to you, they did subpar work. You hired him to do some work on your roof, correct?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And why? What was it that had happened?

Plaintiff: There was a fire inside the attic.

Judge: Okay. How did the fire start?

Plaintiff: Uh, the solar panels caught on fire.

Judge: Oh gosh. How did that happen?

Plaintiff: The electricity arced.

Judge: Okay. And so you hire him. How do you find him?

Plaintiff: Uh, I think I might have got him off Indeed or on the internet.

Judge: Okay. Alright. So he comes over. He gives you an estimate. I presume you got estimates from other people?

Plaintiff: Um, no. Actually, he’s the first one I hired.

Judge: How do you know he gave you a fair price?

Plaintiff: Well, he said he said, uh, $12,000 to do the job.

Judge: Right. I know. How do you know $12,000 was a fair price if you don’t get any more estimates? I’m talking to you like you’re my husband, because this is my husband’s theory too.

Plaintiff: No, he seems— I’d like to have him do it.

Judge: How do you know he’s giving you a fair price if you don’t get two other estimates? I’m just curious.

Plaintiff: I don’t know. I don’t exactly.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: All I went on is the price of what my father paid for his roof.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: Which was $10,000.

Judge: Alright, so you had some guidance.

Plaintiff: I had some guidance.

Judge: So he comes— do you have a contract that you signed with him?

Plaintiff: I do.

Judge: Let me see the contract.

(Plaintiff hands over contract.)

Judge: That’s the contract for $12,000. And what were you getting for the $12,000?

Plaintiff: Uh, I told him I wanted all the burnt lumber removed. It needed shingles. And when I got home from work, uh, I had to put a stop to the work because he didn’t remove the burnt timbers.

Judge: Okay. Let’s see what it says:

(Reading contract aloud)

Judge: "Remove and replace rotted or damaged wood prior to installation of new roof. Install 2x6 wood at rafters and underlayer. Install sistered in wood as needed."

Judge: Alright. Tell me, what is sistered wood?

Defendant: Sistered in means—

Judge: What does sistered in mean?

Defendant: You take a 2x6, and if one of the rafters is weak or cracked or not structurally sound, you put a new piece right up against it, and you nail it into the rafter to give it the support that you’re worried the thing has lost.

Judge: Yes, exactly. Okay. But what did you mean when you said, "remove and replace rotted or damaged wood"?

Defendant: The wood that would have been— when we stripped the roof, the wood that would have been on top. Some of it could have been rotted or damaged. We hadn’t gotten to that point yet.

Judge: Except that he had damaged wood from a fire, and that’s what he told you.

Defendant: Not really that damaged.

Judge: Almost what you think. In all, sistered in just as needed?

Defendant: I wasn’t really sure.

Judge: And according to you, when you say "replace rotted or damaged wood prior to putting in a new roof," you just mean some of the wood, not others of the wood?

Defendant: Not exactly.

Judge: Who are you to say what wood that was? That is legitimately interpreted to mean— you were looking at me saying, "Well, that’s not the wood I meant, I meant the wood underneath," but we didn’t get to that. You know, he’s looking at burnt wood, which is what his concern is.

Judge: Do you have pictures of the wood we’re talking about?

Plaintiff: Yes, I do.

(Plaintiff approaches the judge with photos.)

Judge: This one’s got the beam that was— now, you’re going to have to come over here. No, no, come over, come over. I’m going to need you to stand right here.

Plaintiff: Alright.

Judge: This is the main beam that goes from one end of the house to the other?

Plaintiff: Okay.

Judge: And you can see how it was scraped?

Plaintiff: Uh-huh.

Judge: The integrity of the beam is compromised.

Judge: Who are you to say that though? Did you have— is there somebody else who said that? Do you have an opinion from a professional that says this can’t stay that way, that the integrity of the beam is compromised? Or are you just asking me to deduce that from how it looks? Because you and I might both look at it and feel that way.

Judge: What is it you’re doing? Do you have evidence from a professional that says the integrity of the wood was compromised?

Plaintiff: The house smelled like burnt wood.

Judge: And how am I supposed to sell a house like that?

Judge: That doesn’t answer what I’m asking though.


Judge: Did you hire somebody else to do the job?

Plaintiff: Yes, I did.

Judge: And you paid that person $17,000, but you had them rip everything out and start over?

Plaintiff: Yes, I did.

Judge: Now, did that person ever put in writing that anything the defendant did had to be ripped out, as opposed to that you wanted it ripped out?

Plaintiff: Not that I can remember.

Judge: Do you have anybody who can say that what he did was structurally unsound?

Plaintiff: Probably the building inspector or the guy who did the work.

Judge: Call your next witness right now.

Plaintiff: …

Judge: You see what I’m saying? This is your trial. You need to bring evidence to prove your case. I’m asking you six times— did the new guy say that what the first guy did was structurally unsound? Do we have that in writing?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: My verdict in this case is for the defendant.

Defendant: "I don't always see my son."

Plaintiff: "He moved away."

Defendant: "And I didn't move. I moved a couple minutes—about 45, 45 minutes."

Plaintiff: "You went to go be with the other kids. That's what you did. I got the first baby."

Defendant: "Okay, and you act like a hundred dollars in child support ain't nothing. A hundred dollars is more than what's needed. That's extra."

Defendant: "I cheated 'cause I was bored in my marriage. I was too young to get married in the first place. I only did..."

Judge: "So, why did you get married?"

Defendant: "Because I felt like it was the right thing to do because I was being pressured and I had three kids with her."

Judge: We just read your text, so you're a liar, and you lied to the police about that because I just read you your texts.

Defendant: Yeah, but I never said that—like, I stole her—like, I never even told her I stole your money.

Judge: I mean, well, you don’t need to say you stole your money. You were caught stealing her money, at which your text clearly reflects that she never gave you the money. So that means you went to the cookie jar, grabbed it, and took it.

Defendant: She did know, you know. She did know that I took it.

Judge:
Thank you, Douglas. Okay, Angelo Carion, you are suing Axel Rodriguez, doing business as the Auto Doctor, for $3,455. What you say is the Blue Book value of a 1998 GMC truck. You have a counterclaim against them for $2,315 impound fees that you paid on his behalf that you want reimbursed and storage fees from the time of your dispute until today. Tell me what is going on, gentlemen.

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
Okay, how about we try this in English now? Let's try it in English. Thank you for accepting my case. Okay, I took my truck to Mr. X ride for clutch repair. He completed the clutch repair, and when I took the truck out, there was a rattling noise inside where he fixed the clutch. It sounded almost as if there was a nut or a washer in there. I took it back to him to fix. That's when the whole issue started, where on December 12th, like the truck... What day did you take it back to him?

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
I want to say the 8th of December.

Judge:
Okay, and do you agree with that, that it's the 8th of December when he brings it back to you, he has it towed there?

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
Yes, he has it towed there.

Judge:
Now, the 8th of December, when he has it towed there, why is it being towed there?

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
He's bringing it for me to sell. He’s not bringing it for you to repair.

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
No, he says that the transmission went on it. He wants to sell the vehicle, and I told him I can't sell the vehicle without a title.

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
Is that accurate?

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
I thought about selling it, but I never agreed to sell it. I never agreed to sell.

Judge:
What is the truck there for, to be sold or to fix?

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
To fix.

Judge:
To fix, okay. What is the quote he gave you to fix it?

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
Let me see the paperwork.

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
He didn’t give me a quote. He said it was there for me to sell.

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
Yes, not to fix.

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
No, if you see...

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
How much did he agree for you to sell it for?

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
He wanted to try to get $1,000 for the truck.

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
Did he give you the title so you could sell it?

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
No, that’s what the issue is. I couldn’t take the truck because he never showed me ownership of the vehicle. He never had a title for it. If you notice...

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
What did you do with my property for four days? He left it outside. It was out there for... I don't know how long.

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
Where did you park it?

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
He parked it on a street parking outside the shop.

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
Is that not on my property?

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
I never took possession of it.

Judge:
Wait a second, he had it towed?

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
Yes, he had it towed. If he had it towed, how can it be parked outside?

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
Yeah, they left it. They parked it in a parking spot outside on the street.

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
No, Your Honor.

Judge:
Okay, so what happens? Four days later, you get a call from the police because your car has been stolen. The truck was stolen?

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
December 12th, 6:30 in the morning, I’m notified by the lieutenant of the Marcus Police Department that my 1998 GMC was in the custody of the Lower Southampton police department, and then I even signed a vehicle release report. With this release, he was able to recover the truck.

Judge:
So who ends up taking it out of the impound?

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
You do, upon his permission.

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
I did.

Judge:
But why, if he parks his car on the street and it gets towed, why are you taking it out of impound?

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
The tow company that we used, that dropped off his car, is the same company I use to go down. I told him about the expense, and I texted him about the amount. He agreed to get it out. When I come out of work, I’ll reimburse you for it.

Judge:
Is that in the text somewhere?

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
That’s in my text.

Judge:
Show me the text.

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
While you're looking for that, he takes it out of impound. He pays $650 to take it out of impound. What day do you take it out of impound?

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
A day before Christmas.

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
The day before Christmas, he takes it out of impound. The car is brought over to his place of business, right? He has it now. You go to pick it up, and what happens?

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
When I go to pick up the vehicle, I look at the vehicle. Both of the mirrors are busted, the ignition’s busted, the glass inside is busted. You have pictures of the vehicle?

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
He wouldn't let me...

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
Let me tell you why I couldn’t take pictures. Even with my antique phone... but I said to Alex, you know what, Alex, forget it. I'm just going to take the vehicle, and I'm going to take it with me. So he says, okay. He goes in his office, comes back with a piece of paper, hands it to me, and the paper says, “You owe me $650.” I’m like, for what? He says, “I paid for the towing and the storage and the days that I delayed in picking up the vehicle.” So he says to me, “You’re not taking the vehicle until you pay me.” And I’m like, well, I’m calling 911. I go outside. I call 911. They’re going to send a police officer, and all I hear is Alex saying, “That’s it. Shut the place down.” The gates go down, the locks go in, the keys go to lock, and Alex... I said, “Are you leaving?” I just called the police. He said, “I’m out of here.” He’s out of there, and I’m in there like an idiot with my phone. Finally, I wait half an hour. The police arrive, and at the end of the day, I do have a Philadelphia police report because that was a requirement to get the vehicle released from Southampton. The police tell me, “Well, you already have a police report, it’s recovered. You know where it’s at. This is a civil matter. We’re investigating murders and robberies and everything else. We can’t do anything else.”

Judge:
Okay, so here's what happens. I see that on... there's a couple of texts that don't really matter to me, and then at 12:19, the car has not been removed yet. You say to him, “I don’t have $500 to invest in your truck the week before Christmas.” Sorry. He answers to you, “You still have not picked up the truck.” Well, this is not an investment. Alex, you were recovering a vehicle that was in your possession. Please don’t take my kindness for weakness. I work for some very powerful attorneys, and I am politically tied in. I will work with you and put up half. Need an answer now. Let's stay on good terms and out of court. Your response is, “I’m having it picked up tomorrow. Can’t sell without the title.” He then says, “I hope so. Alex, you are an excellent mechanic. I value this relationship. I will bring you the title. Let’s see how bad the damage is. Hope truck is not totaled. Is the ignition busted? It’s amazing how good it looks just like you left it.” Did you...?

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
It looks terrible.

Judge:
Looks terrible. You have pictures of the truck?

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
Yes, ma'am.

Judge:
What is your position that he agreed to pay half of the impound fees?

Plaintiff (Angelo Carion):
Yeah, but that's not your position. That's not what you said in here, and that's not what he says.

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
When he came to pick up the car, I told him to pay me $650.

Judge:
Why did you take the $650 if it wasn't your agreement?

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
Because he jumped in the car and started pulling it out without paying.

Judge:
When did you tell him to pay you $325?

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
I agreed to $325 plus the title so that when I sell the car, I can recover the other half.

Judge:
None of that is in your texts.

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
No, I agreed to the $325 plus the title.

Judge:
Why don't you say that in the texts? Why don't you say that in court?

Defendant (Axel Rodriguez):
I will... I was trying to explain that I agreed to $325 plus the title.

Judge:
Okay, you’re making the situation confusing now. But listen. I am going to order you to pay $325 for the impound fee because that’s what you agreed to. That’s what you acted on to get the truck out. You’re not entitled to any other damages because he left the vehicle there. No further storage.

Plaintiff (Brian):
I'm suing the cleaning company represented by Ron for $1,700, that you say was stolen from your desk drawer—$1,300 in cash and $400 in a Best Buy gift card.

Plaintiff (Brian):
I had the cash in my possession, which were exclusively $50 bills. I know that because those bills were received by me in Switzerland. I’m an estate attorney. My deceased client had a safe deposit box in Switzerland. I personally traveled to Switzerland. The box was drilled in my presence and I physically carried the currency back to the United States. I placed the currency in my desk drawer where I had placed it for a short period of time—three days.

Plaintiff (Brian):
I remember distinctly seeing the money in my desk drawer and saying to myself, “I have to take this money to the bank.” But I wasn’t able to get to the bank for three days. I was the last person to leave the office that night. When I returned in the morning, the envelope wasn’t there.

Plaintiff (Brian):
I doubted myself a bit at first and said, "Did I put it in the file? Did I put it in a different desk drawer?" But I could not find it. I contacted the defendant, and although he made a stop by my office, I wasn't available to speak to him. I emailed him but never heard back again.

Plaintiff (Brian):
I’m suing him for improper supervision of his staff. I heard that the defendant’s position is that he has one employee who has worked for him for 20 years, but that’s not so. They've only been cleaning my office suite for about a month prior to this incident. I saw four or five different people come into the office, all of whom had their own set of keys during the period in question.

Defendant (Ron):
I’ve been doing this since 1985. We’re always the first ones to be blamed. If something’s missing, fingers are always pointed at the cleaners. I understand that’s the nature of the business. We’re rarely the culprits, if ever. The person in question has been with me for 20 years.

Defendant (Ron):
Orlando is the person who was cleaning the plaintiff's space. He has been with me since 1994. He’s been out at times due to a prostate operation, but when he was available, he was assigned to the plaintiff’s space. The plaintiff claims that Orlando is the one who took the money.

Defendant (Ron):
We can’t prove who took it, but we know Orlando has been with us for a long time and we trust him. There’s no way he would have taken anything.

Plaintiff (Brian):
The cleaning company sent different people into my office. It’s not just Orlando.

Defendant (Ron):
I vouch for Orlando. He has been with me for 20 years. I don’t know how he could be blamed for this.

Defendant (Ron):
We don’t have a definitive answer. It’s hard to prove who took the money, but I don’t believe it was my employee.

Judge:
Brian, what evidence do you have that Orlando took it?

Plaintiff (Brian):
It’s circumstantial, Your Honor. I was the last one to leave and the first one in. I’m fairly certain it was there, but now it’s missing.

Judge:
You don’t have evidence that the cleaning staff stole anything. You don’t have any proof that Orlando took the money. Maybe you’re just a little more careless than you’d like to admit.

Judge:
