Plaintiff: I pay for the boys' private school. They have private piano lessons. I pay for several—
Defendant: Excuse me, excuse me, Your Honor. Both of my boys are on scholarship.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket, the plaintiff says the defendant's dog viciously attacked his dog Jake, and on top of that, his sunglasses got damaged. The defendant says it's pure extortion. It's the case of "Stick ‘Em Up."

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Michael Booth, you are suing Eileen Becker for $1,379.99 in damages that you say you sustained when her dog attacked you. All right, tell me what's going on.

Plaintiff: It was March 7th. I was walking my dog. I had left my house, and I do like a three-mile course.

Judge: Wow, is that for you or for the dog?

Plaintiff: Both of us.

Judge: Wow, you come to my house and walk my dog because I don’t really want to walk my dog for three miles. All right, go ahead.

Plaintiff: At that point, it was about two miles in. I had another mile to get home.

Judge: What kind of dog?

Plaintiff: I have a Jack Russell Terrier.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: He’s about 16 pounds. I passed her house. There were two dogs outside. They actually scared me. There are no sidewalks over there where her house is, so you walk in the street in that part. They were barking like crazy, pulling on the leash. I hear her say to the lady that’s in the black Yukon talking to her in the driveway, "Wow, my dog almost pulled your bumper off." And I just keep walking. Now, I’m about 10 houses up the street, and I hear, "Coco, stop! Coco, stop! Pick up your dog, Mister! Pick up your dog!" I do one of these over my shoulder and I go, "Oh, you know what?" And this dog’s charging at me with its leash dragging, and another dog is next to it—a black dog.

Judge: She's running behind?

Plaintiff: The black dog that’s next to it is also on a leash.

Judge: No leash on that dog?

Plaintiff: That black dog was hers.

Judge: Okay, so both?

Plaintiff: Okay, got it. Both dogs were running up the street.

Judge: Did you pick up your dog?

Plaintiff: Yes, I did. He’s in a harness, you know, so I just grabbed the harness, threw him up on my shoulder. The dog came closer. I turned around to give it my back. It came around. I did a circle to try and keep my back towards the dog. The dog got around me, jumped up, grabbed my—

Judge: The black one or the other one?

Plaintiff: The Shepherd mix.

Judge: Which is the one that was on a leash or off a leash?

Plaintiff: On a leash that was dragging behind it.

Judge: Okay, so go on.

Plaintiff: It got around me, bit my dog and myself. So, you know, I let out a yell, my dog of course, and so did I. She fell down, and I go, "Get up and get your dog!" You know, and she’s like, "Oh!" She gets up and grabs the dog’s leash.

Judge: I’m sorry, she fell down on purpose?

Plaintiff: No, no. She fell down as she was running after the two dogs.

Judge: All right, go on.

Plaintiff: She pulled the dog off me. She was crying. My dog was holding against me. I didn’t even notice at that point. He must have spun around, and the side that got bit—his right side—was up against my sweatshirt. He was just shaking. My finger was bleeding. I got bit across my finger.

Judge: Do you have pictures of the damage?

Plaintiff: Yes, I do.

Judge: May I see them?

Plaintiff: Sure. I also have them on an iPad if you want.

Defendant: Honey, we have to walk the dogs around the front of the house to the backyard. So my girlfriend pulled up, and my dogs got excited because they know her car. At that precise moment, Mr. Booth was walking past the house. I went to walk my dogs into the house, but they wanted to go because they saw Mike. The leash got stuck on the bumper. Coco went around the car. I got the leash off the bumper, took them into the house. As I got up the stairs, our front door was broken—

Judge: Zeke, the black dog, was inside?

Defendant: Yes, he pushed the door open and ran out.

Judge: So you have three dogs?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: The only thing you didn’t feel was appropriate to pay for was what?

Defendant: A day’s pay that he got paid for because he took a sick day, and his sunglasses.

Judge: But you agree your dog was responsible for this incident?

Defendant: Yes, I do, but I don’t believe the sunglasses were even there.

Judge: You’re saying he’s lying about that part?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Mr. Booth, do you have proof of the sunglasses’ value?

Plaintiff: I have a receipt for the same pair purchased last year.

Judge: I’ll review that. Final statements?

Plaintiff: I just want to be compensated for what I lost. It wasn’t my fault.

Defendant: I understand, but I still feel some of this is excessive.

Judge: I will issue my ruling shortly. Court adjourned.

**Judge:**
Thank you, Douglas. Okay, Joseph Rotoni?

**Plaintiff:**
Yes, your honor.

**Judge:**
You are suing Neil McGregor for $34.95?

**Plaintiff:**
That's correct.

**Judge:**
Which, according to you, he owes you to fix a problem that he created with your dryer?

**Plaintiff:**
Yes.

**Judge:**
Okay. First of all, you're wearing these sunglasses because?

**Plaintiff:**
I've been visually impaired due to a disease I have.

**Judge:**
Okay, I'm sorry to hear that. Normally, we ask you to take your glasses off.

**Plaintiff:**
I will.

**Judge:**
No, no. Leave them on if you need to. It's fine. All right. So tell me what happened here.

**Plaintiff:**
Okay. Let me first explain, your honor. Mr. McGregor has done a lot of work for myself and my wife at our home, and we've never had a problem. Whenever we've called him, he's come over, he's done the job, and we paid him.

**Judge:**
For how many years have you used him?

**Plaintiff:**
Well, I've known Mr. McGregor for 27 years. He at one time worked for my wife. I'd say five or six years since I knew he was doing work on the side, and he's been very good. We had a nice rapport.

**Judge:**
In what capacity did you work for his wife?

**Defendant:**
Boston City Hospital. She was a food service director, and I worked under her.

**Judge:**
Okay. So go ahead.

**Plaintiff:**
Okay. This particular time, Mr. McGregor was at the house doing some work that I had requested. Everything went fine. There was one last issue that had to be taken care of, and that was to reconnect the vent dryer.

**Judge:**
So what happened?

**Plaintiff:**
Mr. McGregor was reconnecting the vent from the rear of the dryer to the outside part of the house. There's a vent inside that goes right outside the exterior of the home.

**Judge:**
Why was it disconnected?

**Plaintiff:**
They come apart often, probably from usage, but other than that, I don't know.

**Judge:**
Okay.

**Plaintiff:**
So in any case, he completed that, and rather than just coming around the dryer, Mr. McGregor elected to climb over it.

**Judge:**
After reconnecting it?

**Plaintiff:**
Yes.

**Judge:**
Because he didn’t disconnect it?

**Plaintiff:**
Correct.

**Judge:**
So after he reconnects it, he then walks on the dryer?

**Plaintiff:**
No. Instead of coming around the dryer like he should have done—

**Judge:**
How did he get up behind the thing?

**Plaintiff:**
He hopped over it. He leaped up, and when he attempted to go over, he landed on the backsplash of the dryer.

**Defendant:**
There was no room to go around it. The only way to get behind it was to climb over the dryer. I had to climb over, get myself on the other side, and then check the line.

**Judge:**
How’d you even do that? Did you lie on top of the dryer?

**Defendant:**
No, I had to put my knee up, then both knees, and climb over.

**Judge:**
So you had your knees on the dryer?

**Defendant:**
Right. And then I climbed over to the back.

**Judge:**
Then what happened?

**Defendant:**
As I was climbing back, the loop of my pants caught the knobs on the dryer, and they broke.

**Judge:**
Okay. What happened next?

**Plaintiff:**
Two knobs on the dryer were sheared off. One controlled the temperature, and I had to use the dryer on high heat all the time.

**Judge:**
How much was the cost?

**Plaintiff:**
$75 for the two knobs.

**Judge:**
Do you have proof?

**Plaintiff:**
I don’t have a written estimate, but I contacted a few service companies.

**Judge:**
That’s not enough. You need evidence.

**Defendant:**
I checked online but never ordered them. Then, after threats and repeated calls, I stopped responding.

**Judge:**
If you break something while doing a favor, you're responsible. I'm ruling in favor of the plaintiff for $150.

**Court adjourns.**

Judge: "Okay, so are you being flown out with your job as a flight attendant, or are you doing other things?"

Defendant: "Sometimes, occasionally, I may have a little flown-out situation, but most of the time, I'll be working hard. I pay this $175 insurance—like, I'm at least doing that. Paying to my partner, $175 in health insurance."

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hand.

Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiff bought a car from the defendant and is now having issues with the title. The defendant claims the title is fine, but the plaintiff changed his mind. It’s the case of Every Lawsuit Has a Title.

Thank you, Douglas.

Judge: Mr. Santos, you bought a car from Milross Rodriguez, correct?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: How much did you pay for it?

Plaintiff: $1,500.

Judge: Did you get a title when you bought it?

Plaintiff: I got a title, yes.

Judge: Let me see the title. Was there a bill of sale?

Plaintiff: It was a handwritten note.

Judge: Let me see both of those. So was this your car?

Defendant: Yes, it was.

Judge: How long had you been driving it?

Defendant: It was actually parked and was supposed to be registered. It was never registered. My sister was supposed to register it.

Judge: Whose car was this?

Defendant: It's mine. I was the one who bought the car.

Judge: You paid the money?

Defendant: Yes, I did.

Judge: And who was supposed to be driving it?

Defendant: My sister, Marissa Rodriguez.

Judge: And what happened?

Defendant: We sold it. She left for Boston, Massachusetts, so I sold the car.

Judge: Let me get everybody’s name straight. You’re Raymond Santos, and you’re Milross Rodriguez, correct?

Defendant: Correct.

Judge: Whose signature is this that says Michael on the title?

Defendant: That would probably be the first person that the car was purchased from, I believe.

Judge: Who’s "they"?

Defendant: The person I purchased the car from.

Judge: I have to ask you—you’re the only person who knows where you bought the car. So, you bought it from whom?

Defendant: Cherry Street.

Judge: Is your name even on this title?

Defendant: Is her name on the title at all?

Plaintiff: That’s the problem I’m having.

Judge: Yeah, that’s a problem. Your name’s not even on the title.

Defendant: I could have sworn the title is under Marissa Rodriguez.

Judge: That’s not you, correct?

Defendant: Correct.

Judge: Number one. But number two, her name isn’t on the title either. You mean your sister?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Hand this title to her. Show me where I’m missing it. Maybe I’m missing something.

Judge: Did you try to register the car?

Plaintiff: No, I didn’t.

Judge: Is your name on that title?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Is your sister’s name on the title?

Plaintiff: No, it’s not.

Judge: So what happened here? You tried to register it, and what did they say?

Plaintiff: They said it’s not filled out correctly, so I have to go back to the seller and ask them to request a new title with their name on it. They have to just re-sign it back. It’s called "jumping title," and it’s a problem.

Judge: So did you contact her and say, "Hey, we need to figure this out, I need to ask for a new title?"

Plaintiff: I did.

Judge: And what did she say?

Plaintiff: She indicated that she would help me with that, but then she texted me later that she was running into some personal problems and couldn’t help me anymore.

Judge: Is that accurate?

Defendant: That’s accurate to a certain extent. At the time, I was in the process of moving, and I did tell him that. I asked if he could be a little more patient with me.

Judge: So did you have any further contact with her after this?

Plaintiff: No, but once she told me she was moving, I went into panic mode and went to the court system because I was afraid of losing contact with her.

Judge: So what you’re suing for is the $1,500 that you paid, correct?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: See, when you sell a car, it’s an "as-is" sale. The only thing you can’t do is sell something that isn’t legally transferable. If he can’t register it, he can’t drive it. If you do something funky with the title or refuse to help, that becomes a problem. And now he gets to rescind this contract.

Judge: Do you have anything to say in your defense that you haven’t already said?

Defendant: Does he get to keep the $1,500 and the car?

Judge: No, the car goes back to its rightful owner. You’re not the owner, and you don’t have a way to prove it.

Judge: Do you have a bill of sale that shows that you bought it?

Defendant: I should have one at home.

Judge: Wow. I don’t know what we’re going to do. Here’s what we’re going to do—because you don’t get to keep it if you want the $1,500. We’re going to make arrangements for you to surrender it to the police station. Let somebody else figure it out.

Defendant: That sounds reasonable.

Judge: How are you going to prove ownership?

Defendant: I should have proof at home.

Judge: The proof I’m talking about is a bill of sale.

Defendant: Yes, I understand.

Judge: If you show me the bill of sale and it doesn’t look fake, I will make arrangements through the courthouse for the car to go back to you. On your claim against her, I’m ruling in your favor for $1,500.

Judge: Judgment for the plaintiff. Case closed.

Judge: I see the letters. He does receive Social Security and disability.

Plaintiff: Well first of all I think he's lying. Second of all, he can work with minimal duties.

Judge: What do you think he's lying about? You think he's lying about the disability? You think he's lying about the award letters that I'm looking at? Because they look like official documents from the state.

Plaintiff: Okay, ma'am, it's like this. This guy is no good. Once we got married nine years ago, I took care of him. He doesn't have a job. I made him go back to college. I made him get a degree. He's got a good job in IT, okay? As soon as he got the job, okay, he didn't want to be married anymore. Really? All right. You have a good job, pay child support then, okay? He was paying a thousand dollars a month for two years, okay?

Judge: I understand that, but you understand that he has a legitimate excuse for not paying anything, right? I understand it may be frustrating, but you do understand that, right?

Plaintiff: But he can work in IT. He can just push the buttons. It's not like it's something from a doctor saying that he cannot work.

Judge: Until he gets something that actually releases him to work or he stops receiving benefits from the state, we really can't order him to pay any child support.

Plaintiff: I think what he wants to do, he just wants to stay home, sleep until noon or whatever, then go out there, play guitar or whatever it is that he was doing before we got married. He just doesn't want any responsibilities.

Judge: Landlord, all parties please raise your right hand. Welcome back to the People's Court. Next case in the docket, the plaintiff moved into the defendant's house. It was awful, there were all sorts of leaks and whatnot, but the defendant says the plaintiff never paid squat. Into the case of the squatter with no water.
Judge: Richard and Doris Washington, you have power of attorney representing both you and who's that - your wife? Okay. You are suing Leslie Jackson, your former landlord for the $300 remaining from the security deposit that Mr. Jackson has not returned to you. Tell me what's going on.
Plaintiff: On around October 1st 2011, my wife and I moved onto the first floor of his private house, and because of problems with the electricity-
Judge: What was the problem with the electricity?
Plaintiff: Well, whenever he would leave town, the electricity would go off and on, off and on.
Judge: The actual lights?
Plaintiff: Yes, the lights, everything would go off.
Judge: Until what?
Plaintiff: Until he had someone fix it. And when he left town twice, it happened twice when he left town. The hot water went off as well.
Judge: The hot water and the electricity would go off and then you would call him and then he would have somebody fix it?
Plaintiff: Yeah, sometimes the person that was staying in the basement with him would have to contact someone to fix it.
Judge: How would they fix it?
Plaintiff: He had it rigged up from his basement to our electrical power, his power to our power. And when they came, from what I understand, when they came up and down the steps they would unplug it by mistake, hit the plug and it would knock out my plug, my electricity. The front window wouldn't shut all the way or lock. He said he would fix that, never was fixed. The roof started leaking-
Judge: You lived in the first floor with your own kitchen, a whole separate family unit, right?
Plaintiff: The roof started leaking eventually. The ceiling fell in on my furniture.
Judge: What do you mean from the water filling up on a ceiling from the outside of the roof?
Plaintiff: Well, you're on the first floor and there's another floor above you.
Judge: Or no, there's another floor above us?
Plaintiff: Yes, but there's an outside roof that doesn't cover the first floor- I mean the second floor.
Judge: So you are the topmost floor at a certain portion of your place?
Plaintiff: Yes.
Judge: So then tell me about when you decide that you're leaving. Are you on a month-to-month with him, is that how it works?
Plaintiff: No, it was from August 1st of 2011 to August 1st of 2012.
Judge: But you decide to leave when?
Plaintiff: We decided to leave around October 27th actually.
Judge: And so when you told him you were leaving, did he object because you had a lease or no?
Plaintiff: No.
Judge: Because you told him I'm leaving because of all the problems and he did not object to that?
Plaintiff: No, he didn't.
Judge: So you leave and then he gives you $1,000?
Plaintiff: When he gives us $1,000 about a week after we leave. He wouldn't do the walkthrough with my wife.
Judge: Did you leave the place clean?
Plaintiff: Yes we did.
Judge: Did you take any pictures of how you left the place?
Plaintiff: Someone was supposed to email me the pictures this morning but I never got them.
Judge: Why are you keeping his 300 bucks?
Defendant: The agreement that Mr. Washington and his wife and I made was $1,300 rent and they will go half on the electricity.
Judge: But how is your electricity rigged up there? Is it-
Defendant: I don't know what this individual is talking about because it's a two-family house. It has two legal meters but I stay in the basement.
Judge: So the basement is attached to the first floor, right? Then you rent out two of them and then you're living in another one which you're not allowed to do.
Defendant: Excuse me-
Judge: You know exactly what I said. I don't need to repeat my- you know exactly what I said.
Defendant: I'm holding-
Judge: I'm holding- please be silent on that one.
Defendant: Of course.
Judge: You're going to be silent. So you have some fugazi thing rigged up with- wait, what is that if the tenant says it's okay? Can a landlord rent an illegal house?
Defendant: I would say no.
Judge: Why?
Defendant: It's still against the law. I'd be like going to the grocery store and saying I'm going to steal a camera because you said it was okay.
Judge: Except they would never say it was okay. There's a flaw in your argument.
Defendant: Oh that's true.
Judge: Go inside the courtroom. The electricity from the first floor is connected to the basement where the two meters- the two meters on the outside for the first floor apart, the second floor apartment which is a two-family house. Second floor has their own apartment, their own meter and the first floor which is connected to the basement has his own meter.
Judge: And then what happened?
Defendant: The electricity did go off. I was away.
Judge: How did it go off?
Defendant: The non-payment. I was late on a payment. And they cut it off but it went right back on the same day.
Judge: What about the roof problems? I'm going to get to that.
Defendant: We had a storm and when we had the storm the roof, a part of the shingles fell off.
Judge: When did that happen?
Defendant: The last storm we had besides Sandy but, you know, last year. I forgot what storm we had.
Judge: When did that happen?
Plaintiff: It was Hurricane Irene.
Judge: When?
Plaintiff: It was in like September.
Judge: So if there- why hadn't the roof been fixed in two months?
Defendant: I'm getting ready to tell you-
Judge: No, in two months the roof was fixed right away. First of all, by law you had 72 hours to repair the-
Judge: Did his ceiling fall in?
Defendant: The ceiling did fall in. The ceiling fell in, a lot of water was coming and I fixed it right away.
Judge: According to you he left it that way. How long about the ceiling or the roof?
Defendant: Well first the roof has to get fixed. We need to make sure it doesn't leak, then the ceiling needs to get fixed. There's an order to these things.
Plaintiff: The roof was never fixed because it always had a garbage bag.
Judge: Do you have pictures of a fixed roof?
Defendant: No I don't.
Judge: All right, why are you keeping the 300 bucks?
Defendant: Well the reason why I'm keeping the $300 is because the agreement that his wife and I made- put it like this, the agreement that the head of the household and I made-
Judge: Why you laughing? No, that I know he intended- I know that he intended it as an insult to him but I want to know why you're laughing because of the insult and no more, right? You're not like implying that a woman can't be the head of the household. I mean because usually there's a division of labor and like in my house my husband believes that the natural state of an envelope is sealed and an email is unreturned and a phone call is unreturned so the person who handles all this stuff would be me, exactly.
Defendant: If I'm lying then please penalize me for me lying but I am speak-
Judge: No, I'm not going to probably penalize you for lying. What I'm going to penalize you for is having an illegal apartment.
Defendant: No, what we going to do-
Judge: What we're going to do- see here's the thing. Let's just say that you sold him cocaine and then- like why- let me just explain to you it's a concept I want to explain. So you sell him- no let's do it the other way so that way you can feel it. He sells you cocaine and then you take the cocaine and then you take it back to your place and you realize that only the top of it where you went like that was cocaine and then the bottom of it was laundry detergent. And so now you're angry because you paid him for an entire kilo of cocaine so you come to court and you sue him and say judge he ripped me off, he has breached contract and I want my money back for my cocaine. Would a judge ever get involved in such a thing? Of course not because as a public policy, we do not sit around enforcing illegal things. You've kept $300 for electricity that you've got rigged up in a house you're using as a-
Defendant: Sorry I'm in the middle of speaking but-
Judge: No, no there's no but. You don't interrupt me when I'm explaining to you a house that is zoned for two family that you have rigged up for three that you somehow have- you don't have your own separate unit measuring your electricity so you have him splitting or doing paying some share of the electricity that you've got rigged up in a way that you're not allowed to rig up and you've got used as a three family that you're not allowed to use. What are the odds that I'm going to assist you?
Defendant: No but-
Judge: Hon, what I have to do is I have to correct you on something because the electricity is not rigged up. The first floor and the basement-
Judge: You have a separate unit for the basement?
Defendant: No ma'am.
Judge: Is a separate family living in the basement?
Defendant: I live in the basement.
Judge: That's right and you are not part of his family right?
Defendant: No.
Judge: And you are renting to him a completely separate facility with its own kitchen and bathroom in the basement?
Defendant: Okay.
Judge: Give the man back his $300. You have no right to keep any of $300.
Judge: For the plaintiff.
Defendant: Wow, where's the Justice at?
Judge: Right here baby.
Defendant: Wow, so that- I thought the judge should have heard my case out a lot. She didn't hear my case.
Judge: What do you have for us here that's going to blow the case wide open? Go ahead. I mean you have something to say?
Defendant: The apartment was illegal so that's why you're leaving the court on the losing end.
Judge: Well I guess so there.
Judge: All right, okay, good luck.

**Judge:**
All right, Valerie, you are suing Pamela for $2,327 in pain and suffering, lost wages, and money to repair your car that you say your own sister scratched up. What happened?

**Plaintiff (Valerie):**
Yes, ma'am. Well, uh, my mother left money for my aunt here before she went out of town on October 15th. She left my auntie $70, and she also left Pamela $20. I called my auntie to let her know that my mom left her $70. She said, "Okay, Val, I'll get it when I see you." So I called Miss Pamela to tell her—

**Judge:**
Miss Pamela is your sister?

**Plaintiff (Valerie):**
Yes, to tell her that I had $20 for her. So she started going all off, talking real rude, calling me out my name and whatnot, and she said she knows my mom didn’t leave her the money, that Mom left no money with me for her. So I said, "You know what, Pamela? I’m not gonna give you the money."

**Judge:**
Wait, wait, wait, wait, wait. What was she mad at if you were calling her to give her money?

**Plaintiff (Valerie):**
Because my mom left me the $20.

**Judge:**
Okay. And what's your version of this little conversation?

**Defendant (Pamela):**
Well, actually, that day, how I found out—my mother calls it a "package"—she didn't really say it was like a bittersweet situation. Val calls me at 6:30 in the morning—she does this all the time—to tell me different little stuff about where I should be in life, where she’s at in life, whatever. So she calls me, and she was like, "Yeah, my mommy left me a package. You ain’t going to get nothing because she gave you some pennies to give to me, and you didn’t give them to me."

**Plaintiff (Valerie):**
Oh, that’s not true!

**Defendant (Pamela):**
Yes! My mother picks up pennies. You know, she does all kinds of stuff. I didn’t even want to take the pennies from my mom. I have a recording from my mom about the pennies. That’s what she told me.

**Judge:**
So she tells you she's not going to give you the $20 because one day in the past, you didn't give her pennies?

**Defendant (Pamela):**
Yes. Yes.

**Judge:**
Are you both for real?

**Plaintiff (Valerie):**
Very, very for real.

**Defendant (Pamela):**
Very for real.

**Judge:**
So you're telling me your mother gave you $20 to give to her, but you decided you weren’t going to give it to her?

**Plaintiff (Valerie):**
No, I didn’t say I wasn’t going to give it to her. I only said that after she said, "I know my mom ain't leave you no $20 for me."

**Judge:**
Okay, so now let’s fast forward.

**Defendant (Pamela):**
No, no, I just—this is just too much for me.

**Judge:**
Yeah, we need to fast forward to the next time you two see each other in person. Right? It is someone’s birthday. Whose birthday is it?

**Plaintiff (Valerie):**
My sister—well, my mother—my brother’s girlfriend’s birthday.

**Judge:**
Okay, and you're both there?

**Plaintiff (Valerie):**
Yes, we’re at the birthday party. My brother and his girlfriend were throwing a little kickback at their house. I’m outside barbecuing. I see Valerie, and I told her on the phone, "I’mma mess up your car. I’mma spit in your face." I was just trying to use psychology.

**Judge:**
Oh yeah, that’s classic psychology. "I’m going to mess up your car. I’m going to spit in your face." That’s an old psychology trick. I was a psychology major—there's barely a textbook in college that doesn’t have that in Psychology 101.

**Defendant (Pamela):**
It didn’t work! She still refused to give me the money. And I said, "$20? Who cares?"

**Judge:**
Okay, is that what you said?

**Defendant (Pamela):**
Personally, to myself, yeah.

**Judge:**
Okay, but to her, what’d you say?

**Defendant (Pamela):**
"I’mma mess up your car. I’mma spit in your face."

**Judge:**
Wow. Yeah. Is this about the $20?

**Aunt:**
It’s deeper than the $20.

**Judge:**
I want to hear from the aunt. Is this about the $20?

**Aunt:**
They never got along. Ever. As siblings, growing up as children, yeah. But as adults? No. They don’t get along too much.

---

[The transcript continues with further dialogue from the judge, plaintiff, and defendant regarding the alleged vandalism, threats, and the final verdict of the case.]

Judge: All right, Bettyanne Pajura, you are suing John and his business, the farm where he kept your horses, because you claim he mistreated them by not nourishing them properly. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: I was at a farm in East for about 12 years. I’ve owned horses for most of my life and have never had issues before. The farm where I was boarding was investigated for compliance issues with shelters and horse care.

Judge: Were your horses affected by that?

Plaintiff: No, my horses were well taken care of at that farm.

Judge: Then why did you move them?

Plaintiff: There was a rumor that if the farm was shut down, the state could seize all the horses present on the property.

Judge: So, you moved them to John’s farm out of precaution?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Did you move one horse or both?

Plaintiff: I rode one horse over, but I boarded both within a few days.

Judge: What was the payment agreement?

Plaintiff: I initially agreed to pay $1,100 per month for both horses.

Judge: For how long did you pay that?

Plaintiff: Two months. Then, I negotiated a lower price of $850, which John accepted.

Judge: How long did you board your horses there?

Plaintiff: From January 28th through September 9th.

Judge: How often did you visit?

Plaintiff: On weekends only.

Judge: Did you notice any issues with the horses while visiting?

Plaintiff: Yes. I had repeated confrontations with John and different barn managers. I told him my horses weren’t getting enough water, adequate feed, or quality hay. He always assured me he’d fix it, so I trusted him.

Judge: When you saw them the following week, did they appear malnourished?

Plaintiff: I could see their weight fluctuating.

Judge: Did they lose weight consistently from January to September?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Then why did you leave them there for nine months?

Plaintiff: They weren’t severely underweight at first. When Megan, a western rider managing the barn, was there, my horses were well cared for. She rode them and fed them properly.

Judge: When did Megan leave?

Plaintiff: End of May or early June.

Judge: So, from June to September, your horses were losing weight?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Why didn’t you remove them sooner?

Plaintiff: I wasn’t fully aware of how bad it had gotten until I took one to a horse show. People in the horse community came up to me, shocked at how thin my horse looked.

Judge: But you didn’t notice before then?

Plaintiff: Compared to the other horses at John’s farm, mine didn’t seem as bad. But at the show, I realized how underweight they were.

Judge: What did you do next?

Plaintiff: I confronted John and removed my horses.

Judge: Did he refund you for the last month?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: So, you’re suing for the entire nine months’ worth of boarding fees?

Plaintiff: Yes, including the time Megan was there.

Judge: John, were the horses being adequately fed?

Defendant (John): Yes, Your Honor. We followed the feeding instructions provided by Bettyanne.

Judge: Do you have records of what was fed?

Defendant: Yes, I have an affidavit from Jane Lyman, the only person who mixed the grain. She couldn’t be here today because her husband recently passed away.

Judge: I’m sorry to hear that. What does the affidavit say?

Defendant: It states that the horses were given fresh hay three times a day and that in June, Jane recommended increasing their grain, which Bettyanne agreed to.

Judge: Bettyanne, did Jane ever approach you about increasing the grain?

Plaintiff: No, that never happened.

Judge: Jane says you agreed to it.

Plaintiff: I only spoke to John about feed, and I was often in tears because he kept blaming his staff.

Judge: John, did Bettyanne repeatedly complain to you about the feeding?

Defendant: No, not until September when she confronted me after the horse show.

Judge: Bettyanne says she brought it up multiple times over nine months.

Defendant: That’s not true.

Judge: The issue here is that you were fine paying rent for nine months, then took the horses to a show, got questioned about their condition, and only then decided they were too thin.

Plaintiff: No, I repeatedly expressed concerns.

Judge: Do you have vet records?

Plaintiff: Yes, from both before and after moving them.

Judge: What do the records say?

Plaintiff: My vet saw them in the spring while they were at John’s farm and again in the fall after I moved them. He noted mild weight loss.

Judge: That’s not severe malnourishment.

Plaintiff: But my vet saw them four weeks after they had already been moved and started recovering.

Judge: Did you take them to a vet immediately after removal?

Plaintiff: I called right away.

Judge: Do you have medical evidence proving significant malnourishment?

Plaintiff: I have emails recommending increased feeding.

Judge: Emails aren’t enough. You’re claiming $7,200 in damages because you believe your horses were mistreated to the point you shouldn’t have had to pay board. But I need concrete proof.

Plaintiff: I have photos.

Judge: Let me see them.

(Photos are reviewed.)

Judge: These show weight loss, but I still don’t see evidence justifying full reimbursement. You visited every weekend, rode the horses, and didn’t take drastic action until September.

Plaintiff: I trusted John when he said he would fix the issues.

Judge: But you’re the one who waited nine months before taking serious action. Your vet only noted mild weight loss, and you were still actively showing the horse.

Plaintiff: But—

Judge: My ruling is for the defendant. Case dismissed.

Judge: Michael Sanchez, you are suing Lucas Ornelas and Mr. Tech—that is correct? That's the name of the store?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Okay. Represented here by Lucas Ornelas. You're the owner, right?

Defendant: That is correct.

Judge: Alright. You’re suing for $5,727.22 in damages that you say you sustained when your laptop was stolen from his place. Tell me what’s going on.

Plaintiff: That’s correct, Your Honor. On the date of July 22nd, 2011, I called Mr. Ornelas to ask him about repairing my MacBook Pro screen. The screen had been broken, and if I could for a moment indicate to you where in the computer it was broken—

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: The filaments that control the entire screen are in this area right here, and when the computer fell, it cracked the contact point. So what happens is, the computer screen went entirely dead.

Judge: An entirely dead screen. Alright. So you go to him. Have you ever done business with him before?

Plaintiff: I have, as a matter of fact, and he’s always been good as far as service.

Judge: So you go there, and you quote to him it'll cost how much?

Defendant: $300.

Judge: And what were you going to do for the $300?

Defendant: Replace the entire screen with a brand-new one.

Judge: Okay. Who do you get the piece from? Apple, I guess, right?

Defendant: Actually, if you go through Apple, it’s probably three times more, so I have people who can get me the parts.

Judge: What, off a stolen truck?

Defendant: No! I mean—Apple is just Apple.

Judge: What does that mean?

Defendant: No, they go to the manufacturer directly instead of going through Apple.

Judge: So you go through the company that makes them. They just won’t have a little Apple logo on the back?

Defendant: Exactly.

Judge: Okay. Yeah, I’m fine with that. So it’s $300. That’s how much the repair was going to be. You gave him how much?

Plaintiff: I gave him a cash deposit of $50.

Judge: Okay. And then what happens?

Plaintiff: Well, approximately a week later, I called him just to see how progress was going on the machine. This was on a Wednesday that I called him. I got no return call. I called him again on Thursday. I got no call back. So I happened to see on Friday, I was passing by where his shop was, and his shop was open. He was there. So I walked in, and Mr. Ornelas had a somewhat—oh—kind of wincing pain on his face. More like somebody about to give you some bad news. Because as soon as I saw his expression, I went, "Uh-oh" to myself. And so I’m wondering what exactly had gone wrong.

Defendant: What happened was, I have a storage room in the back. I have the showroom in the front, and then I do repairs in the back. It was a hot day, and my air conditioning wasn’t working correctly, so sometimes I kind of leave the door open in the back. But I’ll put something there so that if somebody tries to get in, they’ll trip over it and make some noise.

Judge: You don’t have a security system?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Try that in your house. See what happens.

Defendant: The way it’s set up is, I actually have a gate in the back that’s locked. So whoever needs to come in has to jump over that gate.

Judge: You severely underestimated the resourcefulness of the average burglar. You figured, "They're too loud. I gotta jump a fence. Then I gotta trip over some stuff. Ah, forget it—I don’t really want that computer."

Defendant: I mean, I’ve done this for many years, and that’s pretty much, you know, if it gets warm, then I’ll open the door.

Judge: Just fix the AC.

Defendant: Yeah. So—

Judge: What happened when you left that night? You forgot to lock the door?

Defendant: No, it didn’t happen overnight. It happened during the daytime.

Judge: Oh!

Defendant: Yeah, I actually have a copy of the police report.

Judge: You realized it the next day?

Defendant: Yes. The next morning when I came in is when I noticed things were moved around.

Judge: How much stuff was taken?

Defendant: Just his laptop.

Judge: Why just his laptop?

Defendant: I know it seems kind of weird, and I kind of know what happened. I knew who it was.

Judge: Who?

Defendant: A high school student who was coming to my shop.

Judge: Why do you think that person wanted his laptop?

Defendant: Because he loved Apple products, and he was always looking at them.

Judge: Was that the only Apple product you had at the time?

Defendant: It was the newest one.

Judge: So you think it was one of your employees?

Defendant: Not an employee—an apprentice from a high school.

Judge: Oh, so you were letting a high school student come in and just hang out?

Defendant: Yeah, he was learning about computers.

Judge: Did you report him to the police?

Defendant: Yes, I did.

Judge: And what happened?

Defendant: The police spoke with him, and they also spoke with his parents, but there was no proof that he took it.

Judge: So nothing happened.

Defendant: Correct.

Judge: Alright. Now, let me go back to you. What happens when you find out your computer is stolen?

Plaintiff: Well, when Mr. Ornelas told me what had happened, naturally I was upset. I mean, I rely on this machine for my livelihood. I'm a DJ, and this machine has all my music, all my mixes, all my files. So I asked him, "Well, what are you going to do about this?" And at first, he told me he was going to replace the machine. So I said, "Okay, let's see how that plays out."

Judge: Did he offer you a replacement?

Defendant: Yes, I did.

Plaintiff: He offered me an older model, which was not the same as mine.

Judge: Was it a comparable model?

Plaintiff: No, Your Honor. Mine was a 2011 MacBook Pro, and he offered me a 2009 model with lower specifications.

Judge: Mr. Ornelas, was it the same or not?

Defendant: It was the closest I could get at the time.

Judge: That’s not what I asked. Was it the same model, same year, and same specifications?

Defendant: No, it was an older model, but I thought it was fair.

Judge: Did you explain that to him?

Defendant: Yes, but he wasn’t happy with it.

Plaintiff: Your Honor, not only was I not happy with it, but I had already looked up the cost to replace my laptop, and it was significantly higher than what he was offering.

Judge: Did you provide him with an estimate?

Plaintiff: Yes, I printed out the cost from Apple’s website, which showed that to replace my exact model, it would be $2,500.

Judge: Do you have that with you?

Plaintiff: Yes, I do. Here you go.

Judge: (Examines the paper) Okay. So, Mr. Ornelas, did you ever offer to pay him for the value of his lost laptop?

Defendant: I offered to give him what I could afford. I’m a small business. I couldn’t just go out and buy a brand-new MacBook Pro.

Judge: I understand that, but the law says you are responsible for items left in your care. Did you have any insurance?

Defendant: No.

Judge: So if you have no insurance and you’re responsible, what’s your plan?

Defendant: I offered him a replacement.

Plaintiff: Your Honor, the replacement was not even close. It didn’t have the same specs, and it wouldn’t work for my needs as a DJ.

Judge: Mr. Ornelas, you are responsible for the full replacement value of the laptop. That’s just how this works.

Defendant: But Your Honor—

Judge: No "but." He left his laptop with you in good faith. You were negligent in securing your store. It got stolen, and now you have to replace it.

Defendant: I don’t have that kind of money.

Judge: Then you shouldn’t be in business without proper security measures.

Defendant: (Sighs)

Judge: Alright. Now, Mr. Sanchez, how do we get to $5,727.22?

Plaintiff: The cost of the laptop is $2,500. Then there is the cost of the software, which was another $1,200. I had Serato DJ software, music production software, and some custom programs that I purchased over time. Then, I had about $1,500 worth of music files that I had purchased legally.

Judge: Do you have proof of purchase for the software and music?

Plaintiff: Yes, I printed out my receipts from my email.

Judge: (Reviews documents) Okay, these look legitimate.

Defendant: But I can’t be responsible for his software and music! That wasn’t my fault!

Judge: You are responsible for the laptop and everything that was inside of it. If someone leaves a car with a valet, and the valet loses the car, they don’t just owe for the car—they owe for what was in it, too.   Defendant: This is going to bankrupt me.

Judge: Maybe this is a lesson in proper security. My ruling is for the plaintiff in the amount of $5,727.22. Court is adjourned.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hand. Back to the People's Court. Next case on the docket: The Plaintiff says the Defendant ruined his hot tub cover by using it as a bench, but the Defendant says not guilty. It's the case of "Undercovered." Thank you, Douglas. William Taylor?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma'am.

Judge: You are suing your former tenant, Lori Phillips, for $425.00, the amount you say she owes you to replace a hot tub cover that, according to you, she broke. What happened?

Plaintiff: Your Honor, last summer, from about May to August 2011, Lori rented a bedroom from me in my house. We have a hot tub in the rear and also a swimming pool. She utilized both of these; that wasn’t an issue at all. The issue was how she used the hot tub.

Judge: How many people lived in the place?

Plaintiff: Around five altogether. Myself and four other roommates. It’s a five-bedroom split-level, kind of a Brady Bunch-style split-level. Right around the middle of August, I saw her coming out of the pool, going to the hot tub on the other deck, and lifting the cover over. So now we have it halfway over like that, covering half the hot tub. Then she proceeded to get in it.

Judge: And you questioned her about this?

Plaintiff: Yes. I saw her at least on one occasion doing this and asked, "What are you doing?" She said, "Oh, I'm just getting warmed up because the pool is too cold." I said, "Oh, okay, well, as long as you don’t get trapped underneath it." That was all I cared about.

Plaintiff: One other time, when I was mowing the lawn, I saw her utilizing the hot tub that way again. On the edge, where she had the cover folded over, and on the outer reinforced side of the hot tub, she would push herself up out of the hot tub in that manner.

Plaintiff: On another occasion, shortly before she moved out, my girlfriend Angela, who is also my roommate, noticed Lori sitting on it—

Judge: Is Angela here to testify?

Plaintiff: No, I have a notarized statement from her.

Judge: Why isn’t she here?

Plaintiff: She’s afraid of flying.

Judge: So she left you hanging?

Plaintiff: Yes, they all did.

Judge: Wow. Okay, continue.

Plaintiff: Angela informed me of seeing that also. At that time, I didn’t think much of it. But when closing the cover—

Judge: When did you discover the damage?

Plaintiff: Shortly after she moved out.

Judge: Did you return a security deposit?

Plaintiff: There was no security deposit.

Judge: How long after she moved out did you notice the problem?

Plaintiff: About six weeks.

Judge: And after six weeks, you then tell her the hot tub cover is damaged?

Defendant: He accused me of something else first. He came after me for not giving a 30-day notice before moving out.

Judge: And did you?

Defendant: No, I gave two weeks’ notice.

Judge: And what were you supposed to give?

Defendant: 30 days. I was guilty of that.

Judge: So you paid the rest of the rent because you felt you owed it?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: And after paying, that’s the first time he mentions you ruined his hot tub cover?

Defendant: Yes, in April. That was six months later. I got a letter at work.

Judge: When did she move out?

Plaintiff: Third week of August.

Judge: Why did you wait four months to bring it up?

Plaintiff: When she made her last payment in December, I told her about the cover and said I would try to repair it.

Judge: Did you ever try to repair it?

Plaintiff: Yes. When I opened it, I saw more damage.

Judge: Did you get a professional opinion?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Do you have proof of the cover’s age and depreciation?

Plaintiff: No, but it’s two years old, with a 10-year lifespan.

Judge: Proof?

Plaintiff: I have a warranty for the replacement one.

Judge: That’s not proof for this one. Ms. Phillips, did you ever lean on the hot tub cover?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Did you use it half-flapped?

Defendant: Yes, but I entered on the other side.

Judge: Did you sit on it?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Does the hot tub have steps?

Plaintiff: No, just low seats.

Judge: My verdict is for the Defendant. Your proof is very thin.

Judge: Ms. Katherine David, you are suing Dorene Kho for $415 that you are out as a result of what you say was a sick puppy that she sold you. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff (Katherine David): That is correct. On January 15, 2017, I answered an ad in The Long Island Newsday for golden retrievers. I contacted the phone number, which turned out to be Dorene Kho. I made arrangements with her after speaking with her on the phone to visit the puppies. I visited them that day, and I was very happy with the puppy I saw—or rather, the puppies I saw. We discussed adoption, and I left a $200 deposit because the puppy was not ready to come home yet.

I waited the recommended period of eight weeks to pick up the puppy, which I did on February 18. I gave her the remaining amount of $600.

Judge: So the total purchase price was $1,800, correct?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: Is this your first golden retriever?

Plaintiff: No, this is my third golden retriever. I’ve had two prior golden retrievers, which I also adopted through Newsday, and I felt very confident applying to this ad.

Judge: So you bring the puppy home, and what happens? What day do you bring the puppy home?

Plaintiff: I brought the puppy home on a Saturday, which was February—

Judge: February what?

Plaintiff: February 18, which was a long weekend. I made arrangements for the dog to see my vet on Monday, February 20. The dog went to my vet on February 20, was examined, and I left a fecal sample with the vet to be tested.

I was informed the following day that the sample showed the dog had Giardia and Coccidia, which are parasites.

Judge: Was the dog showing any symptoms?

Plaintiff: Yes, she was, as a matter of fact.

Judge: What symptoms?

Plaintiff: She was showing a lack of appetite and having very loose, watery stools—consistently. In and out of the house, which is normal with a puppy, but the fact that she wasn’t eating, and just that something didn’t seem right, made me worried. That’s not what a puppy should be doing at this early stage.

Judge: So you bring the dog back to the vet?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And what does the vet do?

Plaintiff: The vet prescribes an antibiotic for five days, with a recheck thereafter, along with another fecal sample to make sure the parasite is gone.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: The dog did not respond to the medications, so I had to go back to the vet again.

Judge: Did you go back five days later, or before that?

Plaintiff: I went back five days later.

Judge: That was your checkup time?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And what happened?

Plaintiff: The same thing. Loose stools, not eating. The vet then gave the dog an antibiotic injection to try to help. He also suggested I change her diet to a prescription diet.

Judge: And did you do that?

Plaintiff: Yes, I did.

Judge: Did it help?

Plaintiff: No, to no avail. The dog continued with the same symptoms.

Judge: So then you took the dog to a veterinary neurology specialist?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And what happened?

Plaintiff: They gave her intravenous fluids to sustain her while she was there. She had several seizures.

Judge: What did the specialist tell you?

Plaintiff: Dr. Bilderbank called me and told me what they had observed overnight. She said the seizures were something the puppy was not going to recover from. The dog was walking in circles, drooling at the mouth, and was not responsive.

She said they could do further testing, but even if I had a Black American Express card, she could not guarantee that the results would provide a solution.

Judge: So the puppy was put down?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Did you notify the defendant?

Plaintiff: Yes, two days before. I called her the morning the specialist told me about the condition and asked if she wanted the puppy back.

Judge: And what did she say?

Plaintiff: She said, “Do not bring that dog here.”

Judge: Ms. Kho, let me talk to you. How long have you been breeding dogs?

Defendant (Dorene Kho): Approximately 40 years.

Judge: Wow, that is a long time.

Defendant: Yes, it is.

Judge: When you first heard about the issue, what did you do?

Defendant: I was in shock. This was an amazing litter—

Judge: How many puppies were in the litter?

Defendant: Seven.

Judge: Did any of the other dogs have issues?

Defendant: Her neighbor owns the brother of the puppy that passed.

Judge: Did that dog have issues?

Defendant: That dog also had Giardia, but it survived.

Judge: Did another puppy from the litter die?

Defendant: Yes. I kept one of the puppies, and she passed away at my home.

Judge: So two from the litter had issues?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Then what’s your defense?

Defendant: I had no idea this would happen. I sent the puppy to Cornell University for a necropsy, and they confirmed it was a virus.

Judge: The law is clear. If the animal is unfit for purchase at the time of sale, the breeder is responsible for reimbursement.

Judge: I’m ruling in favor of the plaintiff for the full amount of $3,600.

[Gavel bangs]

Judge: Verdict for the plaintiff.

Judge: Okay, Miss Kelly, you are suing Mr. Sterling for $1,556.16 for several of your items that you say you left at his place when you two broke up, and he has destroyed because you two broke up. Tell me what's going on.

Plaintiff: Um, I met Sterling on a dating site, mate1.com.

Judge: Which one?

Plaintiff: Mate1.com.

Judge: Got it. Alright, we'll get through this. Alright, mate1.com.

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Okay, I called him. Does it have some kind of specialty that… you know, I’ve never heard of that one actually. I work a lot, so I don’t get time to socialize. I’ve heard of dating sites, girl, I think the whole thing’s very efficient. I mean, I’ve been married for 20 years, but if I wasn’t, that’s how I would… it’s like internet shopping, it’s fine. But, um, I have a question for you though. Does it… it’s just anybody can be on it? Do you have to meet certain criteria to be on it?

Plaintiff: You do.

Judge: Yes. What's the criteria?

Plaintiff: A life.

Judge: Yes, alright. So, you meet him on what day?

Plaintiff: Valentine's Day.

Judge: Yes, we did. We met that Friday, we went out, we discussed what we wanted out of our life. He was real straightforward and honest, and I loved that about him. So, it was like a flick at first sight. Then he was telling me about his plans, his dreams and his aspirations. I really liked that because he was like so honest doing that, and I supported him right off the bat.

Judge: So, at some point, what? You supported him right off the bat? What does that mean?

Plaintiff: You liked him?

Plaintiff: Yes, I liked him.

Judge: Or did you mean actually financially supported him?

Plaintiff: No, I didn’t know what you were saying.

Judge: Okay, that's alright. So, you liked him and then what?

Plaintiff: We talked and he said he wanted me to move in.

Judge: A few weeks after you met him?

Plaintiff: Yes, I moved in.

Judge: Okay, you moved in a few weeks after you met. You move in, now you date and you date, a few years and it’s really working well, so you want to take it to the next level?

Plaintiff: No, it’s just… you move into what?

Plaintiff: To your place.

Judge: Yes, ma’am. Okay, do you have children?

Plaintiff: No, I don’t.

Judge: Okay, we got that going, right. So, because half the time when that happens, I have people moving their children into somebody who could be a pedophile, not to suggest that about you, but you know…

Plaintiff: Alright, so you at least it’s only you who you were putting at risk. So, you move in. How many weeks had you known him when you moved in?

Plaintiff: I think about 3 weeks, two and a half, 3 weeks.

Judge: Oh, you know all about a man by then?

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Judge: Right, in 3 weeks you’re going to know everything there is to know. Yeah, how’d that work out for you?

Plaintiff: It was actually good for the first month, everything was alright, we understood each other, we talked about what and then after a month, it wasn’t so good.

Judge: Right, because it didn’t work out too well for you?

Plaintiff: No, wait and get to know somebody before you moved in with them?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Okay, have you done that before?

Plaintiff: No, it was actually my first time. I realized I was getting old and I really needed to have a relationship.

Judge: And that’s fine and I understand that, alright. I understand the loneliness, but if you want… sometimes you got to think long term. And if what you want is a relationship long term, then you want to get to know someone before you turn around and uproot your life, because it usually doesn’t work when it’s like this. You know, you have to invest a little time in a relationship that’s long-lasting, and if you can’t wait 3 weeks before you move in with somebody you don’t know each other, you’re going to fight non-stop and it’s going to turn out that you two maybe aren’t compatible to live with each other, which is in fact what you found out, because when you moved in, you two started fighting. And what are you fighting about?

Plaintiff: My job, my hours, that hour.

Judge: What do you do?

Plaintiff: Actually, I’m a sales rep and I’m a nursing assistant.

Judge: And you were working how many hours a day?

Plaintiff: Depending how I feel, I work like 14.

Judge: And how long was he working a day?

Plaintiff: Oh, he’s not working.

Judge: You don’t?

Defendant: Okay, alright, so you were lonely?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: You were still lonely?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: You moved the woman in, ma’am, you think your loneliness is over and then you're still lonely?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: Right, exactly. Exactly right, of course, if you knew her a little bit beforehand you’d say, well, maybe this isn’t the woman for me because we’re not compatible in that respect. And why aren’t you working?

Defendant: I’m retired. I’m a military veteran, PTSD.

Judge: Okay, you're going through some psychological issues?

Defendant: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: You’ve handed me a report by a psychiatrist?

Defendant: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: According to the report, you're suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder?

Defendant: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: And dissociative disorder?

Defendant: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: How long has it been? Where did you serve?

Defendant: I was on the USS Saratoga in 1986 when we bombed Libya and we had the hostages off of the… I mean, the kidnappers that kidnapped their cu’s, Lao, the big and they pushed the man off the… we got that, that was our F14s that made that 747 night, president.

Judge: What was your role?

Defendant: I’m a fireman. I help the jets take off.

Judge: Right. Okay, thank you for your service.

Defendant: Thank you, ma’am.

Judge: And I’m sorry that you're going through difficulty. All the more reason why you might want to know somebody before they move in. That’s when you break up. Whose idea was it?

Defendant: I take it, it was yours.

Plaintiff: Yes, it was.

Judge: Then when you leave, why do you leave stuff behind?

Plaintiff: Actually, I found the apartment and I came back the next day to get my stuff, and he didn’t want to let me in the apartment, he changed the locks, because you know, I was going to leave because I told…

Plaintiff: But you had taken some stuff, you hadn't taken anything?

Plaintiff: Not really, only what I needed for the day. I didn’t take anything.

Plaintiff: So you needed your stuff?

Plaintiff: So, I went over there in a cab. I went upstairs and knocked on his door. He didn’t want to let me in, and I said, “Okay, then put them outside. Pack up as much stuff as you can and put them outside.”

Judge: You're just shouting through the door?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: How are you communicating with him on the phone or no?

Plaintiff: I was talking through the door because he closed the door, he didn’t want to let me in.

Judge: Alright, and what does he say?

Plaintiff: Yes, I’ll pack it and put it out.

Judge: Yes, and he opened the door and he has the video camera on me and says, “I should just take up the stuff and leave.”

Plaintiff: So, I just took everything and I said, “There’s a lot more stuff I need.” I leave, and he says, “Just go, go.”

Judge: Do you have that video?

Plaintiff: No, ma’am, I didn’t bring it because I don’t think we were…

Judge: Was there stuff that you wouldn’t let her get?

Defendant: No.

Judge: It’s not what happened.

Judge: So, they move in a couple of weeks after meeting on a dating site. Is that ridiculous?

Defendant: You know what, the way communication is nowadays, I believe it is possible. 20 years ago, I saw my wife in the hallway of our high school, and I fell in love with her, and I’m really touched.

Judge: How soon later did you move in with her?

Defendant: I would say after we found out she was pregnant.

Judge: Okay, is it too long or ridiculous, a couple of weeks moving in?

Defendant: Yeah, I think it’s too soon to move in. Let’s get a different perspective, what do you think?

Plaintiff: I think it’s ridiculous, because you can actually… well, it can happen because people can meet each other and fall in love at first sight. Fair enough.

Judge: When Harry Met Sally. Going inside the courtroom, I went out. I go to see the psychiatrist once a week. When I went to go see the psychiatrist, when I came back, she was gone. You can visibly tell that she took her stuff out of the closet, stuff out of the drawers, so that was the first inkling you got that she was leaving?

Defendant: I was abandoned.

Defendant: The first thing I felt was abandoned.

Judge: Abandoned?

Defendant: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: So, I imploded, you know, it hurt because why would you leave like that? And so she wanted to call me back and talk it over. I didn’t want to talk about it. I didn’t want to… if you left, you should have taken everything.

Judge: Then what happened? What happened to the rest of her stuff that she didn’t take?

Defendant: Oh, the garbage got it.

Judge: The garbage got it?

Defendant: Got it.

Judge: How did the garbage get it?

Defendant: Did it come in and put its hands inside of the stuff and make it suck it into the garbage?

Defendant: You threw it out. I quickly put some stuff together and I videotaped, because I didn’t want her to say open the door and hit her or anything like that.

Judge: So, whatever she got and didn’t want to call back and say she missed stuff?

Defendant: Yes.

Plaintiff: Probably.

Judge: Okay, so what she says that you still had and refused to give her is a digital camera, a computer, six winter coats, two boots, six nursing uniforms, and some computer software. Let's talk about those. The digital camera and computer, did that stay behind?

Defendant: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: Okay. And why?

Plaintiff: Ask her.

Defendant: Okay, where is it now?

Defendant: In my house.

Judge: Okay. So, you do and those things belong to her?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Who do they belong to?

Defendant: We bought those while we were together, and she left it.

Judge: Okay, you bought them while you were together and she left them. But who paid for them?

Defendant: You're not working. She's working 14 hours.

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: Okay. So, you agree that she paid for them, but you feel like since it was during your time together… That’s the logic?

Defendant: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: That sounds a little unfair to me. But let’s keep going.

Judge: How much are you asking for in total?

Plaintiff: $1,556.16.

Judge: Alright, what is that for?

Plaintiff: The computer, the camera, and the clothes.

Judge: Okay, and do you have the receipts for them?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: Well, based on the evidence in the case, I’m awarding you the amount that you have requested. You have won the case.

Judge: The decision is in your favor. Congratulations.

Judge: "What about paying your sister child support to take care of your children? I mean, you don't want them, you're not raising them, they've been with her for the past nine months, so wouldn't you say it's fair to give her some money for them?"

Defendant: "I don't really have it. I only make like 40,000 a year."

Judge: "But you're making money. Okay, do you live alone?"

Judge:
Paul Amazon, you are suing Michael for $1,700 that you paid him and want it returned to you. According to you, he didn’t do anything for it. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff:
Um, I met Michael in the building where I work, and um, I asked him—I have a job that I need to do. I need to redo my porch, and I took him to my house and I told him, "This is what I want to be done." And he gave me a contract.

Judge:
Okay.

Plaintiff:
And he gave me the contract. He said, um, when I start, bring um—okay, it’s $2,200.

Judge:
Yes.

Plaintiff:
