All right. I find that you are entitled to $200 for trash removal and $750 for painting, totaling $950. I find that you, Darcy, are entitled to $1,400. Subtracting the $950, that means a net judgment in your favor for $450. That is my verdict. Good luck, folks.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People's Court. The plaintiff hired the defendant to find a DJ for a party, but the DJ got in a car accident, and now the defendant refuses to return the money. The defendant says the DJ was ready, willing, and able. It's the case of "Can’t Stop the Music." Thank you, Douglas.

Judge: Anette Dunlap, you are suing a DJ company represented here by its owner, John M. for $1,500. You want him to pay you $300, money that you paid him to DJ and, according to you, he didn’t show up. $300 for a replacement DJ. $400 for bank fees—you’re going to have to explain that to me—and $500 for pain and suffering. So you've managed to turn a $300 case into a $1,500 case, mushrooming it into five times what you're actually out. What’s going on?

Plaintiff: Well, I hired the DJ company to come and DJ for my New Year's party.

Judge: Had you ever used them before?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: How did you find them?

Plaintiff: Through a search engine. I picked them because they had good reviews, seemed professional, and with the other DJs I found, they gave me the best price.

Judge: So, what happened?

Plaintiff: I paid them. They told me the budget was $349, and I paid them $300. The day before the party, they called me and said the DJ got in an accident and wouldn’t be able to come.

Judge: Who called you and told you that?

Plaintiff: A lady named Amanda V. She was the main person I dealt with.

Judge: Have you ever dealt with John?

Plaintiff: No, I was told to deal with John during the refund process. But he never returned any of my calls.

Judge: Did you ever meet him before today?

Plaintiff: No. Everything was by phone and email. The only person I talked to and corresponded with was Amanda V.

Judge: So Amanda V. gave you a heads-up the day before New Year's Eve and said one of their DJs got into a car accident and wouldn’t be showing up?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: How were they planning on solving the problem?

Plaintiff: She said they could give me a refund or lease out another contract with another company, but I would have to pay $500 instead.

Judge: Why wouldn’t they cover the extra $200?

Plaintiff: That’s what I asked. I said, "Why don’t you eat the extra $200?" They refused, so I opted for the refund and asked for proof. I got an email from someone named Roxan Simonetti, but it had the DJ company’s logo and contact information.

Judge: John, what actually happened?

Defendant: We were hired to DJ the event. That night, we had multiple parties. The DJ scheduled for her event had an earlier gig before hers. Her party was from 12:30 a.m. to 4:00 a.m., so he was scheduled to do a double shift.

Judge: Wait, her event was from 12:30 a.m. to 4:00 a.m.?

Plaintiff: No, it was supposed to be from 11:00 p.m. to 4:00 a.m.

Judge: Go on.

Defendant: The night before the event, we called the client and were told the party was canceled.

Judge: She canceled on you?

Defendant: Correct.

Judge: So there was never a car accident?

Defendant: No.

Judge: You didn’t overextend yourself and make up a car accident?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Really? You didn’t just book too many parties and ditch her because she was getting a good price?

Defendant: Not at all.

Judge: Show me the email.

Plaintiff: Here’s the original email and my response when they never contacted me about my refund.

Judge: Who is Roxan Simonetti?

Defendant: She’s a secretary at our company.

Judge: Roxan sent an email saying the DJ scheduled for the event was in an accident and wouldn’t be able to attend. It offers a refund or a contract with another company for $500. John, what is this?

Defendant: I don’t know.

Judge: You don’t know? You denied under oath that a DJ was in an accident, yet your own secretary sent this email?

Defendant: I had no idea.

Judge: Who else would instruct her to make that up?

Defendant: I have no idea.

Judge: Why would a secretary make this up unless you told her to?

Judge: You left her hanging, and then when she went to the bank for a refund, you disputed it?

Plaintiff: Yes, I have proof.

Judge: Let me see it.

Plaintiff: Here’s proof my bank reversed my claim because they said the DJ company told them I wasn't owed money.

Judge: Jonathan, you signed this. It states, "All supporting documents are attached. There are no refunds."

Judge: No refunds? Even when you breach?

Defendant: Correct.

Judge: Unbelievable. Here’s what we’re going to do. There is no pain and suffering in a contracts case, but I find this very painful. I’m ordering you to reimburse the $300 you stole, the $68 in bank fees, and an additional $300 as punitive damages for willful breach. Total: $668. Judgment for the plaintiff.

Judge: Good luck.

[Judge]Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket—the plaintiff was moving into an apartment but canceled before moving in, and now the defendant won’t return the deposit. The defendant says the plaintiff is a fraud. It’s the case of You Played Hocus Pocus with My Security.

Tanya Lopez, you are suing Diolinda Canuto for $1,950, the return of your security deposit of $975, plus an additional $975 for aggravation. What happened?

[Plaintiff]I applied for an apartment that she had for rent and gave her a little bit of money bit by bit. I guess the date that I signed the lease, I went to try to put the lights on in my name, and I had an old bill which I could not pay.

[Judge]Okay, back up. So you were going to move in when?

[Plaintiff]September 1st.

[Judge]And do you have a lease?

[Plaintiff]Yes, I had the lease.

[Judge]Do you have a copy of it? And does the lease start on September 1st?

[Plaintiff]Yes, it was supposed to start September 1st.

[Judge]Then you tried to get the electricity in your name when?

[Plaintiff]On the 24th.

[Judge]Why so early? Just to be prepared, or were you going to start moving?

[Plaintiff]To turn it on for the first. So I went on the 24th and tried to get it on.

[Judge]And what happened when you got there?

[Plaintiff]They said that I had an old bill.

[Judge]For how much?

[Plaintiff]$4,800.

[Judge]You didn’t know that?

[Plaintiff]It was from my last marriage, and I didn’t need the lights at that time because I was in another town. I moved away from Norwich.

[Judge]So the bill in your ex’s place was still under your name, and he didn’t pay it?

[Plaintiff]No, it was an old bill.

[Judge]Who was responsible for paying it?

[Plaintiff]I was liable for it; it was in my name.

[Judge]How long ago was the bill?

[Plaintiff]About three or four years ago.

[Judge]So what were you doing for electricity in the meantime?

[Plaintiff]My last apartment had utilities included.

[Judge]So you found out about the old bill, and what happened next?

[Plaintiff]I asked her if she could include the electricity in the rent, and I would pay her separately. She said no. Then I asked if my kids’ father could put the electricity in his name until I could pay off my old bill, and she denied that.

[Judge]Why is that fraud?

[Defendant]Because the ex-husband wasn’t going to live in the house. The utility company requires the name on the lease to match the account holder.

[Judge]Do you have any proof of that?

[Defendant]No.

[Judge]I don’t understand why it matters to you who pays the electricity bill, as long as it gets paid.

[Defendant]I was told that only the leaseholder can open an electricity account.

[Judge]Do you have proof of that policy?

[Defendant]No.

[Judge]You don’t have a legitimate reason for denying her the apartment. If she failed to open an account, that would be her problem, not yours. Instead, you pulled the rug out from under her tenancy without proper grounds. You refunded half her money, but you kept $975. On what grounds?

[Defendant’s Son]If she could have opened electricity, she would have done it.

[Judge]No. Your mother bailed, not her. Your mother refused to rent to her. You need to return the other $975. As for this extra $975 for aggravation, I’m not awarding that. Aggravation is not a cause of action. Verdict for the plaintiff for $975 plus court costs.

JUDGE: Plaintiff, you are suing the defendant for $220, which you claim he still owes you for the return of a car he sold you. Tell me what’s going on.

PLAINTIFF: Well, the defendant and I used to work together. He sold me a car on Friday. As soon as I took the car home, the brakes went out.

JUDGE: What kind of car?

PLAINTIFF: A 1998 Pontiac Bonneville.

JUDGE: A 1998? That car is almost old enough to drink!

PLAINTIFF: Yeah. As soon as I took it home, the car started leaking brake fluid everywhere, and I had no brakes. I called the defendant that night and let him know. I felt like he already knew something was wrong because there was a bottle of brake fluid in the back seat.

JUDGE: Did he ever tell you the car needed brake fluid or had issues?

PLAINTIFF: No.

JUDGE: But did you really think a car that old wouldn’t have some problems? Did you have it inspected by a mechanic?

PLAINTIFF: I didn’t mind fixing some things, but I didn’t expect it to have brake problems.

JUDGE: Why not? A 21-year-old car is bound to have issues. You didn’t even check how much it would cost to fix before demanding your money back?

PLAINTIFF: I didn’t even get a chance! I called him right away.

JUDGE: Defendant, did he call you the same day he bought it?

DEFENDANT: Yes.

JUDGE: And you agreed to take the car back?

DEFENDANT: Yes, I took it back and sold it to another coworker.

JUDGE: Another coworker? Because that worked so well the first time?

DEFENDANT: Well, I offered to fix the brakes for him, but he didn’t want that. So, I sold it to someone else.

JUDGE: How much did you sell it for?

DEFENDANT: $500.

JUDGE: Did that person pay you fully?

DEFENDANT: Yes.

JUDGE: Plaintiff, you claim the defendant did not fully reimburse you?

PLAINTIFF: That’s right. He only paid me $380.

JUDGE: Defendant, what do you say to that?

DEFENDANT: I paid him three different times—$300, $200, and $100. The first payment was made in front of someone. The last $100 was given at work in front of a supervisor.

JUDGE: Do you have that supervisor here to testify?

DEFENDANT: No.

JUDGE: Do you have a written statement from them?

DEFENDANT: No.

JUDGE: Do you have receipts proving you made those payments?

DEFENDANT: No.

JUDGE: Plaintiff, do you have any texts proving he still owed you money?

PLAINTIFF: Yes.

JUDGE: Let me see those texts.

PLAINTIFF: (Hands over phone)

JUDGE: (Reading messages) On September 28, you texted, "Yo, defendant, I’ll see you at work. Since you don’t want to answer, I want my money. Can’t sell a car with no brakes. Have my money, or I’ll have your car." Then on September 30, you wrote, "Defendant, what are you going to do? I don’t have time to play games. If I don’t hear from you today, I’m leaving your car at work." And then on October 1st, "When are you going to start giving me my money? If I don’t have it by Monday, I’m filing a lawsuit."

Finally, on October 19, defendant, you responded, "What money?"

Defendant, you never texted him back saying, "I already paid you everything." You just ignored him.

DEFENDANT: …

JUDGE: Defendant, the burden is on you to prove payment. You have no receipts, no witness statements, and no proof that you paid the full amount. Judgment for the plaintiff in the amount of $220.

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Ramon Chadar? Yes, and Kti Sinini. Cark Cark. Okay. You are suing Michelle and Ton Saunders, okay? You’re the mom? Yes. Alright, for $1,000 for stolen property because, according to you, he stole your scooter, your helmet, and caused you to pay some money in changing locks because your scooter keys were involved. Tell me what’s going on.

Plaintiff (Rayon): Well, your honor, on June 8th, me and my friend went to the pawn shop, and I decided to stand outside. When I was standing outside, the defendant was with a girl named Jennifer. Is she in the car? Yes. Is he in the car? Yes. Okay, and you have driven to the pawn shop on your scooter? Yes. What kind of scooter? It was a tow, tow. It was a 49cc. Did you have any pictures of it? No. Okay, so go on.

Plaintiff (Rayon): Well, when I was talking to her, the defendant hopped on my scooter and drove off and took off. Took off, stole your scooter right in front of you with someone who can identify him?

Plaintiff (Rayon): Yeah, and she gave me false information about him.

Judge: What false information did she give you?

Plaintiff (Rayon): She gave me the last name Wilson. Was Wilson ever one of his names for some reason? No.

Plaintiff (Rayon): Go on.

Plaintiff (Rayon): Do you know Jennifer?

Judge: Yes.

Plaintiff (Rayon): Who’s Jennifer?

Plaintiff (Rayon): His friend. Girlfriend or friend?

Plaintiff (Rayon): Friend.

Plaintiff (Rayon): So at that point, I felt my attention was taken away from the scooter for a reason.

Plaintiff (Rayon): Yeah, you got had.

Plaintiff (Rayon): So then what happens?

Plaintiff (Rayon): You call the police?

Plaintiff (Rayon): Call the police and then what?

Plaintiff (Rayon): The police couldn’t really do much.

Judge: Why couldn’t they do much?

Plaintiff (Rayon): Oh, because you didn’t know who the guy was.

Plaintiff (Rayon): Yeah, until—

Judge: But how do you find out who the guy was?

Plaintiff (Rayon): Because I knew his older sister, Erica Saers.

Plaintiff (Rayon): Okay, and I go and tell the cops, and by that time, the defendant was already in jail.

Judge: And then why wasn’t there an arrest?

Plaintiff (Rayon): Because he was already in jail.

Judge: So what then?

Plaintiff (Rayon): He can be in jail on two things. Why wouldn’t there—like, why didn’t the police follow through? What did they say to you?

Plaintiff’s Dad: Your honor, the detective says we cannot do anything anyway because he’s a juvenile.

Judge: What does that have to do with it? Obviously, things can be done to a juvenile. They’re just done in juvenile court. You still charge them with a crime, and then a judge decides a punishment. There’s juvenile hall. There’s—

Plaintiff’s Dad: Okay, alright, alright, alright, wait, just stop. Just stop. Stop, stop, stop. What’s going on, you H?

Defendant (Ton): Um, the day he said, um, I think he said June 8th, we was with my friend Jenny. He had come to the plaza. We was in talking about he’s selling a scooter. I’m like, how much you selling it for? He like, I want like a thousand. I’ll take eight. I’m like, word. I probably get like 650-700. He like, you know how to ride? I’m like, yeah. He gave me his helmet and the keys and was like, yo, where you going? I’m like, I’m going down to the gas station. Come right back up the street. I gets on, I goes. I’m gone for like 10 minutes. I came back to the plaza. He was gone. I don’t know him.

Judge: Yeah, you know how people are constantly just leaving the plaza after 10 minutes?

Defendant (Ton): I guess my scooter’s not coming back. I’m just going to invest in a 10-minute—not a second more than 10 minutes. Mama, you listening to him?

Plaintiff (Rayon’s Dad): Mm-hm. You know this is a load of garbage, right?

Defendant (Ton): Yeah.

Judge: So are parents largely responsible when a kid becomes a criminal? You got a kid here, so I’m going to ask you.

Judge: Yes, they’re completely responsible because from a young age, you have to mold them into the kind of adult that they should be.

Judge: What do you think? Are parents responsible if a kid becomes a criminal?

Plaintiff (Rayon’s Dad): Oh yeah, I think so, just ‘cause like they like teach him what they do and stuff.

Judge: Fair enough. What do you think?

Plaintiff’s Son: Yeah, I agree ‘cause like your parent has to teach you how to be, like, proper values and all that, and if they don’t teach you that, you become a criminal.

Judge: Interesting. Okay, very interesting.

Judge: Okay, going inside the courtroom.

Plaintiff’s Dad: He has two scooters, so he wasn’t still my scooter. How’d you get the other two?

Defendant (Ton): I bought them.

Plaintiff’s Dad: In his statement, what he says is buy and sell scooters. That might be a reason to take a scooter so you can sell it. I don’t know.

Judge: Yeah, but like he said he came back 10 minutes later. He was going, what was he in for? Now fighting, not stealing. He never got arrested for nothing stealing.

Defendant (Ton): So you come back in 10 minutes and the owner of a scooter has forfeited the scooter because you—‘cause he couldn’t wait 10 minutes for a scooter?

Plaintiff (Rayon): How’d you get home?

Defendant (Ton): My house is directly across the street.

Plaintiff (Rayon): Okay, so he walks home rather than wait for his scooter, and then what?

Plaintiff (Rayon): Where’s the scooter?

Defendant (Ton): It’s gone.

Plaintiff (Rayon): Is obviously, is going now?

Defendant (Ton): No, it’s not obvious to me, because I don’t live in this fairy tale land. So I don’t know what you’re going to say next. Where did the scooter go?

Defendant (Ton): I’m not sure.

Judge: Well, was it g? The same day, a week later?

Defendant (Ton): It was the next day. I still got his...

Judge: Let’s put ourselves in your clown shoes. And we’re going to come back to the plaza after 10 minutes, and when we come back, the guy who owns the scooter couldn’t wait until minute 11. You then find yourself with a scooter and keys and a helmet, and of course, you call the police to say, listen, there’s a problem. This guy might report his scooter stolen, but actually, he’s just an impatient fellow. So you did that, right?

Defendant (Ton): No.

Judge: And then, according to you, the next day, the scooter’s gone. Probably, was he probably sold it between those two days?

Defendant (Ton): I was in jail.

Judge: How’d you steal it?

Defendant (Ton): Oh, you went to jail.

Defendant (Ton): I just told you.

Judge: Alright, and then you—so you went to jail on day two or the day that you took the scooter?

Defendant (Ton): Day two.

Judge: Day two. Show me the receipts for the scooter. Where was your helmet?

Defendant (Ton): On the scooter handlebars. Yeah, it was attached.

Judge: Show me the receipts for the helmet. The $60 for three deadbolt locks, what is that? Is the house locks?

Plaintiff (Rayon): You had to change everything once your keys were missing.

Judge: Alright. Let me tell you what’s going to happen, my friends. I’m issuing a judgment in your favor in the exact amount of your losses, which are $999, because I find that the story he’s giving me is completely and totally preposterous.

Judge: That judgment is against Ton, not against his mother, because he’s a grown thief on his own account, and she cannot be held legally responsible for what he does when he’s thieving on his own. Understand?

Plaintiff (Rayon): Yes.

Judge: So that’s dismissed against her. $999 against Ton. Verdict for the plaintiffs.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hand. You see the controllers have been sworn. Thank you, Douglas.

Judge: Okay, Thelma and Leticia, you are suing Stephen Schaffner for $2,800 that he won’t return to you for a vehicle that you bought from him, which you say is junk. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff (Leticia): Okay, first, I just want to say I love, love, love your show. I watch it all the time!

Judge: Okay, so honestly, what do you…

Plaintiff (Leticia): Right, yes. So, on February 27th, I was looking for a car for my mom on Craigslist. I saw this Ford Escape 2004 listed for $3,500. It had 88,000 miles, one owner, in pretty good condition, and the price was negotiable.

Plaintiff (Leticia): I called Stephen and asked if we could see the car. I asked if we could go down on the price. He said he wasn’t going down that much but was willing to budge a little. He explained that the car was his son's, in good condition, and that his son went to college, so he didn’t need the car anymore.

Plaintiff (Leticia): I went out there, test-drove it for about three blocks, but it was a residential area, so I didn’t go that fast.

Judge: Who was the car for?

Plaintiff (Leticia): It was for my mom.

Judge: Why didn’t she test-drive it?

Plaintiff (Leticia): She was there, but she trusted my judgment.

Judge: Did she get in the car with you when you were test-driving it?

Plaintiff (Leticia): No, he did.

Judge: And your mom didn’t?

Plaintiff (Leticia): No, my mom didn’t.

Judge: Is it a two-seater?

Plaintiff (Leticia): No.

Judge: If it’s her car, how come she didn’t test-drive it?

Plaintiff (Leticia): I always make all the decisions.

Judge: Okay, so which is why I feel bad because I… I know you feel bad.

Plaintiff (Leticia): Right. So, on the 28th, I added it to my insurance policy.

Judge: Wait, so you agreed on a price?

Plaintiff (Leticia): Yes, $2,800. I tried to get it for $2,750, but he wouldn’t budge, so I paid $2,800.

Judge: That’s down from $3,500?

Plaintiff (Leticia): Yes.

Judge: All right, so you got a deal. Did you have a mechanic check it out before buying it?

Plaintiff (Leticia): No, I didn’t.

Judge: Is there any paperwork from the sale?

Plaintiff (Leticia): We gave the bill of sale to the motor vehicle department.

Judge: You don’t have a copy of the bill of sale?

Plaintiff (Leticia): No.

Judge: Do you have a copy of the bill of sale?

Defendant (Stephen): No.

Judge: Do you have a phone?

Plaintiff (Leticia): Yes.

Judge: Do your phones take pictures?

Plaintiff (Leticia): Yes.

Judge: They’re not just for nasty pictures; they’re also for taking pictures of evidence. You should have taken a picture of the bill of sale. Now, I don’t know what it said or the terms of the sale.

Judge: Did he tell you anything besides it runs well?

Plaintiff (Leticia): He said if there were any problems, we could always bring it back, and he would give us our money back.

Judge: Did you say that?

Defendant (Stephen): No.

Judge: That’s why we want a bill of sale. So, what happens next?

Plaintiff (Leticia): Three days later, the check engine light comes on, and it makes a loud rattling noise. I have a video.

Judge: Let’s hear it.

Plaintiff (Leticia): (Plays video of loud rattling noise and smoke.)

Judge: Did you take it to a mechanic?

Plaintiff (Leticia): Yes, Ford said the engine has a knock and to take it back to whoever we bought it from.

Judge: What will it take to repair it?

Plaintiff (Leticia): Stephen called me on March 8th and offered $800.

Judge: Did you know of any issues with the car?

Defendant (Stephen): No, my son was driving it two months before.

Judge: How long did you own it?

Defendant (Stephen): Two years.

Judge: Why didn’t you get it checked out before buying it?

Plaintiff (Leticia): I just trusted that it was okay.

Judge: It’s an “as-is” sale. You should have had a mechanic check it out. The law protects commerce; otherwise, every used car sale could lead to lawsuits. When Ford checked it, did they say what needed to be done?

Plaintiff (Leticia): They said it needed a new engine for $1,600.

Judge: And he offered you $800. Why didn’t you take it?

Plaintiff (Leticia): I felt it wasn’t fair.

Judge: Stephen, why did you offer the $800?

Defendant (Stephen): I felt bad and wanted to compromise.

Judge: Or were you threatened?

Defendant (Stephen): I was threatened. They came to my house, told me they were leaving the car, and the mother yelled she would make my life hell. The son said, “You don’t want to do this to my mother.” I called the police.

Judge: The law is the law. I rule in favor of the defendant. Case dismissed.

dialogue:
Douglas (Plaintiff’s Representative):

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
Rosa Aona.

Douglas (Plaintiff’s Representative):
And Amir Carpets. You are the owner of Amir Carpets, yes? All right, for $585, the purchase price of a rug that he bought from you. And according to you, he didn’t sign the check, so you weren’t able to actually deposit the check.

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
Whoops. Okay, what happened?

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
First of all, we’re in the auction business. We sell on commission; we don’t own the goods. We had an auction in May of 2011, which was a real-time auction and an online auction. This rug was in an online auction at the end of May. It was available to be seen and inspected before the auction.

When was the live auction going to be?

The live auction commenced on May 21st.

So when did he buy this?

Okay, so it didn’t sell at the live auction?

That’s correct.

That’s correct. And then you kept the items online for auction bids, and he bid?

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
Correct.

Judge:
Okay.

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
He registered, left us a message, "I’m interested in buying handmade carpets." I know he’s got the rug; we know he got it. But so tell me about the circumstances where you folks accept a check that’s not signed. Is that what happened?

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
What happened is he came to pick up the rug. He was late. When he came to get the rug, he gave my administrative assistant a check. Apparently, she didn’t look at it. He took the check, which was not signed. We discovered it the next day. My assistant asked me what to do, and I said, "Please give him a call." My assistant went to put—took the check.

Judge:
That’s correct?

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
That’s right. She got fired?

Judge:
No, she didn’t.

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
Okay, go ahead.

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
She’s still with me, but her mother’s ill, and she couldn’t come today.

Judge:
Okay, so I said we’ll give him a call, which she did. He said—she asked him to send another one. He told that he would.

Judge:
You have an affidavit from her?

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
I do. Can I see it?

Judge:
Well, it’s not sworn.

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
Why wouldn’t you bring her?

Judge:
I mean, I heard what you said, but I mean, that’s not the issue.

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
Well, no, I’ll—what the issue is—

Judge:
I understand. May I please see whatever you do have that’s not sworn and not—

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
Her. This is the registration.

Judge:
Why wasn’t the check signed, sir?

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
I did turn that in when I arrived there. They were rushing me too much.

Judge:
You were late?

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
I was late. Yes, I was. You know, it was a one-and-a-half-hour drive for me. I asked directions many times.

Judge:
So how late were you?

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
I was just maybe a couple of minutes. I don’t know.

Judge:
A couple of minutes?

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
Yes.

Judge:
And according to your assistant, he’s—how—

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
Oh, it’s not even signed. Let alone sworn. It’s just a paragraph.

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
The next day, Tom showed me the unsigned check, and I called him to let him know the check was unsigned. He said he would send us a new check by mail, and that you were an hour and a half late, not a few minutes, an hour and a half.

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
No, they close at—I don’t know—5 or 6:00. I was in that town, but all right, so you get there, and what happened?

Judge:
They just had the car all wrapped up and just put it in my trunk.

Are you trying to explain why you gave them a check without inspecting the merchandise? Is that what you’re trying to say?

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
Because they were saying that it was late, and the carpet was all wrapped up and whatever. I said that the—

Judge:

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
Oh, it’s too big. Too big. I couldn’t do it myself.

Judge:
How long did it take to unwrap it in my courtroom?

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
Seven minutes.

Judge:
Okay, so why couldn’t it be unwrapped there?

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
Because it was wrapped with the plastic things, and it was tidy and convenient to just move it on down the road, doggy. That’s all. It’s because it was just like—

Judge:
Everybody’s lazy. And then all of a sudden, look at you now. You got time for all this now. Nobody had seven minutes then. But even though—

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
All right, so they didn’t tell me about all the damages that this carpet has.

Judge:
Oh, you might have seen it if you unrolled the rug, right?

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
But can I see the online auction pictures? Like, I mean, you bought the rug, okay, from the pictures that were online, right?

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
Yes.

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
And so then you bring that rug back to your place, and what is your place?

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
It’s a place that I buy rugs for myself and sell it for my home. I don’t have a store or anything.

Judge:
Yes, okay. But if you look at the back, you can see all the damages and all the—

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
I mean, in the picture, I can see this. There’s some—what is this, by the way?

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
It’s a—uh—I don’t really know. If that’s not my job, we sell these.

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
What was it advertised as?

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
It was advertised as a large-room-sized oriental carpet, Blue Field, from a Virginia collector. That’s it. That’s all it was advertised as. There wasn’t anything more.

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
No, okay.

Judge:
And how is it not what that says?

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
If you look, you can see all the patches on the carpet that they didn’t see.

Judge:
Patches on the—on the—?

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
I’m not lifting this.

Judge:
What patches on the bottom of the carpet?

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
Yes. If you—you know, you’re referring to this.

Judge:
That’s correct.

Judge:
Okay. I mean, all the—even at eBay or other places, other auctions, they disclose all the problems that the merchandise has. Can you—can you flip just—just if you flip this part? I just want to see how it looks on the other end. The receiving end of such a thing is that—

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
Here. That’s the first patch.

Judge:
Yeah. I mean, there’s—you could—I’m looking at the picture, and I can tell that there is some fading in a line right here that is sort of separate and distinct from the kind of stuff I’m looking at, which is patched and holes.

Judge:
What say you to that? Do you feel that when you advertise something, you need to say that it’s patched and that it has actual—

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
With all due respect—

Judge:
Yeah, that usually—you know what we find as judges when people start a sentence with the phrase "With all due respect," we’re about to get disrespected.

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
That’s okay.

Judge:
But I want you to come over here, though, because I do want you to see this first. I’d like to read first. I’d like you to come over here, please, if you don’t mind. I just want you to see what I’m talking about, rather than just hear what I’m talking about.

[Judge walks over to defendant]

Judge:
You see that?

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
Yes. You’re on.

Judge:
I mean, that—you know, the question is in a breach of contract case because essentially what this man is saying is that it’s a breach of contract because you advertised a rug and you don’t mention—can I—let me just get you up there a second. Come on.

Judge:
And then you, of course, can see these that it’s been patched up, where those holes are, right?

Thomas Schwanky (Plaintiff):
Yeah.

Judge:
And he feels that you folks should have to disclose if you’re selling something that’s been repaired, has a hole, and whatever else, that it’s a little less than forthright if you don’t, and that therefore it’s a breach of contract.

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
Number one, he registered in our auction, and people who register to bid in our auction are responsible for having read the terms and conditions of our sale.

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
Okay, we didn’t sell this in a store. It doesn’t come with a guarantee. All goods are sold as is, where is, with all faults, and all sales are final. All auction items are available for bidder examination. Bidding signifies that you have examined an item, either personally or through an authorized agent, or that you have elected not to examine an item. Buyer relies solely on his or her own expertise and judgment when bidding.

Judge:
Okay. As noted above, all sales—do you have an off button? Press the off button.

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
Hand it to my bay. Hand it over to me.

Judge:
Don’t—what were you going to do? Hit my bay? I do not suggest playing kis maacha with Douglas.

Judge:
What say you to this?

Rosa Aona (Defendant):
Actually, I did see that the carpet on the computer. But any place that they—they have to say the damages. Any place that you buy anything—I want to see you. You’re online right now, right?

Judge:
Like, I know. You just do it.

Judge:
Anyway. I’m done with it.

dialogue:
Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to the People's Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiffs say Drew bought a VW Jetta from the defendant that was supposedly in "Superman condition," and it was anything but. The defendant says the plaintiffs didn’t complain for months. It’s the case of "Cool Your Jetta."

Judge: Dorothy and Drew Brown, you are suing Anthony Dorch for $3,284.67 that you say he owes you for things that have gone wrong with the car you bought from him. Tell me what’s going on.

Plaintiff Drew: My son answered an ad on September 4, 2011.

Judge: Why don’t you tell me that part since it’s yours? How old are you?

Plaintiff Drew: I’m 18 now. I was 17 when I answered the ad.

Judge: Is this your first car?

Plaintiff Drew: Yeah, I just really wanted a car.

Judge: You were buying it with your money?

Plaintiff Drew: Yeah, it was my money.

Judge: How did you make the money?

Plaintiff Drew: I worked on a goat farm all summer.

Judge: Slaved on a goat farm? Sounds perfectly medieval.

Plaintiff Dorothy: He was a slave on a goat farm, and he also worked at a restaurant.

Plaintiff Drew: I found the ad on Craigslist. I was looking for a really long time for a car, and I saw this ad. It said it had a new timing belt, which was the main reason I was looking at it because that’s a huge cost. It had 156,000 miles, and I thought everything was just good with it. So I called him up that night.

Judge: What year was the car?

Plaintiff Drew: It’s a 2001.

Judge: Let me see the ad. This is the actual ad you responded to?

Plaintiff Drew: Yeah.

Judge: (Reading) "2001 Volkswagen Jetta 5-speed, black, 1.8T." What does that mean?

Plaintiff Drew: It’s a 1.8-liter engine with a turbo.

Judge: Oh, so it’s souped up?

Plaintiff Drew: It was pretty nice. Black leather, power sunroof, power everything. It said "Super Mint, new timing belt, water pump, tensioner, tune-up, clean title in hand."

Judge: So you go see the car, and you like it?

Plaintiff Drew: Yeah.

Judge: Did you take it for an inspection to your mechanic?

Plaintiff Drew: We put a down payment on the car when we went down there. We drove from New Haven that night. We took it for a test drive, and it drove really nicely. So we put down a $100 down payment.

Judge: What was the date?

Plaintiff Drew: I think it was the 8th or 9th. We went down on the 6th and drove it back to us.

Judge: So what’s the answer to my question? Did you guys have it inspected by a mechanic before buying an 11-year-old car?

Plaintiff Drew: Not before we purchased it, no.

Judge: Did you have it done afterward?

Plaintiff Drew: I did.

Judge: Oh, a post-purchase inspection. What’s the point of a post-purchase inspection? That’s like having a headache, waiting until it’s over, and then taking some aspirin.

Plaintiff Drew: You’re absolutely right. I mean, it’s my first car.

Judge: Not your first car, Mom?

Plaintiff Dorothy: No, it’s not.

Judge: This is what he relies on you for, though?

Plaintiff Dorothy: Yes, I know.

Judge: Tell me about the whole timing belt thing. Did you discuss it with him?

Plaintiff Drew: We assumed it was a new timing belt as stated in the ad.

Judge: Did he give you paperwork?

Plaintiff Drew: He said he worked at a mechanic shop and did the work himself.

Judge: So you finally took it to a mechanic after a month. What possessed you to do that?

Plaintiff Drew: I wanted to make sure everything was running right.

Judge: So a month later, you get it inspected, and someone tells you it needs $3,200 worth of work?

Plaintiff Dorothy: Yes, and there was a piece of wood wedged in to hold the timing belt tensioner.

Judge: Did they take pictures?

Plaintiff Dorothy: Yes, on a cell phone.

Judge: Let me see that.

(Judge examines the evidence, discusses repair costs, and asks Defendant for proof of work done.)

Judge: Defendant, do you have any proof the timing belt was replaced?

Defendant Anthony: No, I got it done by a neighborhood mechanic.

Judge: An alley mechanic?

Defendant Anthony: Yeah, basically.

Judge: You get what you pay for. There was a piece of wood wedged in the timing belt tensioner.

Defendant Anthony: If I knew that, I wouldn’t have driven it 66 miles.

Judge: The sale of a used car is an "as-is" sale unless stated otherwise. However, your ad said "new timing belt." You can’t advertise something that isn’t true.

(Judge rules in favor of Plaintiff for $1,122.)

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hand. Do you swear to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth?

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): Yes.

Judge: Thank you, Mr. Brenson. You’re suing Mr. McGaan for $550 for a damaged headlight and a lost factory bumper that you say happened at his hands. Tell me what’s going on.

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): Okay, let me say first, it’s a pleasure to be here. Thank you. It's a pleasure just to watch you on TV. It’s more of a pleasure just to see you.

Judge: Thank you. You feel the same way, right?

Defendant (Frank McGaan): Yes, ma’am.

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): Again, I knew Frank a long time ago, over five years, and he used to do side work for me, mechanic work. After about the last five years, Frank started getting kind of shy with his work and moving away from people. As a matter of fact, he fixed my headlight on my car, and the headlight turned white from him putting crazy glue on something—Elmer glue or whatever glue he used.

Judge: What happened to your bumper and headlight that you needed him to fix?

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): Well, I got into an accident previously, and it cracked the corner of my bumper. But it was just a crack. It was something that could be fixed. So, I hired him to replace the bumper from it. I went and bought an off-the-market bumper.

Judge: And so he replaced it?

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): Yeah, and I left him there about maybe 11:00 p.m. that night. I called him within the hour to tell him, "Yo, Frank, save my factory bumper for me." And he told me, "Hey, Doug, that’s gone already." And I’m saying, "Within an hour, you gave away my bumper without calling me?" Okay, and then the next day I come to find the light—the headlight that he put in there—my same headlight that came in my truck. It turned white, and he refused to do anything.

Judge: When did all this happen?

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): It happened at—he did the work at night. It happened in 2009.

Judge: Why did you wait three years?

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): Because he was running. He was doing so much stuff, taking people’s money, and he got out of the neighborhood. I just couldn’t find him.

Judge: How did you find him now?

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): I was at a mechanic shop. I needed some more work done, so I went out of my area where I live and went to the mechanic shop to get the work done. I was browsing around, and I looked over and I seen Frank, but he was running for a long time. So, I confronted him and asked him. It turns out he was just in the next town over, not even a mile away.

Judge: A mile away? Your car must not work a lot.

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): No, we don’t, but you don’t have to go in that area.

Judge: I understand. But it’s not exactly running. It’s not like he’s a fugitive.

Defendant (Frank McGaan): Oh, no. He was running. He was ducking. He wouldn’t get in touch with me.

Judge: How much did you pay him to do the repair?

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): I paid him $100.

Judge: And when you picked up the car, why didn’t you complain then?

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): It was at night, and I didn’t see the white.

Judge: Why didn’t you complain the next day?

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): I tried to talk to Frank numerous times about it. "Hey Frank, the headlight turned white. Can we do something about it?" He blew me off. He blew me off, then he got out of the area for years, and then what happened?

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): How did you come to sue him now?

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): I was at a mechanic shop. I needed some more work done, so I went out of my area where I live at and went to the mechanic shop to get the work done. I was browsing around, and I looked over and I seen Frank.

Defendant (Frank McGaan): First of all, I fixed his headlight about two, three years ago. He had an accident. It wasn’t crazy glue. It was glue that we used in the body shop. And I did him a favor in front of my house. It wasn’t at no shop or anything.

Judge: Did he pay you $100?

Defendant (Frank McGaan): No, I never got any money from him. Matter of fact, he still owes me for the brakes he paid me for that he didn’t pay me for.

Judge: And it’s his bumper that’s on the vehicle? The vehicle is in the parking lot?

Defendant (Frank McGaan): Yes. He brought the vehicle to the parking lot. The serial numbers on the parts will match the VIN number to the vehicle. So I want to know how that—that’s his headlight.

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): I had to bring it because the camera wouldn’t take a clear picture because you couldn’t tell.

Judge: Let’s go look at it.

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): You never put any tape on the lens.

Defendant (Frank McGaan): Wait, wait, wait. Is what they...?

Judge: I want to see the vehicle. And I never put any tape on the lens. Stay... let’s go. You got the key?

Defendant (Frank McGaan): Yes.

(They head to look at the vehicle.)

Judge: The plaintiff says the defendant screwed up his headlight repairing his car, but he waited three years to sue. Plus, if the plaintiff was so upset, why did he come back to get other repairs?

Defendant (Frank McGaan): The headlight was already like that before I put the tape on. Where’d you put the glue? If you open the hood, I’ll show you where the glue was. The brackets that hold the headlight in place were broken. He needed a new headlight, but he didn’t have money for a new headlight, so he had me repair that headlight. Did he pay you for the repair? No, he didn’t.

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): No, I did not. That’s his original headlight.

Defendant (Frank McGaan): Well, you did.

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): Where is it that you glued it?

Defendant (Frank McGaan): Behind the grill, the tabs are all the way down there. So I don’t see how any glue got on this lens.

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): Why didn’t you just use the hardware you’re supposed to use?

Defendant (Frank McGaan): Because he never supplied me any hardware.

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): Didn’t my house realize you’re an A1 mechanic?

Defendant (Frank McGaan): You brought it to my shop. I work at a very reputable shop.

Judge: Well then why didn’t you just?

Defendant (Frank McGaan): Because he didn’t have the money for that, and how much could it cost to put the hardware? He needed to buy a whole new light. It was broken.

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): I told him it was a whole new light he needed, but the headlight was my light. You want to see my light?

Defendant (Frank McGaan): Come on right now.

Judge: Wait, wait, wait. Stay... I want to see the vehicle.

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): No problem. Matter of fact, I will hold the headlight in place, and this is why you need a new headlight.

Defendant (Frank McGaan): Gentlemen, hold on.

Judge: Okay, let’s go back in.

Judge: Welcome back to the People’s Court. Harvey Levin here. Is waiting three years in a situation like this too long?

Defendant (Frank McGaan): Yes, it is.

Judge: Well, I think three years is a tough case to try to prove for something of this magnitude. Glue? I mean, three years later, most glue would probably have lost its adhesiveness by then.

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): But what about the notion that it created a milky film? Wouldn’t that have shown up three years ago?

Judge: Three years is too long. Definitely too long. I mean, anything could’ve happened. The guy could’ve messed with the lens on his own.

Defendant (Frank McGaan): That’s a good point.

Judge: And you're going to get the last word.

Defendant (Frank McGaan): He probably spilled the milk.

Judge: You spilled milk on it and that’s what happened?

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): I know that if there’s anything I know right now, it’s that you feel he did you wrong 100%.

Plaintiff (Douglas Brenson): But your feeling that he did you wrong is not as good as proof. And when you wait three years, you’ve basically lost your proof. You have nothing. You have three years of passage where a million things could have happened.

Defendant (Frank McGaan): No, no. We’re done, Mr. Brinson. We’re done.

Judge: My verdict is for the defendant. Good luck.

Judge: "Based on what it is that he makes, if we were to break it down—and you only have one child?"

Defendant: "The thirst is going both ways, ma'am."

Defendant: "I would admit I was being thirsty also."

Judge: "So 'thirst' means what?"

Defendant: "It's the fact that I knew I wasn't gonna have a long relationship with her, but when you feed somebody the lies that you know they wanna hear, that's 'thirst' to get what you want from them."

Defendant: "But yeah, now it's a baby involved, what's your thirst? And now I feel like she's being thirsty, trying to put the baby on me."

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hand. You may be seated.

Judge: Litigants have been sworn. Your honor, this is a car case, right? What's the bird doing here?

Plaintiff: The bird is a witness. She was in the car when we developed a series of issues.

Judge: The bird is a witness? Okay, I have seen it all. For real. The bird is—do you feel the bird is a wit—did you swear the bird in? Oh, raise your right wing. Did you put this one, including the bird? Oh, for the love of all that's holy! I thought I had taken the wrong case out. Okay, let's get to it, Mr. Hess.

Judge: Who is she?

Plaintiff: This is my fiancée.

Judge: Was she in the car with you?

Plaintiff: Yes, she was.

Judge: All right, tell me what happened here.

Plaintiff: Well, on February 15th, I brought my truck into Prestige Auto. It was sputtering and having problems driving.

Judge: What kind of truck is this?

Plaintiff: It's a Ford F-150, a 1991.

Judge: Oh wow, it’s in very good condition.

Plaintiff: It’s actually an art car.

Judge: Yes, it’s also old enough to vote. Okay, and—so what does sputtering mean?

Plaintiff: Sputtering means it was having fuel problems. I was pressing the gas, and it wasn’t really going.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: I brought it into Prestige Auto. I have dual fuel tanks, and I never use the front tank. I only use the rear tank, and it’s been working that way for ten years. I brought it into Prestige Auto to have them diagnose the problem and fix it.

Plaintiff: They changed the fuel filter. Then they said they wanted to do a full oil change. So I agreed to the oil change and expected the car to work. They gave it back to me the next day, and I drove it. As I'm driving to work on the West Side Highway, it breaks down again.

Plaintiff: So I had them tow it back. Then they said it wasn’t the fuel filter or the fuel lines—it was the fuel pump.

Judge: Well, did they say that, or did they say, “Now your fuel pump went”?

Plaintiff: No, they said it was a fuel pump problem. They never mentioned that anything was wrong with it before the first time I brought it in.

Judge: Did you say to them, “Well, I don’t want to pay extra,” or did you pay that second time?

Plaintiff: I paid both times.

Judge: Right. Okay. So the first time you went in there, what was the repair? What did they do?

Defendant: The first time he came in, he asked us to just replace the fuel filter, do an oil change, and replace the neck for the tank that was not working. Those were his notes.

Judge: Can I see the evidence that he’s telling you how to fix it instead of you telling him what needs doing? Isn’t that customary for you to tell the customer?

Defendant: He just wrote notes when he came in. He said he wanted an oil change, to see if we could fix the tank that was not working.

Judge: What tank was not working?

Defendant: The front one.

Judge: But he doesn’t even use the front.

Defendant: Yes, but he asked us to see if we could put it to work again.

Judge: Did you see if you could put it to work again?

Defendant: We couldn’t because the car is older; most of the parts—

Judge: So what did you charge him for that first time?

Defendant: A fuel filter and an oil change. That’s it.

Judge: Okay. Then he comes back the second time and says what?

Defendant: The second time, he was towed in.

Judge: How long after?

Defendant: Two days later.

Judge: So it was towed in, and what does he say?

Defendant: We checked the car; there was no fuel pressure. We diagnosed that the fuel pump wasn’t working. We called him and told him he needed a fuel pump, and we put it in.

Judge: And then was the car working?

Defendant: The car was working fine, yes.

Judge: How do you test a car to make sure it’s working fine before calling the customer?

Defendant: First, we leave it on the lift to make sure there are no leaks while it’s running. Then we leave it outside for a little bit and take it for a test drive.

Judge: So you pick up the car. How long does the repair last you that second time?

Plaintiff: It lasted until I drove home to pick up my tools, then picked up my fiancée and the birds, and we started driving again. On the Grand Central Parkway, people were screaming at us that something was wrong with our car. We smelled gas. We pulled over, and gas was gushing out of the bottom of our truck.

Judge: Gushing?

Plaintiff: Gushing. We called Prestige Auto, and they said they couldn’t do anything until the morning.

Judge: Did you take it to another mechanic?

Plaintiff: Yes, we did.

Judge: Do you have anything in writing from that mechanic?

Plaintiff: Yes, I do.

Judge: Did that mechanic say Prestige did something wrong?

Plaintiff: Yes, they said the problem was a rubber grommet on the front fuel tank, and they also found a faulty relay valve switch. Prestige should have checked these.

Judge: There’s no evidence that the defendant failed to install a fuel pump correctly or predict another issue with a 20-year-old car. My ruling is for the defendan

Judge: This is the plaintiff, Octavia Fields. She says the defendant allowed her to store her two large-screen TVs at one of his houses, and when she went to retrieve them, he told her they had been stolen.

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): Stolen? Really?

Judge: She thinks it was an inside job because nothing else was taken, and she’s suing the defendant for $1,971.

[Music playing]

Judge: This is the defendant, Henry Clark. He says the plaintiff, in her heart of hearts, thinks his tenant stole her TVs, but that’s simply not the case. He went out of his way to help the plaintiff because she was down on her luck, and now all he has to show for his kindness is this lawsuit. Turns out it’s true—no good deed goes unpunished.

[Music playing]

Bailiff: All parties, please raise your right hands.

Judge: Welcome back to The People’s Court. The plaintiff says the defendant let her store two big-screen TVs at his house. He said they were stolen, and she’s not buying it. But the defendant says he was doing a good deed, and now she’s being ungrateful. This is the case of "Big Screen, Big Problem."

Judge: Okay, Octavia Fields, you are suing Henry Clark for two TVs that you say were stolen from his house, a house that you never actually ended up moving into.

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): Yes.

Judge: House, not an apartment?

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): House.

Judge: Okay, tell me what happened.

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): In May 2011, I was looking to move back to New York from Pennsylvania. I found a house on Craigslist that Mr. Clark was renting—a three-bedroom. I liked the house, but the rooms wouldn’t accommodate my bedroom set. I explained that to him, and he told me he had another residence around the corner in the same area, also three bedrooms, but someone was living there at the time.

Judge: So what did you agree on?

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): We agreed that I would wait for the other tenants to move out and then take that house.

Judge: Who were you moving in with?

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): My 12-year-old son and my 3-year-old niece, who I have custody of.

Judge: You were being assisted by Section 8, correct?

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): Yes.

Judge: You saw the house in May?

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): Yes.

Judge: And then again in June?

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): Yes.

Judge: What happened in June?

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): We did the inspection, and Section 8 found a couple of issues that needed fixing.

Judge: A list of 22 items they wanted fixed?

Defendant (Henry Clark): 13, actually.

Judge: Okay, and then?

Defendant (Henry Clark): We tried to comply with the list, but it took time. She brought her stuff in because she was upset and had nowhere else to turn. She said she didn’t have money for storage, so I told her, “Go ahead, put it in. I’ll help you out.”

Judge: What did she store?

Defendant (Henry Clark): A 55-inch, $1,500 brand-new TV, plus a whole houseful of contents. I let her put most of it in the garage and one bedroom.

Judge: Are you new at this?

Defendant (Henry Clark): No, I’ve been doing this a long time. I was trying to be nice.

Judge: So by August, she says she found another house.

Defendant (Henry Clark): Correct.

Judge: When did she inform you?

Defendant (Henry Clark): Middle to late August.

Judge: Did you tell her to take her stuff out?

Defendant (Henry Clark): Yes, I told her to have it out by September 1st.

Judge: Did she get it out by September 1st?

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): No.

Judge: September 2nd? 3rd? 4th? 5th?

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): No.

Judge: When did the theft happen?

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): October 2nd.

Judge: Two months after he told you to get your stuff out?

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): Yes.

Judge: And what happened during that time?

Defendant (Henry Clark): I kept trying to contact her.

Judge: You have text messages showing this?

Defendant (Henry Clark): Yes.

Judge: October 11th: She messages, “I’m still trying to get money to move my things into storage.” Where were you living at the time?

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): I was bouncing from house to house with my two kids.

Judge: Okay, so you weren’t working?

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): No.

Judge: So, you left your things there for free?

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): Yes.

Judge: And in that time, what happened?

Defendant (Henry Clark): October 26th, the TVs were stolen.

Judge: What do you know about that incident?

Defendant (Henry Clark): My witness, Robert Cruz, was staying in the house.

Judge: Mr. Cruz, what happened?

Witness (Robert Cruz): I was staying there to watch the house until it was rented. One day, I came back, and the TVs were gone.

Judge: Were the doors locked?

Witness (Robert Cruz): Yes, but no signs of forced entry.

Judge: Do you think it was an inside job?

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): Yes, because nothing else was taken.

Judge: Mr. Clark, did you have any involvement in the theft?

Defendant (Henry Clark): No, absolutely not.

Judge: Here’s the issue: You left your things in a house you weren’t renting for two months after you were told to remove them. Mr. Clark did you a favor, and you took advantage of that.

Plaintiff (Octavia Fields): But my TVs—

Judge: It’s unfortunate, but legally, Mr. Clark had no obligation to continue storing your items indefinitely. This case is dismissed.

Judge: Tony Ash Maui, you are suing Oliver for $5,000 in damages to a side lamp, lamp post, wall, front stairs, railing, bricks, and foundation after what appears to have been a wild party. Is that correct?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: The party was at your house?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Were you aware of the party happening?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: You’re the son?

Plaintiff’s Son: Yes.

Judge: Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff’s Son: I had a few friends over on New Year’s Eve. We were watching the ball drop and just hanging out.

Judge: How many friends?

Plaintiff’s Son: About ten.

Judge: Were they friends and girlfriends?

Plaintiff’s Son: Yes. Then he and his buddies came over.

Judge: Were they invited?

Plaintiff’s Son: No.

Judge: So they came in uninvited?

Plaintiff’s Son: Yes, and they were very intoxicated. I talked to him.

Judge: You know him?

Plaintiff’s Son: Yes, from high school wrestling.

Judge: Were you friends?

Plaintiff’s Son: Yes.

Judge: So you see him inside your house, and then what?

Plaintiff’s Son: He came with three others.

Judge: Did you know them?

Plaintiff’s Son: I knew of them but didn’t really know them.

Judge: Did you ask them to leave?

Plaintiff’s Son: I confronted them and told them they were intoxicated. I didn’t want any trouble because one of them had issues with one of my friends who was there.

Judge: And then?

Plaintiff’s Son: One of them, Brendan, hit my friend in the face.

Judge: Who is Brendan?

Plaintiff’s Son: One of Oliver’s friends.

Judge: What happened next?

Plaintiff’s Son: The other three, including Oliver, jumped in and started fighting.

Judge: Fighting whom?

Plaintiff’s Son: Everyone in the mix—my friends.

Judge: How many people from your side got involved?

Plaintiff’s Son: About five.

Judge: And on Oliver’s side?

Plaintiff’s Son: Four.

Judge: And this was all happening in your kitchen?

Plaintiff’s Son: Yes, right by my stairs.

Judge: Where were you, Dad?

Plaintiff: I was at another New Year’s party and didn’t know anything until the next morning.

Judge: Did you know he was having people over?

Plaintiff: Yes, he told me, and it sounded fine.

Judge: When did you get the call?

Plaintiff: At 10:30 the next morning.

Judge: From whom?

Plaintiff: My son.

Judge: What did he say?

Plaintiff: He said he was at Home Depot picking up supplies for minor repairs.

Judge: How many stitches did you get on your head?

Plaintiff’s Son: Seven.

Judge: When did that come into the conversation?

Plaintiff: When I got home, he told me he might need to go to the ER. I looked at his head, and he was covered in blood. So I took him to urgent care right away.

Judge: When did you call the police?

Plaintiff: A girl at the party called the cops during the fight.

Judge: Did the police arrive before or after the fight ended?

Plaintiff’s Son: They arrived as we were getting them out of the house.

Judge: Did they arrest anyone?

Plaintiff’s Son: No, they just removed them.

Judge: What happened after the police left?

Plaintiff’s Son: Someone saw them outside again, grabbing the railing and breaking it.

Judge: Did you record them breaking it?

Plaintiff’s Son: No.

Judge: Oliver, what happened?

Defendant: I was invited.

Judge: Can you prove that?

Defendant: Yes, I have a text message.

Judge: Let me see.

Defendant: On December 29th, I asked him what he was doing. On December 31st, he replied, "Only like 20 peeps here. More than welcome."

Judge: But you originally said they weren’t invited.

Plaintiff’s Son: I didn’t invite his other friends.

Judge: What about this text message where you mention a racial slur?

Defendant: That wasn’t meant to be read.

Judge: I read what you don’t want me to read because that tells me what really happened. You apologized and offered to help fix things. So you felt bad?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: But you and your friends came back after the police left?

Defendant: No, I only came back to get my phone.

Judge: So the police escorted you off, and you returned?

Defendant: Yes, just to get my phone.

Judge: So when did the railing get broken?

Defendant: The first time we left, we got pushed off the railing.

Judge: You are contradicting yourself. Did you come back to cause trouble?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Why shouldn’t you have to pay?

Defendant: A fight broke out. It wasn’t all my fault.

Judge: But you acknowledge damages happened?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Let’s look at the damage. (Shows photos) What happened to the door?

Plaintiff’s Son: A body was slammed into it.

Judge: And the railing?

Plaintiff’s Son: It flipped over.

Judge: And the table?

Plaintiff’s Son: That’s the one that hit me on the head.

Judge: You got estimates?

Plaintiff: Yes. The defendant and his stepdad initially said they’d help fix it, but nothing happened for weeks.

Judge: Why didn’t you fix it?

Defendant: I couldn’t get the others to pitch in.

Judge: What’s your plan now?

Plaintiff: I’m suing all four of them separately.

Judge: Why separately?

Plaintiff: It’s easier in small claims court, and I need money to fix my house.

Judge: Your estimates are excessive. The pathway doesn’t need to be redone. I’m going to order the defendant to pay $2,000. That’s my verdict.
