dialogue:
Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket, the plaintiff says the defendant was a provocateur who slammed into her Nissan Maxima. But the defendant says the plaintiff was being overly aggressive because she felt the defendant was simply driving too slow. It’s the case of grody to the maximum. Thank you, Douglas. Delina Claxton?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: You are suing Andrew Taylor for $2,781.91 in damages to your car in a car accident you had with him that you say was his fault, correct?

Plaintiff: Yes, sir.

Judge: What happened? Come on over here to the board and explain it to me. Pick a car, any car.

Plaintiff: Okay, I’m coming up.

Judge: Lexington—no, this is the defendant’s car. Okay, so you’ll be the blue car.

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Now, there are two lanes on Lexington going in one direction?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Okay, so let’s see what’s going on. Go ahead.

Plaintiff: So I got up here, and we were both at the stop sign to see if any traffic was coming from Grand Avenue. There wasn’t, because there was a stop sign. So I proceeded. He said something to me, and I didn’t pay much attention because I was on my way.

Judge: Wait, wait. What did he say to you?

Plaintiff: I really don’t know.

Judge: Had there been a problem? Was there an issue before that between you two?

Plaintiff: Well, not really. He was coming up the block in front of me, and there were people behind the block behind me honking their horns. So I honked my horn as well.

Judge: Ah, okay, so the plot thickens. As you’re driving down Lexington, you’re beeping the horn at him because what? He’s going too slowly?

Plaintiff: Yes. He was with his girlfriend, and they were chatting and taking their time.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: So the person behind me honked their horn, thinking that I was slowing up the traffic. So I honked my horn at him because he was going so slow. When there was any chance for me to pass, I passed him because I knew I—

Judge: So now you’re both at the stop sign. He says something to you, which is probably not nice, but you don’t know what it is?

Plaintiff: I didn’t know what it was.

Judge: And then?

Plaintiff: I waited to see if any traffic was coming. I started to make my turn. When I made my turn here, he came behind, made his turn, and smacked me right here.

Judge: So you hit the front of his car or the back of his car?

Plaintiff: The back of his car.

Judge: Is Grand Avenue one way also?

Plaintiff: Yes, it’s a one-way also.

Judge: Come back to the lectern. Let me hear your version. Come on over.

Defendant: Do you want my whole story?

Judge: Yes, I want your whole story. Start from when you were born.

Defendant: First of all, Lexington is a one-lane street. It’s broad, but there’s no marking down the middle.

Judge: Were cars beeping at you? Agitated cars?

Defendant: The plaintiff was beeping at me.

Judge: Was there another car behind her?

Defendant: I don’t remember. I don’t think so.

Judge: Was there somebody else who passed you angrily?

Defendant: There was someone who turned at the previous intersection.

Judge: Did that person seem frustrated?

Defendant: They seemed like they were in a rush.

Judge: Okay, so what happens?

Defendant: Once we were up at the stop sign, I pulled up first. Ms. Claxton passed me in empty parking spaces and pulled up right after me. I drive a 15-passenger van, and from where she was, she couldn’t see if there was any traffic coming. I stopped at the intersection first. I don’t recall shouting anything out the window.

Judge: Did you say anything?

Defendant: I don’t believe I did.

Judge: Did he say anything?

Plaintiff: The windows were up.

Judge: But sometimes you can say something without making your words heard.

Defendant: I think we were like, “What?” because she was trying to pass in parking spaces.

Judge: Okay, so go on.

Defendant: I pulled up to the stop sign first. I looked to my right and saw that there were no cars coming. I made as wide a turn as I possibly could—again, I’m in a large vehicle. I turned, I was about 80% complete with my turn, and at that point, Ms. Claxton attempted to squeeze between a parked car and me. She couldn’t make it and ended up driving into the left rear wheel well of my car.

Judge: Who has pictures? You want to step back? Okay. Let me ask you a question: after you hit each other, what does everybody say?

Defendant: I got out and attempted to exchange information.

Judge: What’s the first thing you say to each other?

Defendant: I said, "Don’t say anything. Let’s exchange information, call the police, and that’s it."

Plaintiff: He wasn’t doing anything! He didn’t even call the cops!

Judge: I find the accident was your fault. I find in favor of the defendant.

Plaintiff: Ridiculous!

Judge: Case dismissed.

Judge: You know what? You want to be a sailor, fine. Go be a sailor in your private life, but don't be a sailor in my court or in my cases again. I don't judge people with sailor language because I use a little sailor language, but only in my private life. Not in my courtroom. Not to a litigant. Not to an attorney. I don't do that because that's not professional. And ma'am, I warn you, one of these days the state bar is going to catch up to that because if you read the rules, there is an ethical rule about fairness to opposing counsel.
 Defendant: I know that there are also rules about treating people equally without regard to race, ethnicity, or gender. I find it highly objectionable that anyone complains about my language because I know all kinds of male attorneys who have no problem picking up the phone and screaming cuss words at me. So if I am outside there where my First Amendment rights are in full effect, I will say what I choose to say, when I choose to say, and that is my right in this country.

Judge: Are you done?

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People’s Court. The plaintiff says the defendant T-boned her car at a high rate of speed and may have been drunk. The defendant says her car got it way worse. It’s the case of "I got some tea for you." Thank you, Douglas. Okay, Carrie Boylan, you are suing Desiree McGee for $4,885.51 that you say you are out after an accident that she had with your— is this your son?

Plaintiff: Yes, he was driving the car.

Judge: Come front and center. I don’t know why you’re sitting down. Okay, you weren’t in the car?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: What happened?

Plaintiff’s Son: I was driving one of our friends home, and I was going past the side street. I had the right of way. I had no stop sign. She came out, she hit me pretty decent, put a hole in my door. I called my mom first, and she said the cops were on the way already.

Judge: When you say a hole in your door, what do you mean? Is there a picture?

Plaintiff: Yeah, these are all the pictures.

Judge: Were you hurt?

Plaintiff’s Son: No, I went to the hospital for tightness, a back problem, and they said it was just tight muscles.

Judge: Did you hear screeching of brakes or anything?

Plaintiff’s Son: Nope. I didn’t know somebody was actually going to hit me until somebody said, "Oh! Oh!" Yeah.

Judge: What happened?

Defendant: I was driving. I had my phone on one of those clips on the dashboard, and it fell underneath my foot.

Judge: Why was it on a clip on the dashboard?

Defendant: Like, I use it for my GPS and stuff, so I don’t touch it. Like, it doesn’t roam around, but it fell down, and it fell underneath my foot, under the pedal. So, I took my foot off the gas and slowed down to try to grab it. When I looked up, there was a stop sign. I did stop, and we did hit each other.

Judge: It’s not the best time to go grab your phone.

Defendant: Well, if I were to try to, you know, hit the pedal and it was underneath the pedal, I wouldn’t have been able to stop anyway. You know what I mean? Like, if a water bottle had fallen underneath your car, like, your pedal—

Judge: That wouldn’t happen to me.

Defendant: Well—

Judge: You know why it wouldn’t happen to me? Because the phone wouldn’t be that important for me to continue to drive and not look at what’s happening when I’m about to approach a stop sign. You T-boned somebody because your attention was diverted to go pick up the phone you dropped. So it became his problem. You didn’t just crash into a tree and make it only your problem. You made it his problem by crashing into him. That’s if that’s what was happening, as opposed to that you were texting.

Defendant: No.

Judge: No? So, if you grab your phone as you’re driving and you get in an accident, are you automatically responsible for that accident?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Because? There’s a word for it. What’s the word for it?

Defendant: Be responsible?

Judge: No. What’s the word for it? You are a blank driver.

Defendant: Drunk?

Judge: No.

Defendant: Reckless?

Judge: No. Distracted. Really good.

Judge: Were you hurt?

Defendant: No, I was not hurt.

Judge: Okay, you’re very lucky nobody was killed. Now, insurance pays off the car. You are upside down on the car, right? Which is what happens when you finance a car. So, you’re asking that she— after the insurance has already paid you— her insurance has already paid you the value of the car, correct?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: That’s what you’re entitled to in a court of law. And if it turns out that you owe more than what the value is, that’s just too bad for you. You’re suing so that she has to pay not just the value of what she damaged but also $2,750 because you don’t want to have to put a down payment on a new car.

Plaintiff: Yeah. I had four years left on my loan. I wasn’t looking for a new car.

Judge: Yeah, I know, but you also didn’t have to pay off four years of a loan. The damage was paid off by the insurance company by paying off the car. So, you can’t then say, "Oh, by the way, buy me a new car too." No, that’s not how it works.

Judge: The next thing you’re suing for is lost wages for three days of work. Tell me about that.

Plaintiff: I had to take time off from work to take him to the doctor’s, physical therapy, and to come here today.

Judge: Do you have proof of your wages?

Plaintiff: His pay stub.

Judge: Did the police come to the site?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Anybody get arrested? Nothing like that, right?

Plaintiff: Nope.

Judge: You think she was driving drunk?

Plaintiff: She seemed out of sorts.

Judge: Maybe because it was an accident? Did the officer suspect anything?

Plaintiff: I told the officer. He said he didn’t suspect anything and just left it at that.

Judge: Verdict for the defendant. You need to watch what you’re doing. It’s never that important. I know you think you’re that important, but you’re not.

Judge: Mr. Anderson, you’ve admitted to lying about the affair. What do you have to say now?

Defendant: I made a mistake, okay? But now it’s like everyone’s turning on me. I’m not the only one to blame here. I didn’t mean for this to happen! I’m just trying to get through it, okay? Oh, my God. My whole life—my marriage, my kids—is falling apart because of you. And now you sit here acting like you’re the one who’s hurt? It’s just... it’s a lot for me too.

Plaintiff: You’re the one who messed up! You don’t get to play the victim here! You lied, you cheated, and now we might have another baby because of you!

Judge: Mr. Anderson, it’s time to take responsibility for your actions. You’ve hurt everyone involved.

Judge: You have assets that are worth in excess of $200,000 and you don't want to give this woman anything for your son.
Defendant: I'll give her something.
Judge: Excuse me? You'll give her something?
Defendant: Yes.
Judge: No, I'm gonna make sure that you give it to her on a consistent basis.
Defendant: I'm a caseworker, okay? I make very little money, you know. I don't get very many cases.
Judge: Sir, I'm a caseworker. I deal with this all the time, okay. How much do you make as a caseworker?
Defendant: This is so unfair.
Judge: No, what's not fair is the fact that you have not given her any money and you have assets worth $200,000 and you work an everyday job. How much money are you making on your job every day?
Defendant: 40, 50.
Judge: 40-50 thousand? You know what sir, that is a lot of money for you to not pay child support.

Judge: "You said you believe an extra $100 a week is fair for an increase in spousal support?"

Plaintiff: "Yes."

Judge: "Why do you believe that's fair?"

Plaintiff: "Well, like I said, uh, my wages have went down. I'm working part-time now, we're doing layoffs and things like that. My wages are going down, and his are going up because he still gets those two raises every year. He's been with that company forever, and uh, he makes good money. Uh, I don't make half of what he's making, and it's been really tough. I raised his children, I entertained his friends, I kept the house clean, I did everything that a good wife does. I think I deserve that extra $100 a week, and he can certainly afford that."

**Judge:** Ms. Rachel Miles, you are suing Mr. Levi Gaston for $1,643.54 in damages to your car. You say the damage occurred when roofing material from his home fell upon it. Is that correct?

**Plaintiff:** Correct.

**Judge:** What happened?

**Plaintiff:** Well, your honor, on December 16th, 2011, I went out to my car—I was on my way to work—and there was some debris on my back trunk.

**Judge:** What kind of car?

**Plaintiff:** A 2002 Dodge Neon.

**Plaintiff:** I took the debris off and put some of it in the front yard. Then, I proceeded to work.

**Judge:** What did you think when you saw it? Did you know where it had come from?

**Plaintiff:** Oh, yes. Yes.

**Judge:** How did you know?

**Plaintiff:** Because we had some debris in our driveway before from his roofing.

**Judge:** When did you have debris in your driveway before from his roofing?

**Plaintiff:** I don’t know the exact date, but when it gets real windy outside—

**Judge:** Have you ever brought it to his attention?

**Plaintiff:** No.

**Judge:** How come? But when it gets real windy, that implies it’s happened more than once before. I’m curious, because you never mentioned that in your complaint.

**Plaintiff:** No, I didn’t.

**Judge:** You’d think you’d mention it, right? Especially to him, if it happened multiple times before—that he needs to do something about his roof. You’re not just trying to make your case better, are you?

**Plaintiff:** No, ma’am, I’m not.

**Judge:** How often has that happened before?

**Plaintiff:** About three other times.

**Judge:** Three other times during the course of how long a time?

**Plaintiff:** A couple of years or more.

**Plaintiff:** Also, the debris that was in the driveway before—it also damaged my landlord’s automobile, and she lives upstairs from me. And Mr. Gaston knows about that.

**Judge:** Oh? Tell me about that, Mr. Gaston. Do you?

**Defendant:** Yes, I agree with her.

**Judge:** You do?

**Defendant:** Okay.

**Judge:** All right. Good, because I was getting nervous that maybe you were trying to make your case better.

**Defendant:** To be honest, ma’am, I think that was four years ago.

**Plaintiff:** Once I got to work, it was daylight.

**Judge:** Had there been high winds the day before?

**Plaintiff:** Yes.

**Plaintiff:** Once I got to work and it was daylight, I noticed a lot of scratches on the car. When I got out of work, I went over to Mr. Gaston’s residence, but he wasn’t there. His son was there. I wrote down my number and asked his son to tell him to call me. I never heard from Mr. Gaston at all.

**Judge:** When was this?

**Plaintiff:** January 23rd, 2012.

**Judge:** Did you ever make contact with him and talk to him?

**Plaintiff:** That was on the 23rd.

**Judge:** When you did talk to him, what did you two talk about?

**Plaintiff:** Once he heard the estimate—the first estimate—he didn’t want to hear the second estimate. He just said, "I’m not paying it. That’s an act of God."

**Plaintiff:** The debris I put in the front yard—I would think Mr. Gaston did pick that up. Wouldn’t he think, "Hey, it’s time for me to get my roof fixed?" But he didn’t.

**Judge:** What’s going on with your roof, Mr. Gaston?

**Defendant:** I agree with everything she says, except that I went to see my son—haven’t been home in years—I don’t know who she spoke to, but I didn’t get the message.

**Defendant:** I did go around to the house because I rent the house and go there every week, twice a week, to check on it.

**Defendant:** I have a couple of roof issues.

**Judge:** Is this his roof?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, that’s his roof.

**Defendant:** I told her, "Let’s get an estimate for the car, then we’ll see." When she came up with $1,600, I said, "Gee, I got my whole car painted for $1,600."

**Judge:** But apparently, lots of pieces of roof come off your house.

**Judge:** Your roof is supposed to withstand normal weather conditions.

**Judge:** What I’m going to do—I’m ordering you to pay the cheaper estimate, which is $1,335. Verdict for the plaintiff.

**Defendant:** But—

**Judge:** No. We’re done.

Judge:
Okay, John Mitchell, you are suing Michelle Fay for $2,644.49, the cost to repair your Ford Ranger, your 2000 Ford Ranger, because she crashed into you. Tell me what happened. We have a board here. Maybe you could show me on the board.

Plaintiff (John Mitchell):
Can I? Yes, please.
Okay, this truck, this boat, was—I was behind this, my truck. Okay, I was behind here. I had my turn signal on because I saw other trucks coming this way, leaving the ferry. So, this truck started merging into the right lane here. Uh-huh, it went over there. Okay, so I had my turn signal. I was going to go over there anyway because I wanted to go around him, right? So, as he got over here, now I got over here behind him. She came up behind me, okay? After we were going down the road, she came around me and got right there and started gesturing to me. I don’t know what she was saying. She just started gesturing, and all of a sudden, I looked back, and looking on the back of my truck, I thought somebody blew off like a bucket or a rag, you know, stuff from fishing, but I had everything pretty secure. All of a sudden, she bam, ran into me right there, and I slid down this hill, was gone. So, I hit the BR, I didn’t know, I was in shock, it just shocked me. So, as I was in shock, she, my friend, she rolled down the window, and I said, “You just hit me.” She said, “No, you just hit me,” and fled, and yeah, took off, fled. I tried to catch her, she was on the phone with 911. 911 told me to stop chasing them. So, I’m all shook up now. I’m mad, and I’m furious. So, I pull over on the side of the road, and after we get out and look at the damage of the truck, my back in my truck, B, so I bent the back out as much as I could, but by that time, a lady pulled up behind me in a Mustang and asked me, “Well, are we all right?” She witnessed the whole thing, really. She was more shook up than we were, okay? And she stood there for about 20 minutes waiting on the police. I had to call them three times for them to get out there to the scene, and when they got out there, she had given her name and number, who had the—the witness. Okay, she gave him her name and number. Thank God she did. She got a tag number. She did, she did. ‘Cause I was trying to catch up with her to get her tag number. 911 already told me to stop chasing, right? It’s probably good advice to stop. You don’t want to—oh wait, we could have caused another accident. Alright, so you speak to the police, and is there a police report?

Plaintiff (John Mitchell):
Yes, ma’am. I ended up getting that Monday. I had the other one, but it didn’t give me full detail, but that one did. Is this the friend who was in the car?

Judge:
Yes.

Plaintiff's Friend:
Come on up.

Judge:
What happened?

Plaintiff's Friend:
Well, she, we was going down the road like he said, and so then she came up to the side of the truck and wanted me to roll the window down.

Judge:
So what, you’re traveling at what speed?

Plaintiff's Friend:
About 40-45 miles.

Judge:
Roll down the window and chit-chat?

Plaintiff's Friend:
Yeah.

Plaintiff:
Okay.

Judge:
So you’re just going to ignore it?

Plaintiff's Friend:
Okay, so we kept on going. So after a while, she just, what’s—after a while, how much? A minute or two?

Plaintiff's Friend:
She just plowed into us on purpose.

Judge:
A minute or two is 120 seconds, was it that long?

Plaintiff's Friend:
It didn’t take that long. I just said a minute or two, but she hit us on purpose.

Judge:
On purpose?

Plaintiff's Friend:
Yeah, and then so after she hit us, we stopped, and then she said, “I bet you’ll let that—I bet you’ll let it down now,” and she took off.

Judge:
How? Wait, she said what?

Plaintiff's Friend:
Stop. She said, “I bet you’ll let that window down now,” and that’s when she told him that he hit her.

Plaintiff:
Okay.

Plaintiff's Friend:
And he said, “No, you hit me,” and then she just took off.

Judge:
What happened? Can I show you?

Plaintiff's Friend:
Yeah, come on up. Okay, since he’s using this as his truck, I don’t know about who was in front of him. We’re like way back here, I guess this is the road that’s supposed to be coming out of Blunt Island. Okay, so the two of you were not on a feeder lane going into that road? It becomes—extra drive turns into where Blunt Island merges into hex drive. I don’t know what they’re called. I just want to know if you had been on the road for a while, or if you were on a feeder road.

Plaintiff's Friend:
We had been on Hextra Drive for a minute, me and this gentleman.

Judge:
Okay.

Plaintiff's Friend:
Okay, but where everything happened was around the Blunt Island terminal. So, he’s in this lane. I’m in this lane. I immediately get over.

Judge:
Why are you getting over?

Plaintiff's Friend:
Because it’s the normal thing I do when I drive down that road coming from the beach. We go there all the time.

Judge:
No, but why are you getting into the left lane?

Plaintiff's Friend:
In order to achieve what?

Plaintiff's Friend:
To be able to pass, just to be able to go and pass all the craziness in that one lane.

Judge:
Okay, and just prior to this accident, which is probably his witness, um, was a Mustang that had been following me speeding, and I had to get her off of my rear end.

Judge:
And how did you get her off of your rear end?

Plaintiff's Friend:
I had to pass somebody to get her off my rear end, ‘cause she was just staying on my rear end, and she didn’t have enough space to get in, go around both of the vehicles that were in front of her, me and another vehicle. So I had already gotten around her. Then we get to this point where he’s at, where we’re at.

Judge:
Who’s in the car with you?

Plaintiff's Friend:
My daughters, both of my daughters, and my cousin from South Dakota.

Judge:
How old are your daughters?

Plaintiff's Friend:
My youngest one is 13, and she has autism. My oldest one is 15, and my cousin is 22.

Judge:
Okay. But, um, needless to say, I was already committed to this lane. This gentleman started coming over. There was no turn signal on the back of his truck indicating that’s what he was doing. I started blaring on my horn to try to make him aware that he was coming into my lane and about hit me.

Judge:
Okay.

Plaintiff's Friend:
He just kept coming. He ignored it like he didn’t hear it. I don’t know if he’s deaf or what—partially deaf, but I was laying on my horn. I had to slam on brakes and swerve to keep from hitting him.

Judge:
Okay, so that’s why.

Plaintiff's Friend:
Now, put him in front of me. Now he’s in front of me, got it.

Plaintiff's Friend:
And I pull up beside him. But this is where I’m at at this point—after this situation. After I realized I got over here to catch up, just back up, okay, as that happened, my horn was hitting there and it seemed...      Plaintiff's Friend:
...hitting there and it seemed like he wasn't responding. After this, I realized, okay, he finally got behind me.

Judge:
Okay, so now you’re behind him. What happens next?

Plaintiff's Friend:
So, now we're behind him, and I saw him weaving in and out of the lane. He was kind of swerving, and I was thinking, "What in the world is he doing?" Then, out of nowhere, he slams on his brakes. I had to stop suddenly, and that’s when I thought we were going to hit him. But we avoided that collision. But as we continued down the road, that's when she came around me, gestured, and then hit us.

Judge:
So, you’re saying the defendant's actions were reckless and dangerous, right?

Plaintiff's Friend:
Absolutely, your Honor. It felt like she was purposely trying to cause a situation. We weren’t doing anything to provoke her.

Judge:

Plaintiff's Friend:

Plaintiff:
Yeah, I was mad. I was already trying to get her tag number, but she was speeding off. I had no choice but to stop, and luckily, the witness showed up and gave us her information, which helped us track down her car.

Judge:
So, let me make sure I understand. You were behind her, she was driving recklessly, weaving in and out, and then suddenly hit you. After that, she took off, but a witness was able to provide useful details about the incident. Is that right?

Plaintiff:
Yes, exactly.

Judge:
Alright, Michelle Fay, you’re being accused of crashing into the plaintiff’s vehicle, leaving the scene of the accident, and causing significant damage. What do you have to say about this?

Defendant (Michelle Fay):
Well, Your Honor, that’s not exactly what happened. Yes, there was a situation on the road, but I wasn’t trying to hit anyone. In fact, I was trying to avoid getting into an accident myself. Judge:

Defendant (Michelle Fay):

Judge:

Defendant (Michelle Fay):

Judge:
I see. So you’re claiming it was all out of fear and not intentional. What do you say about the witness’s testimony? She’s confirmed the incident and provided the police with your tag number.

Defendant (Michelle Fay):
I can’t speak to what the witness saw, but I know I wasn’t trying to hurt anyone. I’ve been driving for a long time, and this was just a very unfortunate situation. I am sorry it happened, but I don’t think I should be held fully responsible for all the damages.

Judge:
Alright, we’ll consider everything and look at the evidence.

Judge: All parties, please rise. Be seated. Come to order, please. Litigants have been sworn, your honor.

Judge: Thank you. Daniel Petron?

Plaintiff: Yes, your honor.

Judge: How do you pronounce it? The way I did?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Very good. All right. You are suing Connor Lucas for $3,500 that you say you loaned to him and he has refused to repay. Now, my understanding is that you were dating Mr. Lucas’s girlfriend’s mom?

Plaintiff: Not dating, your honor. No, just a friend. She helped me out about five years ago.

Judge: Okay. How? Financially or some other way?

Plaintiff: No, no, I was very sick, and she helped take care of me sometimes.

Judge: Okay. Um, who are you?

Defendant’s Girlfriend: I’m his girlfriend, and my mom—

Judge: This is your mom? I—you know, I wasn’t sure. And how old are you?

Defendant’s Girlfriend: 21.

Judge: How old are you?

Defendant: 20.

Judge: Lord above. All right. So what happens?

Plaintiff: The mother calls me and says to me that they tried to get some money to help get a second car for Connor’s girlfriend, Mary. So I said okay. They couldn't get the funds from somewhere else, so she asked if I could help. I said, “All right, let me talk to your daughter. Let me feel her out a little bit and let me see what’s going on.”

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: So she called me, we talked on the phone. I said, “How much do you need to get a second car and everything?” And she says, “Probably about $4,000.” And I went, “Oh, okay. I didn’t expect that.” But I said, “Let me see what I can do.” See, the difference between you and me is if I had a 20-year-old telling me, who I’d never met—did you know her, or you didn’t know her?

Judge: Did you know her?

Plaintiff: I knew her just for a little bit.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: So if a 20-year-old I barely knew asked me for $4,000 for a car, I’d be like, um, no. I’ve gotten beaten up by my family, friends, everything else. It’s just the way I am.

Judge: But why did you do that?

Plaintiff: I did it for the mother because she did help me, and I really thought that getting these young kids a second car would really help them out a lot.

Judge: Seriously?

Plaintiff: It did.

Judge: The person it didn’t help was you because, according to you, that was a loan. That’s how you were helping them out—giving them a loan.

Plaintiff: Absolutely.

Judge: And according to you, Mr. Lucas, what?

Defendant: Well, our assumption was that it was a gift because—well, the reason we accepted was because we weren’t in a position to pay anything. We are very paycheck to paycheck.

Judge: Okay.

Defendant: We have a little girl.

Judge: How old?

Defendant: Three years old.

Judge: Who’s how old?

Defendant: Three.

Judge: Oh, for the love of God.

Defendant: So we really aren’t in a position—

Judge: Right, you are the kind of people we call bus takers, or public transportation takers, right? You don’t get to have the $4,000 car until you’ve saved up for it, right?

Defendant: Uh—

Judge: Or you have to drop a—You know, that’s the kind of thing it is.

Defendant: Yeah.

Judge: And so when—it’s not—I’m not sure why you would think a virtual stranger was going to rain four grand on you.

(Commercial Break)

Judge: Well, was there any discussion about when the payback would be?

Plaintiff: Your honor, I—I—I had to go to the bank Monday. They didn’t know that I had to go borrow the money to cover a check if he wrote it out.

Judge: So you didn’t even have the money?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: You took it out of what?

Plaintiff: My home equity.

Judge: You put your house up as collateral?

Plaintiff: I had to borrow the money.

Judge: Okay. Who are those folks?

Plaintiff: These are my sister and her husband.

Judge: Oh, they must have been the ones who gave you the most grief. Because they have a bobblehead going while I’m talking—the two of them. All right. So let me—listen, there are worse things, right? So let me ask you a question. When you wrote the check, did you have them sign a promissory note or anything else?

Plaintiff: We were at breakfast. I took them out for breakfast on a Sunday morning.

Judge: You paid?

Plaintiff: Of course, I did, your honor. I paid.

Judge: They know what a nice person you are.

Plaintiff: I know. Listen, kids—he was sitting right next to me, Mary was across with her daughter, we were having breakfast. I took the check out of my pocket, and I handed it to him. And I said, “Listen, you better make sure you look at the check before you fill it out and cash it.” And that was the last of the conversation.

Judge: And on that check, in the memo line, you had written “Personal Loan for Kids.”

Plaintiff: Yes, your honor.

Judge: And you had left the payee blank because you didn’t know if he was going to sign it to himself or to an auto agency?

Plaintiff: That’s exactly right.

Judge: And as it turns out, you wrote it to yourself, right? Like, you filled your name in and then you got the money out. And what’d you do with the money?

Defendant: Well, the money was deposited into my bank account, and then once we found a vehicle—

Judge: You did buy a car?

Defendant: We did buy a car.

Judge: Yeah? How’s that working out for you?

Defendant: Very well.

Judge: Good. Yeah, of course. So did you not read the memo line?

Defendant: No, your honor. I filled the check out in the car.

Judge: Because where you fill out your name with your hand is a half-inch from the memo line. What did the memo line say?

Defendant: I—I do not remember.

Judge: Okay, you’re 21. You’re not blind. What did the memo line say?

Defendant: I don’t recall.

Judge: The memo line said “Personal Loan.” What would make you think it was ever going to be a gift? Did you ever say it was going to be a gift? Did the word loan or payment plan or anything like that come up at breakfast?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Okay. Months later—months—months later, you say, “Hey, you ever going to pay me back for that?” And what happens?

Plaintiff: They thought it was a gift.

Judge: And you said?

Plaintiff: What?!       Judge: So, according to you, this was a loan. And according to you, this was a gift. Now, let me ask you a question, Mr. Lucas. If someone gives you $3,500, wouldn't you at least ask, "Are you sure?"

Defendant: We assumed that because there was no discussion about repayment, it was meant to help us out.

Judge: Right. But common sense tells you that a stranger isn’t just going to give you that kind of money with no strings attached. Did you ever think to clarify?

Defendant: Well, we just went with what we understood at the time.

Judge: Uh-huh. Let me ask you this—when the plaintiff asked you to pay him back, what did you say?

Defendant: I told him we were struggling financially, and that we wouldn’t be able to pay him back.

Judge: Okay. But did you say, "Oh, I thought this was a gift," or did you just say you couldn’t pay him back?

Defendant: At first, I told him we didn’t have the money. And later, when he kept asking, I said that I believed it was a gift.

Judge: And you never thought to call him and say, "Hey, we’re really grateful for this—what are the terms of this?"

Defendant: We just assumed.

Judge: Right. You just assumed the best-case scenario for yourself. You know what that sounds like to me? Convenient.

Defendant: I understand, your honor.

Judge: Now, Mr. Petron, I understand you didn’t have a contract, but you do have a check that clearly states “Personal Loan for Kids” in the memo. That is evidence of intent. It’s not ironclad, but it’s strong. You also asked for repayment, which further supports that this was not a gift.

Defendant: But we genuinely believed—

Judge: No, no, no. I don’t believe that. I believe that you took the money, spent it, and then when you realized there were consequences, you backpedaled and decided it was a gift. But the law doesn’t work that way.

Defendant’s Girlfriend: Your honor, if I may—

Judge: No, you may not. Your boyfriend accepted the check, deposited it, and benefited from it. If you wanted to clarify, you should have done that at the time.

Defendant’s Girlfriend: But we—

Judge: No “but.” You’re young, you’re struggling, and I get it, but that doesn’t make it right to take advantage of someone’s kindness.

Plaintiff: Thank you, your honor.

Judge: Here’s my ruling. Mr. Petron, you made a very bad decision in giving this money without an ironclad contract. That being said, there is enough evidence to support your claim that this was a loan. I am ruling in favor of the plaintiff for the full amount of $3,500.

Defendant: But your honor—

Judge: Case dismissed. Pay the man his money.

(Bangs gavel.)

**Judge:** This is the plaintiff, Lorna Lewis. She says the defendant, her upstairs neighbor, has been harassing her mercilessly. He calls her every dirty name under the sun, bangs on her door at all hours of the day and night, and makes obscene gestures—disgusting ones—toward her. She was forced to move away and is suing this terrible man for the $2,400 she's owed for harassment.

This is the defendant, Tommy Thompson. He says he's the one being harassed by the plaintiff. She has cut off his hot water, maced him for no reason, and she grows pot plants. She’s the instigator. He’s not giving her a penny, and that’s that. He’s accused of starting up with a neighbor. All parties, please raise your right hand.

**Bailiff:** Litigants have been sworn, Your Honor.

**Judge:** Thank you, Douglas. Okay, Lorna Lewis, you are suing your upstairs neighbor, Tommy Thompson, for $2,400 for harassment. Tell me what's going on.

**Plaintiff:** I moved into the unit in July—July 28, 2015. By then, there was a lady named Andrea living above me. Mr. Thompson used to go off on her and her sons, and then it gradually worked its way downstairs to me. Especially when she moved—I became the focus. Um, Mr. Thompson is an alcoholic. He gets drunk, and he starts being very, very belligerent.

I've been called tramps, sluts, yellow hammers—I can't figure out what that one is. Up until June of this year, it had been an on-and-off thing, but I don’t know what triggered him this year. There was another man living above me—Tony. He ran him away with the same thing, and I have a statement from Tony. Now that I’m the only one left...

**Judge:** Does he own the place?

**Plaintiff:** No, he does not.

**Judge:** So why doesn’t the landlord get rid of him and keep all of you guys? What’s going on?

**Plaintiff:** Well, I have a statement from the landlord. He says that being cursed out is no reason to evict a tenant.

**Judge:** Okay.

**Plaintiff:** Like I said, I don’t know how we got back to him cursing me out and making obscene sexual gestures toward me.

**Judge:** Okay, we got you.

**Plaintiff:** I have videos of that.

**Judge:** So why’d you stay there? If you were month-to-month, why didn’t you want to get out?

**Plaintiff:** I’m on Section 8. I like where I live. I thought the owner would work with me on this, but then he finally sent me a message that made me say, “You know what? You’re not going to help me. I’m going to go ahead and move.”

Now, when you're on Section 8, you can't just get up and move. It’s a process. I’ve done everything—I turn in my keys tomorrow.

**Judge:** Oh, you do?

**Plaintiff:** Yes. I moved my belongings out Sunday because after the obscene sexual gestures, I was like, “Okay, this is escalating.” There’s no comparison to peace.

**Judge:** What’s the problem, Mr. Thompson? What’s going on?

**Defendant:** Some of the statements that she said are true.

**Judge:** Such as?

**Defendant:** She said the gesture I made, cussing her out—that happened. But she cussed me too. It’s not just me by myself. Then she says the next-door neighbor, Tony—he didn’t just move. He got evicted. The sheriff came out and served papers on him because he wasn’t paying rent.

**Judge:** That’s right. They served papers on him.

**Defendant:** She said she was renting the backyard of the five units that are there, and the landlord said no. He said a portion, but she takes up at least three-fourths of a 15-by-45-foot-long backyard.

**Judge:** Did the landlord make her take it down?

**Defendant:** Yes, because she moved out.

**Judge:** According to her, she’s staying at her boyfriend’s. Is it because she can’t stand living there because you won’t stop harassing her?

**Defendant:** That’s not true. She’s there every night since she moved out and before then.

**Judge:** What seems to be the problem between the two of you?

**Defendant:** She plays her music loud, so when I play mine, she hollers upstairs, bangs on the door, and tells me to cut my music down.

**Judge:** What kind of music does she play?

**Defendant:** Regular music.

**Judge:** What kind of music do you play?

**Defendant:** I play reggae, all kinds—Bobby, everything.

**Judge:** According to you, she’s growing marijuana plants in the backyard?

**Defendant:** Yes, taller than me, and I’m 6’3”. I got the police report on that.

**Judge:** Let me see that.

**Defendant:** And I got another report—she maced me.

**Judge:** She maced you with spray? When did that happen?

**Defendant:** Yes. When she was harassing me.

**Judge:** How many times were the police out there? Are you just showing me police reports because you kept calling them?

**Defendant:** I called when she was harassing me. She says it’s just me, but she’s doing the same thing.

**Judge:** What do the reports say? Did they find a marijuana tree?

**Defendant:** No crime—it’s legal to have in Los Angeles.

**Judge:** Did you spray mace at him?

**Plaintiff:** No, I never sprayed mace at him.

**Judge:** Okay. Let’s see the video.

[Video plays]

**Judge:** Why are you yelling those things and making those gestures?

**Defendant:** Because she was saying things about me needing a woman.

**Judge:** Okay. I think you’ve both proven that you have been harassing each other. Miss Lewis, I understand that you wanted a forum where someone listened to you because you felt the police and the landlord weren’t. But this is a difficult case. You’re asking for $2,400, but both of you are guilty of inappropriate behavior. I’m not awarding damages to either party. Case dismissed.

**Plaintiff:** I’m just glad I’m moving out.

**Judge:** Good luck to you both.

dialogue:
Judge:
This is the plaintiff, Mikole House. She says she and the defendant have known each other for years, and she booked a trip through her travel agency in April of 2018. Turns out the defendant used a fraudulent card to book the flights. She's now in a whole lot of hot water with the airline, and she was forced to pay them for the ticket again. She's suing for $1,155.86, the amount she's owed for that ticket and lost wages.

This is the defendant, Danielle Williams. She says she was just a middleman in the travel transaction. Her employee had an in with the airline, so the plaintiff should be going after her if there were any problems with the flights. The plaintiff called the cops on her for no good reason. She runs an excellent travel agency, and the angry plaintiff is suing the wrong person. She's accused of taking off on a former friend.

All parties, please raise your right hands.

Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiff used the defendant's travel agency to book a trip, but the defendant used a fraudulent credit card. Now, the plaintiff is in trouble with the airline. The defendant says she was just the middleman, so not her problem. It’s the case of have lawsuit, will travel.

Thank you, Douglas.

Miss House, you are suing Danielle Williams and Miss Danny’s Travel—that’s your company?

Defendant:
Yes.

Judge:
Okay. You are suing for $1,114.51 in lost wages and an airline ticket that you had to pay twice for. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff:
Okay, um, basically, I was trying to book a trip for my anniversary. The defendant had told me—

Judge:
How did you guys know each other?

Plaintiff:
Oh, we've known each other for years. We lived down the street from each other. We grew up on the same block. As we got older, we moved, and we kind of lost touch. Then, we ended up living in the same area again in the last three years. So, from that point, we kind of talked a little bit more than we had in years past.

I have a daycare. I had her children in my daycare for about a year. The following year, it just didn’t work out because of time restraints and her trying to, you know, um, um, trying to get me to go to a certain price that I wasn’t willing to accept for my services. So, um, with that being said, we just kind of didn’t really talk as much.

But over the years, she started telling me about her travel agency.

Judge:
So you decide to use her for a trip to—?

Plaintiff:
Yes, the Dominican Republic.

Judge:
You and your spouse decide that it’s a great idea. You go on it. What goes wrong during the trip?

Plaintiff:
Oh, everything.

Judge:
Well, first, tell me what went wrong with the flights before the trip.

Plaintiff:
Oh, it was horrible. We booked the trip on the 11th, and by the 13th, we already had an issue with the flight.

Judge:
What was the issue?

Plaintiff:
I got an email saying the flight had been cancelled. But before that, I had actually received a confirmation that we were going on a flight that wasn’t the one we originally agreed to. It had a long layover. So, I reached out to her and said, “I didn’t want a layover; we don’t want to be sitting somewhere for two and a half hours.” She told me, “That’s not the flight I originally booked. Let me fix it.”

In the process of her fixing it, she said it got cancelled.

Judge:
Okay, but that cancellation sounds normal. She was canceling that flight because it wasn’t the one you wanted. But why would a flight have surfaced that wasn’t the one you picked?

Defendant:
Because I was dealing with a— It was like a third-party transaction. I had a person at the airport.

Judge:
Who is the she? An employee of yours?

Defendant:
No, she’s just an associate.

Judge:
Okay, go on.

Plaintiff:
The next flight gets cancelled.

Judge:
Why did the second one get cancelled?

Defendant:
That was not what I told her, but, um, the second one got cancelled. The person at the airport told me it was something with the flights to the Dominican Republic—something about the group.

Judge:
So, it wasn’t the airline cancelling flights—it was the transaction that got cancelled?

Defendant:
Yes.

Judge:
Then it’s not something with the trip; it’s something with your methods. Normally, this shouldn’t happen, right? People shouldn’t have their trips cancelled multiple times?

Defendant:
Right, and that’s exactly what I was saying to my person who was booking the flight.

Judge:
Something shady is going on here. What is it? I need to know.

Defendant:
I wasn’t aware of it at first, but later, I found out my associate was using inappropriate credit cards.

Judge:
A stolen card?

Defendant:
Yes, but at the time, I didn’t know.

Judge:
So, let’s fast-forward. You go on the trip. You get to the resort. What happens?

Plaintiff:
I have no confirmation number. I call her. She doesn’t answer. The resort can’t find our reservation. It takes three hours to get a room.

Judge:
And what about the excursions?

Plaintiff’s Spouse:
They were horrible. Our names weren’t on the lists. The driver never showed up to take us to the club.

Judge:
Okay, so the trip is a disaster. You get home. What happens next?

Plaintiff:
I get an email from Southwest's fraud department.

Judge:
Why was the fraud department contacting her?

Defendant:
Because my associate was using fraudulent credit cards.

Judge:
She paid you how much for the ticket?

Plaintiff:
$520. Then, I had to pay Southwest again—$834.51.

Judge:
Why wouldn’t Southwest go after the agency?

Plaintiff:
They said they go after the passenger because we got the benefit of the flight.

Judge:
And you think you shouldn’t be responsible?

Defendant:
I wasn’t given the chance to fix it. I would have fixed it.

Judge:
But fixing it would have meant paying the $834, right?

Defendant:
I would have figured out a way.

Judge:
Okay. I’m finding in the plaintiff’s favor for $834.51. However, I am not awarding lost wages.

Verdict for the plaintiff.

Post-Verdict Interviews
Reporter:
Miss Williams, are you surprised by the judge’s decision?

Defendant:
No, not at all. It’s business. I get it.

Reporter:
Miss House, you’re getting your money back. Thoughts?

Plaintiff:
I would never do business with her again. She is not a friend. A friend wouldn’t do this to me.

Judge’s Commentary:
The person who did work for the defendant is the defendant’s agent. That makes the defendant responsible.

Defendant: "I told you, Your Honor, my money is wrapped up in things, and I'm trying to make more money for all of us."

Judge: "Health insurance isn't important to you for your children?"
Defendant: "It's important, but... but I wouldn't—isn't it best for a man to plan for the whole future of his children? That's what I'm trying to do. I'm just saying, she got health insurance for the kids. Didn't I help you get the braces and all that? No, because the kid running around whistling up.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Next case, in the matter of the Plaintiff, Sandra Kwar, who is suing the Defendant, Dr. Ronald Juvas, a dentist, for dentures, claiming they do not fit. The Defendant states that he has been practicing for 37 years and believes the dentures are properly made. It is the case of the dentist who broke the mold.

Judge: Thank you. You're welcome. Sandra Kwar?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: You are suing your dentist, Ronald Juvas, for $1,567, the amount you paid for dentures that you say do not fit.

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: What happened?

Plaintiff: I joined a dental plan back in January of 2011, and the Defendant was a participant on the plan. I contacted him because his location was close to where I live and work. On my first visit, we discussed the dentures and the price. I told him I have a very small mouth and asked if he could make the new dentures the same size as my current ones. He said no problem. That would never be a problem. But unfortunately, they are not.

Judge: Did you bring him the dentures you were wearing?

Plaintiff: I was wearing them.

Judge: So, he took them out and looked at them?

Plaintiff: Yes, I assume he did a mold of my mouth. He did two impressions, which he said was his standard practice to ensure accuracy. However, I feel the mold he used was too large for my mouth. When he took it out after the plaster settled, it did not seem correct.

Judge: What happened when you received the dentures?

Plaintiff: I went back at least five times. Each time, I told him I couldn’t wear them. He filed them down, but they were still too thick. The gum part was thicker than my previous dentures. Thank you.

Judge:
You came to the right place.

**Judge:** Okay, Ms. Marcado, you are suing Mr. Reel's restaurant. You've asked us not to mention the name of the restaurant. We will respect that. You are suing for $1,853.29 in hospital bills and a refund of a dinner bill because you got food served to you that you had explained to them you were allergic to. What happened here?

**Plaintiff:** We went to dinner, my son and three of his friends, to celebrate one of his friend's birthdays. I’m a widow, I have a young son, so I tell them clearly I am deathly allergic to peppers.

**Judge:** How old is your son?

**Plaintiff:** He’s 17.

**Judge:** Okay, but I'm assuming you would take care of yourself regardless of his age.

**Plaintiff:** Yes, absolutely. I’m very cautious.

**Judge:** What are you allergic to?

**Plaintiff:** Peppers. Any kind of peppers—red or green, doesn’t matter.

**Judge:** How did you first find out you were allergic?

**Plaintiff:** I had an asthma attack and I went into shock.

**Judge:** How old were you?

**Plaintiff:** 18.

**Judge:** Had you eaten peppers before that?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, I’m Italian, so I grew up eating them.

**Judge:** I feel so bad for you because they’re in everything. I don’t even know how you go out to dinner.

**Plaintiff:** It’s very difficult. I have to be honest. But I always tell the waitress, and she was very nice. She went in and asked the chef if what I was ordering would have peppers. She came back and said no. So they served me my food.

**Judge:** What did you order?

**Plaintiff:** I ordered a fried fish dish. It had one clam with breading on it. I took a bite of the clam, and there was a red pepper. As soon as it hit my tongue, my throat started to close and I went into shock. The night manager, Nancy, came over and said to me, "Well, the chef told me there are no peppers. Are you trying to get out of the meal?" I said, "We didn’t even eat." She made me go through the clam and put them in her hand to show her that there were red peppers in there.

**Judge:** Were they crushed red pepper flakes or actual red pepper pieces?

**Plaintiff:** Actual red pepper pieces. I dug them out for her and put them in her hand. She said, "Oh, well, the chef is sorry. He made a mistake."

**Judge:** Did she go back and talk to the chef?

**Plaintiff:** She came back and said that.

**Judge:** In the meantime, what did your son do?

**Plaintiff:** He ran to get my EpiPen from the car. I left it in the car.

**Judge:** Did you take your injection?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, and as I was walking out, Nancy was standing there with the bill in the folder. She said, "You need to pay your bill." I said, "Are you serious?"

**Judge:** Were you walking out with all the boys?

**Plaintiff:** Yes.

**Judge:** And she still made you pay the bill?

**Plaintiff:** Yes. She said, "What do you want? I took your meal off." I said, "The kids didn’t even get to eat. We ruined his birthday dinner, and now I’m on the way to the hospital." So I paid the bill and left.

**Judge:** Mr. Reel, let me hear from you.

**Defendant:** I was cooking that night. The waitress came to the back and asked if there was any red pepper in the dinner. I said no. I interpreted that as she didn’t like spicy food. She never mentioned all peppers.

**Judge:** Did your waitress ask about red peppers or all peppers?

**Defendant:** She asked about red peppers.

**Judge:** Did you say red peppers or all peppers to her?

**Plaintiff:** I said red and green peppers. And there were red peppers. I handed them to her.

**Judge:** It sounds like maybe this was a miscommunication. But she actually went to the hospital. You know that’s not made up, right?

**Defendant:** Yes.

**Judge:** Can I see your hospital bill?

**Plaintiff:** (Hands over bill)

**Judge:** You comped her meal, that was great. And you paid for two EpiPens. On what theory should she have to be out $1,700 in hospital costs?

**Defendant:** We just felt that if she had stated "all peppers," we would have—

**Judge:** Hold on. Did you state "all peppers"?

**Plaintiff:** Yes.

**Judge:** You’re not there. Someone conveyed it to you, and you didn’t verify. You’re not going to win on that.

**Defendant:** We did our best.

**Judge:** You fought refunding the dinner for the others?

**Defendant:** Yes, because they don’t have an allergy.

**Plaintiff:** Nobody ate their meal. We had three bites and left.

**Judge:** I don’t see how anyone could have continued eating after watching her use an EpiPen and leave for the hospital. I order the defendant to compensate the plaintiff for her hospital bill and refund the dinner. Verdict for the plaintiff in the amount of $1,853.29.

**Defendant:** I’m glad it went that way. It’s fine.

**Plaintiff:** Thank you.

JUDGE:

The defendant says the plaintiffs didn’t complain for months. It’s the case of "Cool Your Jetta."

Plaintiff?

PLAINTIFF:
Yes.

JUDGE:
You are suing the defendant?

PLAINTIFF:
Yes.

JUDGE:
For $3,284.67 that you say the defendant owes you for things that have gone wrong with the car you bought. Tell me what’s going on.

PLAINTIFF:
My son answered an ad on September 4, 2011.

JUDGE:
Why don’t you tell me that part since it’s your car? How old are you?

PLAINTIFF:
I’m 18 now. I was 17 when I answered the ad.

JUDGE:
This is your first car?

Yeah, I just really wanted a car.

You were buying it with your money?

Yeah, it was my money.

JUDGE:
How’d you make the money?

I worked on a goat farm all summer.

JUDGE:
Okay.

PLAINTIFF:
I found the ad on Craigslist. I was looking for a really long time for a car, and I saw this. It said it had a new timing belt, which was the main reason I was looking at it, because that’s a huge cost. It had 156,000 miles, and I thought everything was just good with it. So I called the seller up that night…

JUDGE:
What year is the car?

PLAINTIFF:
It’s a 2001.

JUDGE:
Let me see the ad. This is the actual ad you responded to?

PLAINTIFF:
Yeah.

JUDGE:
(Reads ad) 2001 Volkswagen Jetta, 5-speed, black, 1.8T… What does that mean?

PLAINTIFF:
It’s a 1.8-liter engine with a turbo.

Oh, so it’s souped up?

It was pretty nice.

JUDGE:
Black with black leather, 156,000 miles, power sunroof, power everything, super mint, new timing belt, water pump, tensioner, tune-up, clean title in hand. Okay. So you go see the car, and you like it?

Yep.

JUDGE:
Oh, but you had it done after you purchased it?

PLAINTIFF:
I did.

JUDGE:
A post-purchase inspection! That’s how you put it in the complaint, right? What’s the point of a post-purchase inspection? It’s like having a headache, waiting until it’s over, and then taking some aspirin.

PLAINTIFF:
You’re absolutely right.

JUDGE:
It’s his first car. Not your first, though, right?

PLAINTIFF:
No, it’s not.

This is what he relies on you for.

If I knew there was a piece of wood in there, I wouldn’t have driven the car 66 miles!

JUDGE:
But you advertised it as having a new timing belt.

DEFENDANT:
I didn’t know about the wood.

JUDGE:
Okay. So the plaintiffs say the car was advertised in "Superman condition."

DEFENDANT:
That’s just a general description.

JUDGE:
Well, let me tell you something. The sale of a used car is an "as-is" sale…

Judge: Tyler Henshaw, yes? You are suing George Nation for $1,396.60 in rent, utilities, and keys you say he stole from you. Tell me what's going on.

Plaintiff: Correct. I agreed to move into my apartment with my roommate, Albert Adalus, and he was moving to California for the summer for an internship opportunity. George Nation and I agreed to have him move in for the summer.

Judge: Sort of sublet it?

Plaintiff: Yes, correct.

Judge: Do you know George Nation?

Plaintiff: Yes, we were friends.

Judge: You were friends. Alright, and then what happens?

Plaintiff: So, we moved in.

Judge: When did he move in?

Plaintiff: On moving day with us.

Judge: With who?

Plaintiff: Me and Albert. He stayed on the couch for a couple of days before he moved back to New York to fly to California. Everything was fine.

Judge: How much was he supposed to pay you? What was the agreement?

Plaintiff: It was $350 for rent when rent is $1,145, which I have proof of.

Judge: So that was a good deal.

Plaintiff: Yes, plus $100 flat rate for utilities.

Judge: Now, according to you, the negotiated rate was $100 per month for utilities and $350 for rent?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: And then what happens?

Plaintiff: I started asking more seriously, kind of like, "We have to get it together." I fronted it at the beginning.

Judge: When did you start asking him? He had been there how long?

Plaintiff: I would say three to four weeks.

Judge: But you know, rent usually comes at the beginning of the month, right?

Plaintiff: Well, we moved in on the 14th, so we had a prorated amount that was already covered.

Judge: Go on.

Plaintiff: Yeah, so I started asking George for the money. Excuses came up. I got, "My father pays for it, so he doesn’t have to."

Judge: What do you mean, "your father pays for it, so he doesn’t have to"?

Plaintiff: Well, my father is helping me out with rent.

Judge: And he would say to you?

Plaintiff: "Oh, what do you care? You’re not even paying it."

Judge: Really?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And you didn’t kick him out then?

Plaintiff: No, we were friends. We still went out. I kind of just put it to the side.

Judge: So what happens?

Plaintiff: He started moving his stuff out. I ended up taking his PlayStation 3 as collateral.

Judge: Wait, wait. Does he know that?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: At that point, he had lived there how long rent-free?

Plaintiff: Just over two months.

Judge: And what was he saying to you about the rent money at this point?

Plaintiff: After the PlayStation, he said, "I’m not paying it," cursed at me, and other things.

Judge: And then what?

Plaintiff: Four or five days later, he knocked on the door. I opened it, and then we had the argument about the PlayStation.

Judge: You have an argument there, and what happens?

Plaintiff: He was angry, of course, like any reasonable person would be. And from there, he left. We ended up texting back and forth. I texted him. He took some things as collateral from me.

Judge: Collateral? That’s called theft, not collateral.

Plaintiff: Well—

Judge: What did he take?

Plaintiff: A smaller wallet with a couple of cards in it. Plus, I realized my backup car keys were missing a few weeks later.

Judge: (To Defendant) What’s going on?

Defendant: Well, what happened was I had a job.

Judge: Are you guys students?

Plaintiff & Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Where?

Plaintiff: University of Hartford.

Judge: What are you studying?

Plaintiff: Communication and advertising.

Judge: What are you studying?

Defendant: Double majoring in accounting and engineering.

Judge: Okay, go on.

Defendant: I got a job opening for the summer and needed a place to stay. I told him I wouldn’t be able to really pay much. I’m a college student, I don’t have that much money.

Judge: Wait, are you saying you weren’t supposed to pay any rent?

Defendant: No, that’s not what I’m saying at all.

Judge: What are you saying? How much rent were you supposed to pay?

Defendant: We didn’t come to a set agreement at all.

Judge: Were you ever privy to communications between them about the rent?

Witness: Yes, I witnessed a discussion when we moved in that they had agreed upon $350 a month plus $100 for utilities.

Judge: (To Defendant) What say you about that?

Defendant: That is not true. There was no agreement, and he was not present during anything.

Judge: So, according to you, you want me to believe that you were allowed to move in with no commitment about rent?

Defendant: I made no commitment.

Judge: You understand how stupid that sounds? First, you say you’re supposed to pay rent but with no set amount. Then you say you’re not supposed to pay rent but just help with groceries. Then you say you lost wages from an accident and should "call it even." You’re not making any sense.

Plaintiff: (Provides texts about missing items)

Judge: Your evidence on the key is too thin. However, I am awarding you more than you’re asking for on the rent. I am ordering three months of rent at $350 per month, totaling $1,050. As for utilities, three months at $100, totaling $300. Judgment in favor of the plaintiff for $1,350.

Defendant: (Leaving) It went the wrong way, but it is what it is.

Reporter: Did you think you were entitled to a free ride?

Defendant: That’s not exactly what I was trying to say.

Plaintiff: I will not choose a roommate who won’t pay rent again.

Judge: Case closed.

dialogue:
Judge: All parties, please raise your right hand. Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiffs sold the car to their daughter, and she stiffed them. But the defendant says Maureen split with Ronald and got back together, and he has a thing against her. It's the case of Car Crazy. Thank you, Douglas.

Judge: Ronald and Maureen Gabriel, you are suing Maureen's daughter, Victoria—there are six consonants in a row; I can't do it—what is it?

Defendant: Chrismanski. Victoria Chrismanski.

Judge: For $900 that you say is owed to you on a Saab that you sold her. Tell me what's going on.

Plaintiff (Ronald): Well, she needed the car because the car she had was gone. She ruined it, something happened to it, so she said she needed the car. So my wife registered the car in her name and let Victoria pay the insurance so she could go back and forth to work. She did this for about two months, I believe, and then she asked—

Judge: Who owns the title? The title to the car is in whose name?

Plaintiff (Ronald): It's in her name.

Judge: Okay, go on.

Plaintiff (Ronald): And this went on for about, I guess, a couple of months when she was going to work. Then she finally asked Maureen if she could buy the car, and Maureen said, "Well, I'll ask Ronald."

Judge: Okay, Maureen, why don't you tell me the story since none of that has to do with what happened?

Plaintiff (Maureen): Your Honor, I was at my daughter Kimberly's house, and Victoria was living there at the time, and she had an automobile that had broken down—no fixing it. So I—

Judge: Were you living there too, or no? You were just visiting?

Plaintiff (Maureen): I was at my daughter Kimberly's house.

Judge: Were you visiting, or were you living there?

Plaintiff (Maureen): No, I was staying there for a little while.

Judge: Oh, you were also staying there. So the three of you—Is this Kimberly?

Plaintiff (Maureen): No, that's my older sister.

Judge: Okay, okay, so go on.

Plaintiff (Maureen): Okay, so she has my granddaughter, of course, and I couldn't see her not being able to make money because she's a single mother. So I said, "Well, why don't you let me call Ron, and I'll see if he could bring the car here?" I registered it in my name—

Judge: You two were separated at that time?

Plaintiff (Maureen): Yeah.

Judge: Okay, all right, go on.

Plaintiff (Maureen): So I registered it in my name.

Judge: Was it not already registered in your name?

Plaintiff (Maureen): No, I think it was in Ron's name.

Judge: Is that accurate?

Plaintiff (Ronald): It wasn't registered. I bought the car; we never registered it. I had it at my house. It was never registered.

Judge: All right, so you registered it in your name. Why didn't you, if it's your car, register it in your own name?

Plaintiff (Ronald): I had two cars already. I bought that for her, but she didn't like it.

Judge: Okay, so you register it in your name, and then what?

(Conversation continues with details of the payments, disputes, voicemail evidence, and the final verdict.)

Judge: Verdict for the defendant.

"Judge: This is the plaintiff, Elena Taria. She says she parked her car on the street and it got hit by the defendant's car at 5:00 in the morning. The defendant is claiming her car was stolen, but she believes the defendant was driving the car and is responsible for the damage to her car. Elena is suing for $5,000, the cost of her total car.
[Music]
Judge: This is the defendant, Lacy. She says her car was, in fact, stolen and evidently involved in an accident with the plaintiff's car. She's very sorry her car got damaged, but she wasn’t anywhere near the car. She’s tried to explain this to the stubborn woman, but she still insists on coming after her.
[Music]
Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands.
[Music]
Judge: Welcome back to the People's Court. Next case: the plaintiff, Elena, parked her car and claims the defendant smashed it at 5:00 a.m., but the defendant says her car was stolen, so it’s not her fault. It’s the case of ""I'm Smashed, Thanks to You."" Thank you, Elena Taria. You are suing Lacy for $5,000 for a car accident that you say was her fault. Tell me what happened.
Plaintiff (Elena Taria): I live in Far Rockaway, and I went to Astoria to my son after the mega storm because he didn’t have electricity.
Judge: You mean after Hurricane Sandy?
Plaintiff: Yes, I left my car there because there was a problem with parking due to flooding in Far Rockaway. On November 16th, my son called me at 8:00 a.m. and told me, ""Mama, your car is completely destroyed.""
Judge: Did he say how it was destroyed?
Plaintiff: Yes, another car, a Ford, struck the car in front of me and my car. The other car, a Honda, was completely destroyed, and the Ford went on the sidewalk and crushed a pole across the street.
Judge: How did you know all this? Did your son hear the accident?
Plaintiff: He heard a noise, but he didn’t go outside until the morning. When he saw the accident, he called me, then we went to the police in Astoria, and they gave us the police report.
Judge: Can I see the police report?
Plaintiff: Yes.
[Judge reviews the police report.]
Judge: According to the police report, the Ford hit your car and the car in front of you. The driver of the Ford left the scene of the accident and left the car behind.
Plaintiff: Yes, that’s right.
Judge: The Ford was gone by the time you got there, and the Honda was gone too. What year was your car?
Plaintiff: It was a 1992 BMW 525.
Judge: And how did you come up with $5,000 as the Blue Book value of that car?
Plaintiff: The value of my car is $2,500, and the stress I got from this accident is more than $5,000, but I couldn’t ask for more than $5,000.
Judge: So you understand that the Blue Book value of your car is not $5,000, right?
Plaintiff: No, I understand.
Judge: What happened here, Lacy?
Defendant (Lacy): My car was stolen.
Judge: When was your car stolen?
Defendant: I parked my car on November 15th. I live in Jamaica. On November 16th, around 4:00 a.m., I came out and my car was not there.
Judge: Where did you park it?
Defendant: I parked in a neighborhood driveway.
Judge: What does ""neighborhood driveway"" mean?
Defendant: It was just a driveway in my neighborhood. It’s hard for me to find parking because I have an expedition.
Judge: Were you parking in somebody else’s private parking lot?
Defendant: No, I was blocking half of someone’s driveway.
Judge: So the person who lives there knows you park there?
Defendant: Yes, she’s seen me park there before, but I always move it before 5:00 p.m.
Judge: So, you’re saying your car was stolen but it really wasn’t. Is this suspicious to you?
Plaintiff (Elena): Yes, definitely. She’s lying. I think it was towed because she was parked illegally.
Judge: How does that affect your credibility?
Plaintiff: It ruins it.
Defendant: I didn’t park illegally, but yes, I wasn’t parked in a proper space.
Judge: So, when you go outside and it’s gone, what happens?
Defendant: I called 911, and they told me it was too early to file a stolen car report. They said it was probably towed.
Judge: And then what happened?
Defendant: I called again, and they said my car was picked up by the sheriff's department.
Judge: Wait, were the Marshals or sheriffs involved?
Defendant: No.
Judge: It wasn’t stolen?
Defendant: No, it was picked up for illegal parking.
Judge: So, you're telling me that some mystery person was driving your car and crashed it, but it wasn’t you?
Defendant: Yes, that’s what happened.
Judge: Why didn’t you file a stolen car report right away?
Defendant: I didn’t know what to do. I thought it was a misunderstanding.
Judge: I find it suspicious that there’s no stolen car report until later.
Plaintiff: Exactly. If my car was stolen, I’d report it immediately.
Judge: Lacy, why didn’t you report it immediately?
Defendant: I didn’t know what happened until later.
Judge: The police report and the way things happened lead me to believe that you were involved in the accident. You didn’t file a stolen car report, and your story doesn’t add up.
Judge: I am ruling in favor of the plaintiff for $2,500, the Blue Book value of your car."

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket, the plaintiff put a deposit down on a room and less than a day later changed her mind, wants her money back, but the defendant says deposits are deposits. It’s the case of "Let’s Get a Room." Thank you, Douglas.

Bailiff: You’re welcome.

Judge: Kristen, you are suing Kevin. Neither of you want your last names used. You’re suing for $700, a security deposit that you put down that he won’t return to you. Yes?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: I was walking down the block with my brother-in-law and we saw the "For Rent" sign. It said $650 for large rooms. I didn’t call him that same night, so I waited till the next day. I gave him a call and I said I was interested in looking into the apartment. We came that same day and I was in desperate need, so I’m like, you know what? The walls weren’t completely painted, there was no railing going up the stairs, and when I walked up, it was a little shaky on the railing upstairs. And I asked him, I said, you know, how are we going to work out fixing up the apartment?

Judge: Did you take the apartment?

Plaintiff: No, I didn’t.

Judge: Well, you didn’t move in, but did you sign anything?

Plaintiff: No, I just—

Judge: Did you hand over a deposit?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: How much of a deposit did you hand over?

Plaintiff: $700.

Judge: What was the purpose of handing over the deposit? You told him, "I’ll take it"?

Plaintiff: I told him that I wanted him to hold it so I could decide if I could afford it.

Judge: Your story is very different than that, correct?

Defendant: A little bit different. From my understanding, she had agreed to take the apartment. When someone hands you over money, a deposit to hold an apartment, that means they’re going to take it, and she agreed that she was going to pay the remaining balance for the first and last month on the day she moved in, which would have been the first.

Judge: So what ends up happening? You change your mind?

Plaintiff: I talked to my boss and I asked him if I could get more hours and if we could work it out so I could afford the apartment. I asked Kevin if he could lower the rent because it said—

Judge: After you gave him the $700?

Plaintiff: No, before. Before it was said. He said—

Judge: Just tell me what happened after you gave him $700.

Plaintiff: I gave it to him and I told him that I’d give him a call back.

Judge: And then you call him back and say what?

Plaintiff: I told him that I would discuss it with him—

Judge: And then what happened after that? Why was it that you weren’t taking it?

Plaintiff: Because I couldn’t afford to get the place ready for me to move in by the first.

Judge: You couldn’t afford the place, period?

Plaintiff: I couldn’t afford the place, period.

Judge: Because you asked your boss for more hours. So you put down a deposit of $700. Do you have a receipt that says it’s refundable?

Plaintiff: It does not say non-refundable.

Judge: Does it say refundable?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: So no mention of whether it’s refundable or not. Does the plaintiff get the deposit back?

Defendant: I don’t think so. A deposit is a decision you made by yourself and thought about already. I mean, I don’t think you can get it back.

Judge: That’s pretty harsh. Maybe true. What do you say?

Defendant: I also think she wouldn’t receive the money back. I mean, it’s your responsibility if you give a deposit to ask what the refund policy is.

Judge: Is it your responsibility or the person who takes the money?

Defendant: I think it’s both, but somebody’s got to win here.

Judge: Well, if it’s 12 hours, I think she should get her money back. What’s your position on this? Why won’t you return the money?

Defendant: I offered a pro-rated amount until I could get it rented, and I was going to refund that amount of money.

Judge: Did you ever end up renting it?

Defendant: Yes, someone moved in yesterday.

Judge: The problem is that when you hand over a deposit, the default position is not "it’s refundable." The default position is that it’s non-refundable. If you want it to be refundable, you should have that on the receipt. My verdict in this case is for the defendant.

Judge: So all of this money and he hasn't given you anything?
Plaintiff: No, ma'am.
Judge: Okay, sir, you work for the government currently and you inherited some land and you have cattle on that land. You have not paid her any money for your son?
Defendant: I inherited 10 acres, that's it. Okay, that's it.
Judge: Do you know how many acres 10 acres is, sir? Some people's houses aren't even sitting on one acre.
Defendant: It depends where it is, okay.
Judge: Well, you have 10 acres wherever it is, and these acres are worth almost $200,000.
Defendant: Hundred and sixty thousand, okay.
Judge: Okay, well that is still a lot.
Defendant: You know, that's $40,000 less. It's worth less.

Defendant (Dylan): I did, but that was just because I had moved.

Plaintiff (Brock): Exactly. I would have handled it differently if I had known. Instead, my credit took a hit, and I had to spend time and effort just to figure out what was going on.
Judge: I am awarding you the $2,722 that you’re out and ordering him to pay that. And you know what? I am going to order him to pay your time away from work because I do think it was vindictive. Judge: The ruling stands. Dylan, you are ordered to pay Brock a total of $3,975. Case closed.
