**[Judge]**  
Okay, Bonnie, you're suing Cindy—you've both asked not to mention your last names or the company's name—for **$1,400** that you say you loaned Cindy for rent. According to you, that was a business investment. Let me hear from you first, Bonnie. Tell me what happened.

**[Plaintiff]**  
Yes, I moved into a storage facility, and on the counter were business cards. The business card I picked was for sewing classes—offering sewing classes in your home.

**[Judge]**  
Had you ever taken sewing lessons before? Did you know how to sew? Were you good at this, or did you just think it would be an interesting thing to do?

**[Plaintiff]**  
I've never learned how to sew. I don't even know how to thread the machine. I actually needed something to focus on—something therapeutic for me. Learning a new skill, something I can contribute by helping other people who don't know the skill, would be rewarding for me.

**[Judge]**  
So, you started taking lessons with her?

**[Plaintiff]**  
Yes.

**[Judge]**  
And how long were you doing that?

**[Plaintiff]**  
Well, the first two Sundays were in my apartment. We started at the end of May, and the relationship quickly deteriorated. The last contact I had with her was, I think, in August or September.

**[Judge]**  
Okay, let's get to that middle part, though. So, she's in your apartment giving you sewing lessons. You're paying how much an hour or how much per session?

**[Plaintiff]**  
I can't really say because she charged me **$145** for the sewing machine.

**[Judge]**  
Okay, how much was she charging you per lesson?

**[Plaintiff]**  
**$15 an hour.**

**[Judge]**  
So, you're learning, you're liking it, you're enjoying it. And at some point, the two of you discuss no longer doing it at people's homes but instead from a location. Correct?

**[Plaintiff]**  
We had a discussion during the time we were having classes. I said, "Oh, I wish I could have my own shop; then I could have people coming and going like I want." And she said, "Well, why don't you get it?" And I said, "Well, I can't afford it." And she said, "Well, I could help you. I'd be interested in helping you." And that's kind of how everything escalated.

**[Judge]**  
So, you tell her that you're interested in helping her. And what is it you do?

**[Plaintiff]**  
Well, she comes to me for the security deposit. She said she found a place, she had to get it really fast, and she gave me instructions on what to do—to get the money, get it to the landlord, get the lease there, don't ask questions, don't answer questions, give her the cash.

**[Judge]**  
I'm sorry—don't ask questions of whom?

**[Plaintiff]**  
Of the landlord.

**[Judge]**  
Okay. Were you signing the lease, or was she?

**[Plaintiff]**  
She was signing the lease.

**[Judge]**  
So, you got the money to the landlord?

**[Plaintiff]**  
Yes.

**[Judge]**  
How much money was it?

**[Plaintiff]**  
**$1,400.**

**[Judge]**  
All right. And what was your understanding of your role in all of this? What were you thinking that **$1,400** was?

**[Plaintiff]**  
That was my advance payment on the classes.

**[Judge]**  
Okay. So, you expected to get that money back in actual class time?

**[Plaintiff]**  
Yes.

**[Judge]**  
And now, according to you, what is that money?

**[Defendant]**  
That money was shared rent on a workspace that we could have together so I could teach her more, and we could have other people come for classes.

**[Judge]**  
And in return, were you supposed to give her classes?

**[Defendant]**  
Because of her gift that I was grateful for, I wanted to make sure she had formal class time in the amount that she would pay for rent in return for her gift that she gave me.

**[Judge]**  
I thought you said that she was getting access and stuff like that?

**[Defendant]**  
Right, she was sharing rent with me, and I was grateful.

**[Judge]**  
How is that a gift?

**[Defendant]**  
Well, I looked at it—I was grateful for it. I was grateful for her wanting to come in.

**[Judge]**  
So, she gives you something, and you give her something in return?

**[Defendant]**  
Yes.

**[Judge]**  
Yeah, we call that a **contract.**

---

**[Judge's Ruling]**  
"This is a contract case. You paid in advance for something, and now you want to get out of it? I'm not going to let you. You agreed to give lessons, and I’m not going to call this a gift that you don’t have to do anything for. These are lessons that are paid for, and they are going to be given. What we are going to do is try to work out a schedule before you two leave this building." 

**Verdict:** The contract must be enforced. The defendant must provide **$1,400** worth of lessons.

Judge: So now, December 10th—there are two fraudulent transactions according to your lawsuit, correct?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Show me those transactions.

(Defendant hands over paperwork.)

Judge: And both are on the 10th?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: So as it turns out, a week or two later, you find out these charges are reversed as fraudulent transactions?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: Do you know whether she typed the numbers in?

Plaintiff: It was manually done, no card swipe.

Judge: Now we have December 12th. Two more fraudulent charges. One for $660, the other for $465. Again, numbers were typed in, not swiped?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: And the cardholder was not present?

Defendant: The cards they showed me matched the name of the person speaking.

Judge: But the same card was used for multiple transactions by different people?

Defendant: I was busy that day. I didn't check thoroughly.

Judge: Then we move to December 26th. Three more fraudulent transactions. $670, $428, and $214. Who were these purchases for?

Plaintiff: One was M. Clarissa. Another was Nikki for $428. And the third—

Defendant: I explained that to Tequila Fletcher. I never personally used the credit card machine for my own purchase. It was a mistake.

Judge: A mistake?

Defendant: I paid in cash later.

Judge: You expect me to ignore the fact that you yourself used the stolen credit card?

Defendant: It was a mix-up.

Judge: No, what I see is a pattern. I think you're a thief. You got bolder and bolder. This isn't just carelessness; this is fraud. You are responsible for this amount. Judgment for the plaintiff for $3,227.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case: The plaintiff says the defendant’s dog attacked his cat and killed it, then put the cat in the trash. But the defendant says the dog was on his own property. It’s the case of "dog got your cat." Thank you, Douglas. Lenny Rivera, you are suing Alan Esterine for $5,000—$375 for the cost of three cats and $4,000 something for emotional distress. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: Okay, um, I was actually at the Mets baseball game. I received a phone call from my wife and my brother indicating that the dog next door had eaten my cat.

Judge: Okay. Is this the brother?

Plaintiff: Yes, my brother and my daughter, because they were both at home when this happened.

Judge: Okay. Can I see the brother? Can you come up to the microphone? Did you actually see what happened?

Plaintiff’s Brother: No, I heard the cat screaming.

Judge: And where was—did you run out when you heard the cat scream?

Plaintiff’s Brother: I ran out, but the cat, um, already was—the pit was already on her stomach.

Judge: Was it in your yard, or was it in their yard?

Plaintiff’s Brother: It happened—the cat was in our yard, and the dog put his head out and took the cat.

Judge: Put his head out of what?

Plaintiff’s Brother: The fence. It pulled the cat.

Judge: Through the fence? What kind of fence is it?

Plaintiff’s Brother: It’s like, um—my brother has pictures.

Judge: Yeah, let me see it.

Plaintiff: I have numerous pictures that I want to show.

Judge: What kind of dog is it?

Plaintiff: A pit bull.

Judge: What is the fence that we’re talking about? This iron one?

Plaintiff: Yeah, that one.

Judge: When you see it, where’s the dog, and where’s the cat?

Plaintiff’s Brother: The cat was already in his gate.

Judge: When you first see it, the cat is in his gate?

Plaintiff’s Brother: Yes.

Judge: How do you know the cat didn’t just jump in?

Plaintiff’s Brother: I don’t know that.

Judge: Oh, well, that’s important, though.

Plaintiff’s Brother: But that dog—you can’t even go through the gate or anything because that dog wants to attack you.

Judge: Are you supposed to go through the gate?

Plaintiff’s Brother: No.

Judge: So just for the record, this dog’s very vicious?

Plaintiff’s Brother: This dog—my kids can’t even come outside to play because his dog is constantly in the gate, sticking his face out, attempting to bite my children. I have three children—an eight-year-old, a six-year-old, and a four-year-old. They can’t even play on my premises due to this dog.

Plaintiff: This dog actually, over the summertime, bit a crossing guard and required 18 stitches.

Judge: Did the crossing guard report it?

Plaintiff: No, because she said they’re friends, so she didn’t want to.

Judge: Have you filed a vicious dog report?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: What happened? Were you there?

Plaintiff: No, I was at work at the time.

Judge: How about you? Were you there? Come on up. Who are you to him?

Plaintiff’s Girlfriend: Girlfriend.

Judge: Okay. What happened?

Plaintiff’s Girlfriend: The cat—from what we saw, the dog was chasing the cat around the yard and caught the cat in the front of the yard.

Judge: Did you actually see it happen?

Plaintiff’s Girlfriend: I got it on video.

Judge: You got what happened on video? Why were you taking a video instead of solving the problem?

Plaintiff’s Girlfriend: Well, I mean, I just got it off the video, you know, for what was going on.

Judge: Why are you taking video with your camera instead of running out there and calling the dog?

Plaintiff’s Girlfriend: This is after—this is off my surveillance camera.

Judge: You should’ve just said that. So, you were videoing—it was on your surveillance camera, and you brought it into your phone?

Plaintiff’s Girlfriend: Yes.

Judge: Let me see it. (Reviewing footage) Okay, I see. The cat is running around, and the dog is chasing it. That means the cat was already inside the yard. You have no evidence that the dog dragged the cat in.


Judge: After reviewing all testimonies and evidence, the law does not punish animals for acting like animals. The law punishes irresponsible behavior on the part of owners. You own a cat. You can't stop cats from jumping around into other people’s yards. You have no evidence that the defendant’s dog pulled the cat into the yard. Based on what I’ve heard, my verdict is for the defendant.

**Judge:** Litigants have been sworn. Your honor, thank you, Douglas. Miss Kolaric, you are suing Danny for $1,500. $550 of it you want returned from your salon services, $100 to have the extensions removed, a co-pay for the doctor, and $800 in pain and suffering. What happened?

**Plaintiff (Jennifer Kolaric):** So it was Mother's Day, and my mom and I went to the salon. I had an appointment. He did my hair, he cut it.

**Judge:** Who’s “he”?

**Plaintiff:** Oh, I’m sorry, Danny.

**Judge:** That’s fine, I just want to clarify.

**Plaintiff:** I was complaining that it was thin and, you know, what’s going on? It’s thin, and it just doesn’t grow. It takes a very long time to grow. So that’s when Danny suggested hair extensions.

**Judge:** Okay.

**Plaintiff:** And I was concerned because I’ve heard other stories about them breaking your hair, and he had promised that the ones that he was putting in—where he was having one of the girls at the salon put them in—she’s a specialist, and it’s all about how they’re put in. And that they’re tape extensions and will not break your hair.

**Judge:** Okay, so tell me about the extensions and how they work.

**Defendant (Danny):** These are tape-in extensions. How it works is you take a thin slice of hair—

**Judge:** When you say “thin slice,” you mean just a small section of hair?

**Defendant:** Yes, we section off a little piece of hair.

**Judge:** You don’t actually cut the hair or anything?

**Defendant:** No, not at all.

**Judge:** Okay.

**Defendant:** There are two extensions, both of which have tape on them, and we pretty much sandwich the real hair between the two extensions.

**Judge:** What product do you use?

**Defendant:** We get our hair from a wholesale company.

**Judge:** How long have you been using that company?

**Defendant:** Since we opened, so about a year.

**Judge:** How close do you put it to the scalp?

**Defendant:** It’s supposed to be an inch away from the scalp.

**Judge:** And why is it supposed to be an inch away?

**Defendant:** That’s just the proper way to install them.

**Judge:** Do you know why?

**Defendant:** I personally don’t do hair extensions, but it’s because you don’t want it too close to the scalp. Jennifer actually had it done twice. It wasn’t the first time she got it done, and from my knowledge, she was very happy the first time, so she got it done again.

**Judge:** How many times did you get the extensions done?

**Plaintiff:** I had it done the first time on May 18th.

**Judge:** And then you had it done a second time?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, that’s how I was told it works. You have them put in—

**Judge:** When was the second time you went in?

**Plaintiff:** I believe it was June 26th.

**Judge:** Six weeks later?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, around June 27th.

**Judge:** And then what happens on the second date? You have them taken out?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, all of them. I had ten extensions in.

**Judge:** And then you have fresh ones put in?

**Plaintiff:** No, I was told that they could only be used twice. So, the second time, they take them out and put them back in, and then I can’t use them anymore.

**Judge:** Okay. When did you first notice a problem?

**Plaintiff:** Two weeks after that.

**Judge:** And what was the problem?

**Plaintiff:** My friend and coworker Lisa noticed something.

**Judge:** Lisa, go ahead.

**Lisa:** We were at work, and she was showing me her extensions. She was very proud of them. But when she turned her head, I noticed a bald spot. I could see her scalp, and I had never seen that before. We’ve worked together for over ten years, and I had never seen that spot before.

**Judge:** The day you noticed this was about mid-July?

**Lisa:** Yes.

**Judge:** How big was the bald spot? Is it still there?

**Plaintiff:** I have a picture.

**Judge:** Let me see it.

(Examines photos)

**Judge:** The bald spot is gone now?

**Plaintiff:** It’s still there, but less noticeable.

**Judge:** You have a doctor’s note?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, it says I had traction alopecia due to the extensions rubbing against my scalp.

**Judge:** Extensions don’t rub, people rub. Did you feel it happening?

**Plaintiff:** No, but that’s what the doctor said.

**Judge:** Did you take this issue to another salon?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, I had someone else remove them.

**Judge:** Did they tell you anything was wrong?

**Plaintiff:** She said they were close to the scalp.

**Judge:** Do you have any documentation of that?

**Plaintiff:** No.

**Judge:** Your theory, Danny, is that she left the salon happy and whatever happened later isn’t your fault?

**Defendant:** Correct.

**Judge:** How could something like this happen?

**Defendant:** I don’t know what happened after she left. When she returned, all ten extensions were still in place.

**Judge:** That’s a strong point—if all the hair that was attached to the extensions was intact, then something else likely caused the bald spot.

**Judge:** Based on what I’m hearing, these cases are tough to prove. Typically, the way to prove them is by getting a second opinion from a professional, stating what was done wrong. The issue here is that she had no issues until two months later, and the evidence doesn’t support that the salon was negligent.

**Judge:** I don’t see that you have proven that the salon did anything wrong. I am ruling in favor of the salon.

**Plaintiff:** I’m disappointed, but that’s life.

**Defendant:** I wasn’t sure I would win, but I am happy with the outcome.

**Judge:** Case dismissed.

Judge: I know, but that’s all of high school.

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: So, how did you guys reconnect, or had you stayed connected?

Plaintiff: We hadn’t stayed connected, but I reached out to her over Facebook to start being friends again, I guess. And after talking for a few months, she realized she wanted to move to Florida. I needed a roommate, and that’s when we decided to—

Judge: So you live where?

Plaintiff: Jacksonville.

Judge: Jacksonville, yes. All right, so you invited her to be your roommate?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Did you come up with any plan on what the rent would be?

Plaintiff: Yes, we had agreed on $450 a month in rent and splitting utilities. And I have proof of that being discussed.

Judge: I’d like to see that. What proof do you have? Is it Facebook?

Plaintiff: I have messages on Facebook as well as text messages. Unfortunately, and this is my own lack of foresight, I didn’t get a lease signed.

Judge: Okay, you can stay where you are, don’t approach me. That’s why my bailiff is there.

Bailiff: Thank you.

Judge: He gets all kinds of anxious when people approach. Oh my God, I can’t read that. That’s like 1.5 font.

Plaintiff: I know, I have a terrible printer. I can’t afford a new one.

Judge: Okay, let’s start with—it’s upside down, that’s how much I can’t read it. Okay, when does she move in with you? Listen, you’re young. How old are you?

Plaintiff: Twenty-nine.

Judge: Okay, let me explain to you what judge-friendly font is. It’s not one-point font.

Plaintiff: Understood.

Judge: All right, so she moves in with you when?

Plaintiff: August 1st.

Judge: So these are what exactly?

Plaintiff: These are messages within Facebook where we discuss the cost of rent being $450 a month, and she says $450 is okay with her and she can handle it.

Judge: Do any of them predate her moving down?

Plaintiff: No, I don’t have that.

Judge: Well, how did you two decide what rent would be before moving down?

Plaintiff: We decided it over the phone. We had many phone conversations and agreed on—

Judge: How does this happen in every single case where people tell me "Here’s the proof that we had the rent"?

Plaintiff: I know, it’s my fault. I trusted a friend.

Judge: Okay, no. You’re communicating through Facebook, and you guys are of a generation that takes pictures of the food you eat before you do, so why isn’t that here?

Plaintiff: Understood. But every time I bring up the $450, it’s not refuted by her.

Judge: That’s a different level of proof than what I’m saying. I would love to see a message saying, "No, Judge, I don’t owe him that." But okay. So now she moves in with you on what day?

Plaintiff: August 1st.

Judge: And then what happens?

Plaintiff: The defendant, Mr. Thompson, was seen exiting the jewelry store at approximately 3:15 PM. Surveillance footage confirms this timeline.

Defendant: Objection, Your Honor. The footage only shows a figure in a dark hoodie; it does not definitively identify my client.

Judge: Sustained. Plaintiff, please clarify the basis for identifying Mr. Thompson.

Plaintiff: Your Honor, aside from the footage, we have testimony from Officer Martinez, who apprehended the defendant less than two blocks away, with a bag containing items matching those reported stolen.

Judge: Officer Martinez, please take the stand.

(Officer Martinez is sworn in.)

Plaintiff: Officer, can you describe the events of the afternoon in question?

Officer Martinez: Yes, around 3:20 PM, I received a radio call regarding a robbery at the jewelry store. A suspect wearing a dark hoodie and jeans was reported fleeing westbound. When I turned onto Maple Avenue, I saw Mr. Thompson matching the description.

Defendant: Officer, is it possible that other individuals in the area also matched that description?

Officer Martinez: It is possible, but when I approached Mr. Thompson, he immediately ran. I pursued and detained him. In his possession was a black duffel bag containing various pieces of jewelry, which were later identified as stolen from the store.

Plaintiff: Was the defendant able to provide an explanation for possessing the jewelry?

Officer Martinez: No, he refused to answer my questions.

Defendant: Your Honor, I move to exclude the defendant’s silence as evidence of guilt.

Judge: Granted. The jury will disregard the defendant’s silence. Continue, Plaintiff.

Plaintiff: Thank you, Your Honor. Officer, did you conduct any forensic analysis on the items recovered?

Officer Martinez: Yes, we processed the bag and found Mr. Thompson’s fingerprints on both the bag and the jewelry inside.

Defendant: Officer, could these fingerprints have been placed on the items prior to the alleged robbery?

Officer Martinez: That is possible, but highly unlikely given the timeline and circumstances.

Judge: I’m finding in favor of the plaintiff in the amount of $1,800 in rent as well as the car damage. I don’t see any evidence anywhere that she’s supposed to pay utilities separately. That total is $2,467.12. Thank you.

Judge:
The plaintiff Rachel Bremol is suing the defendants, Carol and Shawn Davenport, for $600. She claims that they owe her money for flowers provided at their wedding. She argues that no matter what she does, she can't get them to pay. She says the defendants went on vacation and spent money all over town but refuse to pay her for the services she provided. She is suing for $600—$400 for the flowers and $200 for aggravation.

Plaintiff (Rachel Bremol):
Well, um, in a thousand words or less, I worked with Carol at a plant job company. We take care of interior plants, and she got engaged to Shawn in January of that year, 2013. She knew my flower background—I worked at a flower shop—and she liked my work I was doing with her at the company. So, she asked me to be their florist. She ended up leaving that company, and I was still working there. But we met a couple of times to discuss her flowers. We met for lunch at a brewery. She invited me out to the warehouse of the company she went to work for to get silk flowers from her company, and I did several arrangements for her.

Judge:
Was there a contract between you two?

Plaintiff:
No, it was all verbal.

Judge:
So, what was the agreement?

Plaintiff:
We kept talking, and she kept saying, "I want this, I want that," then things would change. She wanted personal flowers—fresh flowers like the bouquet, the bridesmaid flowers, flowers for the men, and a big, huge mantle piece over the fireplace of fresh flowers. She provided the silk flowers, the artificial ones from her company, to go into arrangements for things like lining the walkway for the Justice of the Peace. But I went to a wholesaler to get fresh flowers for all the personal things—like the bouquet.

Judge:
How much were you supposed to get paid?

Plaintiff:
Well, we never really discussed it.

Judge:
You didn’t discuss it? You’re just going to do business like that? And now, you come crying to me?

Plaintiff:
Yes, that’s correct.

Judge:
Okay, go on.

Plaintiff:
I was very trusting.

Judge:
No, no, no. You have a big "S" on your forehead. You're a sucker. You're doing a job you expect to get paid for, but you didn’t agree on a price.

Plaintiff:
Yes, I admit it.

Judge:
So, why would you do that as a business?

Plaintiff:
Well, we were friends.

Judge:
So, you’re saying because you were friends, you didn’t want to bring up money?

Plaintiff:
Yes.

Judge:
Well, let me tell you, you need to have a figure in your head, especially if you want to spend $1,200 on flowers. Did you ever bring up the price?

Plaintiff:
It came up the day of the wedding. She said she spent too much on other things and asked if she could pay me later in installments.

Judge:
Did you agree to that?

Plaintiff:
Yes, because I thought she was going to be my boss, and I trusted her.

Judge:
Did you ever ask her what she owed?

Plaintiff:
Yes, I did.

Judge:
You never mentioned how much was owed?

Plaintiff:
No.

Judge:
So, when you decided to sue, how much did you think you were owed?

Plaintiff:
I thought I was owed $600, $400 for the flowers and $200 for aggravation.

Judge:
So, why did you wait until three years after the wedding?

Plaintiff:
I was patient, but after a while, I got tired of waiting.

Judge:
So, when you quit, that’s when you decided to file the lawsuit?

Plaintiff:
Yes.

Judge:
And how much have you been paid?

Plaintiff:
They paid me $100 in September 2013, $100 in February 2014, and $100 again.

Judge:
So, $300 in total.

Plaintiff:
Yes.

Judge:
You have no proof of these payments.

Plaintiff:
No, it was in cash.

Judge:
And you never gave her a receipt?

Plaintiff:
No, I didn’t.

Judge:
What about the invoice?

Plaintiff:
I gave her a handwritten invoice.

Judge:
So you were paid $300, but you say you’re owed $600.

Plaintiff:
Yes.

Judge:
This case has become quite complicated. The defendant says you paid them more, but there’s no proof, and the contract was unclear. You’ve done a lot of things informally, and it's hard to figure out exactly how much was agreed upon.

Defendant (Carol Davenport):
We didn’t have a written contract. We were friends, and she said she’d charge us for materials plus labor.

Judge:
Did she ever mention a specific price?

Defendant:
No, but she did tell us it would be around $300 at one point.

Judge:
Did she ever give you an invoice?

Defendant:
No, I don’t recall receiving an invoice.

Judge:
But you kept paying her money. Why?

Defendant:
We thought we owed her, but we didn’t know how much.

Judge:
So, you paid her $300, $150, and $250?

Defendant:
Yes, but we never got a clear invoice, and it was hard to track how much was actually owed.

Judge:
And you have no receipts for these payments?

Defendant:
No.

Judge:
So, you’re both claiming you don’t know what’s owed. This is where things get confusing. You didn’t have a contract, you didn’t discuss a price, and now you’re both here arguing about what’s owed.

Defendant (Shawn Davenport):
Yes, it’s been a mess.

Judge:
In this case, the plaintiff has the burden of proof, but there’s no solid evidence for what was agreed upon. It’s very difficult to determine what’s owed or if anything is owed at all.

Judge (to Plaintiff):
You’re the one suing, so it’s up to you to prove that the defendants owe you money. However, you’ve failed to provide proof that they owe you more than what they’ve already paid.

Judge (to Defendant):
You’ve also failed to prove that you paid the full amount. You can’t just hand over cash without a receipt or documentation.

Judge:
The lack of documentation and the informal nature of your agreement makes this case very difficult to resolve. I’m ruling in favor of the defendants.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiff says the defendant gave away her expensive pottery equipment without her authorization. But the defendant says the plaintiff gave her orders to 86 it. It’s the case of "You're Kiln-ing Me."

Judge: Lisa Lynn Berra, you’re suing Nicole and Christopher Domini for $3,975.40 in pottery equipment—a kiln, pottery wheels, toolkits, etc.—that you had in their possession and that they, according to you, inappropriately disposed of. Tell me what’s going on.

Plaintiff: Well, actually, in 2008, when I was pregnant, the father of my son and I were moving out of a storage unit. He went ahead and took that equipment over to their house without my knowledge.

Judge: Without your knowledge?

Plaintiff: Right. He thought it would be—I mean, this was my most valuable equipment—and he took it over to their house. I’m not sure why he did that.

Judge: Did you ask him?

Plaintiff: I asked him, and he just kind of took liberties like that. That’s why he’s not in our life anymore.

Judge: All right, but when you asked him, what did he say?

Plaintiff: He said, "Oh, I took it over to Chris and Nikki’s house."

Judge: In order to do what with it at Chris and Nikki’s?

Plaintiff: In order to store it there. Apparently, he had sought permission from Chris and Nikki to leave it at their house for storage.

Judge: Is that what you were saying?

Defendant Christopher: That’s correct.

Judge: All right, and then what happened?

Plaintiff: I went to talk to them after I found out. This was around November 2008.

Judge: And what happened?

Plaintiff: They agreed that it would be okay—a verbal agreement—that it would be okay to keep it there.

Judge: Tell me about what both sides discussed.

Plaintiff: It was kind of—you know, it was a verbal agreement.

Judge: No, I don’t want any more conclusions. I want to know what you said and what they said. If you don’t remember, just give me the gist of it.

Plaintiff: I don’t remember exactly, but it seemed to be okay to have it there.

Judge: What did you guys discuss about when you would take your stuff out of their storage?

Plaintiff: It was kind of a loose verbal agreement.

Judge: A verbal agreement to what? That you’d leave your stuff there for free? For how long?

Plaintiff: Until I could come and get it or until they could bring it to me.

Judge: And when did you finally get around to coming and getting it?

Plaintiff: Well, I tried to get it in 2010. Then I had an altercation with Nikki, and it was right around then that I was ready to have it because I had moved a couple of times and had a little baby on my own. Then, I finally bought a house and had a place for it. I called them. I called Chris right after we had our altercation, and I told him on the phone that I wanted to make a plan to get my belongings back.

Judge: And what did he say?

Plaintiff: He said that they were in Florida.

Judge: When was that? What month and year?

Plaintiff: That was July 2010.

Judge: So what does Chris say to you?

Plaintiff: He said that he would be happy to do that. They were really busy because they were on a trip in Florida, and when he got back from his trip, he would help me take care of it.

Judge: And then what happened?

Plaintiff: Then Nikki called right away from his phone.

Judge: And she started yelling at you?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Defendant Nicole: Actually, we weren’t in Florida; we were in New Jersey burying Christopher’s grandmother.

Judge: I’m sorry to hear that. So you called her back?

Defendant Nicole: I asked her not to call us back because we were in New Jersey burying his grandmother.

Judge: So what happened? Did you ever get the stuff?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: And how long did it stay in their shop?

Defendant Christopher: From December 2008 until June 2011, when I donated it to the school district.

Judge: What did you do between July 2010 and June 2011?

Defendant Christopher: I had a lot of personal things going on.

Judge: Okay. But then you finally got rid of her stuff in June 2011. And now she’s suing you for $4,000. Why didn’t you just go get it?

Plaintiff: I tried.

Judge: Not hard enough. You left your stuff there for years. How long do you think you have free storage?

Plaintiff: I had a lot of personal things going on, and my child was in the hospital.

Judge: And I’m sorry for that, but it doesn’t change your obligations. After three years, when is it your responsibility?

Judge: My verdict in this case is for the defendants.

"JUDGE: This is the plaintiff, Christa Burkhart Vigil.
She says she put down a $500 deposit on an old lamp she saw at the defendant’s store, and when she went back to inquire about the lamp's age and history, the defendant’s salesperson got snooty with her. She was outraged, demanded a refund, and is suing for the return of her $500.
ANNOUNCER: This is the defendant. He says the plaintiff put a deposit down on an imitation Tiffany lamp, and when he couldn't give her the history of the lamp, she got all crazy on him. All sales in his store are clearly marked final sale, no refunds, and the shopaholic plaintiff, who had a change of heart, isn't getting any money back from him.
He's accused of being a pain in the glass.
BAILIFF: All parties, please raise your right hands.
JUDGE: Welcome back to The People’s Court.
Next case on the docket: The plaintiff put $500 down on a lamp, but when the sales clerk got shady, she wanted her money back and can’t get it. The defendant says it was an imitation Tiffany lamp, and she knew it.
It’s the case of You Don’t Light Up My Life.
Thank you, Douglas.
Christa Burkhart Vigil?
PLAINTIFF: Yes.
JUDGE: You are suing the defendant’s store. You've asked us not to mention your last name or the store’s name, so we will refer to you as ""plaintiff"" and ""defendant."" You are suing for $500, a deposit you put down on a lamp that you no longer want to buy.
Tell me what happened.
PLAINTIFF: I went by the store and saw a lamp I liked very much. I went in a couple of days later and wanted to buy it. The lamp I originally saw was too tall for our apartment, so I saw another one that was just perfect. The salesperson showed it to me, and I said I’d take it.
I came back the next day—it was pouring rain, and my husband couldn’t really find a parking spot on Austin Street in Kew Gardens. So, I went in, gave them a $500 deposit—
JUDGE: Because you wanted to make sure they didn’t sell the lamp?
PLAINTIFF: Right. And then, I said I’d come back the next day. Now, I work as a tour guide in the city, and I have a crazy schedule, so I couldn’t come back the next day. I came back a couple of days later, and the salesperson I had spoken to wasn’t there. Richie, another salesperson, was also not in.
So, I did not want to buy the lamp that day because nobody could really help me with it. We came back on the 4th of January—
JUDGE: Okay, just a few days after you put the deposit down.
PLAINTIFF: Yes. I had the money in my pocket to pay the difference, but I had been thinking about it. There was no evidence on the lamp—like where it was manufactured or where it came from—so I asked.
They told me, ""We never do that."" Then, they put the owner of the store on the phone. I asked him about the lamp’s history, and he said, ""I’ll write you down anything you want,"" but there was no printed evidence.
So I said, ""I’m not spending $900 on something I have no background on.""
JUDGE: Well, it sounds like you had already decided to spend $900 on something you didn’t know the background of because you had already paid a $500 deposit.
PLAINTIFF: I did, but I was a little impulsive. I get carried away very easily.
JUDGE: So, she wants to invoke the ""carried away"" exception to deposits at your store.
Tell me what your store policy is.
DEFENDANT: My store policy—can I show you?
JUDGE: Sure, approach.
DEFENDANT: Thank you.
We have a lot of impulse buyers—
JUDGE: What kind of store is this?
DEFENDANT: It started as a gift shop, but I expanded into furniture and clothing. We sell all kinds of art and new stuff.
JUDGE: New stuff? No used?
DEFENDANT: No, it’s all new. Once in a while, I get a vintage piece of furniture I love, but everything is new.
JUDGE: Okay.
DEFENDANT: She came in and fell in love with the lamp.
JUDGE: Was that lamp something you came into, or something you bought from a vendor?
DEFENDANT: We purchased a whole lot of lamps from a vendor who was manufacturing them in Mexico. The first day she came in, I explained to her that the glass is from Germany, and it’s manufactured in Mexico.
Originally, the price was $1,800. But since I figured she was an impulse buyer, I said, ""$800 takes it.""
She was shaking for it, but her husband said, ""Let’s go have dinner first."" Then, when she came back, I wasn’t there. Later, she called and my manager said she was upset and wanted a warranty.
So I said, ""I’ll give you any warranty you want—it’s a lamp, what can go wrong with it?""
She asked, ""How much warranty?"" I said, ""Is one year good enough?""
Then, she changed the subject. She wanted to know where it was made and asked for a printed story. I told her, ""It’s not a real Tiffany lamp.""
JUDGE: Did she think it was a Tiffany lamp?
DEFENDANT: You can ask her.
JUDGE: Did you think it was a Tiffany lamp?
PLAINTIFF: No.
JUDGE: Well, now what?
PLAINTIFF: I would like my money back.
JUDGE: Of course you would, honey, but you don’t get your money back because the receipt where you put your deposit specifically says ""no refunds.""
PLAINTIFF: But this is not a layaway. This was a deposit.
JUDGE: I don’t care. What do you think a deposit means?
A deposit means you’re paying him $500 so that he doesn’t sell the lamp to anybody else. And he didn’t. He did his part. Why should you just be able to take it back?
PLAINTIFF: I don’t know if the lamp is still there.
JUDGE: Is the lamp still there?
DEFENDANT: Yes, it’s still there.
JUDGE: Okay, go visit it—it’s your lamp.
Can she use the $500 to buy something different?
DEFENDANT: Your Honor, we are a neighborhood store, and I love my customers. I want them to be happy, especially her—she’s very dramatic, like an actress.
JUDGE: He says he loves his customers. You have a $500 credit there. You can either buy the lamp or use the $500 to buy something else.
But he has no legal obligation to give you back the cash. Your deposit is non-refundable, as your receipt clearly says.
Next time, don’t be an impulse buyer.
PLAINTIFF: Okay.
JUDGE: Verdict for the defendant. Good luck, folks.
BAILIFF: Thank you."

Judge: How can you not know this is a problem? Are you surprised by what I'm saying?

Judge: What efforts did you make to try to resolve this before it got here?
Defendant: To me, the complaints that he gave me were the dog droppings. The other thing is he doesn't live on the property. He only uses it as what?
Plaintiff: I don't live there full time.
Defendant: He made single occupancy rooms in the house, and he wants to do the same thing in the basement. That’s the reason why he doesn't want the dogs in the yard. I could get rid of them, I asked him. I said, "Why haven’t you done that before we got here?"
Plaintiff: He’s suing you.
Defendant: I asked him where he came up with these numbers. Before he bought the house, he thought you'd be better about picking up the poop.
Judge: You’re suing for the defendant’s dogs pooping on your lawn. You had to hire a professional to clean it up. Why are you suing for $1,400 for poo pickup?
Plaintiff: In June, I had to hire a neighbor to do the cleanup, which I paid, roughly $100 a month.
Judge: So you're paying a neighbor $100 a month to pick up a few logs of poop in a yard that is how big?
Plaintiff: In the driveway.
Judge: Okay, so a few yards.
Defendant: Did he do it for $100 a month?
Plaintiff: Yes.
Judge: How big is the yard?
Defendant: Is that the guy you paid $100 bucks?
Plaintiff: Yes.
Judge: Come on up, everyone wants to meet you.
Plaintiff’s Hired Helper (BR Medina): Yes, I got paid $100 a month.
Judge: Did you get paid $1,400 to pick up dog feces?
Helper: No, I was paid $100 a month from June 2011 to August.
Judge: Did you do anything else besides pick up the poop?
Helper: Yes, I had to clear the drain when it was clogged. The dog poop went down there.
Judge: Why aren't they citing him? Why isn't the city citing him?
Plaintiff: They said it’s a private property issue.
Judge: So you need to pursue this with the city. If it becomes a nuisance, that’s where you need to go.
Judge: Are you satisfied with your claim of $1,400?
Plaintiff: I believe it’s justified.
Judge: Let me see the pictures of the door.
Plaintiff: Here's the door that got ruined.
Judge: Wait, wait. Let me go ahead and talk to you.
Defendant: The fence was built after the fact.
Judge: I understand that, but the fact remains, you can’t continue to let your dogs run loose on a shared property.
Plaintiff: That’s a problem, Your Honor.
Judge: I am finding in favor of the plaintiff. The amount won’t be the full amount they’re suing for, but I am awarding $2,000 to the plaintiff for the dog cleanup and other issues.
Judge: The dogs may not be vicious, but they are a nuisance. I’m ruling in favor of the plaintiff for $2,000.

Judge: Tracy Unique Alexander. Yes, you are suing your old friend Mickey Story for $5,000 and missing medications, broken car windows, hair and wig, a jacket, and defamation and pain and suffering.

You have a counterclaim against her for $4,362.62—some bills and diabetic and high blood pressure medication that went missing.

All right, let's start with you.

Plaintiff: Yes, your Honor. This has been a friend of mine for a very long time—about 20-plus years. I called her my mother. She was the first transgender woman that I looked up to.

Anyway, last year sometime, a few months ago, she had borrowed a truck of mine—a Land Rover Discovery—and I hadn't heard from her for like a week, maybe longer. And something kept telling me, like, something’s not right, to go over to where she lived at.

And I did that—I popped up over there where she lived, saw my truck, and the windows were busted out of it.

So right there from the parking lot, I called her. I said, "Um, what’s going on? Why are the windows gone, and why haven’t you called me? I could have reported this to my insurance or whatever."

And she got cute, screaming and hollering, calling me a couple of Bs, you know? Just upset because I was complaining about my truck. And she kept saying, "Well, I was going to pay for it. I was going to pay for it."

And I'm telling her, "Like, you should have told me about what was going on."

Judge: Anyway, how did the windows get broken?

Plaintiff: She says that her boyfriend found out some information about her, and he got mad and busted the windows out.

Judge: What was the information he found out about her?

Plaintiff: I don’t know exactly.

Plaintiff’s Account of Living Situation
Plaintiff: Weeks later—well, actually months later—she was having hard times. She asked me if she could come and stay at my place.

Judge: Had you talked to each other in all that time?

Plaintiff: Oh yeah, we had talked to each other. Like I said, she was a friend.

So I allowed her to come to my place, where she stayed, and it was like a living hell.

Judge: Who lived with you?

Plaintiff: I live alone.

Judge: Alone? Okay, so she comes alone?

Plaintiff: Yeah, at the time. But a couple of days later, I ended up in the hospital.

Judge: What necessitated the double mastectomy? Did you have cancer?

Plaintiff: Well, I went to Tijuana and had some silicone injected into my breasts, and it gave me issues. So they had to remove it, put implants and stuff like that.

So I came home. I was fine. She was there; she did help me out a lot, seeing as I just had those surgeries.

But she started all these live videos—she wants to be Facebook famous—and she does a lot of live videos where she's screaming and hollering, playing these songs just all day, all night.

Boys in and out of my place. In and out. Different boys all the time.

Judge: How long was this arrangement going to last?

Plaintiff: She was only supposed to be there two months. She came in November.

Judge: Was she helping out with the rent?

Plaintiff: Well, she tried to. I wouldn’t accept it. So I said, "You keep that for yourself, put it up—that way you can move next month like you're supposed to."

So she left, went to a nephew—a friend of ours. She said she wasn’t coming back to my home. She was like, "I'm gone, I'm going to give you your space," blah blah blah.

So she was gone about a week.

Then she came back. She just popped up at my house one day while I was getting dressed.

Plaintiff Describes Altercation
Plaintiff: So I said, "When we leave, you have to leave." That’s what I told her.

I said, "I don't want anyone in my house. I cleaned my house spotless because it was horrible—I had to bleach it and do all the things, honey."

So I said, "I don't want nobody in my house. My house is clean, and when I leave and come back, I want it to stay that way."

So she—she—that didn’t sit well with her. She got irate. She got up in my face, told me to "put my dukes up," she was going to beat my ass.

Judge: Connie, were you there when that happened?

Connie: Yes.

Judge: Why don’t you tell me what happened?

Connie: Well, we came back. Christina got mad, and she said, "We could fight, I want to beat your ass anyway. I’ve been wanting to beat your ass for many years," and whoop whoop and whoop whoop.

They was arguing and all that.

Judge: Did they actually hit each other?

Connie: No, not at that point.

Plaintiff: Well, what happened was I had to call the police because she told me, "Well, B, I'm not going nowhere."

So she told the police, "Look, I got my ID here. You need to bobblehead."

The police told me, "Well, she's a resident there, nothing we can do."

Plaintiff’s Restraining Order
Plaintiff: So I left.

The very next morning, 7:00 AM, I went to court and got a restraining order.

Judge: And the restraining order was based on what?

Plaintiff: Based on the battery—because she had, at one point, pushed me. She didn’t hit me; she pushed my head. I hit the door seal, and I had a lump.

Judge: When had she done that, supposedly?

Plaintiff: The second time when I came, 'cause I left and came back.

So I had somebody serve her that very same day.

Judge: So once she was served the restraining order, she left your house?

Plaintiff: She didn’t leave immediately. I didn’t have a sheriff give the restraining order. I had my next-door neighbor serve her the restraining order.

So he gave her the restraining order.

Judge: The broken car windows—$450.

The wig—$641.74.

The jacket—we’re going to make arrangements for that.

The cable bill—$327.57—subtracted from the total leaves a net judgment in favor of the plaintiff in the amount of $316.71.

Judge: Let’s not put ourselves in a situation again where all kinds of bad things happen that we can't prove one way or the other.

Final Comments
Defendant: If I see her again, I’m going to beat her down.

Plaintiff: I have a restraining order. She will go to jail.

Judge: That will do it for this case. Litigants for the next case on the way into the courtroom right now.

dialogue:
**[Judge]**  
Okay, you’ve asked to be referred to only as Lynn. Lynn, you are suing Irvin Robinson for $275, the amount it’s going to cost to fix your car, which you say was damaged as a result of his negligence. Tell me what happened.

**[Plaintiff]**  
Okay. August 24th, I was in my car, parked. Keys on the dash, car shut off, windows down.

**[Judge]**  
Yeah.

**[Plaintiff]**  
Because I have a smart car, and if you have the windows down, you have to turn the car off, or the car will go *ding ding ding ding*. So, I take the keys out, put them on the dash, and I’m reading, waiting for my witness to come out of the store.

**[Judge]**  
Who’s your witness?

**[Plaintiff]**  
My son.

**[Judge]**  
Okay.

**[Plaintiff]**  
While I was reading, I felt my car—

**[Judge]**  
What were you reading?

**[Plaintiff]**  
I was reading a book. I have it with me. Uh, it’s called—I can’t remember right now, I’m nervous. But I was reading my book, and I felt my car moving.

**[Judge]**  
*50 Shades of Grey*?

**[Plaintiff]**  
No! It wasn’t! It’s called *Some People Some Other Place*, I’m sorry.

**[Judge]**  
Okay.

**[Plaintiff]**  
I felt my car moving. I look up, I see a van coming on the side of my car. He’s coming across, he’s moving my car.

**[Judge]**  
Moving your car with his van?

**[Plaintiff]**  
With his van! Shaking! I turned the car on, started blowing the horn.

**[Judge]**  
You have to turn the car on to blow the horn?

**[Plaintiff]**  
Yes, I had to turn it on. So I start blowing the horn. He continues on into the parking spot.

**[Judge]**  
Wait, wait. He hits you as he goes into the parallel park?

**[Plaintiff]**  
He’s sliding right across my car going into the spot in front of me.

**[Judge]**  
Okay.

**[Plaintiff]**  
So, I get out of my car. My witness is coming across the street.

**[Judge]**  
Why are you out of the car?

**[Plaintiff]**  
I said something happened here. I said my car was shaking. I want to see—I hope he didn’t damage my car. We look down. We see that it’s scraped the front bumper. So I said to him, “What’s wrong with you?!” I probably cursed. I don’t—

**[Judge]**  
Who cursed?

**[Plaintiff]**  
I probably cursed. I was upset. And I said, “Look! Look at my car!”

**[Judge]**  
And?

**[Plaintiff]**  
He says, “Oh, listen, we don’t have to call the police or anything because I have a friend who has a body shop, and we can get the car fixed.” And at that point, he goes and gets inside his van.

**[Judge]**  
So you stand in front of his van?

**[Plaintiff]**  
Yes! That was crazy because he could have pulled off and hit me. But I stood in front of his van.

**[Judge]**  
What’s your son doing?

**[Plaintiff’s Son]**  
I took a picture.

**[Judge]**  
Did you take a picture?

**[Plaintiff’s Son]**  
Yes.

**[Judge]**  
Okay, let me see the picture.

(Reviewing picture)

**[Judge]**  
So what you’re saying is, he hit the front of your car as he’s going into the parallel park?

**[Defendant]**  
She pulled out while I was coming in to park, and my car was hit.

**[Judge]**  
Did you see her pulling out?

**[Defendant]**  
No, because I was already in my parking slot.

**[Judge]**  
Okay. The first time you realize that there’s a problem is when?

**[Defendant]**  
When I felt a bump.

**[Judge]**  
Okay. Well, it’s pretty clear to me that you weren’t moving. Your car is lined up. He doesn’t even claim to have seen you moving. So I find in favor of the plaintiff in the amount of $275.

Judge:
Thank you, Douglas. Mr. Whitman, you are representing Southshore Power Squadron as command and suing Ilana Vasquez for $180 for four persons' admissions to a Halloween party back in 2015. What’s going on?

Plaintiff:
Well, actually, 2014 was the Halloween party, and we did the Halloween party in conjunction with the local yacht club.

Judge:
What is Southshore Power Squadron?

Plaintiff:
We are an educational organization teaching safe boating through education. We’ve been in existence since November 10, 1928—just celebrated our 90th anniversary.

Judge:
Oh, good for you guys. All right, so you had this Halloween party in 2014.

Plaintiff:
Yes, I stand corrected.

Judge:
And then what happens?

Plaintiff:
Well, the treasury collected money from the participants, which included the defendant as well as other members of the squadron. They paid the fee via check to our treasurer. He, in turn, I in turn, turned over a check for the amount of money collected to the yacht club.

Judge:
Okay.

Plaintiff:
Unfortunately, this involved an evening of open bar, 15-16 dishes of food—

Judge:
Was everybody in costume?

Plaintiff:
Yes, in costume. Prizes for best costumes.

Judge:
Did everybody participate, or did some people come not in costume?

Plaintiff:
No, everybody participated.

Judge:
Do you have pictures of your costume?

Plaintiff:
No.

Judge:
What did you go as?

Plaintiff:
Oh boy, it was so long ago I don’t remember.

Judge:
Come on, you dress up every Halloween. You remember.

Plaintiff:
I think it was a doctor’s uniform.

Judge:
Okay. So, they paid, and then what happened with your treasurer?

Plaintiff:
Well, what he did is he put the checks in a folder, similar to what these are, put it away, and forgot about it. It wasn’t until April or May of 2016 that he realized the checks were never deposited.

Judge:
By this time, the checks had gone dead?

Plaintiff:
Well, they’re stale.

Judge:
Why did he not deposit them? You mean none of the checks or just some of them?

Plaintiff:
None.

Judge:
Is he still your treasurer?

Plaintiff:
No.

Judge:
Was he still treasurer after this debacle?

Plaintiff:
Yes.

Judge:
How much longer?

Plaintiff:
Well, I’ll explain that. Everyone gave replacement checks.

Judge:
Okay, and then what happened?

Plaintiff:
He did the same thing again.

Judge:
Are you kidding me?

Plaintiff:
No, I’m being very honest.

Judge:
When did the accountant get fired?

Plaintiff:
He only resigned about three months ago.

Judge:
Why did you keep him for so long?

Plaintiff:
We’re a volunteer organization. Nobody is paid.

Judge:
Okay, so what happened next?

Plaintiff:
I took over again in 2017. In July 2017, we realized two checks were still outstanding, one of which was the defendant’s.

Judge:
Okay. Ms. Vasquez, you went to the party, had fun, and wrote a check. Then they asked you for a replacement check, and you gave them one. Then they asked for another, and you gave them another. And now they want another one.

Defendant:
Yes.

Judge:
Why won’t you pay again?

Defendant:
If I give you a check and you forget to cash it, do I still owe you the money? I don’t think so.

Judge:
Going inside the courtroom...

Defendant:
It’s not a matter of not paying. Each of us gave them a check of $90 the night of the party. Then we also paid a second time. Now they’re asking for a fourth check.

Judge:
Yeah, I don’t blame you for being frustrated. Did you quit the organization?

Defendant:
Yes, in 2018.

Judge:
And then you got a letter from Mr. Whitman?

Defendant:
Yes, and it was insulting.

Judge:
Why?

Defendant:
It was aggressive. He said I better pay by a certain date, or else. It felt like a threat.

Judge:
Let me see the letter.

[Examines Letter]

Judge:
This is severe under the circumstances.

Plaintiff:
I don’t think so.

Judge:
Well, I’m going to tell you—because this may be your first time in court, but it’s not mine—if you’d been a little nicer, we wouldn’t be here. But you still have to pay.

Defendant:
[Scoffs]

Judge:
I’m not ordering you to pay interest because the only reason you’ve had to wait three years is because of the incompetence of your treasurer. But I am ordering you to pay the $180. Should I make you pay the $15 court fee? I can’t decide. Usually, when someone wins, they get their court costs covered. Yes, I’ll order that too.

Judge:
But here’s a word of advice: I tell my children, “Say it, forget it; write it, regret it.” Assume that what you write will be interpreted in the worst way possible. Rewrite it. Especially when you’re asking someone to do something. Don’t threaten them.

[Verdict:]
Verdict for the plaintiff. Defendant must pay $180 plus $15 in court fees.

Judge:
This is the plaintiff, Aila Brebnor. She says she was driving down the street one day and she saw the defendant drop his wallet out of his car on the next block. She caught up with him and informed him where he dropped his wallet. The guy opened his car door, striking her side view mirror, and he knocked the thing clean off her car. The defendant now refuses to repair her car. Her good deed’s not going to cost her the $500 she’s owed, so she’s suing.

Judge:
This is the defendant, Deid. He says the plaintiff got all crazy because the mirror fell off her car and he said he’d have it fixed if she sent him an invoice from a reputable repair shop. She told him it was going to cost 160 bucks. Then, next thing he knows, her father calls him, ranting and raving, demanding $500 from him. He feels as though he’s being conned. He didn’t even touch the girl’s mirror, and he wants to let the judge decide what’s right. He’s accused of sideswiping a girl.

Judge:
All parties, please use your seats.

Clerk:
This litigant has been affirmed.

Judge:
Thank you. You’re welcome. Okay, Akila Brebnor, correct? You are suing Deid for $500, $152 of it to repair a damaged mirror and $348 for missed work. What happened?

Plaintiff (Aila Brebnor):
Okay, so we were driving down the street on the North Conduit. At that time, he’s sitting in the passenger seat of the vehicle. He opens the door—

Judge:
While he’s driving?

Plaintiff (Aila Brebnor):
While he was sitting. He was at a red light.

Judge:
Oh, he’s at a red light. Correct.

Plaintiff (Aila Brebnor):
The door opens, his wallet falls out to the floor. The light turns green, I’m not able to step out to get it, so I continue to drive. I match up to like the passenger back door, and I’m like waving them down. His son opens the window and I said, "Your wallet, your wallet!" I drive up, I state to him, "I said your wallet fell back there." He steps out.

Judge:
Who’s he? I’m sorry.

Plaintiff (Aila Brebnor):
The defendant steps out.

Judge:
Is he the passenger or the driver?

Plaintiff (Aila Brebnor):
He’s the passenger.

Judge:
Okay.

Plaintiff (Aila Brebnor):
He steps out. Our car is like about this leveling, and that’s how close you are. As close as your hands are. He opens the door and what happens?

Plaintiff (Aila Brebnor):
It taps my car mirror on the driver’s side. I say to him, "Don’t open it, the light just turned green." Wait, so as my car rolls a little bit, he pushes it more, slides out from the car, and the mirror on my driver’s side just falls off.

Judge:
Okay, what happens then?

Plaintiff (Aila Brebnor):
He starts running down North Conduit. His son screams “Pop” or “Dad” in their language, runs out the car with him. They’re running down to North Conduit. I stay to the driver, "Do you have insurance? You have registration, something?" He states, "No, it’s not my car, it belongs to the defendant." I said, "Okay, so we pull over to the side. I’m waiting for him to come back." He says he comes back and he states, "I’m going to exchange my information with you." I said, "Okay, well, do you have any insurance?"

Judge:
No insurance?

Plaintiff (Aila Brebnor):
No, I don’t have insurance. I’m like, "Well, how don’t you have insurance?"

Defendant (Deid):
Well, because the car belongs to the Air Force. I work for the Air Force. I’m a chaplain in the Air Force, and the car doesn’t belong to me.

Plaintiff (Aila Brebnor):
Who does the car belong to?

Defendant (Deid):
My ex-girlfriend.

Plaintiff (Aila Brebnor):
Is she in the Air Force?

Defendant (Deid):
No, I am.

Plaintiff (Aila Brebnor):
Did you tell her?

Defendant (Deid):
Well then, why did you tell them the car belonged to the Air Force?

Defendant (Deid):
I never told her that. It has Air Force plates.

Judge:
She asked.

Defendant (Deid):
Okay, can I speak? First of all, I want to thank her for telling me about the wallet.

Judge:
Do you?

Defendant (Deid):
Yes. No, no, no. Wait, wait, wait. Wait. Because we’re going to get there in a minute. She tells you about the wallet, you open the door, and you knock her mirror off. If it was me, if anybody did it, it was me.

Judge:
Okay. So you exchange information, did you have insurance on the car?

Defendant (Deid):
Sure, your own. Has it. I gave it to the—

Judge:
Okay, did you give it to her?

Defendant (Deid):
No, why not?

Defendant (Deid):
I didn’t have it on me.

Plaintiff’s Father:
Okay, so now you are what to her?

Judge:
I’m her father.

Plaintiff’s Father:
Okay, and you get involved when what happens?

Plaintiff’s Father:
When she called me and she told me that she had an accident, I drove to where she was. I was expecting to see him there, but she told me he left. I called him when I got there. I said, “Why did you leave?” He said, “I’m going to a wedding.” My response was, "You had an accident. Did you exchange information?" He said, "No."

Plaintiff’s Father:
I said, "What happened to the insurance?"

Defendant (Deid):
I do not have insurance on the car.

Plaintiff’s Father:
I said, "So you’re driving in New York state without insurance?" He says, "Well, I don’t want to give you the insurance because it’s going to mess up my friend’s driving license. He wants to take care of it on his own."

Plaintiff’s Father:
Okay, this is what he said to me.

Plaintiff’s Father:
All right, and so then what happens? He decides he’s going to take care of it himself and he gives you some information to go to a place of his choosing. What happens when you get there?

Plaintiff’s Father:
So after we’re having a conversation on the phone, he states that the person can put the mirror on for $40, and if that doesn’t work out, after going to the individual twice, because he says sometimes you have to go back twice to get the job done properly, he can silicone the mirror on himself because he’s a contractor engineer.

Plaintiff’s Father:
So he went from a chaplain to a contracting engineer now?

Plaintiff’s Father:
Are you a chaplain or a contracting engineer?

Defendant (Deid):
Both.

Plaintiff’s Father:
Okay, I’m a licensed New York State engineer. He said he’s done them for 15 years and that he can silicone it himself, which I didn’t want to happen because the mirror works with air.

Plaintiff’s Father:
You need to give me a reason why you don’t want the guy who hit your car, who was careless enough to hit your car and knock your mirror off, to put your mirror back on. You don’t need to give me a reason why you don’t want to.

Plaintiff’s Father:
So I go to the individual he suggested. I went with my father. I did. I went with my father.

Plaintiff’s Father:
The individual did not have the mirror for my car. He tried to put a four-door mirror on my car. It wouldn’t work out, and it was black.

Plaintiff’s Father:
So we’re like, well, if you get the mirror for us, will you paint it?

Defendant (Deid):
No, I don’t paint. I just put it on and that’s it.

Plaintiff’s Father:
So he said, "Give me about an hour and I’ll see if I can find somebody that has a two-door silver one or a black one, and if not, then there’s nothing I can do." We waited an hour. We waited longer than an hour. He never called us back.

Plaintiff’s Father:
I went to my regular mechanic, who called within 5 minutes and was able to locate a mirror for my vehicle and also stated he can get it painted and put on without a problem.

Plaintiff’s Father:
Okay, and he got it done for how much?

Plaintiff’s Father:
$152.

Plaintiff’s Father:
Okay, do you have the bill?

Plaintiff’s Father:
I do.

Plaintiff (Aila Brebnor):
Okay, then now who contacts him to tell him, "Hey, we’re going to do it our way and it’s $152."

Plaintiff (Aila Brebnor):
I spoke with him, and I stated that, you know, I got the car fixed. I’m able to send you the bill. Can I have your information? He goes, "Well, first before I give it to you, how much does it cost?" So I didn’t want to give him the approximate because I wanted to see what he was going to do. I said, "Approximately $160."

Plaintiff (Aila Brebnor):
And he’s like, "Okay, well I told you where to go, that’s too much money," and he starts yelling at me. Is when—and that’s when I hand the phone to my father to have the conversation with him.

Plaintiff’s Father:
Okay, so let’s put a pin in it and let me hear from you.

Defendant (Deid):
I have, by the way, I have some recordings of this whole conversation, with the father, with the thing, even with the $160.

Judge:
Can I just ask you a question? How much money was in your wallet?

Defendant (Deid):
In my wallet? No money. Actually, it was my ID cards and my credit cards.

Judge:
What’s your time worth? Getting ID cards, cards, and credit cards again. I’m just kind of curious how it is that the young lady, who is the reason why you didn’t lose your wallet, has to go through all these hoops. Why is that? Over $10 and something bucks?

Defendant (Deid):
No, no. I told her, and I have a conversation of that, too, that, "I’m going to take care of it."

Judge:
The court has heard everything. Here’s what I’m ruling. You’ve knocked her mirror off. You didn’t do anything to fix the mirror, to try to come to terms with fixing it. It’s your responsibility. I’m awarding the plaintiff $500 for the damage, and you’ll make sure the mirror gets repaired.

Judge: Alan Madza, you are suing Dane for $250 that the two of you agreed he would pay you after he hit you from behind. What happened?

Plaintiff: So I was, uh, going home from work. I was driving home, and I was approaching an intersection, and I had the green light. And the police officer had his car, and he had his lights flashing.

Judge: So?

Plaintiff: And he was—

Judge: What? In the intersection?

Plaintiff: He’s in front of me.

Judge: Trying to cut in front of you?

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Judge: Okay. Go on.

Plaintiff: So I come to a stop because that’s the right thing to do.

Judge: His lights are on?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Oh. Oh. Okay. Was the siren on?

Plaintiff: Uh-huh.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: So about five to ten seconds later, um, I just get hit from the—from behind. The same police officer stops to see that everything is okay with us. And, uh, what he told—what the police officer told me himself is that he saw my car stopped, and then it got launched forward, like it got hit.

Judge: Okay. Did the police officer write a report?

Plaintiff: The police officer said it was optional to write a report, um, just because it’s just whether—how we want to settle it. So we just made an agreement. Judge: Samuel Rodriguez, you are suing Mike Karu and Captain Mike’s Diving Services, hello Captain Mike, represented by Mike, the owner, for $1,773.53—the amount that you paid him for scuba certification classes plus your cost of a trip that you consider wasted because you were not able to dive.

Judge: All right, and you have a counterclaim against him for fraud and defamation. Let me hear from you first.

Plaintiff: Okay, this is the line of the week. Every year I go on vacation with my family, and every year I come back more tired than I was before the trip.

Judge: I feel your pain. So tell me about it.

Plaintiff: So, um, May 4, I went to see Mr. Karu, and I told him that I was going to Mexico just to scuba. Even though I was going with my family, I was going to take four days just to scuba dive. Told him how hard I work for this vacation—overtimes and all these things.

Judge: When was this? You went to see him when?

Plaintiff: On, uh, March 4th, sorry.

Judge: March 4th. And when was your trip?

Plaintiff: May 13th.

Judge: Okay, almost two months apart.

Plaintiff: So he told me, "Okay, so do $450, you take some classes online, and then everything goes well. In two weeks, you have your certification."

Judge: Great.

Plaintiff: So I got my online classes—

Judge: So the part that he does—are the online classes free?

Plaintiff: No, no, it’s part of the $450.

Judge: How’s the online part work?

Defendant: I, uh, purchase them from PADI, which is the Professional Association of Diving Instructors—that’s the organization we teach for. I, uh, send the link to him.

Judge: Okay, so you send the link—that’s the only way he can do it, right?

Defendant: Right.

Judge: And that’s part of the $450. And then what do you actually do?

Defendant: You have to take them on two dives in a pool.

Judge: So you take them in a pool—

Defendant: Usually, it’s two-hour sessions, and there’ll be a number of skills that they have to perform before we can take them out in the open water.

Judge: And then they—so it’s two times in a pool and one time in the open water?

Defendant: There’s four dives they will do in the open water, and they’ll do the same skills in the open water as they did in the pool.

Judge: Okay. So what went wrong in this case? You didn’t get to the dives?

Plaintiff: No, I got my two pool sections.

Judge: Good.

Plaintiff: You know, I was very happy. And the last one, I asked him, "What’s next?" He said, "Okay, the open water." I asked him when. He said, "I’ll give you a call."

Plaintiff: Okay.

Judge: After a few calls, we make an appointment for April 28th.

Judge: That’s cutting it close. When was your trip? May 13th, right?

Plaintiff: Right. I go to the—I take my day off, went to the store, Mike wasn’t there.

Judge: Well—

Plaintiff: Next weekend—

Judge: Wait, wait. You go to the store, Mike’s not there. Do you tell them, "Get Mike on the phone, I’m supposed to go on a—"

Plaintiff: I call him in the week, and we make another appointment for the 3rd—next Saturday.

Judge: Wow, you’re very relaxed. Go on.

Plaintiff: I—I trust him.

Judge: What’s to trust him about? You’re cutting it too close. You’re skipping too much.

Judge: What happened? When did you call him, and when you got him, what did he say about not showing up?

Plaintiff: He said something about hitting his head.

Judge: You—hitting his head? Yes. What happened?

Defendant: No, I—I banged my head March 3rd, prior to his last lesson. So, yes, I was out of the pool for the first two pool sessions. I was present at the pool session, had another instructor do his work with him in a pool.

Judge: Okay. Did you fail to appear at your dive shop on the day that he was supposed to do an ocean session? Did he ever schedule the ocean sessions?

Defendant: The open water training dives did not happen because the days he was off and he wanted to go, weather did not permit, and it was not safe to do the dives.

Judge: Okay. How many times did he schedule ocean—the ocean part that weather didn’t permit?

Defendant: Twice.

Judge: Okay. So the last time—

Judge: And both times, were you present?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: And you said, "We can’t go out in this weather?"

Defendant: Correct.

Judge: Okay. And was he disappointed?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Okay. And how—what were the days that we’re talking about? Do you know the days? Does anybody write anything down?

Plaintiff: The 28th, then the 3rd.

Plaintiff: Okay. Went back to the store. Mike wasn’t there. They told me his wife was sick.

Judge: Back to the same thing—phone calls.

Plaintiff: I went to the store.

Judge: So are you telling me that you had ocean dives scheduled, and that you would show up for them, and Mike just wouldn’t show up, wouldn’t call you, wouldn’t cancel?

Plaintiff: Exactly.

Judge: Do you have any proof of that?

Plaintiff: Uh, no.

Judge: Okay, because he runs a dive shop, and I assume you are not the only diver there, correct?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: Are there any ocean dives that you just didn’t show up for?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Now, it becomes obvious that before his trip—when was the last ocean dive appointment?

Defendant: Uh, the 3rd.

Judge: What did you do between the 3rd and the—you went to Mexico when?

Plaintiff: The 13th of May.

Judge: Okay, that’s ten more days. You can do an ocean dive. Why didn’t you schedule it?

Plaintiff: Well, when I went back to the store on the 10th, I told him, "Mike, I’m leaving the 13th. Whatever’s got to happen from today to Saturday can—"

Judge: And today is what? What day do you call?

Plaintiff: Thursday.

Judge: You tell him on Thursday, "We need to have two dives between today and Saturday." And what happened?

Plaintiff: That’s when he pulls out these papers. "With this, you go to Mexico, and with, uh, this other proof of your classes, you will have no problem."
