dialogue:
Judge: This is the plaintiff, Bob Perry. He says he built a countertop and a stage at the defendant's performance space, and the woman flipped out after the job was completed and refuses to pay him for the materials he purchased for her. He did a great job, gave her free labor, and he's rip-roaring mad that he can't get her to pay him the $800 she owes him. So he's suing her.

Judge: This is the defendant, Adrien. She says the plaintiff led her to believe he was going to be renting her space, and that's why she allowed him to make some renovations. She let him paint the place black for his biker club meetings. He moved the stage to the other side of the room, and he built a new countertop. Then, the guy did an about-face, told her he wasn't going to rent the space after all, and demanded she pay him. No way! She's accused of billing a biker.

(All parties raise their right hands.)

Judge: Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiff built a countertop and stage at the defendant’s dance performance place and got stiffed. But the defendant says the plaintiff suckered her and made it seem he was renting the space for his biker club meetings. It’s the case of the gnarly Harley deal. Thank you.

Judge: Okay, Mr. Perry, you were part of a motorcycle club, correct?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Tell me about your motorcycle club.

Plaintiff: We—we’ve been a motorcycle club for 42 years. Uh, I’ve been in the club about that length of time.

Judge: Really?

Plaintiff: So, you know, we’re not young anymore. (Laughs) We ride, we do events, and, uh, we travel.

Judge: Okay. So your club was looking for a place to meet up?

Plaintiff: We were looking for a place to call our clubhouse.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: Because we lost our clubhouse about three years ago.

Judge: Okay. And so you find her place?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And you don’t own it. You were going to sublet it, correct?

Plaintiff: That was the idea.

Judge: So you two talk, and you like the place?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: All right. But in order to rent the place, you have to have the approval of the whole club?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: How’d that work?

Plaintiff: So I spoke to her about sharing space, okay, and we were willing to take three days a week and pay her $1,200 a month.

Judge: And she was fine with it?

Plaintiff: Seemed like it—until the last minute. And then she and her boyfriend told us that we have to pay, uh, by the hour.

Judge: So?

Plaintiff: We didn’t want it.

Judge: But I don’t understand. See, because part of your lawsuit is for improvements you made on the place. Why would you be making improvements before having a lease in place?

Plaintiff: No, no, no. I wasn’t making improvements for my club, so to speak. I was actually making improvements for her.

Judge: Was he making improvements for you?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Did you ask him to make the improvements?

Defendant: No, ma’am.

Judge: What improvements did he make?

Defendant: He painted the studio black.

Judge: And what color was the studio before that?

Defendant: White.

Judge: Okay. Why did you let him make improvements before you two had, like, a sublet lease in place?

Defendant: Because we are an art studio. We do have live performances. And if he’s renting for $1,200, which would substantially help out on the rent—

Judge: Except that you didn’t have a lease yet.

Defendant: Right.

Judge: When you say he’s gonna—he’s gonna—but he didn’t, right?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: So why—I’m just so confused—why you let him make improvements and why you make improvements when apparently it hadn’t been voted on yet and there was no sublet in place?

Defendant: He explained that in order for his club to approve, they would make minor adjustments, and I did feel it would be a bit of a benefit. Not so much the black walls.

Judge: Okay. So black walls and what else?

Defendant: He put in a very large counter. We call it a paint bar because we do a lot of sip-and-paint parties. We have a refrigerator there and a coffee pot.

Judge: Okay. So he put in a counter. And what else did he do?

Defendant: We already had a stage. The stage was actually built last March. He decided he didn’t like the stage and wanted to rebuild it.

Judge: Okay. So if you want to put in your money to rebuild something—

Defendant: Well, he’s now suing me for all that.

Judge: Yes, ma’am. Okay. Did you ever agree with him that if they didn’t rent it, you would pay for these improvements?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Did you ever say you would pay for the materials for these improvements?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Okay. And so you are suing her for the materials that you put in for those improvements, correct?

Plaintiff: That’s correct.

Judge: Do you have any proof that she—are you saying she agreed?

Plaintiff: Yes. My first, uh, conversation with her was that, uh, I’m—I’m not sure my club members would want to be here, but I can tell you, you do need to improve the place and make it—

Judge: Now, she said, "Well, go ahead and do whatever you like"?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Then show me how you sent her immediately, since she’s supposed to pay for it, how you sent her the receipt to get reimbursed.

(Defendant shows text messages.)

Judge: What am I going to see?

Defendant: You’re going to see where he sent me an original text saying his brother died, he hurt his leg, so on and so forth. I said, "I can help you out. You can throw a party there. You can do whatever."

Judge: What—what are we talking about? I thought these guys were just going to rent by the month?

(Conversation continues with Judge asking for proof, and neither party being able to provide it.)

Judge: Okay, really simple. It is insane to go in and make adjustments to a place before you sign the lease.

Judge: My verdict—zero for both parties, with the exception that Mr. Perry is entitled to retrieve his framed wall hangings.

Plaintiff: Okay.

Defendant: Okay.

Judge: Okay, T, you are suing Wendy for $500—$250 of it is money you loaned her, and the other $250 is for lost wages. You have a claim against him for $200 for wasting your time and lost wages. What happened here?

Plaintiff: On about the 6th of August, she asked to borrow money from me.

Judge: How did you know her?

Plaintiff: We met on a dating website.

Judge: How long earlier had you met on the dating website?

Plaintiff: Two weeks, three weeks.

Judge: Okay, and so she says to you, "I need some money to pay my mortgage," and that doesn't send you running in the opposite direction?

Plaintiff: No, it didn’t.

Judge: Okay, so you must have liked her.

Plaintiff: We had only met once before.

Judge: Oh, so why didn’t it send you running in the other direction?

Plaintiff: Just didn’t.

Judge: Okay, so what happens?

Plaintiff: She kept asking for a greater sum of money than I could.

Judge: How much money did she want?

Plaintiff: I think it was $1,200.

Judge: Wow, she’s bold. Alright. Who’s that with you?

Plaintiff: This is my friend.

Judge: Your friend, okay. Go on.

Plaintiff: And, um, she kept asking and asking, and I said, "Well, I can’t afford that amount right now because I have a lot of bills." And she said, "Well, then I was a waste of her time, as well as I'm a broke brother, and she doesn’t know why she chose me in the first place."

Judge: Okay, and then you loan her the money?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Oh, after she calls you a broke brother?

Plaintiff: Well, she had other choice words.

Judge: Do you have her in your phone?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: So, how long had you known him before you tried to hit him up for mortgage money?

Defendant: I had known him for maybe like a month and a half.

Judge: And then you asked him for your mortgage?

Defendant: No, that’s not how it went.

Judge: How did it go?

Defendant: Okay, him and I, we met on this dating website called Tinder. We both started liking each other, and then I invited him to come over. He said to me, "I’m coming over, I’m coming from work." I said, "Fine, it’s cool, I’m coming from work as well, and I’m a little tired." So when he came over to my house, he says, "Okay, I want to take a shower."

Judge: So?

Defendant: So I was like, "Okay." So he went in the bathroom to take a shower. When he came back—I have a sectional couch—you sleep on one, and I sleep on the other. So I was sleeping, and when I woke up, this man was staring at me.

Judge: Okay.

Defendant: So I’m like, "Okay, something’s wrong." So then he says, "Well, I don’t sleep. I don’t sleep that much." So I was like, "Okay." So I got up, I made us something to eat. So he says, "Well, do you like me? Do I look like my pictures?" I said, "You okay, you alright. Yeah, I like you. Let me just get a little time to know you."

Judge: And then?

Defendant: So I did tell him, I said to him, "I want a relationship, but it might not be something that I need right now." So he says, "Okay, don’t worry about it. I can work with it, I can work." So I said, "Alright."

Judge: Okay.

Defendant: So, um, he had promised me that our relationship was going to take its time and we were going to get to know each other. And he says that, um, maybe I could find a job over here, and I can move to Long Island, and then I can help you pay your bills and take care of you.

Judge: What?

Defendant: So I said, "Wait, wait, wait, slow down, slow down." I said, "You know, let’s take our time." So he was like, "Okay."

Judge: That was the first date?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: And then?

Defendant: So, um, maybe like a week later, I invited him back again. So when he came back the second time, he brought his son.

Judge: How old is his son?

Defendant: I think he’s like 14.

Judge: Okay.

Defendant: So I said to him, "Who is that?" He says, "This is my son."

Judge: Okay.

Defendant: So I said, "You didn’t know he was bringing his 14-year-old?"

Plaintiff: No.

Defendant: So I said to him, "Well, why didn’t you bring him the first time? Why didn’t you tell me about him?" He says, "Well, I didn’t have any place to leave him this time."

Judge: Okay, let’s move forward.

Plaintiff: She asked me for $1,200.

Judge: And you gave her?

Plaintiff: $250.

Judge: And she doesn’t have to pay it back because?

Plaintiff: She said because we had sex.

Judge: Right, just like that?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: I’d like to see the text messages.

[Plaintiff presents text messages]

Judge: I see in these texts, you’re saying if he doesn’t give you the money, you’ll just ask your ex-husband, and your ex-husband will expect sex.

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: And then he texts you that if you don’t pay him back, he’s going to say you stole it?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Alright. I also see that he says, "I just did you a favor," and you responded, "What favor? You paid for sex, and now you want your money back?"

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Alright, here’s what I think. Your countersuit for $200 is dismissed. And as for you, sir, I’m awarding you $250. Don’t loan out money to people you just met on Tinder.

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: Court is adjourned.

Judge: Valerie Kirkton Nance, yes? And Dempsey Reigns, yes? You are suing BNM Towing, represented here by Brian Shinen, the owner, for $180 that you want paid back to you because you feel that the car was inappropriately towed. Mr. Reigns, you're the one who parked the car, right? What happened?

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
I was, uh, giving people a ride to the store. Then, um, one was going to one store, one going to another store. Then we were going to meet back and... uh, who was going to what store? And what store were they going to?

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
They were going to... uh, Driftway. One was going to another store.

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
I went to check on my taxes across the street.

Judge:
Okay, and what were you doing? What do you mean by "check on your taxes"? You give it to...?

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
It was H&R Block across the street, right?

Judge:
You sat with them? You talked about it with them, and they either had them ready or they didn't. But what were you going physically to do over there?

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
I was going to pick them up.

Judge:
Okay, yeah. I asked, what time was this?

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
Around 6:00.

Judge:
Okay, what time did you get a call regarding the tow?

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
Approximately quarter to 7.

Judge:
Okay, who called you to tell you to tow the car?

Defendant (Brian Shinen):
An agent from the property. I was in the office, I got the phone call, gave me the car’s description and where the car was and the plate number.

Judge:
And they told you that the person, the one person, parked the car and walked straight across to H&R Block. When did you... So this is at 7:00. When did you get the call from somebody saying, "Hey, do you have my car?"

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
10:00 at night.

Judge:
Okay, so if you were just picking up your taxes, what time did you come back and notice your car missing?

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
Around 6:30.

Judge:
Okay, so what did you do?

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
I called the police, and I walked all the way back home.

Judge:
How far was back home?

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
About 10 to 11 blocks.

Judge:
Okay, and what did the police say to you?

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
Did you call the police first?

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
Yeah, I called the police.

Judge:
The police tell you the car had been towed?

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
Yeah, they looked it up.

Judge:
Right, so you already knew at 6:30 the car was towed. Why did it take until 10:00 if you were there by 6:30? Why did it take until 10:00 to call the tow company?

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
Well, they gave me the number.

Judge:
Right, but why did it take until 10:00?

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
Maybe you were at H&R Block a little longer?

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
No.

Judge:
Who's the gentleman with you? Was he in the car with you?

Plaintiff (Dempsey Reigns):
Yeah.

Judge:
Can I hear from him a second? Could you come up and you two switch places?

Thank you.

Judge:
What's your name?

James.

Judge:
All right, and are you related?

Plaintiff's companion (James):
Yes, that's my cousin.

Judge:
Okay, were you in the car?

Plaintiff's companion (James):
Yes.

Judge:
Tell me where you guys were going.

Plaintiff's companion (James):
We was going to M Avenue to go get my sister some soup and some medicine for her daughter and her son. Uh, my uncle, my cousin had dropped us off a block before Thriftway because we wanted to check a different store before we got to Driftway. Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands.

Bailiff: Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiff hired the defendant to provide a DJ for a party, but the DJ got into an accident, and now the defendant refuses to refund her money. The defendant claims the plaintiff canceled at the last minute. It’s the case of Can’t Stop the Music.

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Annette Dunlap, you are suing John M., the owner of a DJ company, for $1,500. You claim that you paid $300 for DJ services that were never provided, and you're also seeking additional costs, including bank fees and pain and suffering. Let’s start from the beginning.

Plaintiff's Side
Judge: Ms. Dunlap, what happened?

Plaintiff (Annette Dunlap): I hired the DJ company to provide music for my New Year's Eve party. I found them online because they had good reviews and offered a reasonable price compared to others. They quoted me $349, and I paid a $300 deposit in advance.

Judge: Had you used their services before?

Plaintiff: No, this was my first time. I spoke to a woman named Amanda V., who was my primary contact throughout.

Judge: Did you ever speak to the defendant, Mr. John M.?

Plaintiff: No. I only spoke to Amanda V. I was told to contact Mr. M. when I started asking for my refund, but he never responded to my calls.

Judge: What happened the day before the event?

Plaintiff: I received a call from Amanda. She told me that the DJ assigned to my event had been in a car accident and could not make it.

Judge: What solution did they offer?

Plaintiff: Amanda said I had two options:

Get a refund, or
Hire a different DJ through another company, but that would cost $500 instead of $300.
Judge: Did you ask why you had to pay an extra $200?

Plaintiff: Yes, I asked why they wouldn't cover the difference, since it was their DJ who couldn’t make it. Amanda didn’t give me a clear answer. At that point, I told her I would take the refund instead.

Judge: Did you get anything in writing about the refund?

Plaintiff: Yes. I asked for an email confirmation, and she sent one. But it wasn’t from Amanda—it was from someone named Roxanne Simonetti.

Judge: Who is Roxanne Simonetti?

Defendant's Side
Defendant (John M.): She’s a secretary at my company.

Judge: Mr. M., can you explain why Ms. Dunlap was told the DJ was in a car accident?

Defendant: I don’t know anything about that.

Judge: You don’t? Because I have an email here, sent from your secretary, which clearly states, "The DJ that was scheduled to do your event was unfortunately in an accident and won't be able to attend." Did your secretary make that up?

Defendant: I have no idea why she would say that.

Judge: So you're saying there was no car accident?

Defendant: No, not that I know of.

Judge: Then why did your secretary lie to your customer?

Defendant: I don’t know.

Judge: That’s interesting because you originally claimed that the plaintiff canceled on you.

Defendant: That’s correct.

Judge: So which is it? Did she cancel, or did your DJ back out because of a supposed accident?

Defendant: She canceled.

Judge: So if she canceled, why would your secretary send an email saying your DJ was in an accident?

(Pause. The defendant appears visibly nervous.)

Defendant: I don’t have an answer for that.

Judge's Analysis
Judge: Here’s what I think happened: You overbooked yourself for New Year’s Eve. You had multiple events going on, and you didn’t have enough DJs. When you realized that you couldn’t fulfill all the contracts, you started choosing which clients to keep—probably the ones who were paying the most. Then, rather than being honest, you lied to Ms. Dunlap and tried to push the extra cost onto her by suggesting a $500 alternative.

Defendant: That’s not true.

Judge: It is true, and you know how I know? Because if Ms. Dunlap had canceled on you, there would be no need to mention a car accident at all! The fact that your secretary sent that email proves that you canceled on her.

(The defendant remains silent.)

Plaintiff’s Additional Costs
Judge: Ms. Dunlap, you’re also suing for $400 in bank fees and $500 in pain and suffering. Explain.

Plaintiff: I had to make multiple bank transfers and cover extra fees while trying to sort this out.

Judge: What about the pain and suffering?

Plaintiff: I went through a lot of stress trying to find a last-minute replacement. My boyfriend helped me find someone, but I had to negotiate, and it was a hassle.

Judge: How much did you pay for the replacement DJ?

Plaintiff: Another $300.

Judge: So, in reality, you’re only out $300, correct?

Plaintiff: Well, yes, but I also had to—

Judge: I understand it was stressful, but pain and suffering is not something I typically award in small claims court for a business contract issue.

Final Verdict
Judge: Here’s what I’m going to do. I am ordering the defendant to refund the original $300 deposit. You don’t get an additional $300 because that would mean you get a free DJ. Your bank fees are not directly tied to the defendant’s actions, so I will not award those. Pain and suffering is also denied.

My judgment is for the plaintiff in the amount of $300.

Closing Remarks
(Gavel bangs.)

Bailiff: The judge has ruled in favor of the plaintiff for $300. Court is adjourned.

(Outside the courtroom, the plaintiff smiles while the defendant shakes his head.)

Plaintiff: I’m happy I at least got my money back. They should have just been honest from the beginning.

Defendant: I still don’t think I did anything wrong. It’s just business.

Bailiff: That’s it for The People’s Court.

Judge: Can a landlord deny someone based on disability?

Defendant: I don’t think it’s right, but they can.

Judge: Actually, they cannot. That’s against the law. Verdict for the plaintiff, $1,765.

Defendant: I thought returning $1,500 was fair.

Judge: But you were the one who changed your mind, not her. Pay the full amount.

Court Officer: Case closed.

Defendant: "Oh, Your Honor, it's not like that all the time. I have brought it up, like, at the times."

Plaintiff: "She doesn't need monetary help for our daughter. This is about revenge. This is clearly about getting back at me and punishing me for not, I don't know, staying with her forever."

Court Clerk: All parties, please raise your right hand. Be seated. Come to order, please.

Judge: Maryann Gambella?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: You are suing Yolette Cherubin Hy for $5,000 in personal injury that you say you have undergone as a result of her negligence in maintaining a sidewalk?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Okay. What happened?

Plaintiff: Well, um, it was actually last August, August 12th. It happened to be my birthday. I was out for dessert with my husband, my son, and his girlfriend in the next town from where I live. And after we had dessert, I decided that I wanted to walk home to burn off the calories from dessert.

Judge: So alone?

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Judge: On your birthday? You couldn't get any of these guys to walk back with you?

Plaintiff: I can't believe I wanted to walk then.

Judge: I know. Well, they need to want to walk too.

Plaintiff: Not so much into their weight as I am.

Judge: Okay, so you decided to walk home.

Plaintiff: And, um, must have been about maybe four blocks from where the ice cream parlor was that I came upon the sidewalk.

Judge: Was it day or night?

Plaintiff: It was around 7:00 at night.

Judge: Was it light or dark?

Plaintiff: It was light.

Judge: And the walk was going to be how far?

Plaintiff: I would say approximately about a mile and a half.

Judge: Great.

Plaintiff: So I was walking along, and I came to this part of the sidewalk. I could see that it was rough. As I walked over it, my foot twisted, and then I started to fall, but my right foot caught into a piece of concrete, and I went down.

I was knocked unconscious, and the next thing I knew, there was a young man standing over me saying, "Lady, lady, you all right?" You know, it's so funny because when my foot caught, it was like everything went in slow motion. I knew I was going down. I knew it was going to happen. But I didn't realize that I had actually passed out.

So there was this young fellow—I guess he was coming home from work. He said, "Don't worry, I called the police. I called an ambulance."

Judge: Come on up, husband. How much time had passed when you got that phone call? Were you already expecting her?

Plaintiff’s Husband: Maybe only about 15 minutes.

Judge: All right, so you get the phone call from him, and he says your wife had a fall?

Plaintiff’s Husband: Right. He said, "Well, there's been an accident." I said to him, "Is she okay?" He said, "Oh yeah, yeah. She was unconscious, but she looks like she slipped on the sidewalk. There's police here now, and the ambulance will be here any minute." And I was there in like five minutes.

Judge: Okay. So what were your injuries? You ended up having to have dental surgery?

Plaintiff: So when I got to the hospital, I knew that I cut my forehead open. They told me they would have to put in stitches, internally and externally. It came to about 35 stitches.

Judge: 35 stitches? Wow.

Plaintiff: Yes. And then my husband said to me, "Do you know that you chipped three teeth?" The minute I heard that, I said, "It's one thing when I have 35 interior and exterior stitches on my head, but chipping my teeth? No, I can't go out looking like that."

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: Well, I paid a fortune for these teeth—they're all veneers. So I was like—

Judge: So you had to go in for dental surgery?

Plaintiff: Yes, I did. I went to the dentist a few days later, and it was $3,000 to repair those three teeth—$1,000 a tooth.

I also thought that I had broken my leg, so they x-rayed my leg. They said it wasn’t broken but recommended that I go to an orthopedic doctor, which I did later. Then he sent me to physical therapy. It just became a whole fiasco.

Judge: What do you do for a living?

Plaintiff: Oh, I’m a retired RN.

Judge: Then why are you suing for $1,800 for lost wages?

Plaintiff: After I retired, I had opened up a small delivery service company, and I'm paid as I work.

Judge: Do you have any proof that you would have made $200 per day and that you lost nine days?

Plaintiff: Well, I have my tax return—

Judge: What she does have is—hold on.

Plaintiff’s Husband: The company she works for as an independent contractor wrote a letter saying she didn't show up.

Judge: Let me have that. Let me talk to you. When did you first learn that all this had happened?

Defendant: The house is a rental. A two-family rental.

Judge: Do you own it?

Defendant: I own the house, but I don’t live there.

Judge: Right. So you rent it out?

Defendant: The tenant moved out. It was when people were cleaning the house for me after the renters moved out that they found letters. A lawyer had sent me letters, and in one of them, it actually stated that she broke her hip.

Judge: Did you break your hip?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Why is your lawyer sending letters saying you broke your hip?

Plaintiff: I don’t know. I only hired the lawyer to find her.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hand. Welcome back to The People’s Court. The next case on the docket: the plaintiff says the defendant’s German Shepherd attacked her Viszla badly in a dog park. The defendant says it was just a scratch, so chill. It's the case of German attack. Thank you, Douglas.

Judge: Anna Chernovich, you are suing Roy Bamford, correct, for $2180.89 in vet bills that you say resulted from his dog. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: On December 23rd, at three o’clock in the afternoon, my daughter and I took the dog to the dog park.

Judge: What kind of dog do you have?

Plaintiff: It’s a Viszla. It’s a hunting dog.

Judge: What does that look like? Do you have a picture?

Plaintiff: Yes. You can just give her all of them. There’s a headshot somewhere in there.

Judge: So go on.

Plaintiff: We approached the orchard, which is a dog area where dogs are allowed off-leash. There were two dogs and two individuals present. My dog recognized one of the dogs and started to run over.

Judge: Is that the defendant’s dog?

Plaintiff: No. His dog, Bentley, approached. Our dog had played with Bentley maybe two or three times in the past.

Judge: And his dog played well with your dog before?

Plaintiff: Yes, so I was not concerned when I arrived at the dog park. There are usually a lot of dogs there. Bentley, however, approached my dog, growled, and my dog ran away. His dog proceeded to follow and within 10 seconds bit my dog. There was no fight. My dog did not cry out. I just noticed that out of the corner of my eye, something was wrong. He was running over to me, and he had this big gash on his side.

Judge: So you could see the gash?

Plaintiff: Oh yeah.

Judge: And your dog didn’t yelp or anything?

Plaintiff: I think it was out of shock. The skin was sort of like a triangular laceration and was sticking up. He started to just lick it immediately.

Judge: Do you have pictures of the wound?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: What did you do next?

Plaintiff: Right away, I was like, “Oh my God, this is a bad situation. We need to get him to the vet immediately.”

Judge: Well, like a thinking person would think that too, you know.

Plaintiff: Yes, so I went into Mommy Mode. Mr. Bamford and the other gentleman took a look at the dog, and I said, “Oh my God, I have to go right to the vet.” Mr. Bamford said, “It’s nothing but a tooth snag.”

Judge: What happened at the dog park, Mr. Bamford?

Defendant: I was at the dog park for maybe 15-20 minutes. Her dog entered from the side, started to run with them, changed course, and they collided. I turned around and saw a white spot on the dog. The dog has no hair, so in the collision, the tooth must have gone in, but it wasn’t a bite.

Judge: Did she see your dog bite her dog?

Defendant: No, she didn’t.

Judge: Did her dog yelp?

Defendant: There was no growling or barking. They were running, playing like they always do, and all of a sudden, we heard a yelp. They both split up, and I saw the white mark. I walked over, and two gentlemen were there. When she left, I asked if she wanted my phone number.

Judge: Why would you offer your phone number if it was just a collision?

Defendant: Because I’m a dog person, and I felt obligated.

Judge: Okay, so what ended up happening with the dog?

Plaintiff: We took him to the vet. He had surgery that afternoon. They cleaned the wound, stitched it up, and put a drain in. The next morning, he was feverish. My daughter would sit with him, cuddle with him, and put blankets on him.

Judge: And then what happened?

Plaintiff: By December 26th, he had to go back. The vet suspected an infection. It turned out he contracted streptococcus in his wound.

Judge: What did they do then?

Plaintiff: They gave him a different dose of antibiotics.

Judge: And did he recover?

Plaintiff: He developed three sacs of fluids. He had to be brought back constantly. Eventually, he leaned against furniture, knocking over a speaker and breaking his toe.

Judge: And you’re suing him for that because…?

Plaintiff: Because if he hadn’t been in pain from the bite, he wouldn’t have leaned against the furniture.

Judge: And if you had secured the speaker, he also wouldn’t have had a broken foot.

Defendant: Exactly.

Judge: Mr. Bamford, did you ever offer to pay anything?

Defendant: Yes, I sent a check for $1,000. She refused it.

Judge: In your state, there’s a strict liability rule. If your dog causes damage, you’re responsible. However, the broken toe is too attenuated. I find in favor of the plaintiff for $1426.89. Case closed.

Plaintiff: Well, my son was married to the respondent and he died. They had a child that's now three years old that has been left in my custody, and I'm asking for some sort of relief or support because I'm retired from the military and on a fixed income.

Judge: Okay, first of all, my condolences for the loss of your son and thank you for your service as well. How long has the child lived with you?

Plaintiff: Two years.

Judge: Has mom given you any support for the child?

Plaintiff: No, she hasn’t. Not significantly, no. But I haven’t had—I’ve just now come to the point where I need some relief and I need some help.

Defendant: Well, I’ve been traveling. My job had me traveling a lot, and I was in between jobs. I'm making 35,000 now. And you know, I'm not—I’m a travel agent. Okay. So because of that, I can just travel. I get discounts, and I get the flight free.

Judge: That is amazing. But that has nothing to do with you giving some sort of financial support for your child.

Defendant: It is my child, that is correct. But like I said, my job had me traveling, and I really didn’t have the extra money.

Judge: What are you doing with yourself every day? What do you do? Tell me about your travels.

Defendant: Well, I had got this new condo for one thing. And you know that it’s so expensive.

Judge: Wait a minute. And you’re traveling. How much is this condo?

Defendant: It’s pretty steep. I like to live nice. And so I pay 5,000 a month.

Judge: See, you know what? You obviously came here to waste my time.

Defendant: No, no, I didn’t really, I didn’t.

Judge: Is this three-year-old in daycare?

Judge: What, how much is daycare?

Plaintiff: A daycare runs about 300 a week. He’s autistic, so he has special needs and counseling.

Judge: Counseling. Does mom show up to any of those doctor’s visits or anything?

Plaintiff: Well, no, of course, I haven’t always told her, but—

Defendant: They haven’t expected I would come.

Judge: Well, you haven’t given him any money either.

Plaintiff: Now, I don’t have anything against my former daughter-in-law. I mean, she was married to my son, but I do need a little more involvement and a little help.

Judge: I agree with you. Definitely, if she’s spending 5,000 a month to own a condo—

Defendant: I don’t even stay in the condo, ma’am. I need that. I have to have that. I need that. I have to have that.

Judge: So we’re going to go ahead and make that happen today. And the child has been living with you for the past two years, you say?

Plaintiff: Two years.

Judge: In Texas, we’re only allowed to take 9% of her gross. So based on 9%, the child support will be 262.50.

Defendant: I can’t afford that.

Judge: Well, sell your condo, then maybe you can afford it.

Defendant: Will that start—can you give me maybe three months before that starts so I can re-budget my bills?

Judge: Um, no.

Defendant: I had a question. Why are you being so hard on me?

Judge: Ma’am, I’m not being hard on you. You have not given this man any type of child support to support your child. And then you come to court and say you don’t have money, but you travel.

Defendant: I just don’t have it.

Judge: Well, I can’t help you.

Judge: Okay.

Judge: Now, your back child support comes out to 394.56. You have to pay that back from the time that the child has lived with Mr. Schaefer.

Defendant: Wow, that’s not fair.

Judge: Yes, ma’am. In Texas, it goes back four years. Your child is three. So with that calculation, it comes out to 14,204 dollars and 16 cents to be paid monthly at an amount of 200. That makes your total child support obligation.

Well, I’m going to make it 300 because 14,000 is a huge amount. So that makes your monthly child support obligation 694.56.

Defendant: I got some receipts that I can show you. I just can’t afford them.

Judge: And you know what? He has bills that he can show me as well, and you have not done anything.

Judge: Welcome back to the People's Court. Next case on the docket, the plaintiff says the day after she bought a car from the defendant, it died. But the defendant says it was a 1999 Cougar and in fine shape. It's the case of the Cougar that...

Judge: Thank you. You're welcome. Carolyn Gardner Hodnik, you are suing Jeffrey. You've asked us not to use your last name. You're actually suing his company. You're the owner?

Defendant: Yes, I am.

Judge: Okay. You purchased the car for $2,414.50 that you want returned to you, and the purchase price of the car plus repairs that you put into it because, according to you, you bought a lemon. Tell me what's going on.

Plaintiff: Okay. On February 5th, my husband and I went to his business to pay for the car. He actually made provisions for us on a Sunday, usually not open on a Sunday.

Judge: Prior to this, had you ever done business with him before?

Plaintiff: Yes. In the past, my husband bought a car from him a few years ago, and the car was perfect. That's how we knew of him. So it's not like we just went to some stranger or anything like that. So we did do business with him in the past. So nonetheless, we went there on the 5th, we paid for the car.

Judge: What kind of car?

Plaintiff: A 1999 Cougar.

Judge: And how much did you pay?

Plaintiff: It was $2,000.

Judge: Okay, and then what happened?

Plaintiff: When we went to start the car, the car did not start.

Judge: At the dealership?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: Yes. So he was like, "Well, I'll have my mechanic look at it and everything like that." And I'm like, "Okay." So the next day he calls me and tells me that it needs a new starter. But he didn't make any money off the car when the guy traded the car in and that I would have to pay for half of the starter. Never produced a receipt or anything. Told me it was $175.

Judge: Why didn't you just walk away?

Plaintiff: He told me there were no refunds.

Judge: How could there not be a refund when the car won't even come off the lot?

Plaintiff: I can't answer that.

Judge: Why would you put up with such an answer?

Plaintiff: I have things here saying how many times I've called him, and he said it's written on my receipt.

Judge: Why would there not be a refund on a car that hasn't even—you can't even deliver it, you can't even call.

Defendant: There would have been a refund if she didn’t want the car. I would have gladly given her money back.

Judge: So do you tell them that "I have to put in a new starter, it's going to cost X, do you want to back out, what do you want to do?" What is it you say to them?

Defendant: No, I didn't ask her if she wanted to back out because she didn't say she wanted to back out. She wanted the car.

Judge: So when you say to them, "I put in a new starter, and guess what, you owe me half," what do they say?

Defendant: I told her it was costing $400 to repair the starter. I told her I sold the car to her at cost and if she wouldn’t mind paying 50% of it.

Judge: And she said?

Defendant: And she said, "Okay, she will do it."

Judge: Did she ever say to you, "No, I guess I just want my money back"?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Did you ever say to him, "Forget it, I don’t want to go through with the deal"?

Plaintiff: I said to him, "What are my other options?"

Judge: That’s not what your complaint says, though. Are you trying to make the case better now?

Plaintiff: No, ma'am.

Judge: Okay. So go on from there. You decide you're going to pay half the cost of the starter, and then what happened?

Plaintiff: I picked up the car Monday the 6th from the auto mechanic. We drove it. On the 7th, the 8th, on Thursday, the check engine lights come on. I called him and I said, "The check engine lights are coming on, there’s a grinding sound when I start the car." He’s like, "Okay, you know there’s a one-year warranty on the starter, bring it to me if there are any problems."

Judge: And did you bring it back?

Plaintiff: I parked the car in my driveway Friday. I go to start the car, and the car does not start at all. I call him, leave a message at 10:00 at night expecting to get a phone call back from him the following day. It’s 1:00 in the afternoon, no phone call, nothing. I call him. "Jeff, the car won’t start." And he’s like, "Well, what’s wrong with it?" I said, "I’m not a mechanic." He’s like, "Well, what do you mean it won’t start?" I said, "Exactly, it does not start."

Judge: Did you have it towed back?

Plaintiff: Yes, on the 13th.

Judge: And what happened next?

Defendant: I had a mechanic look at it, checked everything, and the car was fine. I returned it to her house.

Judge: Did you tell her you were dropping it off?

Plaintiff: No. He left my keys in my mailbox.

Judge: Did you hear back from her after that?

Defendant: Yes, she left a note listing new complaints about the car.

Judge: And?

Defendant: The transmission slipping, a rumbling sound, check engine light. I checked, added antifreeze, drove it up the block, no issues.

Judge: The state law requires certain warranties for used cars, but with over 100,000 miles, only safety at the time of sale is required. Did you have any additional warranty?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Then your claim for a refund doesn’t hold. You assumed risks with an old car. Case dismissed.

Judge: Thank you. Doug John and Joseph Hayes, yes, you are suing Benjamin Genta for $2,935, the cost of a motorcycle that you want to return to him because you say that it is defective, pain, and suffering, mileage, tolls, and mechanic’s fees. Tell me what’s going on.

Plaintiff (John Hayes): Correct. My son purchased a motorcycle from Mr. Genta. Mr. Genta gave him on two occasions in writing a 30-day warranty.

Judge: How old is your son?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): 21.

Judge: How many times did you look at the bike before you bought it?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): Twice, I believe.

Judge: Did you test drive it?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): No, he wouldn’t allow me to.

Judge: Did you have a mechanic look at it?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): No.

Judge: How many bikes have you owned?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): This was my first.

Judge: Okay. Go ahead.

Plaintiff (John Hayes): My son and his girlfriend were there, went and looked at the motorcycle, and he gave Mr. Genta a $50 deposit. When it was time to pick it up, I went with him.

Judge: You did go with him. Okay.

Plaintiff (John Hayes): When he arrived home that evening, he had said to me that Mr. Genta had given him a 30-day warranty in writing, which I gave to the court as evidence.

Judge: Let me see the original.

Plaintiff (John Hayes): The original is the handwritten one. That’s what I want.

Judge: Okay, thank you.

Plaintiff (John Hayes): 30-day guarantee on all non-wear and tear items.

Judge: Was that something he just offered up or something you demanded?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): It wasn’t a demand. He swore by his work and his bikes, and his words. I said, “Would you be willing to put it in writing?” and he said, “Absolutely, no problem.” And in front of myself and my girlfriend, he took out a pad and a pen, asked for my driver’s license, and wrote it up right there. That’s why I had him sign it.

Judge: So, he signed both?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): Yes.

Judge: Okay, go on.

Plaintiff (John Hayes): A little less than 200 miles on the motorcycle, my son had a problem with it starting.

Judge: How long after the purchase?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): About 10 or 12 days.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff (John Hayes): I instructed him to call Mr. Genta and let him know.

Judge: And what was the problem?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): At the time, I had no idea. It just wouldn’t start. It wouldn’t even turn over.

Judge: How was it manifesting itself?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): It turned over but it wouldn’t start at all. It just continued to crank and crank and crank, to the degree where I put the battery charger on it to make sure it wasn’t a battery issue.

Judge: And what did Mr. Genta tell you?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): Mr. Genta instructed him to bring it to him. When I spoke to him, I asked what was going on. Mr. Genta demanded $300 for the repair.

Judge: So, let me get this straight, you had the bike for how long before you had the issue?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): 10 to 12 days.

Judge: And Mr. Genta demanded $300 to take a look at it?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): Yes.

Judge: Okay, continue.

Plaintiff (John Hayes): I spoke with Mr. Genta myself, and I asked him why he was demanding the $300. He said, “You can’t expect me to check it out for nothing.” I said, “I sort of can, if there’s a warranty.”

Judge: And what happened next?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): I told him that standard practice with any motor vehicle is that if it’s under warranty, you bring it in for a diagnosis to see if the issue is covered.

Judge: So, what did Mr. Genta say?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): Mr. Genta said he wouldn’t look at it without the $300.

Judge: Okay. And you have a diagnosis from another mechanic?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): Yes, from a reputable shop. It cost $149 for them to diagnose the bike, and it took about an hour and 20 minutes to identify all the issues.

Judge: So, you’re asking for that diagnostic cost and the price of the bike?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): Correct.

Judge: What else are you claiming?

Plaintiff (John Hayes): Mileage, tolls, and other costs for repairs.

Defendant (Benjamin Genta): When I gave him the bike, it was in perfect working condition. He was just learning how to ride, and I suspect he may have damaged it.

Judge: Wait, stop. Are you saying the bike was fine when it left your shop?

Defendant (Benjamin Genta): Yes, it was.

Judge: Okay. And you gave him a warranty on the bike?

Defendant (Benjamin Genta): Yes, but I don’t usually warranty vintage bikes.

Plaintiff (John Hayes): He gave us a guarantee, not a warranty.

Defendant (Benjamin Genta): Right, it’s a guarantee. But I don’t normally guarantee vintage bikes.

Judge: So why did you give him a guarantee on this bike if you don’t do that?

Defendant (Benjamin Genta): Because I wanted to reassure him. But I don’t usually do that for vintage bikes.

Plaintiff (John Hayes): He promised to repair it under the guarantee.

Defendant (Benjamin Genta): Well, I didn’t agree to give a warranty.

Judge: The issue is whether the warranty or guarantee was honored. If it wasn’t, you breached the contract.

Defendant (Benjamin Genta): I didn’t breach anything. The bike was fine when I sold it.

Judge: I’ve reviewed the evidence and testimony. The bike was sold with a guarantee that was not honored when it failed. The mechanic diagnosed the issue, and you refused to honor the guarantee. I’m granting the plaintiff’s claim for the cost of the motorcycle, diagnostics, and reasonable expenses.

Judge: The verdict is in favor of the plaintiff in the amount of $1,653. The bike is to be returned to the defendant.

Plaintiff: "Yes, now he does. Yes."

Judge: "No, three years. He's been living with him."

Plaintiff: "Yes."

Judge: "So you want an increase in child support to do what exactly?"

Plaintiff: "To help my son, to buy things for my son."

Judge: "She's been letting you stay with her for three years. She pays for everything for your children. She feeds your children, she takes them to school, she pays for health insurance. She's literally doing everything. You're doing nothing."
Defendant: "But that's—that's her story. I'm doing more than that. So I'm doing exactly what I can. I cook, I clean, I um... do some of the stuff she has to do."
Judge: "Hold on, hold on. Cooking and cleaning for a house that you reside in—you don't get any credit for that, okay? You should do those things, right? But in terms of your children, what are you doing? Because she said she's doing everything."

Defendant: "Well, I don't know if he's still subscribing to the same psychic, but she charges—I think it's four hundred and twelve dollars a month."

Judge: "Okay, what does this psychic have to do with your child support?"

Defendant: "Well, because I just feel like if he can afford the psychic, then maybe he can afford the insurance, and I—I guess I feel that that is money that could have gone towards my education while we were married."

Judge: "That has nothing to do with me. I mean, you should have addressed that in your divorce, obviously. And whatever he pays a psychic, if he chooses to do that, that has nothing to do with your financial responsibility to your daughter."

Judge: "At least make sure the kids stay insured, okay? And you have to keep working because you're going to pay your sister child support. You understand that, right?"

Defendant: "But I don't make enough."

Judge: "Did you think you were going to come in here, not take care of them, and not pay child support for them?"

Defendant: "Well, I just think... I just think they're doing okay, and my sister can do it, right?"

Judge: This is the plaintiff, Nina. She says she worked as a yoga instructor at the Deon Studio and wasn’t paid for her services. She also took training classes and later found out the instructor was uncertified, making the training useless. She can’t get her training certificate. The woman is running a scam, and she’s here suing her for every penny of the $3,375 she’s owed.

Judge: This is the defendant, Carolyn McFerson. She says she offered the plaintiff the tools and training she needed to become a bar-certified yoga instructor. The plaintiff ended up quitting before she completed the required 200 hours of training. She has no obligation to give her a refund, and if anyone was left high and dry here, it certainly wasn’t the plaintiff. She’s accused of not being certified. The defendant has filed a counterclaim for $5,000 for breach of contract.

Judge: All parties, please be seated.

Bailiff: Litigants have been sworn in.

Judge: Nina, you found these folks how?

Plaintiff (Nina): On Craigslist.

Judge: On Craigslist, yes. And what was it you were looking for?

Plaintiff: I was looking for a certification that would help me start my fitness career.

Judge: Okay, so they had a program where if you paid a certain amount of money and taught a certain amount of classes in order to pay down that money, then in the end, you would be certified? Are they the certifying entity? How does that work? Is there like a national association of something?

Defendant (McFerson): Our studio is affiliated with Yoga Alliance. It’s a nonprofit that sets the standards for yoga teachers, but not all yoga studios have to abide by or subscribe to them. We do voluntarily. We certify the teacher, and if she chooses to register with them, then she could teach anywhere they’re recognized.

Judge: So hold on one second. Have you given out certifications to people before her? Is she the first person you ever handled?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Okay. How many have you given out before her?

Defendant: Gosh, I don’t know. I want to say at least up to 100.

Judge: And there’s never been a problem?

Defendant: No.

Judge: So, Nina, what exactly is the program that you bought into?

Plaintiff: I started with bar training and then...

Judge: Bar is separate from yoga, yes?

Plaintiff: Yes, it is.

Judge: B-A-R-R-E, bar class, right? I’ve done them. I just know that I can barely walk out afterward. Tiny movements, you don’t even look like you’re doing anything, and you’re dying.

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: So, you were going to get certified for both bar and yoga?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And what was that going to cost you?

Plaintiff: Together, the bar training was $1,250, and the yoga training was $3,200.

Judge: And now explain to me the part about where you have to pay if you don’t teach.

Plaintiff: In the contract, it states that we can work off the hours. Instead of having to pay $1,250 plus $3,200, I could work at $16 an hour to cover the costs.

Judge: Or pay?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: So, you specifically chose that program because it was a work-study program?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And then you started having problems when you got a full-time job elsewhere?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: What was the full-time job?

Plaintiff: Teaching bar and other fitness classes.

Judge: And how were you qualified to teach those if you still weren’t done getting certified?

Defendant: She completed the training for both yoga and bar.

Judge: So then, what was she still working towards?

Defendant: She was working to pay off the fees. She didn’t pay out of pocket. If she had, she would have gotten her certification and been on her way.

Judge: And then what went wrong?

Defendant: From the very beginning, she started flip-flopping. I have emails to prove it. First, she said she wanted to work two days a week.

Judge: Were the two days approved?

Defendant: Yes, I said okay.

Plaintiff: And then I got that full-time job. At first, I was paying them off. I told her I would pay for all Thursdays of the month.

Judge: Did she agree to that?

Plaintiff: Yes, she did.

Judge: And that’s in the contract as an option?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Then what happened?

Plaintiff: I heard she had sued five people for not finishing out their contracts.

Judge: So you decided not to finish yours?

Plaintiff: No, I heard one of them proved in court that it wasn’t in accordance with Yoga Alliance standards.

Judge: Are you prepared to prove that now?

Plaintiff: I am.

Judge: How?

Plaintiff: The teachers who trained us had just graduated before we started. Under Yoga Alliance standards, they weren’t qualified to teach us.

Judge: Show me the proof.

(Plaintiff hands over resumes.)

Judge: Where does it say they aren’t qualified?

Plaintiff: Under Yoga Alliance standards, trainers must have 500 hours of experience or two years of relevant experience.

Judge: And your proof that they didn’t have that?

Plaintiff: Their resumes.

Judge: Let me see.

(Examines resumes.)

Judge: It says here one of them interned elsewhere before coming to you.

Defendant: Yes, that counts toward experience.

Judge: Do you have proof they weren’t qualified?

Plaintiff: I don’t have specific proof.

Judge: That’s a problem.

Judge: You claim she sued other students.

Defendant: I sued two students, not five.

Judge: And what happened?

Defendant: One didn’t have a contract, so I lost. The other cried in court and won.

Judge: Wait... a man cried?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: And it worked?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: I might have cried, but I wouldn’t have succumbed.

Defendant: Oh, you would have.

Judge: Okay, Nina. You say the training was bad. But what’s your plan now?

Plaintiff: I don’t want to teach yoga anymore.

Judge: So now, you’re asking for a refund?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: But you haven’t proven she did anything wrong. And she’s given out 100 certifications.

Judge: Carolyn, you’re counter-suing for $5,000. Why?

Defendant: She left a hole in my schedule.

Judge: You can’t get money for that. What are your actual damages?

Defendant: She still owed me $1,040.

Judge: Nina, you owe her that.

Plaintiff: Sighs.

Judge: Plaintiff’s claim—denied. Defendant’s claim—granted for $1,040.

Judge: All right, Anthony Reel, you are suing Monty McCoy, Real versus McCoy, for $1,248.196. That you won't return to you. Okay, tell me what happened.

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): Yes, how you doing, Yan?

Judge: Good, how are you?

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): Okay. On May the 16th, I hired Mr. McCoy to come and lay some new sod down on my yard because my grass had weeds in it and it was looking a little bad, so I figured I’d get a whole new grass done, you know, have it dug up and had Mr. McCoy lay some new sod. The way I was referred to Mr. McCoy, one of my neighbors down the street had him do the same thing, and I liked the way it looked. So he gave me Mr. McCoy's phone number, and I called him. I gave him a down payment. Two days later, he came and dug up my old grass. The next day, he laid the new sod, and then I finished paying him.

Judge: Then I guess it looked good?

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): Yes, it looked good.

Judge: All right. What did he tell you about how to care for it?

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): He told me that he was going to come back a week later and lay some fertilizer down and he was going to cut the grass.

Judge: But what did he tell you about watering it or anything?

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): Yes, I know that everybody knows you have to water grass, old grass and new grass. So that’s what I did. I watered it every day. The rain helped; it rained a couple of days within that week.

Judge: Okay. He came back. Mr. McCoy came back. He said he laid some fertilizer down, he cut the grass. A few days later, my grass started browning. I called him back and said, "Mr. McCoy, you got to come back over here, my grass is brown." He comes over and he sees what's going on, and he started coming up with a lot of different excuses. "My kids played in the grass, ran on the grass." Did you water?

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): Yes, I did water it. I told him. Then he said he was going to take a sample of my grass. He thought I got a leak underground that's messing my grass up. He was going to take some of my grass and get a sample test done.

Judge: I said, okay. He comes back about a couple weeks later. It gets worse. This is where my pictures start. When it got worse, and by now it’s in June.

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): Okay, so go on.

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): I’m calling, calling, calling. He’s not answering my phone calls. He started ignoring my phone calls, right? So I had to trick him. I borrowed my daughter’s phone and I called him with another number. He answered that one, right?

Judge: Yes.

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): Yes, and I said, “Mr. McCoy, what are you doing? I paid you good money to fix my grass and look at my grass, it’s dying. What are you going to do?” He said, “Mr. Reel, I’ll be over there in two, three more days.” A week passed by, another week passed by. We’re getting into July now. I’m calling, calling, calling. He’s ignoring my calls, he’s not returning my calls. So now I decided I’m going to have to take him to court.

Judge: Okay. I have a question. Is this your house too, like that's part of your house, or is that the neighbor’s house?

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): Let me see. See what I mean? There, all your house or is this someone else’s?

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): No, this is the neighbor. I didn’t get to this part. This neighbor down the street, grass died that he did.

Judge: Wait, next door to you?

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): No, about four houses down.

Judge: Oh, whose... Wait a minute, wait a minute. Are those... Did you hand me everything you handed me were pictures of your house?

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): No.

Judge: Oh, for the love of God, when were you going to tell me that?

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): I got it on the back.

Judge: Okay, I’m sorry. That’s the neighbor whose grass you had seen and said, "Ooh, that looks good. I want me some of that before his died."

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): Okay, before his died. Okay.

Judge: Is the neighbor suing him too?

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): No, the neighbor, after the neighbor's grass died, he figured he better fix it. He fixed it. I got a picture in there.

Judge: Wait, to fix the neighbor’s?

Plaintiff (Anthony Reel): But not mine. Not mine.

Judge: I think they’re friends. I’m not sure. I don’t know why, but I have a picture... What’s going on?

Defendant (Monty McCoy): Good morning, Judge. This is what’s actually happening. Mr. Reel contacted me. I work in an area. I’ve got 72 houses that I basically maintain their area alone. He approached me, telling me something about he had a contractor do some popcorn ceiling in his house. He said the yard was contaminated from the popcorn ceiling chemicals.

Defendant (Monty McCoy): I told you what I can do. I tore it up, treated the soil, fertilized the soil. How do you treat the soil?

Defendant (Monty McCoy): With lime and liquid fertilizer, and that should take care of the chemicals from the popcorn ceiling.

Defendant (Monty McCoy): Well, that’s what we were trying to do, you know, use lime. Lime usually kills or neutralizes any chemical contaminants, usually.

Defendant (Monty McCoy): I did exactly what Mr. Reel asked me. Now, the first 7 to 10 days, you must not water it, saturate sod, not just water it but saturate it. Did you tell him that?

Defendant (Monty McCoy): I explained that to him and every other client.

Defendant (Monty McCoy): What he did, if you look clearly at stuff, it’s drying out. It’s not exactly dying; it’s drying out. If you look very closely, it’s drying out.

Judge: How do you dry out when you water grass? If you were grass, how would you dry out?

Defendant (Monty McCoy): I can’t. It dries out if you don’t water it properly, it will dry out. New sod.

Judge: Are there other things besides not watering it properly that could cause this sod to turn this way? For example, when he says that you said to him, maybe the chemicals from the popcorn ceiling... I’m going to get your sod tested. Did you ever test the sod?

Defendant (Monty McCoy): I never told him that. I don’t know where he got that from. I didn’t test it.

Judge: Did you ever say to him that you would take it somewhere to be tested?

Defendant (Monty McCoy): No.

Judge: All right.

Defendant (Monty McCoy): Not at all.

Judge: Did the neighbor’s yard also go bad?

Defendant (Monty McCoy): His yard? What actually happened is it separated after it settled, and the grass died. He called me back, he said, “Listen, can you just come redo the hill?” I said, “No problem. I’ll redo the whole yard as long as you pay for the sod.” He paid me for the sod. I went back down, redid the whole yard at my expense. I didn’t charge him any further labor. I didn’t charge him anything else but the sod.

Defendant (Monty McCoy): Now, I have pictures. His yard has been growing for weeks now, no issues. Now, the soil on the sod has dried completely out. When I walked across it, I got issues.
manipulation_techniques: Deflection, Minimization, Playing the victim, Gaslighting

dialogue:
Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to the People’s Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiff was hired as a mystery shopper by the defendant and says he got stiffed, but the defendant says he scammed, he didn’t shop where he said. It’s the case of "shop till you sue."

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Okay, Ronald Kerer, you are suing the company that you were working for, represented here by Julia Gwyn. How do I pronounce the last name?

Defendant: Gwyn.

Judge: Gwyn. You've asked us not to mention the name of the company or its clients, and we'll respect that. You are suing them for $1,293 that you say they owe you in reimbursements for the job that you performed. Now tell me, I’m fascinated by this case. Tell me the job that you perform.

Plaintiff: Okay, Your Honor, this is a situation in which I was employed as a mystery shopper.

Judge: Mystery shopper?

Plaintiff: That’s correct.

Judge: And your job description is?

Plaintiff: To visit the business and perform multiple duties. In the case of a supermarket, you have to evaluate the deli counter, the cleanliness of the supermarket, and the produce aisle. In the case of a fast-food restaurant, you have to time the amount of time it takes from when you get to the order line to when you place your order, to when you receive your order, to when you pay your order in nanoseconds. You have to use a digital timer. In a clothing boutique, you have to go in there acting nonchalant like you’re looking to buy a gift and hope they present non-sale merchandise and make recommendations, and then you make a purchase.

Judge: Okay. Who hires you? You work for them, and you get hired by the chains?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: Right. Because they’re trying to see how the franchises are operating or how their own employees are operating. It’s like "Undercover Boss"?

Plaintiff: Exactly right.

Judge: How long have you been doing this?

Plaintiff: I did it for the company for about three or four months.

Judge: You’ve never been a mystery shopper before this?

Plaintiff: That’s correct.

Judge: All right. So what happened here?

Plaintiff: In this particular situation, the criteria from the mystery shopping company is overwhelming, and they are critical when it comes to reporting. In the event that there is a miscalculation or a mistake in the report, or if the procedure isn’t followed, then the mystery shopping company denies payment. So now you’re out your time, you’re out the visit where you should have been paid, you’re out the money you paid for the visit, and you’re also out your expenses, your tolls, and your gas.

Judge: Now is that what happened in this case?

Plaintiff: That’s what happened.

Judge: Okay. Do you have a list of the work that you did that, according to you, was not reimbursed?

Plaintiff: Okay. May I see it?

Judge: All right. What happened here?

Defendant: So we have 600,000 mystery shoppers across the United States. We consider them independent contractors. As part of the application process, they do sign an independent contractor agreement, which I have here. Paragraph five states that they are not entitled to any reimbursements except for those that are set forth in the job posting. What we have is a website that has a bunch of available jobs that the mystery shoppers will take a look at. They’ll see what’s in their area, they’ll see what amount they’re going to get paid for the actual shop, and if there are any reimbursements. Sometimes the fast-food restaurants or even some of the restaurants will just give up to $20 for you to go do a mystery shop at their location, plus you may also get a fee for doing that as well.

Judge: Meaning you can have lunch and get a fee?

Defendant: Right. You might get—the fees are pretty minimal, like $10, $7, depending on the job. But if, like, you were going to go to the burger joint anyway and get a burger, and you were going to go shopping at this big retail chain and buy stuff, you also get the stuff you buy, right?

Judge: Exactly. This is fascinating. It’s a great business model. But hold on one moment. Okay, so I have a list of the jobs that you say you were not paid for. According to this list, there are 24 different jobs, and you’re suing for the visit, the item that was purchased there, and gas and tolls. What is your defense to what he’s saying?

Defendant: We were only able to match three visits out of the 24 to our records, and all three were canceled by Mr. Kerer. In some cases, he claimed he performed work for a client we don’t even have. There are also issues where he submitted visits that seem impossible, such as being in four different locations just a minute apart.

Judge: So you’re saying he falsified records?

Defendant: Yes, and one of our clients is considering prosecution for attempting to return an item he never purchased from their store.

Judge: Mr. Kerer, did anyone tell you that you were being removed from stores due to your behavior?

Plaintiff: No, Your Honor. This is the first I’m hearing of it.

Judge: Your claims are inconsistent and don’t add up. You have a bank listed that isn’t even one of their clients, exaggerated expenses, and job IDs that don’t match. Verdict for the defendant.

Judge: Case dismissed.

Judge: All parties, please step forward.

Judge: Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiff bought a car from the defendant and claims he knew it was a lemon, but the defendant says the plaintiff checked the car out, so tough luck. It’s the case of "Ain’t No Lemonade Here." Thank you. Douglas, okay. Ms. Zigler, you are suing Jose Medina for $4,000 that you say he owes you for knowingly selling you a lemon. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: So this all happened within a five-day span. I’m a college student. I withdrew from my savings to buy a car. I was looking on Craigslist, where I came across his ad, which I have a picture of. In his ad, it says it runs and drives great, which I came to find out that it doesn’t.

Judge: When did you meet up with him?

Plaintiff: On a Monday. The check engine light was on, so he’s like, "Let’s bring it to AutoZone down the street."

Judge: Wait. When you're test-driving the car, the check engine light goes on?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Why didn’t you just look for another car?

Plaintiff: Well, because I was told that the check engine light can go on for multiple reasons.

Judge: Why would you take the risk? Is this your first car that you’re buying?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Who was the gentleman with you?

Plaintiff: My boyfriend.

Judge: Was he with you when you test drove the car?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: All right. I mean, you know, there are lots of cars for sale. A car with the check engine light on may not be my first choice.

Plaintiff: This isn’t the first car I looked at. It was what I was looking for. I knew what I was looking for.

Judge: So you go with him to AutoZone?

Plaintiff: Yeah. He suggests, "Let’s go to AutoZone." The guy there took the cord, whatever they use, and hooked it up to the car. He goes inside, looks up the computer, and says it only needs a $45 part. At this point, I don’t know if he knew that guy or what because I didn’t know that the hookup does not check the engine.

Judge: That is what you were told when you brought it to the dealership?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: What does the dealership say?

Plaintiff: They said that AutoZone’s scanner does not diagnose full engine problems.

Judge: So, you buy the car. How much did you pay?

Plaintiff: $7,400 cash.

Judge: You hand him the cash, and he puts it in his pockets?

Plaintiff: Yes. Then I drive the car home.

Judge: What happens the next day?

Plaintiff: I go to register it, start the car, and hear noises coming from underneath.

Judge: Sounds that weren’t there when you test-drove it?

Plaintiff: Yes, because when I went there, the car was already on.

Judge: Why would the car be on when you got there?

Plaintiff: He was sitting in the car with it on, waiting for me.

Judge: And you didn’t turn it off and turn it on?

Plaintiff: No. Now I know why it was on—because that’s when you hear the initial sounds.

Judge: Did you have a mechanic check the car before buying it?

Plaintiff: I thought AutoZone was sufficient.

Judge: Okay. What happens after you take it to Nissan?

Plaintiff: They tell me it needs $5,867.75 worth of work. I couldn’t afford to fix it, and I couldn’t reach him. So, I traded it in.

Judge: For how much?

Plaintiff: $4,000.

Judge: So you lost $4,000?

Plaintiff: Yes, and now I have a $310 car payment.

Judge: Mr. Medina, did you ignore her calls?

Defendant: No, Your Honor. I’m a truck driver. I was working. When I did answer, she was rude, and her boyfriend sent me messages saying, "Handle this like a man."

Judge: What did you tell her when she demanded her money back?

Defendant: I told her the car was sold as-is. The car did not need all that work.

Judge: Had you heard any noise from the car before selling it?

Defendant: No, Your Honor.

Judge: Then why did Nissan say it had serious issues?

Defendant: I don’t know. I had the car for three months with no problems. I only sold it because I wanted a motorcycle.

Judge: Did you take it to a mechanic in those three months?

Defendant: No, because it didn’t need anything.

Judge: Ms. Zigler, did you read his Craigslist ad?

Plaintiff: Yes. It said it "runs and drives great."

Judge: That’s an opinion. Buyers have to test a used car before purchasing. Unfortunately, this is an "as-is" sale. I feel bad for you, but my hands are tied by the law. Verdict for the defendant.

Judge: Tania Jenkins, you are suing Ryan Voorhees the second for 500, the amount of your insurance deductible, as a result of damage that he did to your car that you say was his fault. Tell me about what happened.

Plaintiff: So, he is coming that way, and I'm turning in. Traffic is going this way. Back here is my daughter's Taekwondo class, so I'm turning in there, passing other buildings. I actually had to slow down because there is a dip. I get to here, and he collides here, hitting my tire. His skateboard goes under my vehicle.

Judge: Did he get knocked down? Was he on the ground?

Plaintiff: No, I looked up and he jumped off before.

Judge: Did you jump off beforehand?

Defendant: Yes, ma'am.

Judge: How far away from the car did you jump off?

Defendant: It was literally right when the board met the car. It was like a split-second reaction.

Judge: So what happens next?

Plaintiff: I'm looking like, "What in the world?" And of course, we exchanged words.

Judge: What were the exchange of words? Tell me the words exchanged.

Plaintiff: I don't know the exact words, but I think I said something to the effect of, "Watch where you're going." He's like, "Watch where you're going."

Judge: Did you ask him if he was okay?

Plaintiff: I don't think I made it out of the car at that point. He says to me, "Just drive forward and let me get my skateboard." So he's standing about right here doing like this, telling me to move forward. I move forward, and his skateboard ends up getting wedged under my back tire. He's doing this, so I end up going over his skateboard, and it cracks. He lost his mind.

Judge: So what happened next?

Plaintiff: By this time, he comes right back here, and he punches my car.

Judge: Wait, he punched your car?

Plaintiff: He punched my car.

Judge: Where did he punch your car?

Plaintiff: Right there.

Judge: Do you have a picture? Did it make a dent?

Plaintiff: Yes, it did.

Judge: His fist did that?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Let me see your fist.

Defendant: (Shows fist)

Judge: I look like I weigh more than him. Did he turn into one of those Hulk fists? Why are you punching her car?

Defendant: I was angry. She ran my board over.

Judge: What are you, two? That's what somebody who's two does. It wasn't on purpose. It was called a car accident. What would entitle you to punch her car?

Defendant: It was out of rage and anger.

Judge: So you agree you need to pay for the repair of the car?

Defendant: Well...

Judge: Because I'm kind of shocked that you're suing for $89 to fix a skateboard, but you do agree you have to pay the $500?

Defendant: I'm not sure. In fact, it would be more than $500. She's just suing you for the deductible. Your insurance company paid how much?

Plaintiff: The difference of like $300 and something. When I first got the appraisal, it was $997. Then I went through my insurance, and the price dropped to $859. My insurance company paid $359. I'm just suing for the $500 I'm out.

Judge: Now you have a counterclaim against her for $89.80 for the amount owed to fix your skateboard?

Defendant: Yes, ma'am.

Judge: You punched her car. But see, I feel that if you punched her car, you should be paying $900 for the punch. So who counterclaims to fix a skateboard?

Defendant: Honestly, I feel like I'm not at fault because it was the initial wreck in the first place.

Judge: You think because you were angry, you had a right to punch her car?

Defendant: Exactly.

Judge: Are you seriously saying that in a court of law? Are you crazy?

Defendant's Mother: (Steps up) Are you kidding me?

Defendant: It just happened so fast. I wasn't going extremely fast, just kind of steadily going. I looked down for like a split second, and I looked back up, and I see her car there.

Judge: Yeah, don't look down. Tell me again how you think she should pay you $89 when you punched her car and caused her $800 in damages.

Defendant: I understand.

Judge: Does he have an anger control issue?

Defendant's Mother: No, not usually.

Judge: Were you surprised?

Defendant's Mother: Very surprised.

Judge: Sweetheart, are you going to be paying for the car that you punched? Because under no circumstances would that ever be appropriate. As for the skateboard fix, no, she's not going to pay it. I find the accident to have been your fault. On your counterclaim, zero. On her claim against you, $500. Verdict for the plaintiff.

Judge: All parties, please. Let it get—have you been sworn in?

Bailiff: Yes, Your Honor.

Judge: Okay, Jane. You're suing your ex, Stephen Jacobs, for $3,158.36, half the cost of your son's wedding expenses, which according to you, he agreed to pay. You are counterclaiming against her, I guess, for half the cost of college?

Defendant: No, not half the cost of college—she made no contribution to things like tuition.

Judge: And so how do you pick $7,000 as the amount you're counterclaiming for?

Defendant: Massachusetts law limits the amount I can sue for in this court.

Judge: I see. How much was college in total?

Defendant: I paid about $207,000 for both boys.

Judge: Okay, so you're suing for the most you can sue for. It's a tiny fraction of what you actually paid for college because, according to you, she's supposed to pay for half of that. All right. Let's talk to you first. Tell me about why you're here today.

Plaintiff: We have two sons. The oldest, who's now 29, was married last June. Steve and I had been in conversation about paying for the rehearsal dinner, some flowers to go along with the rehearsal dinner that were going to be repurposed and used at the wedding the following day, and then the day after, there was a brunch held at the bride's family home.
