Plaintiff: It’s in a driveway at my boss’s property.

Judge: But you must have taken it to a mechanic who told you the engine was blown.

Plaintiff: The defendant told me that.

Judge: How does he know the engine’s blown?

Plaintiff: Because he came and did the testing and figured out that it is blown.

Defendant: Your Honor, I do auto body work.

Judge: Okay, we’re in court, and nobody has seen fit to have an actual mechanic diagnose this and figure out how it happened and why it happened?

Plaintiff: I know how it happened because I purchased the oil coolant line. Ron and his brother showed me that the oil coolant line blew.

Judge: And who am I supposed to get the answer from? That both should be changed at the same time?

Plaintiff: Ron’s brother told me that.

Judge: That’s not evidence. That’s hearsay. I need an expert.

Defendant: He told me he was coming out of work, it was pouring rain, and he was going up Southington Mountain, a steep hill. He saw the oil light come on, then he saw the oil pressure gauge go down to zero. He continued to drive the truck.

Judge: But your knowledge of whether he continued to drive it after the lights turned on is based on what?

Defendant: That’s what he told me.

Judge: You guys are fascinating. You take up my time in court, but you don't think to bring an expert witness to confirm what happened?

Plaintiff: Ron told me that the engine was seized.

Judge: You need a mechanic’s report saying the cause of failure was X. Do you have that?

Plaintiff: No, I don’t.

Judge: You’re suing for the money you paid for the truck, brake pads, registration, oil, and lost wages. What was the day of purchase?

Plaintiff: I believe it was the 7th.

Defendant: It was a good running truck when I had it. I feel really bad, but I don’t feel guilty. The line blew, and he ignored the gauges on the dashboard.

Judge: Did you sell it “as-is?”

Defendant: Yes.

Plaintiff: No, the bill of sale doesn’t say “as-is.”

Judge: Does the bill of sale have a warranty?

Plaintiff: No, it doesn’t.

Judge: The default position in every state is that a used vehicle sale is “as-is” unless otherwise stated. You, as the plaintiff, have the burden of proving your case. You have to show that the failure was due to something the defendant did wrong, not just that the car broke down.

Judge: My verdict is for the defendant. Good luck.
manipulation_techniques: evasion, deflection, persuasion, framing the narrative

dialogue:
Judge: This is the plaintiff Edward McKernan Jr. He says his former landlord is trying to pull a fast one on him by only offering to return 50% of his security deposit because he's mad they moved out. He left the place in better shape than when he got it. This is a typical case of a landlord trying to take advantage of a tenant for no good reason, and he's here seeking the $3,200 he's most definitely owed.

This is the defendant Michael Orus Sr. He says this is a clear-cut case of a tenant breaking a lease, not giving proper notice, and just up and leaving two months early. He's not about to eat the two months’ rent. The security he kept is covering those two months, and he owes this former tenant nothing.

He's accused of treating a tenant terribly.

All parties please raise your right hands.

Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiff says his former landlord is screwing him over by keeping half of his security, but the defendant says the plaintiff cutting rent is tough.

It's the case of renter regret.

Douglas Edward McKernan, right? You are suing Michael Orose Sr. for double the $1,600 security deposit that you say he has wrongfully withheld. What’s going on?

Plaintiff: That’s correct, your honor. So this is the first apartment my wife and I rented as a new couple. We’ve been married for six years. I was in the Marine Corps, got out. This is our first apartment we had together in the United States. She’s an immigrant from the Philippines, so, you know, we were looking around on Craigslist and we decided to move into his apartment.

We were residents here for two years. Never really had any issues for the most part until around our sixth, seventh month there. I noticed coming home from work late, kind of smelled like a, like a Grateful Dead concert. I guess I’ll leave it at that.

Judge: Don't leave it at that. I don’t know what you're saying.

Plaintiff: Smelled like pot.

Judge: It smelled like marijuana?

Plaintiff: Okay.

Judge: And who lives—what kind of a building is this?

Plaintiff: Uh, it’s an old Victorian, three-family home.

Judge: And are there three families living there?

Plaintiff: Yes, I was on the third floor. He was on the first floor. And his son, granddaughter, and new daughter-in-law were in the second floor.

Judge: And which apartment was the smell of marijuana coming from?

Plaintiff: Well, it was—you share one stairway, and you would smell it the second you walked in the door going up.

Judge: So you’re saying from the first floor?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: So you're saying that the smell of marijuana was emanating from his apartment on the first floor?

Plaintiff: All the way up to the third floor. You’d smell it all the way up in the apartment.

Judge: And then, uh, when did that start bothering you?

Plaintiff: Like I said, around probably six months in, your honor.

Judge: Okay. So what did you do about it? Did you ever mention it to him?

Plaintiff: I mentioned it once. Well, one time it was actually—I didn’t mention it. I didn’t take the initiative and actually tell him. We got into a small altercation about—I think I was like throwing recycling in the trash, like, like individual water bottles in the trash can, and he basically called me out on it. And then I called him out on smelling the, uh, the marijuana in the apartment. So that’s kind of how I brought it up to his attention.

Judge: Okay. So after that?

Plaintiff: Like I said, uh, also to add on to hers, uh, the main reason why we stayed even though she was going through pain was just financially, it was just sound at the time.

Judge: But you have a lease. And your lease takes you through December. So what happens to make you decide, "I’m leaving"?

Plaintiff: Yes. Um, that's—that is the lawsuit. He kept our money ‘cause he says we breached a lease. So September 19th of 2018, he called my spouse. He never really communicated with me when it came to business. He always communicated with my wife.

Judge: Why didn't you just say, "Talk to me," instead?

Plaintiff: He always avoided me whenever—

Judge: Why don’t you just call him?

Plaintiff: He wouldn’t answer phone calls. It was just typical.

Judge: Is that it, or you just leave these things to your wife to handle?

Plaintiff: No, ‘cause—

Judge: I live in a house where the guy leaves these things to his wife to handle.

(Laughter in courtroom.)

Judge: Okay, I know exactly what that looks like. Sometimes it’s a good tactic to use your wife—for him and you. But go ahead.

Plaintiff: For the most part, he would just dodge all the time.

Judge (Final Verdict): I have a quandary here. And my quandary is this: I think you’ve perjured yourself in my courtroom when you tell me that he told you, “Yeah, no problem, you go ahead and move.” I think that’s perjury. When you tell me that the reason you wanted to move was the health and welfare of your baby and your wife, I think that’s perjury. I think the reason you wanted to move was that there was a friend with an apartment, and it was going to be a better situation for you. I don’t like that.

And you’re asking me to enforce the bonanza of a double penalty? I’m not feeling that warm, all-over glow to do it for you. When this is the situation that presents itself.

However, you don’t get to keep that $1,600 because you can’t collect rent from someone if you don’t have a CO. That’s the law. And if you can’t collect the rent, then you cannot keep the security deposit to collect the rent because you didn’t have a CO.

But it’ll be a snowy day in hell before I allow someone to blatantly breach a contract and get double the security deposit. That’s intended as a remedy for unscrupulous landlords and a tenant who is victimized by it, and that security deposit is wrongfully withheld. That’s not for a situation like this. The security deposit was rightfully withheld. You breached the contract.

But as it turns out, I must return it to him. So it’s not going to be double, but you must return the $1,600 because you can’t collect it as rent. That is my verdict. Good luck, folks.
manipulation_techniques: playing the victim, deflection, framing the narrative

dialogue:
Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiff says his former landlord was a slacker who wouldn’t fix anything, then had the nerve to call the cops on him, and now won’t return his security. But the defendant says the plaintiff was bad news. It’s the case of “There’s Really No Place Like Home, and It Sucks.” Thank you, Douglas.

Bailiff: You're welcome.

Judge: Okay, Jamal Harris. You are suing your former landlord, Alia Fips, for $2,500—$1,425 that you say you’re owed as a security deposit, and the rest for increased electric bills from July 9th to February 12th, which you will explain in a moment. According to you, your landlord improperly kept your security deposit with no rights. Tell me what’s going on.

Plaintiff: I moved into the apartment around 2006. Upon moving in, my mother lived there before me. She left a security deposit. Once I moved in, Ms. Fips let me know that there was an increase in the security, so I gave her the cash for the increase. Over the years, I had multiple problems with it. Now, I said the security was $1,425. I just came from court in December. At no time did she say that I owed her anything upon the security deposit. She tried to charge me late fees for being late on my rent. The court told her that she couldn’t charge me. So, upon me moving out, I gave her the keys—

Judge: Wait. Stop. Stop. Stop. You guys settled a case in landlord-tenant court, right? And part of the settlement—let me get the settlement by memory—part of the settlement is that you were going to be out. When was that supposed to be?

Plaintiff: I was supposed to be out by the end of January.

Judge: What day in January?

Plaintiff: January 31st.

Judge: January 15th, not 31st. So, middle of January. All right. Were you out in the middle of January?

Plaintiff: No, I wasn’t.

Judge: When did you get out?

Plaintiff: I didn’t leave until March 2nd, 2012.

Judge: Okay. All right. Why did you leave on March 2nd when you were supposed to be out January 15th?

Plaintiff: Being that I receive a subsidy from Section 8, I can't move and do anything without their approval. They didn’t give me my approval situation until the 15th of February.

Judge: But the court gave you a deadline. You seem to think that your Section 8 problems are her problems. You were on a month-to-month lease that was already terminated by a court of law, where you agreed to do certain things. That’s the problem—sticking around until March 2nd. Tell me your side of this.

Defendant: Mr. Harris rented the apartment from me after his mother, who was a very good tenant, lived there. She recommended that I leave the apartment with her son.

Judge: How long did she live there?

Defendant: She lived there for four years.

Judge: Was she on Section 8?

Defendant: Yes. She came off Section 8 but transferred it to her son. When she left it with this able-bodied man, I thought he would be able to pay his portion of the rent, which was only $365–$369. It varied according to his income, because he was working at that time. I constantly had to take him to housing court. I took him to housing court in 2008, 2009, and when I notified him in May of 2011, I gave him notice that his lease that expired in July 2011 would not be renewed. From then on, he had a vendetta. He told me he was going to make my life miserable before he left, and he did. He punched holes in doors, broke tiles, broke cabinet doors, and did all kinds of destructive things to the apartment. Section 8, when they came in, told me I had to fix them and take him to court for the money.

Judge: So, you had issues with him not paying and damaging the apartment?

Defendant: Yes. The court told him he should be out by January 15th, but he stayed until March. I allowed him to work out whatever his problems were and leave peacefully, because it was a constant fight between both of us. He would intimidate me, come up in my face. He thought because he’s a man and I’m a woman, he could intimidate me.

Judge: Do you think anybody can intimidate you? Of all people?

Defendant: He then told me he was going to leave by the end of February. He didn’t. He left on March 2nd. Technically, even according to the letter I read from Section 8, he actually owes me for the entire month of March. I didn’t charge him for that. I charged him just for the two days he stayed.

Judge: Why didn’t you charge him for all of March?

Defendant: First of all, the $128 wouldn’t even cover the $1,425 anyway. But it was mainly the repairs to the doors and tiles.

Judge: I don’t even need to get into whether you were allowed to do that or not. The fact is, he admits he stayed past the deadline. Do you understand that when you’re there in March, you owe rent for March?

Plaintiff: I understand that, but—

Judge: So why are you suing if you owe rent for March? Why are you suing to get money back when you still owe her money?

Plaintiff: Do I get to speak now?

Judge: Do you hear what I just said?

Plaintiff: I understand.

Judge: At some point, you have to take responsibility. The verdict is for the defendant. You don’t get any of your security deposit back. That’s the law, and it applies to you too.

Judge: Elizabeth Green, you are suing Diane for $60 that you paid for a used tire there that turned out to be no good, according to you. What happened?

Plaintiff: I was coming from the senior center on July 24th, and I came outside, and I had a flat tire.

Judge: Do you know how you got the flat tire?

Plaintiff: I have no idea. So, I come out, and I have a flat tire. I'm with my cousin, and she said there's a gas station at the corner. We'll go and get air in the tire, then we'll take the tire around and, uh, we'll get a— a— a used tire because I— I was due for inspection about a week later.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: So, we go, and we get the air in the tire, and we drive to the tire shop.

Judge: And the tire shop is her tire shop?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: All right. And then you deal with somebody else, not her?

Plaintiff: Never seen her before.

Judge: Right, okay. She's the owner. You're the owner, right?

Defendant: Yes, I am.

Judge: Okay. And, um, that person sells you a $60 tire?

Plaintiff: The guy comes out, and, uh, usually a, uh, used tire is $40. So, he comes out, and he says to me, "I can give you this new tire for $60."

Judge: A new tire?

Plaintiff: He said a new tire for $60.

Judge: So, what kind of tire was it?

Plaintiff: I have no idea, Your Honor. I know nothing about— I still don’t know.

Judge: Do you have paperwork?

Plaintiff: I have, uh, paperwork from Volkswagen because I went for inspection, and Volkswagen would not pass my inspection because of that tire.

Judge: Okay, so let’s slow down a second. Let’s back it up. When did you buy the tire from them?

Plaintiff: I got the tire from them on July 30th.

Judge: Are you sure?

Plaintiff: I’m positive.

Judge: Because your complaint says it’s July 24th.

Plaintiff: That’s the date that I got the used tire.

Judge: That’s what I’m asking.

Plaintiff: That’s fine.

Judge: So, July 24th, you got the used tire from them?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: I’m sorry, I thought you said you bought a new tire for $60 from them?

Plaintiff: So that’s not a used tire. I went to get a used tire, but—

Judge: But you ended up with a new tire for $60?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: All right. So that’s on 7/24. And when is it that you go in for inspection and Volkswagen tells you you need a new tire?

Plaintiff: On the 30th.

Judge: Okay. You go in for inspection.

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And what do they tell you? What does Volkswagen tell you?

Plaintiff: They tell me that my car is fine. I pay for inspection, except for that front—

Judge: May I see something from Volkswagen saying that?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: (Reading) During service, found right front tire has a bubble in the sidewall. Did they show you the bubble?

Plaintiff: Volkswagen?

Judge: Yeah.

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: You never saw the bubble yourself?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: And so you paid them $185 for the new tire?

Plaintiff: Yes, to pass inspection.

Judge: Do you have paperwork from this transaction?

Defendant: No, Your Honor, I don’t.

Judge: Why don’t you? Like, wouldn’t you—?

Defendant: I— I would, uh, normally, Your Honor. But, uh, this particular sale was a, um— it was a cash— cash sale, and I don’t— didn’t bring the receipt. I’m sorry.

Judge: Okay. Uh— Why? We don’t tell the taxman about cash transactions?   

Judge: Did you ever talk to your employee to see if he remembered?

Defendant: I did, yes.

Judge: Okay. And did he remember the situation?

Defendant: Absolutely, Your Honor.

Judge: All right. Did she buy a new tire or a used tire?

Defendant: She did not. She purchased a used tire.

Judge: She purchased a used tire. Now, the used tire has a bubble in it. You shouldn’t be selling it, right?

Defendant: Well, a bubble is a side bulge, and it’s usually caused from an impact on a tire.

Judge: Okay, so if you sold her a used tire that had a bubble in it, how— how— your used tires— tell me how the process works. Would you know it had a bubble in it?

Defendant: You absolutely would see it.

Judge: Why?

Defendant: Because it would be visible to the eye.

Judge: So it’s a 60-buck tire. Even if it’s defective for 60 bucks, does the plaintiff have any recourse here?

Spectator: Yes.

Judge: Why?

Spectator: Because, um, it’s— it’s a matter of he should have known that tire was bad.

Judge: It was a used tire.

Spectator: It’s a used tire.

Judge: But isn’t it a thing of where you get what you pay for?

Spectator: You get what you pay for.

Judge: So 60 bucks— any recourse if it’s defective?

Spectator: Yeah, they should have checked and made sure it wasn’t defective before they bought it.

Judge: But whose obligation is that? Isn’t that the customer’s or the business’s?

Spectator: Both.

Judge: Oh. Okay. Going inside the courtroom— did you see a bubble in the tire when they sold it to you?

Plaintiff: No, I didn’t see a bubble.

Judge: You never saw a bubble?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: All right. But now, if that tire had a bubble in it— tell me what a bubble is.

Defendant: It’s a protruding, uh, bulge on the tire.

Judge: And it comes from what? How does it happen?

Defendant: It comes from impact on the tire.

Judge: Okay, so if the tire’s not on her car, could it have a bubble?

Defendant: No, you wouldn’t see it unless it was—

Judge: If the tire was inflated?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: And the tire is not inflated until it’s put on her car?

Defendant: Right.

Judge: Because what? It’s in between the treads?

Defendant: No, it’s on the sidewall of the tire.

Judge: It’s on the sidewall?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: And an uninflated tire— I’m just trying to understand— an uninflated tire that got reinflated and has a bubble in it because of an impact in its prior life, right?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: That could come out again once inflated?

Defendant: Once it’s inflated, yes.

Judge: That— that is a true fact, what I just said?

Defendant: Yes, Your Honor.

Judge: I was just curious. All right. But you would see it?

Defendant: Yes, you would.

Judge: Okay. And you never saw it. How do you know these guys at that dealership weren’t just trying to rack up a bill?

Plaintiff: What do you mean?

Judge: I don’t know how to make myself any clearer.

Judge: And then you drove the car for six days. Did you hit any potholes or anything strong, or park a little bit into something?

Plaintiff: No.

Plaintiff: This is a credit only because, like, I’m standing there boohoo-ing, and I said, "Just give me some of my money back." Like, I just gave you $60, and I just paid $185— I’m not paying $300 for a tire.

Plaintiff: So the boss was there from the guy who originally sold me the tire, and the boss said to him, "Give her a credit."

Judge: So he gave you the date on it?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: What else do you sell besides tires?

Defendant: Rims. We have, uh, hubcaps.

Judge: May I say something, please?

Judge: What else can she buy with her 60-buck credit besides a tire? Because she doesn’t want to buy any more tires.

Plaintiff: I’m not.

Defendant: No.

Defendant: We’ve been in business for over 30 years. We’ve always had the same policy— no cash refunds. We give store credits.

Judge: That’s not advertised.

Judge: First of all, you don’t even have paperwork, so let’s start with that.

Judge: But if they were to give you a warranty— like this other tire company, do you give a warranty?

Defendant: Yes, we do.

Judge: How many days?

Defendant: 30.

Judge: On a used tire?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Then what a warranty entitles you to is to get another tire.

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: It does not entitle you to a money refund back.

Plaintiff: Right.

Judge: And you’re accepting nothing less than a money refund?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Because you say, "They sold me a tire with a bubble in it."

Judge: And I say, if in fact they did that, then they owe you $60.

Judge: The problem you’re having is, how are you going to prove this case?

Judge: You looked at the tire when it was put on. You didn’t see a bubble. You drove it for six days.

Judge: You take it to Volkswagen. Volkswagen tells you there’s a bubble.

Judge: And you still don’t see a bubble.

Judge: A bubble is something that you see. It’s a protrusion in the sidewall.

Judge: And you’re driving it around for six days.

Judge: How am I going to tell them, "I know for a fact that you sold her that tire with a bubble in it"?

Judge: How am I going to say that to her on the facts of this case?

Judge: I can’t.

Defendant: Your Honor—

Judge: Yeah?

Defendant: And if Miss Green had brought the tire back, we were willing to give her a credit, even if she had a bubble in the tire, because we would have to honor our 30-day guarantee.

Judge: Right.

Defendant: That’s not—

Judge: Well, that’s what ended up happening.

Judge: He wrote down "$60 credit" on a business card?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Is that valid?

Defendant: Well, yes, it is. That’s what we use for credits.

Defendant: But the thing is, if she had come back with the tire and wanted a new tire instead of buying one from Volkswagen, she could have come back and applied the $60 credit—

Defendant: Applied the $60 credit towards getting a different tire.

Judge: Diane, I get it.

Judge: I don’t know if it sounds like I don’t get it, but I get it.

Judge: My verdict in this case is for the defendant.

Judge: Thank you. As Diane Aen, otherwise known as Diane Vigata. Which would you like me to call you?

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): I prefer Vigata. I just got... I’m married to May, so...

Judge: Oh, well, congratulations.

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): Thank you.

Judge: You’re suing Family Auto Sales, owned by Chris Pendle, yes?

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): Yes, ma’am.

Judge: Okay. For $820, the balance that you say is owed back to you on a car that you took back to him. All right, what happened?

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): We bought a car, in May of this year, a used car from his dealership.

Judge: What day?

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): The bill of sale is for, let’s see what it says... 5/24.

Judge: Okay. What kind of car?

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): It’s a Grand Cherokee Jeep, 1995.

Judge: Uh-huh, and what happens? What goes wrong?

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): Well, when we first took it for the test drive, we saw that there were some broken lights on the interior as well as the speedometer wasn’t working. So before we took possession of the car, he agreed that he was going to fix those things, and he, in fact, did do that.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): And when we purchased the car, the odometer said 159,000 miles on it. But when we got it back, he actually had to replace the whole unit, so it took the mileage up to 200,000, which we didn’t like.

Judge: Why did it do that?

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): It was a replacement. They’re not easy to get new. I called Chris beforehand and asked him if that was okay; otherwise, I could have it reprogrammed.

Judge: Who’s Chris?

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): Her husband.

Judge: Husband?

Defendant (Chris): He said that was fine.

Judge: Was that fine?

Defendant (Chris): It was fine until I told my wife.

Judge: Exactly! Cook Douglas. What’s the correct daughter? Find out if it’s fine.

Judge: Okay, and now you’ve been married how long?

Defendant (Chris): 20 minutes.

Judge: I get to know this lesson!

Judge: I was married once before for 20 years.

Defendant (Chris): Yeah, how’d that work out?

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): Married again?

Defendant (Chris): Oh, to her!

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): Oh, you were married to her for 20 years?

Defendant (Chris): No, no. My first wife was married.

Judge: Okay, all right. We’ve been married only since May.

Judge: Listen, you got to train him better than the last one, okay? Laughs Lordy, lordy.

Judge: Speak first, ask questions later. Okay, so now it was fine. You agree you told him it was fine, and then your wife didn’t like it. All right, so go on.

Defendant (Chris): Well, that wasn’t the issue with the car. I mean, the sunroof leaked profusely into the car and just drenched everywhere. And we told him about it, and there was also an oil leak under the car. So he said, “Okay, he would fix it.” I mean, you don’t sell a car that’s not roadworthy. Those kinds of things, it shouldn’t be sold that way.

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): I mean, the first rainstorm, the rain comes right in.

Defendant (Chris): So he agreed to fix it, but we got it back, and it continued to leak, and we continued to notice the oil leak under the car. So we were getting very annoyed. I mean, he was, you know, we liked each other at first, everything was fine. But, you know, he became more and more contentious because these things were not getting fixed.

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): So finally, when we took it back... I mean, I can show you the pictures of how they finally repaired it. The sunroof was all gummed up with silicone, and I have photographs of that, which was not really the way it didn’t look nice. But we were so sick of taking it back and forth. We said, “Okay.”

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): So here are the pictures of that. Okay. And so the car was running a little rough, and my husband decided to get an oil change. He said, “Maybe that would make it feel, you know, run a little bit better.”

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): So when he went to take it to get an oil change, the mechanic called him over and said, “Come and take a look at this underneath the car,” and he showed the transfer box underneath the car had been gummed up with the very same silicone that you see there. And I have pictures of that on the transfer box.

Judge: What’s your response to that?

Defendant (Chris): There are multiple things on the car that can leak. My mechanic told me that they fixed an oil pan leak.

Judge: How did they fix it?

Defendant (Chris): Silicone gaskets are sometimes used for the gaskets. I don’t know what was used for what we’re talking about here.

Judge: Okay, let’s take a look at what Tomaz...

Defendant (Chris): What’s that?

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): Um, pretty close-up. But if they say it’s the transfer case, I wouldn’t disagree.

Judge: Okay. Would that be an appropriate repair, though, or would that be sort of like a cheap and fast and easy way to finish it?

Defendant (Chris): Fast, it would be a short and easy way to do it.

Judge: Okay. Did you sell this car with a warranty?

Defendant (Chris): Yes.

Judge: And how long is the warranty?

Defendant (Chris): 30 days.

Judge: All right. Now, at some point, you decide you don’t want the car?

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): Yeah.

Judge: When do you decide you don’t want the car?

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): It was after the... after we discovered the silicone underneath.

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): It was probably whatever the date is on that invoice. It’s probably the invoice, which is July.

Judge: Okay, so it’s after the 30-day warranty has expired.

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): Right.

Judge: All right. And then what happens?

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): You talk to him?

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): So we tell him the situation. We tell him it was a dangerous repair. He should never have repaired it that way. I mean, if you go and you say you’re repairing something, you know, you would assume it would be repaired the right way, not some faulty way. He is a business owner.

Defendant (Chris): Right.

Plaintiff (Diane/Vigata): So to repair it the right way would cost how much?

Defendant (Chris): I don’t know.

Judge: Exactly! So if it would cost 50 bucks or 100 bucks, that would be your measure of damages here, but that’s not what you wanted. You, in general, you were disillusioned. You were no longer in love with the car. You didn’t want it.

Judge: Did she sign something? Please tell me you had her sign something.

Defendant (Chris): I believe I did, but I think I was in a rush to get them out, and I believe I gave them the signed copy.

Judge: Seeing that I wouldn’t continue to get my full... What this says... I’ll see if... I’ll tell you if it’s a settlement or not.

Defendant (Chris): Well, I didn’t... See, here’s the idea: courts want to encourage... long pause Why? Judge: That’s a mark of a good deal, where you feel like you give, they feel like they’re both unhappy. Not one’s unhappy, both unhappy. Then you know that.

Judge: So everybody gave up a little something, right?

Judge: Okay, and the idea is that we don’t want to overflood the courts. So when you guys settle, the law says you’ve got to respect the settlement.

Judge: Okay, if this paper didn’t exist, and the testimony were, “Well, yeah, I told them I’d take the $2,000 because that’s... because I just wanted $2,000 better than zero,” but I was always planning on that still being a settlement. Okay?

Plaintiff: "He didn't have to leave me."

Okay, Salsa Lrat Incorporated. Miguel Hernandez and Nora Cono, who you have power of attorney for, you are suing Eric Pakun, who bought your business, for $2,000-some-odd dollars because you say he actually owes you $27,000.

Judge: This is the plaintiff, Merlene Washington. She says that her upstairs neighbor flooded her apartment and won’t step up to do the right thing and right this wrong. Judge: Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiff says her upstairs neighbor’s fish tank leaked and flooded her apartment, but the defendant says it was just a little water and he steam-cleaned the plaintiff’s couch. It’s the case of Holy Mackerel! You have sworn, your honor.

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Merlene Washington, you are suing your upstairs neighbor, Stafford Banister, for $2,448.60 in damages that you say you have sustained as a result of water that leaked into your apartment from his fish tank. Tell me what’s going on.

Merlene Washington (Plaintiff): On the 27th of February, I got home at about 9:00 PM, and I switched on my TV. I heard these popping sounds, and I was wondering what it could be. As I walked over to the TV, I realized that my carpet was soaked. So I switched on the light and saw that the whole ceiling was wet, my couch was wet, the carpet was wet—just about everything was wet. I realized the water was coming from upstairs, so I went up and knocked on his door. I said to him, “You have water coming down in my apartment. Come down and take a look.”

Judge: What did he say when you knocked on his door?

Plaintiff: I think he said he was going to come down in a while.

Judge: He didn’t say why you had water in your apartment?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Okay, so then what?

Plaintiff: I went back down to my apartment and was looking around in shock because I couldn’t believe what I was seeing. After about five minutes, I went back up to his apartment and knocked again. I said, “You need to come down and see my apartment because it’s wet.” I went back down and waited, but he didn’t come. So I went back up a third time and knocked on his door again. I said, “You need to come down and see my apartment because my whole apartment is wet.”

Judge: And what did he say then?

Plaintiff: He said, “I’m coming, I’m coming. Let me put some clothes on or whatever.”

Judge: Okay, then what happened?

Plaintiff: I went back down, and he finally came down. I asked him, “What happened in your apartment?” He said his fish tank leaked. He told me he came home at 12:00 PM and saw his fish tank leaking.

Judge: So he knew his fish tank was leaking since noon?

Plaintiff: Yes! I told him, “I left here at 1:30 PM. If you came home and saw your fish tank leaking, you could have knocked on my door so I could move my things around so they wouldn’t get wet.” He said something about trying to save his fish. I said, “You’re trying to save your fish, and all my things are damaged?” And then he said, “Oh, you have nice things.”

Judge: What do you mean by that? Was he being sarcastic?

Plaintiff: Maybe not. He just said, “You have nice things.” Then he moved one of the pillows off the couch and placed it over to the other side. I moved it back because one side of the apartment was dry, and one side was wet, so I wanted to keep all the wet things together. The light fixture on my ceiling even had water in it!

Judge: Do you have pictures?

Plaintiff: Yes, here they are.

Judge: How long have you two been neighbors? Did you know each other before this?

Plaintiff: I’ve seen him a couple of times.

Judge: How long have you lived there?

Plaintiff: About 40 years.

Judge: And you, sir?

Stafford Banister (Defendant): Two years.

Judge: Okay, what happened with your fish tank?

Defendant: I have a 90-gallon fish tank.

Judge: That’s pretty big.

Defendant: Yeah, it’s a big tank.

Judge: What kind of fish do you have?

Defendant: I have three fish: a shark and two others.

Defendant: Yeah, it’s about seven inches long.

Judge: And the other two?

Defendant: I don’t know what they are.

Judge: You have a 90-gallon tank, and you don’t know what’s in it?

Defendant: I bought them a while ago, and I just don’t remember.

Judge: Okay. So what happened with the tank?

Defendant: I tried to find out where the leak was, but I couldn’t. I put pots, pans, and towels down, but the water kept leaking. I had to get the fish out so they wouldn’t die. I put them in a big plastic tub and then pumped the rest of the water into the sink. Then I took the tank outside and threw it away.

Judge: Did you go downstairs to tell her?

Defendant: I knocked on her door, but no one answered.

Judge: Did you leave a note?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Okay, so then what happened?

Plaintiff: No, I did not.

Judge: And then what happened?

Defendant: I eventually put on my pants and went downstairs. I saw the water on the ceiling, the soaked couch, and the drenched carpet.

Judge: Yeah, so?

Defendant: I got someone to steam clean the couch and the carpet.

Plaintiff: But that didn’t fix the damage! My belongings still smell like fish, and my furniture is ruined.

Judge: Is putting a seven-inch shark in a 90-gallon tank cruel or cool?

Audience Member 1: It’s cool because sharks are animals, and animals are pets.

Audience Member 2: If you’re impeding its growth, then it’s a little cruel.

Audience Member 3: If it’s used to a big, wide-open ocean, then it’s cruel.

Judge: Fair enough. Back to the case. So you did clean the apartment, but you think she just wants all-new things?

Plaintiff: My things were damaged! It’s not fair.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case in the docket, the plaintiff says her own cousin stiffed her on daycare services, but the defendant says the plaintiff was a lousy daycare worker. It’s the case of "She Don't Care About Daycare." Okay, Anastasia Graves, you are suing Donna Bulock, your cousin, doing business as Donna B’s Daydreaming Center. This is the daycare center?

Plaintiff: Yes, Daydreaming Center.

Judge: Okay, for $5,000 in pain and suffering, taxes, and $750 that you say you weren’t paid in your last paycheck. What’s going on?

Plaintiff: I worked for her. She hired me November 17, 2008, and I worked for her until April 17, 2010. My last check, she did not give me, but she paid everybody else. Then I filed taxes—

Plaintiff: The month of March and April.

Judge: For March toward April?

Plaintiff: Yeah, because you get paid every third Friday.

Judge: All right. When she fired you, did she tell you why she was firing you?

Judge: Okay, did you give her a chance to pay you before you left?

Plaintiff: No, because she said she wasn’t paying nobody. I called her—

Plaintiff: No, I didn’t have no problems with her at all before that.

Plaintiff: We was talking, we was all that. It wasn’t no problems. I didn’t have no problems with her.

Judge: All right. And at this daycare, her mother was working?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Was your great aunt?

Plaintiff: Yep.

Judge: And you were getting along fine with her?

Judge: And did she tell you why she felt she didn’t have to pay you?

Plaintiff: No, she didn’t. She just told me to leave her alone.

Defendant: Judge, I did pay her. What she’s talking about when she walked off the premises— that’s not that she just walked off the premises. I came into the job, I don’t know what had happened before I got there. There was— she was swearing at me, cussing at me. I said, "You’re not going to talk to me that way, and I need you to leave off the premises."

Judge: That’s why she says it’s because you had a dispute over payment. So you do know what happened before you got there.

Defendant: No, we didn’t have a dispute over payment because that was a payment day, and I was coming to do payroll that day.

Judge: Stop. So what is the reason then that she’s mad?

Defendant: I have no idea.

Judge: I find that to be untruthful because people know why their employees of two years who happen to be their cousin are so mad. Something happened, and you know what it is that happened. Why won’t you tell me?

Judge: What day of the month was this?

Defendant: Around April 17th, that Friday.

Judge: What day do you pay your employees?

Defendant: Once a month.

Judge: And that was the day you were supposed to pay her?

Defendant: Yes.

**Judge:**
This is the case of Chenise Hawkins. She says she put down a deposit on an apartment and was ready to move in when the defendant abruptly changed her mind and rented the place to someone else. Now, the defendant refuses to return her \$500, which the plaintiff believes is unfair. She is here suing for the money.

**Plaintiff (Chenise Hawkins):**
On the evening of October 21st, I contacted Glattus to see an apartment she was renting. We liked the place, so we left a cash deposit. She wanted us to bring more information the next day, which I did. I brought my pay stubs and everything. She then told me that a few other couples had come and seen the place as well and were willing to give her \$500 to move in that day until November 1st.

**Judge:**
And you were planning to rent it from November 1st?

**Plaintiff:**
Yes.

**Judge:**
So what did she ask you for?

**Plaintiff:**
She asked me for an additional \$250 to move in that day.

**Judge:**
Or else what?

**Plaintiff:**
She’d rent it to the other people.

**Judge:**
And what did you say when she said that to you?

**Plaintiff:**
At first, I agreed. Then I went home and discussed it with my fiancé, and we decided that November 1st was better because I had already paid rent for October.

**Judge:**
Did you call her back and tell her that?

**Plaintiff:**
I did. I called her back the next morning, and she said she was going to teach me the law and that I could only get \$500 back.

**Judge:**
Was the topic ever discussed that you could just go ahead and move in as planned?

**Plaintiff:**
No, she did not. She wanted the extra \$250.

**Defendant (Glattus Hoffman):**
She came on the 21st with her boyfriend. I showed them the apartment, and they loved it. They asked me what the requirements were, and I told them one month’s security and one month’s rent. Once a deposit is made, I cannot rent it to anyone else.

**Judge:**
Did you call them and tell them you had other interested renters?

**Defendant:**
Yes, she came back with her documents, and I told her about the other people.

**Judge:**
Why were you trying to get another \$250 if you couldn't rent it to anyone else?

**Defendant:**
Because it was 10 days from the 21st to the 31st, so I said I would take off five days and she would only pay for five.

**Judge:**
But why did you do that? If she already had the apartment, why were you trying to charge her more?

**Defendant:**
They paid \$1,000, and then she came back, and I told her about the other offer. She went outside and called her fiancé. Then she came back in.

**Judge:**
If your premise is that the \$1,000 deposit secured the apartment, meaning you couldn’t rent it to anyone else, then why did you ask for an additional \$250? That sounds like extortion. She already had the apartment for November 1st, so she didn't have to give you another penny. You changed the deal, not her.

**Defendant:**
I told them the requirements from the beginning.

**Judge:**
Did you tell them after accepting the \$1,000 deposit that they needed to give you another \$250 the next day?

**Defendant:**
Yes.

**Judge:**
You can't do that. Once you accepted their deposit, you had an oral agreement. You can’t turn around and demand more money. You breached the contract, not her. And when she backed out, you rented it to someone else the same day. You didn’t lose anything. In fact, you made an extra \$500.

**Defendant:**
But they changed their mind.

**Judge:**
No, she always planned to move in on November 1st. You tried to charge her more after the fact. If you had other renters, why didn’t you just return her deposit and rent to them?

**Defendant:**
I did rent it to them.

**Judge:**
Then you’re out nothing. Keeping the deposit is meant to cover a loss, not to give you extra profit. Pay the plaintiff her \$500. Verdict for the plaintiff.

Judge: This is the case of Kevin McLoud vs. Angela Hutchinson. Mr. McLoud, you are suing your ex-girlfriend and the mother of your daughter, Ms. Hutchinson, for $1,400 that you claim she stole from your Macy’s account by using an old card that she was once authorized to use and charging $1,400 worth of gift cards. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff (Kevin McLoud): Okay, so I’m in the process of buying a house. I ran my credit and saw that there were some charges on my Macy’s card that I rarely ever use. So, I initiated a fraud claim through Macy’s. When I did that, they told me to go file a police report. When I filed the police report, the police told me to find out any more information that I could from Macy’s.

Macy’s told me that someone ordered a card, had it sent to an address, and used it four days later. That’s when all the charges were made on December 30th. Someone went on December 30th and bought a $500 gift card, another $500 gift card, and a $400 gift card. I don’t know what they did with the gift cards, honestly. I just know that it was put on my card.

Judge: Did Macy’s tell you who made these charges?

Plaintiff: I asked if they signed for it, and Macy’s said yes. I asked, “Who?” They said they couldn’t tell me the full name. I asked if they could give me anything, and they gave me the first name: Angela. I asked if I could confirm the last name, and they said if I told them the last name, they could confirm if it was correct. So, I said “Hutchinson.” They said yes.

Judge: Was she an authorized user on your account?

Plaintiff: Yes, but a long time ago. In 2006, I put her on as an authorized user because we used to date. But after we broke up, around 2008 or 2009, I called Macy’s to have her removed. I know for a fact that I called to have her removed. Nothing ever came up on my account since then, until now.

Judge: Are you in contact with Ms. Hutchinson?

Plaintiff: Yes, we have a daughter together.

Judge: Have you had financial disputes with her?

Plaintiff: In ways, yes.

Judge: Ms. Hutchinson, what do you have to say about this?

Defendant (Angela Hutchinson): Your Honor, I don’t know what he’s talking about. He said he put me as an authorized user in 2006, but even though I was an authorized user, I couldn’t call in and order a card because I wasn’t the main account holder. That’s impossible.

Judge: Being an authorized user means you can use the card. Are you saying you never used it?

Defendant: I haven’t had a card. I haven’t been around him. He said he took me off the account in 2008. If that’s true, I shouldn’t have been able to do anything.

Judge: Did you go to Macy’s on December 30th and purchase three gift cards?

Defendant: No, Your Honor.

Judge: According to Macy’s, you did.

Defendant: That’s not possible.

Judge: Ms. Hutchinson, did you ever receive a new card from Macy’s?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Where were you living at the time of the charge?

Defendant: I had just moved. Was the card sent to my new address?

Judge: Mr. McLoud, do you have any supporting documents?

Defendant’s Lawyer: I disagree with that. I think this Court definitively interpreted the phrase "first accrues" in Gabelli versus SEC just 11 years ago, and it said, in common parlance, a right first accrues when it comes into existence.

Plaintiff’s Lawyer: We made very clear that that was a default rule, a general rule that could be, of course, countermanded by Congress but that also could be countermanded by different circumstances. If you look at the Crown Coat opinion, for example, there’s a very explicit recognition by this Court of the hazards inherent in attempting to define for all purposes when a cause of action first accrues. A word like that should be interpreted in the light of the general purposes of the statute, with due regard to those practical ends which are to be served by any limitation of the time within which an action may be brought. You couldn’t find better language to point to. This is a really different context with really different interests, including reliance interests of many, many parties who are not before the Court. And courts have responded to that and created a different rule which has lasted—this is kind of a revolutionary ask.

Defendant’s Lawyer: We disagree. On Crown Coat, the top-line holding from Crown Coat as we read it is that Congress would not want the statute of limitations to start running until the plaintiff had the opportunity to sue. The language you just quoted, we see that as a recognition that obviously the underlying cause of action accrues differently depending on the type of claim. Torts accrue at different times than breaches of contract. Different torts can accrue at different times. And as far as the purposes of the statute, this Court said in Abbott Laboratories that the purpose of the APA was to embody a presumption of judicial review. So, if we're going to look at the underlying statute and its purposes, I think that cuts our way, not the government's way.

Judge: I thought that we had sort of basic first principles governing statutes of limitations. Ordinarily, we say that a cause of action arises—that is, accrues—when all of the facts necessary to establish the elements of that cause of action have occurred. In a tort situation, when there's a duty, if there's a breach and injury as a result of the breach, those facts have occurred, the cause of action has arisen, and we say the clock starts running at that point because a claim against the defendant can be sustained in court when those facts exist. If that’s right as a first principle, I don’t understand your argument that the cause of action arises when the plaintiff can bring the claim. The law regarding when a plaintiff can bring a claim is something different. But here, we have a cause of action arising out of the final agency action, because that is the point at which a person can sustain a claim against the agency under the APA. Why am I wrong about that?

Defendant’s Lawyer: This Court has identified the elements of an APA claim, and it requires a plaintiff who is injured and injured by agency action.

Judge: Where have we said that that was an element? I thought that was just a statement of the statute as to who can bring the claim, not the element of the claim itself—like when the defendant has violated the law.

Defendant’s Lawyer: I would point the Court to the Lujan decision, 1990, where it outlines the elements of an APA claim.

Judge: Right. Who has the cause of action? I'm talking about what are the elements of the cause of action. I thought it was that the agency has enacted a final rule that you claim is arbitrary and capricious or not in accordance with the law. Once the agency has done that, we have a cause of action—it has arisen—and then these other elements or aspects of the statute say who is the person who can bring such a claim.

Defendant’s Lawyer: I disagree with that. This Court has said that certainly final agency action is an element of an APA claim, but the other element, as this Court noted in Lujan and Newport News, is that someone must be actually harmed by it—a plaintiff who was harmed by it. Accrual-based statutes are necessarily plaintiff-specific. That’s in their nature. We’re not aware of a statute that uses accrual language or accrual-like language where the statute of limitations starts and ends on the same day for everyone. If that were the case, it wouldn’t be an accrual statute—it would be a statute of repose. Congress certainly knows how to pass statutes of repose, and it didn’t do so when it passed the APA. In 1934, Congress passed a Hobbs Act-like statute for the SEC. It did so again in 1938 for the FTC. And in 1950, it actually passed the Hobbs Act itself. But in between those years, it passed the APA and did not subject it to a repose-based statute of limitations, and it passed Section 2401 two years later. That must have been an intentional choice—APA claims are not subject to the kind of repose that applies to other types of causes of action.

Judge: So the other grounds, I think, would be the master principle that we talked about that the operative complaint almost always controls.

Lawyer of Defendant: The only context that I'm aware of where it doesn't control is the amount in controversy. That, by the way, was also codified through binding text. That's 1446. I agree that it goes back longer to cases like St. Paul Mercury. As an aside, I actually think that's a completely defensible interpretation of the old statutory text precisely because Congress understands it doesn't want to blur the line between jurisdictional facts and the merits. We don't want to create the Judge Posner problem where a plaintiff comes into court and loses or wins an amount that's less than the amount in controversy and now we have to --

Judge: Thank you.

Lawyer of Defendant: -- remand for lack of jurisdiction.

Judge: Do I understand your -- what you just said to mean that you would win this case even if 1367 had never been enacted?

Lawyer of Defendant: I think that I would win this case if 1367 hadn't been enacted and we were still in a more common law regime and this issue were squarely presented to the Court for the first time. Cohill had this issue obliquely presented. Yes, there was an amended complaint. But the party presentation rule should matter. No one made that fact relevant for the Court's consideration. You could have considered it sua sponte because it went to jurisdiction, but no one did. And this Court has pointed out before that drive-by jurisdictional rulings don't have any precedential effect. The reason you had to say that is sometimes, even though you would like to avoid it, you issue drive-by jurisdictional rulings.

Judge: Why --why -- why -- why would we say Cohill addressed this? As I understand it, in -- the question there was whether to remand or dismiss, and this -- this issue wasn't presented to the Court at all.

Lawyer of Defendant: I completely agree with it. It was not presented to the Court. The facts of Cohill, though, I have to say in the -- in the spirit of candor was that there was an amended complaint and it dropped the federal claim, and then there was the question of whether there is discretion to remand versus just discretion to dismiss for lack of continuing jurisdiction.

Judge: And do you have any way to rationalize St. Paul Mercury other than it's been codified now?

Lawyer of Defendant: No, I do think that I can rationalize St. Paul Mercury. As I was saying just a moment ago, I do think that the amount in controversy, even before Congress said in 1446 we have to look to the initial pleading, going back to cases like St. Paul Mercury, it is reasonable to read -- read the words "amount in controversy" to mean theoretically possible to be recovered. It doesn't matter what happens after you file your lawsuit. And so, if the plaintiff pleads in an initial complaint, consistent with Rule 11 or whatever the equivalent was in 1938, I'm above the jurisdictional amount in controversy, that's showing that it's theoretically possible to recover that amount in good faith, and that's good enough for the statutory jurisdictional requirement that Congress added onto Article III.

Judge: Mr. Lawyer of Defendant, in thinking about -- you know, the different boxes and some of the inconsistencies. One way I've been thinking about this is I think it's been true for a very long time, back to Strawbridge versus Curtiss and the complete diversity requirement, you know, talking about Mottley and the well-pleaded complaint rule, that the Court for a very long time exercised a pretty free hand in interpreting 13-1 and --1331 and 1332. That language is identical to Article III, but yet the Court interpreted it to mean something different. And I think that in the Gibbs regime pre -1367, the Court was exercising a pretty free hand in -- in articulating the contours of pendent jurisdiction and ancillary jurisdiction before Congress controlled it. Can you think -- I mean, I think a lot of this case seems to kind of come down to is that just the way we've been treating jurisdictional statutes and do we keep it up with 1367, or in 1367 because, in Finley, the Court kind of said no, look, Congress, there need to be clear jurisdictional rules, expressly invited Congress to address it, which Congress did. Would you say, do you think it's fair to say, or can you think of a counter-example that in 1367, when it comes to supplemental jurisdiction, the Court has tightened its belt and isn't being as free-wheeling, or can you think of other examples where the Court, this Court, has done kind of what the court of appeals seemed to have continued to do in 1367, which is maybe make a little bit more jurisdictional policy than was set out in the text?

Lawyer of Defendant: Yeah, an important question, Judge. I think I would describe the history a little differently. I wouldn't describe it as free-wheeling. I would say it all points in one direction. The Court construed jurisdictional statutes more narrowly than Article III. So that's certainly true with Strawbridge versus Curtiss. We know that there's not a complete diversity requirement because of CAFA. It's the same thing with 1331. Justice Thomas noted this in Grable. From the very beginning of the Jurisdiction and Removal Act of 1875, this Court almost immediately construed the words "arising under" to be not coextensive with Article III.

Judge: We will hear argument this morning in Case 23-1127, Wisconsin Bell versus United States ex rel. Todd Heath.

Lawyer of Defendant: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: The False Claims Act, which casts its shadow over every aspect of the administrative state, has always been trained on guarding the public fisc.

The FCA protects government funds by defining a claim as a request for money the government provides or that's presented to a government agent.

As a result of political branch choices, E-rate reimbursement requests check neither box.

The program could have been funded with public money and administered by a government agency, but the political branches chose private funding and a private administrator to prevent E-rate money from being used to mask budget shortfalls and to avoid the Government Corporation Control Act.

The consequence of those choices is that E-rate reimbursement requests aren't FCA claims.

First, the government doesn't provide any money in the E-rate program.

Text, context, structure, and history all confirm that the government provides money for FCA purposes only if it supplies money from its own funds, putting the public fisc at risk.

That never happened here.

The government doesn't provide money by making one private party pay another private party, and the government doesn't provide money by collecting debts owed to a private party and in which the government has no financial stake.

Second, the program's private administrator, the Administrative Company, isn't a government agent.

By design, it lacks power to bind the government, which in turn lacks control over what matters here: grants of E-rate reimbursement requests.

In fact, we know the company can't be a government agent because, if it were, it would violate the Government Corporation Control Act.

Choices have consequences, and the choices made by the political branches to insulate the E-rate program from the public fisc foreclose applying the FCA.

I welcome the Court's questions.

Judge: Ms. Ho, could you focus just briefly on the $100 million that the government says it contributes or provides? That -- much of that is collected under a debt collection provision that authorizes the government to collect its -- a debt owed to it. That seems somewhat at odds with your argument that it's not the government's money.

How could it be collected under that Act if it is not owed to the government? And if -- if it is owed to the government, then why isn't it the government's money after that?

Lawyer of Defendant: Yes, Justice Thomas, and let me answer both parts of your question.

Let me begin by addressing the debt settlement and restitution.

Those funds are no different than the E-rate contributions themselves.

They are owed to the Administrative Company.

The United States just collects and returns those funds to their private owner.

A -- a -- a good analogy is like child support.

Like a parent provides child support even when the United States withholds from the parent's income and sends to the other parent, the private telecom carriers provide E-rate funds even when the United States collects their delinquent debts, just like when a private litigant uses a sheriff to go after a property to pay judgment.

Now let -- Justice Thomas, let me address directly your question about the Debt Collection Improvement Act.

And those debts don't belong to the government, even under the Debt Collection Improvement Act, for three reasons.

Number one, that's a different statutory scheme with different language. That's the Blanca case from the Tenth Circuit that we cite in our brief.

The FCA limits a claim to money that the United States provides, and the Debt Collection Improvement Act defines "claim" more expansively without regard to its effect on the public fisc.

And, number two, relatedly, the Debt Collection Improvement Act applies to funds that the United States is authorized by statute to collect for the benefit of any person.

That is Section 3701(b)(1)(D).

So money belongs to the person for whose benefit the government collects it.

The government just holds it in trust.

And that's in our brief on page 32.

And my friend, the Solicitor General, admits on page 17 of the Solicitor General's brief that they are obligated, the government is obligated, to transmit funds back to the Administrative Company.

Judge: The -- the --

Judge: Can I ask you a question -- oh.

Sorry.

Judge: I was just -- the government, though, treats this, these funds, as appropriated funds, right? They -- they're -- as I understand it, they're called backdoor appropriations?

Lawyer of Defendant: You're correct, Mr. Chief Justice, that OMB and the President's budget have -- have labeled the E-rate funds as -- I think they're -- I think the -- the bureaucratic term is "permanent indefinite appropriations," but even -- even OMB, in using that term, admitted that -- I think -- I think the language used was that the line between the private sector and government can be murky and that it was including those funds in the budget out of a desire to be -- to be comprehensive. So, ultimately, it is this Court's responsibility to interpret this statute and determine what the nature of the funds are.

Judge: But I guess I'm wondering why the government isn't collecting the money here for a public purpose for the funding of this program.

Judge: We'll hear argument this morning in Case 23-1141, Smith & Wesson Brands versus Estados Unidos Mexicanos.

Lawyer of Defendant: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: Mexico asserts that American firearms companies are responsible for cartel violence ravaging Mexico.

Its theory is that federally licensed manufacturers sell firearms to licensed distributors, who sell to licensed retailers, a small percentage of whom sell to straw purchasers, some of whom transfer to smugglers, who then smuggle them into Mexico, hand them over to cartels, who in turn use them to commit murder and mayhem, all of which requires the government of Mexico to spend money.

Needless to say, no case in American history supports that theory, and it's squarely foreclosed by the Protection of Lawful Commerce in Arms Act.

As to proximate cause, this Court has repeatedly said there must be a direct relationship between the defendant's conduct and the plaintiff's injury.

But no such relationship exists if plaintiff's injury is caused by multiple intervening independent crimes committed by foreign criminals on foreign soil to inflict harm on a foreign sovereign.

As to aiding and abetting, Mexico doesn't identify a specific crime, criminal, or criminal enterprise that defendants supposedly helped.

Instead, it asserts that defendants are liable for every illegal sale by every retailer in America because they know that a small percentage of firearms are sold illegally and don't do more to stop it.

Again, no case in history supports that theory.

Indeed, if Mexico is right, then every law enforcement organization in America has missed the largest criminal conspiracy in history operating right under their nose, and Budweiser is liable for every accident caused by underage drinkers since it knows that teenagers will buy beer, drive drunk, and crash.

The First Circuit gravely erred in embracing that implausible theory and should be reversed.

Judge: Mr. Francisco, as to the predicate exception, which federal or state law is your -- is Petitioner reputed to have violated?

Lawyer of Defendant: So my understanding, Your Honor, is that they're invoking the federal aiding-and-abetting statute to argue that we have aided and abetted the federal statutes that govern the sale of firearms, and they're alleging that retailers have knowingly sold firearms to straw purchasers and that we aided and abetted that knowing sale.

That actually raises a very important question about their allegation of knowing.

I don't think it's relevant because I'm willing to even assume a certain level of knowledge.

I don't think it matters.

But their theory of knowledge is that we actually know that retailers are selling illegally.

I'd actually urge you to look at that 2010 Washington Post article that they incorporate into their complaint.

That article talks about a particular retailer called Lone Wolf.

In 2010, it was the number one seller of firearms that were found in Mexican crime gun scenes.

And, in that article, you actually have a quote from ATF that says that ATF has no -- has no basis to believe that Lone Wolf is doing anything illegal or wrong.

Well, if the government doesn't know, how are we supposed to know? It reflects this convoluted theory that -- that simply because the gun is found in Mexico, can be traced back to a retailer, that means the retailer necessarily sold it illegally and that we know that the retailer sold it illegally.

Judge: Would this be a different case if there was a specific federal or state statute that was alleged -- that you were known to have violated?

Lawyer of Defendant: Your Honor, it would be a different case.

I would want to know more because I still think that, depending on what they alleged, I would have very strong arguments on proximate cause and aiding-and-abetting liability, but it would certainly be a different case.

Judge: Well, the -- the -- the reason I ask is because the exception is for knowingly violating a state or federal statute, and it would seem helpful in determining aiding and abetting and then eventually proximate cause if that comes up if you knew which statute we were dealing with.

Lawyer of Defendant: So the complaint is a little bit vague on this.

To the extent I understand it, they're looking at federal statutes that restrict the knowing sale of firearms to people who aren't authorized to purchase them, and then they're invoking the criminal federal aiding-and-abetting statute to claim that we're then liable for those illegal sales.

I'm willing to assume for the sake of argument that that's valid because I don't think they come anywhere close to establishing aiding-and-abetting liability, and even if they did, I don't think they come anywhere close to establishing proximate cause.

Judge: I'm sorry, counsel, but exactly what role -- I had difficulty telling from your brief -- does foreseeability play in your proximate cause analysis?

Lawyer of Defendant: So, as -- as this Court has made clear in a number of cases, it's not that foreseeability is irrelevant.

It's that foreseeability alone is not the standard. So it's necessary but not sufficient.

In addition, there has to be a direct relationship between the defendant's conduct and the plaintiff's injury.

And, Your Honor, I think that the plurality opinion you authored in the Hemi Group is directly on point.

That is where a case -- a case where the plurality held that the City of New York couldn't sue a cigarette retailer for not filing the tax reports in order for the city to recover its lost tax revenue because in between the city's injury of lost tax revenue and the retailer's failure to file the reports stood the citizens of New York who illegally failed to pay their taxes, and that broke the chain.

This is a much easier case.

Here, we don't have just one intervening independent crime.

We have a multitude of intervening independent crimes.

So, even if they could establish aiding-and-abetting liability -- and I don't think they come even close under Twitter -- they couldn't establish proximate cause, which is the other requirement here.

Judge: Yeah, I have a question about the phrase in (c)(1), the specific intent. Do you agree it's specific intent with the intent to impair the object's integrity? Okay.
What is your view about how that parenthetical applies to (c)(2), if at all? Like, do you think that that intent requirement carries over to (c)(2)?

Defendant's Lawyer: The corruptly intent requirement?

Judge: Not—not corruptly. The "with the intent to impair the object's integrity or availability for use in a proceeding"?

With respect to intent, I mean, I think Your Honor makes an excellent point, which is that this intent is a specific form of intent. The "corruptly," which has been construed to be the mens rea up there, is not different than—at least on this reading, is not—is not—or on the accepted reading by the D.C. Circuit right now is not different than—than some form of specific intent.

It's not just evidence. It's a proceeding. (c)(1) is an example of, you know, the corrupt tampering with certain things. And (c)(2) broadens it out a bit. It's not just documents and records. What do you think about that?

Defendant's Lawyer: Well, I think that's—that's a correct reading, Your Honor. I mean, we—as—as—as 1512(f) demonstrates, it doesn't—you know, 1512(f) we would submit actually supports our position because it says the evidence need not be admissible or free of a privilege claim.

Now what would that mean about what the statute is addressing if it's not evidence? But (c)(2) has been applied, and—and occasionally (c)(1) has been applied.

Judge: In a non-evidentiary way?

Defendant's Lawyer: Yeah, to—to—to things that could become evidence, to the efforts to shape someone's grand jury testimony.

Judge: All right. Let me—

Defendant's Lawyer: —to answers to interrogatories.

Judge: —let me ask you about the question that the other judge asked before. You know, you—you suggested that it has to be to the document, but—in other words, the—the—the activity has to be actually to the document, but I don't know why that's the case under (c)(2).

Another judge says, well, one of the commonalities between (c)(1) and (c)(2) could be the impairment of the object's integrity or availability. The previous judge posits a scenario in which you have someone who is impairing the availability by doing something to prevent the object from getting to the proceeding. Defendant's Lawyer: Well, first, it's not affecting the integrity of the document, Your Honor, or—or the—or—

Judge: Availability is also in the statute.

Defendant's Lawyer: Availability it says too, but, as I mentioned earlier, simply delaying the arrival of evidence at the courthouse—

Judge: No, not delay. Let's say the person steals the envelope and takes it away.

Defendant's Lawyer: Then it gets harder, I agree. If they steal the envelope, they take it away, they rip it up, all of those things, which is certainly not what happened here, and it's not in the indictment—the—the ballots or the—the vote count is not even in the indictment.

Judge: Well, we—we wouldn't have to decide that.

Defendant's Lawyer: Right.

Judge: We could send it back if we clarified that that is what the statute means. I'm trying to understand if you agree that that's what the statute could mean.

Judge: Just looking to history, I know South Carolina you have in your corner. Do you have any other antebellum cases from the states?

Defendant's Lawyer: So we have the Louisiana Hudson decision, which I think even Plaintiff agrees is in our camp. And I think Plaintiff agrees all of these are in our camp. We have the—
